webTitle: UN troops killed by Sierra Leone rebels

fields.headline: UN troops killed by Sierra Leone rebels
fields.trailText: Seven United Nations peacekeepers have been shot dead in the past two days by rebels in Sierra Leone who are also holding hostage dozens of other peacekeepers and unarmed military observers, UN officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
Seven United Nations peacekeepers have been shot dead in the past two days by rebels in Sierra Leone who are also holding hostage dozens of other peacekeepers and unarmed military observers, UN officials said yesterday.

The 8,500-strong UN mission - mainly comprising Indians, Kenyans and Nigerians - is a key element in the west African country's shaky peace process, now made even more unstable by the killings.

Reinforcements have been sent to some UN positions and security has been stepped up in Freetown, the seaside capital, where there were helicopters hovering overhead yesterday morning.

Since Monday the rebel Revolutionary United Front, which remains, at least officially, part of a power-sharing government, has seized 50 UN workers during incidents in three towns in the interior, officials said. The whereabouts of many more remains unclear.

Four Kenyan peacekeepers were killed on Tuesday during a gunfight with the rebels in the central town of Magburaka, according to a senior official. The rebels signed a ceasefire last July in Togo.

Philip Winslow, a spokesman for Unamsil, the UN mission in Sierra Leone, said that fighters of the RUF had attacked UN positions in Magburaka and the nearby city of Makeni. The peacekeepers returned fire.

The UN force commander, Major-General Vijay Kumar Jetley, said on Tuesday: "It seems as if Foday Sankoh [the RUF leader] is trying to derail the peace process."

Mr Sankoh, who was brought into the government as part of a power-sharing agreement last year, has been refusing to talk to government members, including President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, in recent days.

The kidnappings began on Monday after about 100 armed RUF guerrillas surrounded a demobilisation centre in Makeni, demanding the return of 10 fighters who had turned in their weapons. When the UN troops refused, the rebels fired into the air and seized a UN military observer.

Another three observers and three peacekeepers were captured after going to negotiate their colleague's release. AP

webTitle: Chelsea set their sights on Viduka

fields.headline: Chelsea set their sights on Viduka
fields.trailText: Gianluca Vialli could begin the refurbishment of Chelsea by signing Mark Viduka, the prolific Celtic striker.
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli could begin the refurbishment of Chelsea by signing Mark Viduka, the prolific Celtic striker.

Viduka's agent Bernie Mandic yesterday denied that his player was considering a move to Tottenham Hotspur, and preliminary discussions between Chelsea and Celtic are believed to have opened early this week.

Viduka is currently the Scottish Premier League's leading scorer with 27 goals, but it is accepted he will be auctioned off to the highest bidder this summer to give transfer funds to the club's new manager.

The Dynamo Kiev striker Sergei Rebrov has revealed that his £10m move to Tottenham should be completed within the next two weeks, and that George Graham has beaten Arsène Wenger to his signature.

"Arsenal didn't do a deal because they are playing in the Uefa Cup and all their transfer policies will be decided after the final," Rebrov said.

Andy Cole has been advised to see a specialist about a toe injury that threatens his participation in Euro 2000.

Fabien Barthez, whom Manchester United attempted to sign last season, has demanded a transfer from Monaco after saying that his coach had accused him of throwing a match against his former club Marseille.

fields.headline: Thorne's hat-trick fires up Stoke
fields.trailText: Stoke 3 - 0 Bury
fields.byline: Adrian Milledge at the Britannia stadium
fields.body:
Peter Thorne's hat-trick for Stoke City last night earned Gudjohn Thordarson's side a sixth successive victory and leaves them needing just one point from Saturday's trip to Reading to guarantee a place in the play-offs.

It is an impressive affirmation of the revival that has followed the Icelandic takeover. But it has been fuelled by the predatory instincts of a typical English striker.

Thorne has scored 29 goals this season and the only surprise was that he did not add more here. All his three efforts offered a different aspect of the striker's art - a tap-in, a fierce half-volley and a header.

"I'm scoring so frequently because the team is playing so well and making a lot of chances for me," Thorne said. "Kyle Lightbourne has set me up on countless occasions and he deserves a goal or two himself."

Thorne's first arrived on 11 minutes when he took advantage of a lack of communication between Bury's central defender Chris Swailes and their goalkeeper Paddy Kenny to sidefoot home.

City's midfield, with Brynjar Gunnarsson and Graham Kavanagh pulling the strings, was dominant throughout. So much so that the visitors managed only one shot of any menace in the first half, a half-volley from Adrian Littlejohn in the dying seconds.

Thorne took over again with a right-footed half-volley from Kavanagh's cross in the 55th minute and completed a comprehensive victory shortly before the end with a header following a right-wing corner.

webTitle: Rangers close in on their century of goals

fields.headline: Rangers close in on their century of goals
fields.trailText: Rangers 5 - 2 Hibernian
fields.body:
Rangers last night heeded the words of their manager Dick Advocaat in the match programme. "Complacency can be a terrible thing - it won't creep in at Ibrox. You have my word," he wrote.

The promise stirred his side to shrug off a half-hearted challenge from Hibs and move closer towards the target of scoring 100 goals in a league season.

Advocaat had also tried to motivate his players by saying that Cup final places were up for grabs, even if he probably already knows his team for Hampden Park. But he did pick Tugay, Seb Rozental and the Finn Tero Penttila who have spent most of the season looking on.

The game was played at three-quarter pace and only the sight of the Hibs' manager Alex McLeish jumping up and down out of his dug out was a reminder that somebody desperately cared.

Rangers made a business-like start, the quality of their passing never in doubt. In the 11th minute Barry Ferguson linked up with Arthur Numan. The Dutchman measured his through ball to the inch and Ferguson ran on to hit his shot low past Nick Colgan. It was only his fifth goal in 46 games this season.

Seven minutes later the Chilean Rozental, looking sharper with every match, was the man combining with Numan and this time it was Billy Dodds who sprinted through the Hibs' defence to fire Rangers a comfortable two-goal lead.

The champions appeared to have the game safe in the 47th minute when, after Numan had again penetrated on the left, Shaun Dennis turned the Dutchman's low cross into his own goal.

However Hibs were hardly finished. Kenny Miller skipped through to score 90 seconds later and when Dirk Lehmann's 72nd-minute snapshot further narrowed the gap, there was a real game to watch.

But a late double by Georg Albertz - an 81st minute penalty after a foul on the Rangers substitute Jonatan Johansson by the unfortunate Dennis and a long-range drive three minutes later - put Hibs' fightback into its true perspective.

webTitle: Leeds ready to join Europe's elite

fields.headline: Leeds ready to join Europe's elite
fields.trailText: Leeds 3 -1 Watford
fields.body:
Leeds United have rediscovered the art of winning with an impeccable sense of timing. Although seldom illuminating, they did enough to outshine limited opponents here last night while bloodying Liverpool's nose in the skirmish for European places.

Whether David O'Leary's youthful team will qualify for the Champions League or the Uefa Cup remains to be seen, but at this juncture they can harbour serious aspirations of rubbing shoulders with Manchester United et al in Europe's premier competition next season.

An ultimately comfortable victory, achieved through Michael Bridges' 20th goal of the season, Michael Duberry's first since November 1996 and Darren Huckerby's first in six months, hoists Leeds back into the Premiership's top three courtesy of Liverpool's failings against Leicester City.

The fatalists will point out that mathematically Leeds are assured of nothing, but O'Leary said: "The bottom line is that if we win our remaining two games against Everton and West Ham we will be in the Champions League. That is what I have set my sights on all season and the Liverpool result is a marvellous bonus. Our destiny is in our own hands now."

Leeds had not triumphed on home soil since March 19 but their early hesitancies evaporated, for a short time at least, when Bridges capitalised on some loose marking from Stephen McPhail's 20th minute corner to score with a right-foot shot from the fringe of the penalty area.

For all their deficiencies, however, Graham Taylor's players are victims of their own limitations rather than any lack of endeavour and within five minutes they had equalised. David Perpetuini manoeuvred space on the left and Heidar Helguson nodded down for Dominic Foley to lash a low shot beyond the Leeds goalkeeper Nigel Martyn.

Rather than spur Leeds into action the goal was the catalyst for a sudden bout of jitters to afflict the home side. Only a fine save from Martyn prevented Foley from earning a few more brownie points and it was against the run of play when Duberry volleyed in McPhail's free-kick late in the first half.

If that was tough on Watford, any sense of grievance was dissipated six minutes after the interval when Huckerby flummoxed Robert Page with a couple of neat shimmies and curled an exquisite right-foot shot into the opposite corner of the net.

A 16th away defeat for Taylor's willing but limited squad means they will rejoin the Football League with an ignominious footnote attached to their brief flirtation with the domestic game's most demanding and unforgiving tier.

Ipswich's haul of 27 points in 1994-95 is the previous record low for a Premiership season but Watford - 20 points and counting - have been threatening to plunder that dubious honour for some time. It is now a guarantee.

fields.headline: Liverpool hunt is outfoxed
fields.trailText: Liverpool 0 - 2 Leicester
fields.body:
There were still 10 minutes or so remaining but as Anfield began to empty, as hope began to fade, it became clear that Liverpool really were threatening to finish the season much as they had begun it -squandering opportunities and spilling points.

Leicester City's third consecutive league win at Anfield may just cost Liverpool a place in next season's Champions League and if that proves to be the case they will certainly rue this clumsy, almost inept performance.

As Liverpool's chief executive Rick Parry perhaps unwisely reminded everyone on Tuesday, the stakes remain very high at a club that still believes itself to be worthy of a place in the vanguard of European football.

Parry was doing no more than stating fact by announcing that Champions League success can bring untold riches - well, around £40m in his estimation - but it was a curiously timed declaration, one you suspect Gérard Houllier and his tiring team could have done without.

With only two games to go, Houllier and his boys find themselves outside of the top three. They are being stalked by disappointment and the portents are not good.

They have collected only one point from their last three games and, perhaps more significantly, despite the presence of men like Michael Owen, Emile Heskey and Robbie Fowler, they have failed to register even a single goal.

"Perhaps this game shows that we are not yet ready for Champions League football," Houllier said. "It is not finished yet, though, because things can change very quickly.

"This was not our day. This is football; you have to live with it. We must win at least one - maybe both - of our remaining games." Leicester were magnificent. They have always loved a good party but they possibly derive as much pleasure from raining on the parade of their perceived betters.

The game was less than two minutes old when Liverpool's wake-up call arrived. The blame for what was a very sloppy goal lay at the cultured feet of Dietmar Hamann, for as Neil Lennon delivered the lobbed pass that Tony Cottee was to convert with such a flourish, the German international was dawdling.

Liverpool's response was confusing to say the least, because by injecting so much pace into their football they surrendered any semblance of rhythm. They were often two steps ahead of Leicester but always one step ahead of themselves.

Liverpool's discipline was also to desert them. Standing toe to toe with a team that extols the virtues of ceaseless endeavour, Liverpool allowed themselves to be distracted.

Leicester did not hesitate to take full advantage. Three minutes into an equally robust second period they doubled their lead, Phil Gilchrist bundling the ball in after Muzzy Izzet's corner had flicked off the head of Dominic Matteo.

Robbie Fowler was promptly introduced as a substitute and the onslaught began, a red tide rolling forwards and over the Leicester barricades. The chances came - plenty of them - but Pegguy Arphexad was in outrageous form, defying not only the Liverpool strikers but also the odds and gravity with a catalogue of sublime stops.

"At some stage someone is going to realise that we can play a bit," said the Leicester manager Martin O'Neill. "For some periods in that game we were sensational. My players fancied the challenge tonight but then again, they generally do."

webTitle: Bold Bolton keep Wolves from door

fields.headline: Bold Bolton keep Wolves from door
fields.trailText: Bolton 2 - 1 Wolves
fields.byline: Stephen Bierley  at the Reebok stadium
fields.body:
Bolton ended Wolves' play-off hopes and enhanced their own chances of making the top six with victory courtesy of Claus Jensen and Eidur Gudjohnsen's second-half goals here last night. The win moved Bolton into seventh, one point outside the play-off zone, just below Huddersfield.

There had been little to choose between the sides during almost the entirety of the first half as patchy as the Reebok Stadium pitch which resembled the carpet of a large hotel that had seen better days, with the new pieces not matching the former faded splendour.

Wolves were a touch more impulsive, although their keenness to open the scoring too often fragmented into tetchiness with Lee Naylor finally trying the patience of the referee Mr Lynch who had made do with a pointed word of reprimand up until the half-hour. Not that Bolton were innocent bystanders, Mike Whitlow also being booked.

An early free-kick by Claus Jensen was athletically turned over by Michael Oakes but thereafter Wolves drove forward vigorously without ever producing a clear-cut opening. The most obvious chance fell to Allan Nielsen but he hesitated and was lost, while Ade Akinbiyi defeated Bolton's goalkeeper in the air but there was no Wolves player supporting.

However, Wolves continued to press and after Oakes had saved well from the Bolton substitute Robbie Elliott, on for the injured Paul Warhurst, Wolves finished with a flourish, finally breaking through five minutes into first-half injury-time when Darren Bazeley's cross from the right was headed home by Ludovic Pollet with a simplicity that defied the previous efforts.

 Peter Thorne's hat-trick in Stoke City's 3-0 win over Bury last night confirmed the belief that the club are fast beginning to resemble the geezers of their Icelandic owners' homeland - they are building up an impressive head of steam at exactly the right time.

The striker's treble ensured Gudjohn Thordarson's side recorded their sixth win in succession, a victory that keeps them on course for a second trip to Wembley this season.

That sextet includes victory over Bristol City in the Auto Windscreen Shields final; the latest leave City needing just one point from Saturday's trip to Reading to guarantee a place in the play-off.

fields.headline: Anelka gives Real edge
fields.standfirst:
Anelka 4, Jeremies 33og
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Real Madrid 2 - 0 Bayern Munich
fields.body:
Nicolas Anelka redeemed himself last night with a goal after four minutes to put Real Madrid on track with victory over Bayern Munich in the first leg of the European Champions League semi-final.

Before an 85,000 crowd at the Santiago Bernabeu stadium, Anelka raced on to a long pass from Aitor Karanka and deftly curled the ball past Oliver Kahn. It was Anelka's first goal in the competition and his first since returning from a club suspension.

Real's coach Vicente del Bosque said: "I believe that with the team in their current form we can hold on to our advantage. We played very well in the first half and kept our discipline in the second. But we have to be realistic, it's not over yet."

Bayern had gone into the game having beaten Real twice so far in the tournament, 4-1 and 4-2. But the team that turned out last night, besides missing their key midfielder Stefan Effenberg, displayed lit tle of their famed composure and fitness. Their best effort in the first half was a long-range free-kick from Michael Tarnat.

Madrid's control paid dividends in the 33rd minute when their right-back Michel Salgado latched on to a through-ball, rounded Kahn and then saw the ball hit Jeremies' shin and roll into an empty net.

Real resumed control in the second period with Kahn forced to make a diving save from Fernando Morientes in the 49th minute. The players got involved in a pushing match in the 80th minute following fouls by Roberto Carlos and Steve McManaman. Kahn also ran out to remonstrate after which the crowd behind the goal hurled missiles at him. Real travel to Munich for the return leg next Tuesday.

Real Madrid: Casillas, Salgado, Carlos, Redondo, McManaman, Campo, Helguera, Karanka, Raul, Morientes (Savio, 61min), Anelka (Balic, 80).

Bayern Munich: Kahn, Babbel, Lizarazu, Scholl, Elber (Jancker, 78), Sergio, Jeremies, Fink, Tarnat (Weisinger, 47), Salihamidzic (Santa Cruz, 78), Linke. Referee : Anders Frisk (Sweden)

webTitle: London and Frankfurt marry to create champion of Europe

fields.headline: London and Frankfurt marry to create champion of Europe
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The historic merger between the stock exchanges of London and Frankfurt announced yesterday is expected to prompt a wave of consolidation in Europe.
fields.body:
The historic merger between the stock exchanges of London and Frankfurt announced yesterday is expected to prompt a wave of consolidation in Europe.

The merger of Europe's two largest markets to form iX, unthinkable just two years ago, was given an additional global dimension through a link with US technology market Nasdaq.

Smaller exchanges in Milan and Madrid yesterday signalled their desire to join the alliance, which will be one of the world's most powerful exchanges. Others are expected to follow suit, and were invited to do so by the heads of iX yesterday. The London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange (Liffe) is one of their potential partners.

Announcing their much leaked merger, the London stock exchange and Deutsche Börse tried to dampen anxieties that the euro would now become the currency of business in the City. Don Cruickshank, newly appointed chairman of the London exchange who will retain the position in iX, insisted it was not up to the exchange to decide whether British companies should list their shares in euros.

Yesterday's deal is a carefully constructed balance of interests between London and Frankfurt, neither of which wanted to be seen as junior partner in a deal which has been two years in the making. They gave up on plans to create a pan-European platform for trading involving eight competing exchanges and agreed a straight two-way merger. "What belongs together, finally comes together," said Werner Seifert, the Frankfurt chief executive who will hold the same position in iX.

"It is good news that the fragmentation and bickering about who is going to be champion of Europe is going away. I think in the next few months others are going to fall into line," said one investment banker yesterday.

London will be centre for trading in the 500 biggest shares in Europe; the administration - the chief executive will relocate to the City - and its regulations will be used for trading. Frankfurt will provide the electronic trading platform and be the centre for hi-tech stocks.

Gavin Casey, the chief executive of the London exchange for the last four years, said "egos mustn't stand in the way" of the creation of a single European exchange. He will leave this year and is expected to receive a hefty pay-off. He was credited yesterday with cementing the deal, particularly the involvement of Nasdaq.

Combining the two exchanges is expected to involve cost savings and job losses, but Mr Seifert declined to be specific. The merger has prompted talks between the two main European share settlement houses, Crest in London and Clearstream in Frankfurt.

How share trading will change: the ins and outs of listing, pricing and buying

Will share prices look different in the newspaper?

For now, no. Newspapers will continue to list prices in pounds and pence for as long as firms use them and readers want to see prices quoted in sterling.

Is it the end of the FTSE 100?

It might be its death knell, although the move towards a wider benchmark has been developing for some time. The exchanges have yet to decide which indices will be used but for now, the FTSE 100 and its sister indices are safe.

Does this mean we have to buy euros to buy shares?

Share prices in the UK will not be quoted in euros until firms do so. If and when euro dealing does get under way, settlement systems should mean that brokers will be able to cope with multi-currency deals. Unless Britain joins the euro, however, investors will also have to watch currency gyrations in any euro trades.

Will stamp duty be payable?

On companies registered in the UK, yes, until the chancellor decides to scrap it.

Do I get dividends in euros?

If investors have bought shares in companies where the euro has been introduced, the dividends will be accounted for euros. Not until the UK adopts the euro will firms here start to pay in euros.

Will the cost of trading go up?

The exchanges insist it should go down as brokerage costs fall.

fields.headline: 'Snubbed' Murdoch daughter quits
fields.standfirst:
Elisabeth turns back on BSkyB and News Corp to set up own production company

Analysis: Why Sky driver fled the nest
fields.trailText: Elisabeth Murdoch, once tipped as a business successor to her father, Rupert, as head of his News Corporation conglomerate, has flown the coop. Ms Murdoch, 31, announced yesterday that she is to leave BSkyB, in which her father has a stake, to set up her own independent production company.
fields.body:
Elisabeth Murdoch, once tipped as a business successor to her father, Rupert, as head of his News Corporation conglomerate, has flown the coop. Ms Murdoch, 31, announced yesterday that she is to leave BSkyB, in which her father has a stake, to set up her own independent production company.

The move took the broadcasting world by surprise, although friends of Ms Murdoch said she had been thinking about leaving Sky for some time. As well as giving up her role at Sky, she has quit the executive committee of Mr Murdoch's sprawling News Corp empire.

As managing director of Sky Networks, Ms Murdoch played a key role in attempts to reposition the broadcaster's entertainment channel, Sky One, as a rival to BBC1 and ITV. She was overlooked for the position of chief executive when the post became vacant at BSkyB last year, and one source suggested that the snub had been a "wake-up call".

Ms Murdoch told BSkyB's chief executive, Tony Ball, of her move on Friday morning, and is said to have informed her father later.

Close friends said last night that the catalyst for her decision to leave Sky came when she discovered she was pregnant by her partner, the flamboyant public relations executive Matthew Freud. According to unconfirmed reports, she would merely be lending her name and contacts to the new venture. Until last night, news of the pregnancy had been a closely guarded secret.

Turbulent times

Ms Murdoch is understood to have been frustrated by the promotion of her younger brother, Lachlan, 28, within the corporation. Last year he was rewarded with a place on the six-strong board at News Corp - which has a 37.5% stake in BSkyB - becoming the only one of the young Murdoch clan to make it that far.

In an interview with the magazine Newsweek last year, Rupert Murdoch had indicated that Lachlan would eventually succeed him at the head of News Corp. Last month Mr Murdoch was diagnosed as suffering from "low grade" prostate cancer.

At Sky, Ms Murdoch is understood to have had turbulent relations with successive chief executives, Sam Chisholm and Mark Booth. The appointment of Mr Ball to the chief executive's chair last year reportedly prompted Ms Murdoch to reconsider her future there.

"At the end of the day no one likes working with the boss's daughter and her father was not prepared to do the ultimate and put her in charge. Four years on she was still pretty much in the same job as when she joined. And Sky spends more time shifting dishes than it does worrying about creating programmes," said one insider. In a statement released through BSkyB yesterday, Ms Murdoch said she was leaving to set up her own production company. The new venture, she said, will be specialising in film, television, and new media.

Declaring that she had enjoyed and was proud of her four years' work at Sky, Ms Murdoch said: "I have had the privilege of working with some of the best television executives around and it is with some lament that I leave such a winning team. However now is a great time to pursue something that I have been thinking about for some time."

Mr Ball, who succeeded Mr Booth eight months ago, praised Ms Murdoch's work, saying she had been "pivotal" in the company's creative development.

He added: "Under her direction, our channels have thrived and led the way in the multi-channel world; we have launched major new film and television divisions, attracted leading talent both in front of and behind the camera to our network, and invigorated our brand through our latest marketing campaign. We will miss her greatly and wish her well with her new venture."

The statement made no mention of Ms Murdoch's pregnancy, which was later confirmed by her partner's public relations firm.

Mr Murdoch's three children employed in the News Corp empire are often depicted in the press as sibling rivals. Lachlan has run the Australian end of the Murdoch empire and has recently taken on the US print business. The youngest son, James, 27, has made a name for himself running the corporation's American internet business and was recently appointed to run StarTV, the group's Asian pay-TV operation.

But Mr Murdoch recently anointed Peter Chernin, who built up the Fox television and cinema business, and, at the age of 48, he has a maturity that eludes the Murdoch juniors as his successor in the short term. Mr Murdoch has told Newsweek that his children would have to demonstrate their mettle before he would think of handing over the reins to them. He said: "They all have to prove themselves first. I don't like contemplating my death. It would certainly be a matter for the board. I would think Peter would probably be the chief executive. Maybe my older son [Lachlan] would become chairman."

He added, however, that his recent marriage to Wendi Deng, 33, had "re-energised" him.

The new company will be based in Britain, and News Corp will not be involved in it. Ms Murdoch has negotiated a deal to produce programmes for Sky, but she also intends to supply shows to some other channels. "This is an audacious move. She is doing something that she feels passionately about," a friend commented last night.

Shares drop

At Sky, Ms Murdoch was heavily involved in attracting top stars and shows to the station, and she is thought to want to pursue her connections now in the entertainment industry.

With the growing proliferation of digital channels, a huge market for original programming is developing. By becoming involved with a new production company, Ms Murdoch will be able to take a "global view", using her connections, and those of her partner, to precipitate big deals for her company.

But it seems likely that she will decide to leave the day-to-day management of the venture to others, and concentrate on her family. She has two children by a previous marriage.

Shares in BSkyB fell 25p to £17.11 after the announcement yesterday. One City analyst said: "I would not have predicted this but with the benefit of hindsight it wasn't as if there was really anywhere for her to go at BSkyB. But she is still relatively young for that kind of role and could very easily do it after a period."

The other members of a media dynasty

Lachlan Murdoch, 28

The elder of Mr Murdoch's two sons, Lachlan appears to be the natural successor to run News Corporation when his father finally steps down. Mr Murdoch hinted as much last year in an interview with Newsweek.

Lachlan recently moved to New York from Australia, where he was running more than 100 newspaper titles, a share of the country's leading pay-television business and the recently opened Fox film studios in Sydney. Last year he was also given responsibility for US print operations, including HarperCollins and the New York Post. He is the only one of the three children in the business to sit on the six-strong executive board.

James Murdoch, 27

The youngest of the family, James has nonetheless gained credibility in recent months because of his new media credentials. Based in New York, James has run News Corp's US internet interests for two years and insiders say he has become a powerful influence on his father. He is a friend of Jerry Yang, the founder of Yahoo!

James was recently put in charge of StarTV, News Corp's Asian pay-television business, which underlined his growing status within the group.

His choice to enter the new media field when Elisabeth chose television and Lachlan newspapers raised eyebrows at the time but has since been seen as an insightful move. He dropped out of Harvard to set up a record business and began his career in the music arm of News Corp.

Peter Chernin, 48

Rupert Murdoch's number two at News Corporation, Peter Chernin is the man earmarked to manage the company at least until Mr Murdoch's offspring are old enough to run the show.

Mr Chernin is widely held to have helped refocus the group after a difficult time in the early 1990s when it was weighed down by debt. He is also the man who gave James Cameron the go-ahead to launch Titanic, the biggest grossing film of all-time, and turned Fox into the top television producer in the world.

He recently told the Guardian: "Rupert has been nothing but candid with me. While he has no plans for leaving the company, longer term he would like his children to be in a position to lead it when they are ready to. He has built the company and he has every right to dispose of it in any way he likes."

Prudence Murdoch, 41

The only one of Rupert Murdoch's children not to work in the business. She is, however, married to Alastair MacLeod who runs the internet division of News International.

fields.headline: Euro tumbles into free fall
fields.standfirst:
Currency crisis: market turmoil mars stock exchanges' merger announcement

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Waves of selling sent the ailing euro tumbling below $0.90 yesterday for the first time since its launch 16 months ago.
fields.body:
Waves of selling sent the ailing euro tumbling below $0.90 yesterday for the first time since its launch 16 months ago.

Dealers took fright at the lack of intervention by the European Central Bank and ignored attempts by a chorus of politicians and central bankers to "talk up" the euro's value.

The currency fell almost two US cents in London trading, prompting some analysts to warn that it was on the brink of free fall. It fell against the pound to 58p. The turmoil spilled over into equity markets across Europe and North America, with London's FTSE 100 index falling by 188 points.

"It's fair to call it a euro crisis," said Nick Parsons, currency analyst with Commerzbank.

"Technically the euro is in free fall, with the very last chart-based support now eroded. But the euro's decline is having macro-economic effects that go beyond euroland's borders. You only have to see what it's doing to UK manufacturing to realise that."

With the Bank of England's monetary policy committee due to announce its decision on interest rates today, Tony Blair said in the Commons yesterday that he understood the plight of exporters but had no plans to order the Bank to wade into the currency markets to cap sterling's rise.

The pound was trading at the equivalent of 3.43 German marks yesterday, its highest level since May 1986. Its trade-weighted index against a basket of world currencies stood at 113.6% of its 1990 level - stronger than at any time since December 1985.

Mr Parsons said the euro had devalued by 29% against the dollar since the start of 1999. Breaking the negative cycle meant that the G7 group of industrial nations had to first threaten intervention on the foreign exchanges and then use their $660bn of reserves if the threat proved to be insufficient, he added.

Uwe-Karsten Heye, spokesman for German chancellor Gerhard Schröder, said his government viewed the euro's fall below $0.90 "with a great deal of calm", saying the currency should recover thanks to the economic strength of the euro zone.

ECB vice-president Christian Noyer said he was very optimistic about the outlook for growth in the euro zone, though it would depend on structural reforms.

Dealers said there was no obvious trigger for the latest euro weakness, but news that the European Commission had given Greece the go-ahead to become the 12th member of the euro zone next January rattled nervous markets.

There was a cooler response from the ECB which issued a coded warning about Greece's public finances, which it fears could further shake market confidence in the euro.

fields.headline: Bewitched by the tutu triumphant
fields.standfirst: La Bayadère Festival Theatre, Edinburgh ****
fields.trailText: Svetlana Zakharova uncurls her unbelievably long foot onto the stage of Edinburgh's Festival Theatre, and in that single moment La Bayadère begins. Until then a crowd of warriors, priests and temple maidens (the bayadères) are rather boringly busy with a bit of old-fashioned fire worship. Zakharova changes the pace and the audience is immediately seduced.
fields.body:
Svetlana Zakharova uncurls her unbelievably long foot onto the stage of Edinburgh's Festival Theatre, and in that single moment La Bayadère begins. Until then a crowd of warriors, priests and temple maidens (the bayadères) are rather boringly busy with a bit of old-fashioned fire worship. Zakharova changes the pace and the audience is immediately seduced.

Making its Scottish debut this week the Kirov, under the youthful directorship of Makhar Vaziev, brings new blood and a rare elegance to a ballet that essentially belongs to the company. Programme notes remind us that La Bayadère, a simple story of love lost and found, set exotically in India, was first presented at the Mariinsky Theatre (the Kirov's home) in St Petersburg in 1877 as an extravagant royal entertainment.

By rights, it is a museum piece. And the Kirov to some extent seems bound by that - the costumes are high on eastern promise, the sets have that slightly highbrow but dusty look and the format respectfully recreates the classic set pieces. These include crowds, swoony duets, death scenes, folk dance diversions and the little jokey interlude (here, a papier- mache elephant carrying our hero, followed by a tatty tiger trophy). The trappings are traditional, the music by Minkus strangely unmemorable, so what clicks?

The dancing itself. On the whole it is good; in parts it is ravishing. The Kirov has allowed much attention to be lavished on its younger proteges, who revel in the sensuous, gestural Russian style inherited through the company that produced Nureyev and Baryshnikov.

In the final act our heroine Nikia and her prince Sonor (played with aquiline composure by Farukh Ruzimatov) meet in the Kingdom of Shades, a deathly place. Entering one by one, 32 white tutus spiral in an ever- increasing line to fill the stage. Bend and point, bend and point, repetitively, precisely - nowhere in ballet is the tutu more triumphant as it frames these slowly moving limbs sculpted to perfection by Petipa's choreography.

Startlingly close to the rhythms and abstraction of much late 20th-century ballet, this scene is exactingly executed by the Kirov. The ballerinas even seem to breathe collectively as they create their kaleidoscopic patterns across the floor. Soloists in this act also cut shapely figures, thrilling the audience with their complex simplicity. Put all that postmodern irony behind you, and this might just be a new experience.
fields.bodyText: Svetlana Zakharova uncurls her unbelievably long foot onto the stage of Edinburgh's Festival Theatre, and in that single moment La Bayadère begins. Until then a crowd of warriors, priests and temple maidens (the bayadères) are rather boringly busy with a bit of old-fashioned fire worship. Zakharova changes the pace and the audience is immediately seduced. Making its Scottish debut this week the Kirov, under the youthful directorship of Makhar Vaziev, brings new blood and a rare elegance to a ballet that essentially belongs to the company. Programme notes remind us that La Bayadère, a simple story of love lost and found, set exotically in India, was first presented at the Mariinsky Theatre (the Kirov's home) in St Petersburg in 1877 as an extravagant royal entertainment. By rights, it is a museum piece. And the Kirov to some extent seems bound by that - the costumes are high on eastern promise, the sets have that slightly highbrow but dusty look and the format respectfully recreates the classic set pieces. These include crowds, swoony duets, death scenes, folk dance diversions and the little jokey interlude (here, a papier- mache elephant carrying our hero, followed by a tatty tiger trophy). The trappings are traditional, the music by Minkus strangely unmemorable, so what clicks? The dancing itself. On the whole it is good; in parts it is ravishing. The Kirov has allowed much attention to be lavished on its younger proteges, who revel in the sensuous, gestural Russian style inherited through the company that produced Nureyev and Baryshnikov. In the final act our heroine Nikia and her prince Sonor (played with aquiline composure by Farukh Ruzimatov) meet in the Kingdom of Shades, a deathly place. Entering one by one, 32 white tutus spiral in an ever- increasing line to fill the stage. Bend and point, bend and point, repetitively, precisely - nowhere in ballet is the tutu more triumphant as it frames these slowly moving limbs sculpted to perfection by Petipa's choreography. Startlingly close to the rhythms and abstraction of much late 20th-century ballet, this scene is exactingly executed by the Kirov. The ballerinas even seem to breathe collectively as they create their kaleidoscopic patterns across the floor. Soloists in this act also cut shapely figures, thrilling the audience with their complex simplicity. Put all that postmodern irony behind you, and this might just be a new experience.

webTitle: A&L appoints chief after seven-month search

fields.headline: A&L appoints chief after seven-month search
fields.trailText: Alliance & Leicester yesterday called a halt to its seven-month search for a chief executive by appointing Peter McNamara to the new post of group managing director.
fields.body:
Alliance & Leicester yesterday called a halt to its seven-month search for a chief executive by appointing Peter McNamara to the new post of group managing director.

Ditching the title of chief executive, A&L said that Mr McNamara, former managing director of personal banking at Lloyds TSB, would be responsible for the day to day running of the bank.

John Windeler, the chairman who stood in as chief executive after the acrimonious departure of Peter White last year, said he would continue to take personal responsibility for setting up new partnerships, corporate development and corporate communications.

The bank refused to disclose the terms of Mr McNamara's employment or his salary. Mr Windeler said Mr McNamara, who spent 26 years at Lloyds TSB, was one of "quite a long list" of people considered for the role, including those who contacted the bank directly after the departure of Mr White.

The title of group managing director better suited the role than chief executive, Mr Windeler said. He insisted the new arrangements complied with corporate governance codes which he said required a clear separation between the chairman and the day to day management of the group.

Mr White eventually received a £1.7m pay off after threatening to take A&L to an employment tribunal over his sudden dismissal last October when the bank said it was looking for a more "consensual style of leadership".

The bank also strengthened its board with the appointment of Peter Barton, previously a non-executive director, to the position of deputy chairman, to work alongside existing deputy chairman Sir Michael Thompson.

Jonathan Watts, managing director of Colt Telecommun ciations, was named a non-executive director as was David Brougham, formerly of Standard Chartered bank.

Mr Windeler, who said the bank would unveil a strategy review in the coming months, said A&L would install 700 more cash machines, some of which would involve a £1 surcharge for withdrawals in "convenience locations".

The shares, which have fallen from over £9 in the last year, ended yesterday at 586p, down 12.5p.

fields.headline: Jobs boost as Vauxhall expands
fields.trailText: Vauxhall gave the beleaguered motor industry a badly needed boost yesterday by announcing a £189m investment at its British plants, creating 500 new jobs.
fields.body:
Vauxhall gave the beleaguered motor industry a badly needed boost yesterday by announcing a £189m investment at its British plants, creating 500 new jobs.

The move will help to lift some of the gloom in the industry after BMW's decision to sell Rover and expected job losses at Ford.

Nick Reilly, chairman and managing director of Vauxhall, said: "These moves are a significant announcement for our manufacturing operations in the UK.

"The investment is necessary to prepare us for the new products and to improve further our productivity and cost competitiveness."

At the IBC plant in Luton, £130m will be spent to build a new range of vans, creating 500 new jobs, as part of a new GM/Renault project.

A further £32m will be invested at the company's sister plant in Luton, which builds the Vectra. In Ellesmere Port, Cheshire, where the Astra, Astravan and V6 engines are produced, Vauxhall will spend £27m to transfer production of the Frontera 4x4 off road vehicle from IBC in Luton where it is now built.

fields.headline: Mr Keep-It-Real
fields.standfirst: Paul Weller Royal Albert Hall, London **
fields.trailText: Strange chap, Paul Weller. He tours as regularly as clockwork, dutifully checking in at the Albert Hall every year or so, but never shows any sign of actually enjoying it. Operating on the principle that his mere presence is sufficient reward for his faithful public, he works his stony-faced way through a condensed version of his solo career and, well, that's it.
fields.body:
Strange chap, Paul Weller. He tours as regularly as clockwork, dutifully checking in at the Albert Hall every year or so, but never shows any sign of actually enjoying it. Operating on the principle that his mere presence is sufficient reward for his faithful public, he works his stony-faced way through a condensed version of his solo career and, well, that's it.

The routine rarely varies, whether he is in an artistic trough or, as with the new Heliocentric album, starting to peak again. He doesn't make an entrance as such, but just walks on, plugs in and gets on with it, backstage pass still dangling from his neck. It is typical that Weller should wear a pass at his own show, semaphoring that he is just another member of the band. And he could be, dressed down in jeans and exuding about as much star quality as tour guitarist Steve Cradock of Ocean Colour Scene. When he sings, in a voice mellowed to an attractive huskiness by his 42 years, he is not the commanding figure you would expect. He is just one of the lads, doing his bit in a show that has all the dynamism of a large pub gig.

No one expects Weller, long enthroned as custodian of traditional geezerly values, to do anything fancy (though the string orchestra that appears for the second half verges on artiness). But if he can't bring himself to put on a show, he could at least play more than the handful of hits he grudgingly sprinkles between unfamiliar tracks. The reaction when he performs his prettiest love song, You Do Something to Me, immediately followed by an almost punk version of The Changingman, should be instructive. People snap out of their torpor, get to their feet and dance - then stop when he reverts to Heliocentric and its unpopular predecessor, Heavy Soul.

One of the few mystifying things about this painfully straightforward artist is his fondness for spinning songs into 10-minute jams, as he does with Heavy Soul's title track. Someone of his punk roots should abhor the practice of stretching tunes beyond their natural limits, especially when the tunes are so lumpen. Playing with head down, chopping industriously at his guitar, he resembles nothing so much as one of the dinosaur rockers he came to destroy in 1977. But that's Weller: campaigner for authentic rock'n' roll, Mr Keep-It-Real.

Paul Weller plays the Nottingham Arena (0115-948 4526), tomorrow, then tours.

fields.headline: Boo.com investors press for sale
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Boo.com, the troubled online sportswear retailer, lurched into a fresh crisis yesterday after it emerged that some of its shareholders have abandoned any hope that it will succeed in raising new funds from a stock market flotation and are pressing instead for the company to be sold off.
fields.body:
Boo.com, the troubled online sportswear retailer, lurched into a fresh crisis yesterday after it emerged that some of its shareholders have abandoned any hope that it will succeed in raising new funds from a stock market flotation and are pressing instead for the company to be sold off.

The move follows a sharp downturn in investor sentiment towards business-to-consumer internet companies, which have been particularly badly hit by the recent volatility in technology stocks.

The private company's shareholders, including the French entrepreneur, Bernard Arnault, clothing group Benetton, investment bank JP Morgan and Bain Capital, are understood to be seeking to minimise losses from the estimated £80m of venture capital that has been pumped into the company.

A spokesman for Boo refused to comment on the issue of the sale but admitted that JP Morgan, which co-ordinated earlier fundraising efforts, was no longer an adviser to the company.

Analysts said the fate of Boo.com is likely to resonate throughout the European internet sector and is likely to have a significant influence on the valuations made for dozens of other start-ups attracting heavy funding.

"Boo shows that many turtles may hatch but few make it to the sea," said Peter Bradshaw, an internet analyst at Merrill Lynch investment bank. "If you are not a market leader in this area you're under pressure. It is very brutal."

Rumours about the condition of Boo.com's finances and the rate at which it is burning cash have dogged the company for some time.

Despite an expensive global advertising campaign the company has failed to attract the customers it hoped, and has cut about 25% of its once 400-strong workforce.

Despite no longer acting for Boo.com, JP Morgan - which is a 5% shareholder in the company - is understood to be playing a central role in the proposed sale.

A spokesman for the bank refused to comment.

Separately, Chris Batailard - the corporate financier who led JP Morgan's interest in Boo - has left to start his own telecoms company.

Observers have named sportswear manufacturers Adidas-Salomon and Reebok International, along with retailers Marks & Spencer and Kingfisher, as potential buyers. US internet firm Fogdog has also been mentioned.

Sources close to Boo.com indicate most of its value lies in the technology platform in which it has invested heavily. Analysts say shareholders will have to write off some of their investments to secure a sale.

The shareholder unrest follows a series of executive departures. Finance director Dean Hawkins quit to join Dutch broadband firm Chello just a few weeks after joining from Adidas.

His predecessor and one of Boo's founders, Patrick Hedelin, has returned to Sweden and no longer plays an active role in the company.

Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander, Boo.com's remaining founders, were unavailable for comment. They were responsible for setting up Swedish online book store bookus.com.

But Boo has been hit by negative publicity in the wake of launch delays and technology problems. At Christmas a report from investment bank CSFB suggested the net firm may be turning the corner after ranking it the number one retail site in the US in overall e-commerce terms.

fields.headline: Powerhouse meets Nasdaq challenge
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The merger between the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges marks a decisive shift in the balance of power in the struggle over share trading in Europe.
fields.body:
The merger between the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges marks a decisive shift in the balance of power in the struggle over share trading in Europe.

Together the two exchanges will form a powerhouse with which other bourses will be forced to come to terms.

Separately they could have formed cores of competing groups; now no other combination can rival it. Even before the ink is dry on the deal, Milan and Madrid are preparing to sign up.

At the same time the exchanges have neutralised the challenge of the hi-tech US exchange, Nasdaq, which was lining up its European invasion plans but has now opted to join the Anglo-German group.

In uniting to form iX, the exchanges are burying years of rivalry, although the time it has taken them to negotiate a deal - nearly two years - indicates the scale of the challenge.

It remains to be seen how members react to the merger and whether the two cultures can be brought together. Executives are seeking to bury any notion of London versus Frankfurt and stress that they taking the first steps towards a pan-European exchange.

But the structure of the deal shows how carefully national sensitivies have been handled.

The new company is a 50:50 joint venture. Its chairman will be British - Don Cruickshank - balancing the appointment of Frankfurt's Werner Seifert as chief executive, who in turn will have to move to London. The capital will provide the administrative base but it is Frankfurt's trading system that will be used there.

Trading in blue-chip stocks will be in the City, but the hi-tech market will be centred in Frankfurt. That reflects the success of Frankfurt Neuer Markt but it is also the point at which the merged exchanges will hook up with Nasdaq.

That link could prove crucial: it gives London and Frankfurt a global dimension via the Nasdaq's strength in the US and its links with markets in Hong Kong and Japan.

"The market will follow the sun for the biggest companies," says Nasdaq chairman and chief executive Frank Zarb.

But for all yesterday's cheery camaraderie - shared even by the London exchange's chief executive Gavin Casey, whose job will go under the deal - the two exchanges did not jump into bed together, they were pushed. The initiative came from the big investment banks and fund managers who push billions of pounds worth of trades through the market every day.

They want to trade more cheaply, more easily and above all across borders from a single base, rather than needing individual links into 15 exchanges.

The pressure has been compounded by the introduction of the single currency in most of the EU which has removed exchange rate risks from cross-border equity deals.

"What we are about here is promoting the efficiency of capital markets in Europe," says Mr Cruickshank.

But the merger is only one step. Although the new exchange will cover Europe's biggest and fastest growing stocks, the institutional investors will still want to see the range widened - allowing them to deal on an industry basis across Europe.

fields.headline: Beyond belief
fields.standfirst: Solemn Mass for a Full Moon in Summer Traverse Theatre, Edinburgh *****
fields.trailText: Such an old friend is Québécois playwright Michel Tremblay to contemporary Scottish theatre that a critic once described him as "the greatest Scottish playwright Scotland never had". This is the sixth of his plays to be produced in Scotland and translated by Martin Bowman and Bill Findlay (whose previous Tremblay successes include the vernacular Scots version of The Guid Sisters, which made Tremblay's name in 1968). It is his strongest yet.
fields.body:
Such an old friend is Québécois playwright Michel Tremblay to contemporary Scottish theatre that a critic once described him as "the greatest Scottish playwright Scotland never had". This is the sixth of his plays to be produced in Scotland and translated by Martin Bowman and Bill Findlay (whose previous Tremblay successes include the vernacular Scots version of The Guid Sisters, which made Tremblay's name in 1968). It is his strongest yet.

Inspired by and structured as a Catholic mass, the play presents the loves, lives and beliefs (nearly all broken, with only glimpses of redemption) of 11 Montreal tenement dwellers, spilled out confessionally on their balconies. Their relationships play out in front of us: Isabelle and Yannick revel in their first flush of lust-meets-love ("I want you" is their particular litany); a father and daughter are caught up in a spiral of reliance and blame; a widow rocks on her chair with only memories for company. As the full moon floods them with light and the summer's sultry heat draws them outdoors, the shards of love that remain for most are revealed, tugged at, questioned.

It is the mass-like quality of the production that deepens all this human misery into something transcendental and moving.

A third of the play is delivered in a cacophony of voices, sometimes in unison, as in spoken prayer, other times in two or three groups. Individual voices ("No, no, no," the widow repeats rhythmically for 10 minutes) add to the sense of high church meeting spoken opera. So too does Neil Warmington's magnificent set design - the balconies are like cages or witness boxes, set against the fullest moon you can imagine.

Tremblay is such a gifted writer that he manages to blend the big, universal human dramas with local details that bring the work to life. In this he is supported by a flawless cast.

This is an unmissable play for all Catholics, lapsed and otherwise and for anyone who has ever believed in anything or anyone, anywhere.

Until 13 May. Box office: 0131-228 1404. The play will open the Bite:00 season at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), on 17 May and will run until 3 June.

fields.headline: Hiddink leaves Celtic bemused
fields.trailText: Dundee United 0 - 1 Celtic
fields.body:
Guus Hiddink last night dropped a broad hint that he may not become Celtic's next manager - at the same time as the team were failing to reassure their supporters here about the future of the club.

The Dutchman, targeted as the experienced successor to the novice John Barnes, was sacked yesterday by Real Betis after a three-month stint in which his side won only one out of 13 matches.

The immediate conclusion was that Hiddink, who had met Celtic's chief executive Allan MacDonald in Spain last month, would now be free to come on the first flight to Scotland, but he insisted: "I still feel quite Spanish."

It left the fans bemused but their feeling, expressed noisily, was that if Hiddink, offered more than £1.5m a year to put together a side capable of overhauling Rangers, turned down the offer, Celtic would face another summer of turmoil.

Hiddink's record is formidable, despite being unable to save Betis from probable relegation. He managed PSV Eindhoven to the European Cup in 1988 and repeated the feat with Real Madrid, who sacked him soon after the triumph. He was in charge of Holland when they got to within a penalty of reaching the last World Cup final, but he has also been sacked by both Fenerbahce of Turkey and Valencia.

The indications remain he may end up in Glasgow. Celtic were confident enough to send their coach Tommy Burns to Spain to brief him on the club's needs.

That all leaves Kenny Dalglish, Celtic's director of football, in an intolerable situation. He had conceded before last night's match that any new manager would be totally in charge, and after a brief spell in the dug-out winning only half his games his position is seriously under threat.

At least Celtic gained the win through a Mark Burchill goal in the ninth minute. But there was little to inspire in a half-empty ground that told its own story about the merits, or otherwise, of both teams. Stephen McConalogue's header in stoppage-time came back from the bar and United deserved better against a club waiting for something to happen.

The Dutchman, targeted as the experienced successor to the novice John Barnes, was sacked yesterday by Real Betis after a three-month stint in which his side won only one out of 13 matches. The immediate conclusion was that Hiddink, who had met Celtic's chief executive Allan MacDonald in Spain last month, would now be free to come on the first flight to Scotland, but he insisted: "I still feel quite Spanish." It left the fans bemused but their feeling, expressed noisily, was that if Hiddink, offered more than £1.5m a year to put together a side capable of overhauling Rangers, turned down the offer, Celtic would face another summer of turmoil. Hiddink's record is formidable, despite being unable to save Betis from probable relegation. He managed PSV Eindhoven to the European Cup in 1988 and repeated the feat with Real Madrid, who sacked him soon after the triumph. He was in charge of Holland when they got to within a penalty of reaching the last World Cup final, but he has also been sacked by both Fenerbahce of Turkey and Valencia. The indications remain he may end up in Glasgow. Celtic were confident enough to send their coach Tommy Burns to Spain to brief him on the club's needs. That all leaves Kenny Dalglish, Celtic's director of football, in an intolerable situation. He had conceded before last night's match that any new manager would be totally in charge, and after a brief spell in the dug-out winning only half his games his position is seriously under threat. At least Celtic gained the win through a Mark Burchill goal in the ninth minute. But there was little to inspire in a half-empty ground that told its own story about the merits, or otherwise, of both teams. Stephen McConalogue's header in stoppage-time came back from the bar and United deserved better against a club waiting for something to happen.

webTitle: Honesty to start at the top

fields.headline: Honesty to start at the top
fields.standfirst: Rulers stake out the moral high ground
fields.trailText: Members of the International Cricket Council executive board, meeting at Lord's to discuss match-fixing, began their two-day gathering by signing a declaration of honesty over their financial interest in the game.
fields.body:
World cricket's ruling body took the first steps yesterday towards repairing its battered reputation by introducing a series of measures designed to tackle corruption after weeks of match-fixing allegations which have blighted the sport.

Members of the International Cricket Council executive board, meeting at Lord's to discuss match-fixing, began their two-day gathering by signing a declaration of honesty over their financial interest in the game.

All 18 members of the ICC executive board signed the declaration, which states that they have no financial interest, direct or indirect, "in the game of cricket, either nationally or internationally, other than those which have been declared... to their domestic board and which are in the public domain".

The declaration is designed to remove world cricket administrators from corruption allegations, after claims in recent weeks that they too have benefited from shady financial dealings in the sport.

The idea of a declaration of honesty was raised by Lord MacLaurin, the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, and was unanimously backed by all those present.

ICC members also agreed to the establishment of a panel, made up of a group of people from within the organisation, that would have the right to inspect the financial accounts of directors if any corruption allegations were made against them.

Lord MacLaurin, who is also proposing an amnesty in return for information from players involved in match- fixing, said in a statement: "I strongly believe that the high ground which we occupy in relation to our governance of the game demands that we are, and are seen to be, as transparently open as possible at this time when the cry of corruption within the game is becoming ever louder. Only by taking such a lead can we expect to foster public confidence in the steps we shall propose and, were any director or delegate to decline to give the assurances which should now be sought in turn, he must forfeit the confidence of the ICC and this executive board."

The ICC's chief executive Dave Richards said after yesterday's meeting that he was confident that other strong measures designed to combat corruption would be announced today. He said that all 18 executive board members were united in their determination to cleanse cricket once and for all.

The ICC also moved yesterday to defend its president Jagmohan Dalmiya, who was accused in India last week of financially benefiting from the sale of cricket television rights.

According to the allegation, he profited from the sale of rights to an ICC knockout tournament in Bangladesh in 1998. Dalmiya denies the allegation and is taking legal action over the claim.

Richards claimed yesterday that Dalmiya was not involved in any of the negotiations and that four television companies had bid for the tournament: the state-run Indian television station Doordarshan, TWI, WorldTel and CSI.

Richards said that the highest offer, from Doordarshan, had been accepted and that he himself had signed the contract, with most of the bidding process overseen by a lawyer.

He said: "At no stage did Dalmiya get involved in any of the negotiations." The ICC also said yesterday that no fees or commission had been paid to any party and that there was no evidence to suggest that anybody had benefited from the contract.

It was also agreed at yesterday's meeting to receive evidence from Inderjit Singh Bindra, a former president of the Board of Control for Cricket in India who claims to have proof of match-fixing. Bindra, who is currently in London, claims to have a dossier detailing allegations of corruption involving both cricketers and administrators.

 The Pakistan Cricket Board will receive the much-awaited Qayyum report on match- fixing on Friday and it will be made public before the end of June.

webTitle: Spurs step up efforts to sign Rebrov for £10m

fields.headline: Spurs step up efforts to sign Rebrov for £10m
fields.trailText: Tottenham have stepped up their interest in Sergei Rebrov and hope to conclude a £10m deal for the Dynamo Kiev striker.
fields.body:
The absence of George Graham because of arthritis has not prevented the transfer wheels whirring at White Hart Lane. Tottenham have stepped up their interest in Sergei Rebrov and hope to conclude a £10m deal for the Dynamo Kiev striker.

The 25-year-old, scorer of eight goals in 12 Champions League appearances this season, is poised to leave Ukraine, and Spurs' director of football David Pleat said yesterday: "We do have an interest and we have had talks but nothing has been finalised yet."

Pleat flew to Kiev for a meeting with Dynamo officials last week and has also spoken with Rebrov's agent. Some reports suggested personal terms of £25,000 a week have been settled. Pleat, though, denied that the player had agreed to move to London. "It depends on many things," he said.

Tottenham would have to dig deep to sign Rebrov, with Kiev thought to be demanding £12m, twice Spurs' record fee. A bigger hurdle, however, might be persuading the player to join a club who will not be in Europe next season. Last term he was playing in a Champions League semi-final.

The Ukrainian has already been linked with moves to both Milan clubs. Inter were said to see him as a replacement for the injured Ronaldo; their city rivals would be obvious candidates because Andrei Shevchenko is there.

The pair formed a formidable striking partnership at Kiev and play together for their country. But Shevchenko dropped what may be a hint that Rebrov has his sights set on the Premiership when he told the latest issue of World Soccer: "I think he is ready for Italy, or for an English side."

The Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association for comments he made to the referee Neale Barry after his side's 2-1 defeat at Coventry on April 15. Robson complained that Coventry's second goal was offside.

Jonathan Greening is set to sign a new contract at Manchester United. Liverpool have announced a new sponsorship deal with Reebok worth £21m over three years. Everton have elevated Michael Dunford from secretary to become their first chief executive.

 The Football Association chairman Geoff Thompson is standing for election to Uefa's executive committee. He is one of 13 candidates vying for seven seats on the decision-making body. England currently has no representative on the committee. Desmond Shanklin, treasurer of the Football Association of Wales, is also standing in the June 30 election.

webTitle: Sack the cheats, says Critics Corner

fields.headline: Sack the cheats, says Critics Corner
fields.trailText: If the ICC needed any persuading yesterday that the rank-and-file supporter expects immediate action against match-rigging, it should have abandoned deliberations at Lord's and sought out the only county match taking place in England.
fields.body:
If the International Cricket Council needed any persuading yesterday that the rank-and-file supporter expects immediate action against match-rigging, it should have abandoned deliberations at Lord's and sought out instead the only county match taking place in England.

Here in the county game's most northerly outpost about 3,000 spectators saw Durham open their championship season against the defending champions Surrey, and endless talk of bribes and bungs helped to while away the balmiest of spring days.

At Critics Corner, where the most loyal and frank of Durham's members gather, there was universal agreement: anybody accepting money for match-rigging should be banned sine die.

These were not retired right-wing majors peddling their extremist views, that false caricature of the make-up of county crowds. These were doctors, social workers, teachers, unemployed people; people who might have been expected to offer a more understated view. No matter. No mercy. Ban them for life.

There was Dr Jan Woodward - "a doctor of bugs and beetles, not people" - a Durham member even before they gained first-class status in 1992. She said: "Cricket is meant to be the last bastion of civilisation. There are still a lot of strong values around. Lose those and you lose the game itself."

There was real bitterness at international cricket's failure to guard the moral framework that, for many, remains at the core of the game. Mike Taylor, a social worker, cited the former Indian all-rounder Manoj Prabhakar, a former Durham overseas professional who has threatened to name Indian test players on the take. "He is more popular here now than he was on the field," Taylor said. "Then he didn't always seem interested. Now you have to admire his bravery."

Chris Lewis, who reported allegations that three English players had taken pay-offs from bent bookies, might have been booed by a few stupid souls at Old Trafford. Here they saw it differently. Given the choice between hero or villain, what was he? "Hero," they chimed with barely a flicker of dissent.

And, make no mistake, this was a day for heroes. Nick Peng, at 17 years 227 days, his time at Newcastle Royal Grammar School barely over, narrowly failed to become the youngest player to make a century on his championship debut.

He reached his 50 with two edged boundaries off Martin Bicknell and was 89 when Durham's last man, Simon Brown, joined him. A fluent straight drive off Ben Hollioake took him to 98, from 145 balls, but there it ended. He cut at Hollioake and was caught at the wicket.

Surrey were generous in their recognition. There was a heartfelt pat from Alex Tudor, handshakes and applause. He looked quite a prospect. The message was simple and convincing.

"This is what cricket's all about," said Tony Day at Critics Corner. "A young lad still full of honest ambition, not a twisted old pro screwing the game that made his name." Alongside him Neil Barker laughed. "He's no need of the money anyway. His dad brings him to the ground in a Rolls-Royce."

And in Critics Corner they all laughed again, as they will laugh throughout the summer. But in between the laughter, there is a fear the game they love is in the possession of scoundrels.

webTitle: Pack's lack of punch a bad omen

fields.headline: Pack's lack of punch a bad omen
fields.standfirst: Simon Pack and Lord MacLaurin have a few things in common...
fields.trailText: When the England cricket team flew home from their last tour, Simon Pack, the England and Wales Cricket Board's international teams director, went to meet them and was bewildered when they failed to turn up. Pack went to Heathrow; the players arrived at Gatwick.
fields.body:
When the England cricket team flew home from their tour of South Africa and Zimbabwe, Simon Pack, the England and Wales Cricket Board's international teams director, went to meet them and was bewildered when they failed to turn up. Pack went to Heathrow; the players arrived at Gatwick.

At the Oval they will tell you, with a snigger, about the time he got confused between Alec and Eric Bedser. Easily done, this. Except that Pack appeared not to realise they were related. "My word, aren't you two alike?" he exclaimed.

Then there was the occasion he admitted not knowing that championship cricket in England was once played over three days.

This is hardly surprising. In the current edition of Who's Who, Pack names cricket as one of his hobbies. But before his Lord's appointment he listed golf, tennis, sailing, gardening, music and even current affairs, with no mention of cricket.

This is the man who was involved in the maladroit pay negotiations that preceded England's premature exit from last year's World Cup. And the man who talked to Chris Lewis before the Board cleared England players of match-fixing allegations last week.

Now, the point of this particular piece is not to make fun of Pack, even though, for a military man, he does present an alarmingly soft target.

There is ample evidence to suggest that he is a serious and well intentioned fellow. His military career is also a half-decent one, though I'm pleased he wasn't around during the war because it's easy to imagine him patrolling Skegness while the dreaded Hun nipped in at Dover.

No, the point is this: if, for argument's sake, English cricket were totally corrupt and every England player since the days of tall hats and curved bats were as bent as one of Uri Geller's teaspoons, Pack would probably be one of the last people to know anything about it.

In fact if Pack knows as much about betting as he knows about cricket he would experience considerable difficulty distinguishing between a bookmark and a bookmaker, a turf accountant and a chartered accountant.

Then there is Pack's golf chum, Lord MacLaurin from Tesco, the chairman of the ECB. MacLaurin knows a great deal about supermarkets but if English cricket were totally corrupt he too would probably be one of the last people to know.

He acted quickly in calling for the current International Cricket Council meeting. But his chairmanship of the board is widely viewed as a bit of a disaster, which is why there are already committee-room whispers of forcing him out of office if he doesn't go voluntarily later this year.

During his time at the top, county cricket has been virtually destroyed, the England team dropped to the bottom of the world rankings and the organisation of the World Cup was a fiasco, sold too cheaply to television and not sold at all to the public.

MacLaurin punches about as much weight at ICC level as he does among the counties. Which is very little.

On the radio yesterday he spoke in wonderfully hawkish tones about the ICC needing to show leadership. But he sounded rather like a troubled US president who has decided to bomb some distant despot to deflect attention from problems nearer home.

But this is no more an attack on MacLaurin than it is on Pack. It is merely to point out that men who have tried, and failed, to run English cricket are way out of their depth when it comes to getting to the bottom of a murky, worldwide business that involves multimillion-pound corruption. And the same applies to their colleagues on the ICC.

The ECB's handling of Lewis and the match-fixing allegations is also reminiscent of the Premier League's bung investigation. The football authorities didn't find anything and gave the strong impression that they didn't want to find anything. The only ones nailed were those who had already been outed by the press.

But football, like horse racing, athletics and many other sports, is some way ahead of cricket when it comes to investigating skulduggery. Many at the ECB and the ICC have no idea what is going on. And you can bet on that.
