Teams

Real Madrid: Casillas, Salgado, Carlos, Redondo, Raul, McManaman, Morientes, Campo, Helguera, Karanka, Anelka. Subs: Illgner, Savio, Baljic, Geremi, Karembeu, Julio Cesar, Ognjenovic.

Bayern Munich: Kahn, Babbel, Lizarazu, Scholl, Elber, Sergio, Jeremies, Fink, Tarnat, Salihamidzic, Linke. Subs: Dreher, Kuffour, Andersson, Weisinger, Strunz, Jancker, Santa Cruz.

Referee: Anders Frisk (Sweden)

1 A gentle knock around sees the game get underway with neither team willing to be on the receiving end of a Valencia-like drubbing.
3 McManaman gets into space on the left of the Bayern penalty area but fails to capitalise.
4 Goal: Real Madrid 1 - 0 Bayern Munich So much for avoiding a drubbing. Raul releases Anelka with probing through ball down the left; Anelka pauses inside the penalty area and curls the ball around Casillas with a right-foot shot to the far post.
8 Raul again attempts to find Anelka with a long ball slotted through the middle of the Bayern midfield, but Anelka appears reluctant to make the chase.
11 Bayern begin to build from the back but lose possession. McManaman makes a break down the left and tries to play Raul into the penalty area but the ball goes for gaol-kick.
14 McManaman again the playmaker on the edge of the Bayern area as he feeds Morientes into six-yard box. Morientes gets around Babbel before he is muscled into touch. The resulting corner comes to nothing.
17 Bayern finally come awake when Elber gets on the end of a whipped-in ball to test Casillas with a swift shot.
18 Lizarazu attempts to make space down the left for Bayern but Real snuff out the move.
19 Roberto Carlos cuts into the penalty but his cross is cleared for a corner. McManaman plays it short to Roberto Carlos, he passes back to McManaman and MaManaman loses possession.
23 Real win a free-kick 20 yards out. Roberto Carlos winds up and hits it straight at the wall. At Paulo Sergio to be precise.
24 Real come close to scoring a second when a nicely worked move between McManaman and Raul leaves Morientes with a tap in, but the goal is ruled offside.
25 All Real for the last eight minutes as Bayern nervously clear a Real corner.
26 Bayern win a free-kick after Babbel finds space down the right and his cross allows Elber to get in a wayward strike. Better than nothing.
28 Booking Karanka for a challenge on Sergio.
30 Morientes makes a deep run on the right but Jeremies forces a corner.
31 Raul again in acres of space in the middle of the park as Bayern give away possession on the break. He plays another deep through ball towards Anelka but Bayern muster well.
33 Goal: Real Madrid 2 - 0 Bayern Munich Salgado runs on to a superb one-two from Raul on the edge of the area; Salgado puts the ball around Casillas but it is Jeremies who runs the ball in to score an own goal.
37 Bayern win a free-kick from all of 35 yards out. Tarnat takes and does well to keep the ball down, if wide of the right-hand upright.
40 Tarnat plays in Paulo Sergio, who then shimmies along the edge of the area before shooting straight at Casillas.
41 A bit of a push-and-shove fest breaks out after a tackle on Scholl.
43 Bayern lucky not to concede a penalty. Anelka cuts the ball back from inside the Bayern area and as McManaman tries to retrieve he is shoved to the floor.
45 Bayern come close to scoring an equaliser from a Scholl corner kick when Babbel heads on to Elber on the far post; Casillas makes the save. Half-time.

46 Substitution Weisinger on for Tarnat. On the balance of the play in the first half, Bayern have got an almighty task ahead of them if they are to turn this tie around.
49 McManaman keen to maintain his sparkling form as he threads a pass down the left; Anelka checks his run and loses possession.
50 Substitute Weisinger gives the ball away in his own half, allowing Morientes to play in Raul on the right of the penalty area, but Kahn comes out to smother the shot.
52 Booking Salgado.
55 A brief lull in the pace of play sees some scrappy action and neither team making much progress.
57 Scholl takes a corner for Bayern but Casillas punches clear.
59 Anelka uses his pace deep on the right and whips in a cross that Jeremies does well to glance clear.
61 Substitution Savio on for Morientes. McManaman wins a corner on the right; he takes but Campo can only head away from goal.
63 Bayern finding it hard to get out of their own half. Raul and Anelka work their way into the Bayern area but the German side defend well and Kahn clears.
65 Elber has a great opportunity at the other end but can only head over.
69 Jeremies, on the break, plays in Elber but Bayern fail to make the most of the opportunity.
70 Bayern step up their search for an away goal and just fail to play Paulo Sergio into a goal-scoring opportunity.
72 Campo upends Elber on the edge of the area; Scholl takes the free-kick and curls it around the wall but Casillas is perfectly placed.
74 Just as Bayern were enjoying their best spell of the game, Real threaten to put them well and truly out of the game. Anelka and Raul work the ball around the area; Anelka passes to Redondo, who feeds Savio on the left but Kahn saves.
75 Booking Roberto Carlos, after an unsightly altercation with Kahn. Kahn on the receiving end of a few Madrid missiles in the Bayern goalmouth.
78 Substitutions Jancker and Santa Cruz on for Elber and Salihamidzic.
80 Substitutions Baljic on for Anelka.
81 Real come close to wrapping up the game when Raul chips the ball in from the edge of the area, but Kahn tips it over. Corner comes to nothing.
83 Salgado goes down after a challenge by Santa Cruz and spends two minutes writhing around before rejoining play.
85 McManaman runs into the area and on to another superb through ball from Raul but Babbel does just enough to help run the ball out of play.
86 Bayern win a free-kick just outside the area but the ball is tipped over for a corner; Fink's low header goes wide of the far post.
90 Bayern continue to look for that elusive goal with three minutes of extra time to play. They win a corner, Scholl takes but Real clear. A Lizarazu long throw into the Real area is cleared by McManaman as Real charge upfield, but they have doen enough... full-time: Real Madrid 2 - 0 Bayern Munich.

fields.headline: Devolution, one year on
fields.standfirst: As the anniversary of elections nears on Saturday, how has the Edinburgh parliament performed so far?
fields.trailText: May 3 2000: As the anniversary of elections nears on Saturday, how has the Edinburgh parliament performed so far?
fields.body:
There could be no less likely a saviour for the Scottish parliament than Tommy Sheridan. The sole representative of the Scottish Socialist party, who took his oath of office with a raised fist, last week brought the ruling Labour,Liberal Democrat executive to its knees. And in so doing he showed, on the anniversary of devolution, that the parliament could work the way Scotland was promised it would.

The issue was warrant sales, a uniquely Scottish and widely hated system of debt recovery where debtors' homes are entered, often forcibly, and goods seized and sold at auction. Mr Sheridan, who was jailed eight years ago for opposing their use on poll tax evaders, introduced the parliament's first private member's bill to have them abolished.

Three parliamentary committees - the supposed linchpin of Scotland's new political set-up - backed his move, but the executive opposed it, preferring to hold off until alternative measures were in place. In a stormy debate, with Mr Sheridan urging MSPs not to abandon the poor and Labour backbenchers threatening a revolt, the executive was forced to allow the bill to go through.

The first defeat the first real sign that the system could work. And not a moment too soon, after a year remarkable for all the wrong reasons: the soaring cost of the new parliament building, ministers' mishandling of the section 28 issue, the crisis over tuition fees , a lobbying scandal, senior advisers sacked and chastised, and humiliation for Labour in Ayr.

'The Sheridan bill was an example of how differently things can be done compared with Westminster,' said John Curtice, pollster and professor of politics at Strathclyde University. 'In Westminster, the bill would have been introduced on a Friday and would have been killed by the government quite easily. At Holyrood, it showed that some of the distinctive procedures of the parliament were beginning to have an impact.'

There has been a second seismic event to mark the parliament's first year. A routine medical test discovered a faulty aortic valve in Donald Dewar's heart, requiring major surgery. There is plenty of goodwill for the first minister, still viewed as the father of the nation for his delivery of devolution, but there are also very real questions over whether he will run for a second term. Speculation over a successor has revealed a fair selection of credible candidates, a good proportion of them women.

'The Dewar succession struggle is changing everything,' said Tom Nairn, director of the centre for Scottish and Irish studies. 'And the prospects for this in terms of the identity of the parliament are rather good. 'No doubt great efforts will be made to promote someone suitably grey to succeed Mr Dewar, but I don't think it's going to work.

'What people wanted from the parliament was a sense of difference, a new departure. There is a dynamic which is forcing its way through, and that is nowhere more noticeable than on the gender side. The contrast with Westminster is unmistakeable. In Holyrood, women have moved into the front rank, and some are serious contenders for succeeding Dewar. That onlyhappens when things are really changing.'

But they may not be changing fast enough for the public. The most recent poll suggests continuing apathy towards the devolved body. About 27% think it is doing a good job, 34% believe it is doing a bad job, but 38% don't care how it's doing.

'By the standards of the other devolution experiments - Wales and the London mayor - it's going well,' said Prof Curtice. 'Polls show people are not antagonistic towards it, but they are saying what's this body doing? People are underwhelmed but not seriously upset, and still prepared to give it a chance.' The main problem, according to Geoff Scobie, a Glasgow University psychologist, is that few Scots have felt the parlia ment's impact. 'People have not yet seen any benefits coming directly from it. But a new system takes time to bed down and make decisions that have a direct effect on people's lives. It's only when the issues become significant and important that politics regains its imperative.'

But the parliament has been the making of the opposition parties. The Scottish National party and the Conservatives have flourished under devolution. The Tories, routed in Scotland in 1997, won 17 seats through proportional representation and took Ayr in the parliament's first byelection.

The SNP has embraced devolution with unexpected vigour. Party rhetoric on independence has been toned down, bringing suggestions that it is backtracking on its core commitment. Party leaders, however, say they need the parliament to persuade Scots to make the jump to full autonomy.

Richard Holloway, bishop of Edinburgh, said Scots should need little encouragement to champion their parliament. 'It came in with unreasonably high expectations, so there was bound to be a bit of 'the party's over' feeling. There was a whining spirit that came in too soon.

'But in spite of all that, they dug in and they are beginning to create a kind of authentic Scottish political culture which excites me. Not just in the way they are distanced from Westminister, but a kind of social, cultural, ethical climate - significant attempts to create a liberal multicultural ethos that show brave and imaginative leadership.

'There is something of a Scottish neo-enlightenment going on: there is a lot of good Scottish poetry, film making, novels. And while the parliament is not the cause of that, politics is an important part of it.'

Prof Curtice said all the difficulties of the past year should not cloud the simple truth behind the parliament's creation: 'There is no doubt about whether Scots should have devolution. We may argue about the form of it but not about the fact of it.'

webTitle: Hague links May Day riots to mayoral race

fields.headline: Hague links May Day riots to mayoral race
fields.trailText: As William Hague accused Tony Blair of weakness over law and order at prime minister's questions yesterday, it was clear that party leaders were concentrating on tomorrow's elections across the country.
fields.body:
As William Hague accused Tony Blair of weakness over law and order at prime minister's questions yesterday, it was clear that party leaders were concentrating on tomorrow's elections across the country.

The Conservative leader accused the prime minister of displaying "wretched weakness" over the anti-capitalist riots in central London at the weekend. The protesters damaged shops and sprayed graffiti on landmarks including a statue of Winston Churchill and the Cenotaph.

Mr Hague said the demonstrators had "dishonoured our war dead." Condemning what he called the government's failure to prevent the "appalling, disgraceful" scenes, he challenged Mr Blair to back a call by Steve Norris, the Conservative candidate for London mayor, to ban May Day demonstrations next year.

Mr Blair rejected Mr Hague's accusations, and dismissed Mr Norris's "cod" election address. He accused the Conservative leader of "exploiting" the riots, and insisted the initial low-key policing of the protests had been correct.

Mr Hague, again tying the issue of law and order to the London elections, accused the Labour government of "weakening the fight against crime", and said "London needs a mayor who backs the police, not the rioters," in a reference to Ken Livingstone, the independent mayoral candidate accused by his rivals of supporting the demonstrators.

Mr Blair said that Labour had in fact introduced measures to cut crime, including a "three strikes and you're out" policy for burglars. He accused Mr Hague of leaping on any passing bandwagon" and added: "Your capacity to exploit any situation is absolutely unlimited."

Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, also criticised Mr Hague. Referring to an incident in Birmingham this week where a black man was set on fire in racist attack, he accused the Tory leader of "gutter politics" for his recent comments on asylum seekers, and said politicians "should not play or pander to racism".

While Labour and the Conservatives are focusing on the London elections, the Liberal Democrats' hopes are pinned on the Romsey byelection, where they hope to overturn a Tory majority of more than 6,000.

Mr Blair followed up the attack on Mr Hague over asylum seekers, saying it was a "deception" to suggest that spending on pensions, health and education could be significantly increased by reducing money spent on asylum seekers, which in any case he said only amounted to less than 0.2% of all expenditure.

The debate turned directly to the London polls again when the prime minister was asked to say what he would do with his second vote in tomorrow's proportional election for mayor, after he had given his first to the Labour candidate Frank Dobson. Mr Blair replied only: "No", and sat down.

fields.headline: Cook's new sanctions on Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst: British arms sales halted as Mugabe threatens to take half white farmers' land
fields.trailText: Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, today announced a series of sanctions against Zimbabwe as President Robert Mugabe launched his party's election campaign with a promise to show white farmers "ways to leave" the country
fields.body:
Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, today announced a series of sanctions against Zimbabwe as President Robert Mugabe launched his party's election campaign with a promise to show white farmers "ways to leave" the country

From Wednesday the government will refuse all export licence applications for arms and military equipment to Zimbabwe, Mr Cook told the House of Commons. He said the embargo would cover spare parts for previously exported equipment, including Hawk fighter jets. It would also prohibit the sale of 450 Land Rovers ordered by the Zimbabwean police. "We are urgently reviewing all export licences to Zimbabwe," he told MPs.

Mr Cook said that Britain will not fund land reform in Zimbabwe unless it was conducted legally and that farmers were given fair compensation for any redistributed land. He also accused Mr Mugabe of creating a "condition of crisis" to secure his party's re-election.

In Harare, Mr Mugabe brushed aside criticism and said he would never order war veterans to end their occupation of white farms. As his launched his Zanu-PF party's election manifesto Mr Mugabe said he was the champion of democracy and justice in Zimbabwe. "What we are saying is we need half of the 12 million hectares (30 million acres) in white farmers' hands," he said. Mr Mugabe, 76 and in power for 20 years, challenged the farmers to take up a British offer of sanctuary and leave Zimbabwe. Around 20,000 of 70,000 white Zimbabweans are eligible for British citizenship.

"There are 20,000 opportunities Britain has provided for their citizens. They are free to leave and we may assist them by showing various ways to leave the territory," he said.

His address caused an immediate three-cent fall in the value of the rand in neighbouring South Africa, where fears of a spill over of unrest from Zimbabwe have pushed the currency to record lows.

At least 18 people have died in 10 weeks of land invasions and political violence in Zimbabwe related to the coming elections. The opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) poses the biggest threat to Zanu-PF's 20-year-old rule and has built its campaign on Mr Mugabe's handling of the economy.

The latest killing occurred on Monday night when an MDC supporter was beaten to death by suspected Zanu-PF followers. Police today also confirmed that three MDC members were killed in late March, although their deaths were not been made public until now.

Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, backed Britain's policy towards Zimbabwe during an hour-long meeting with the Prime Minister, Tony Blair in London today. Mr Mandela is believed to fear that land-related violence in Zimbabwe could spill over to South Africa. Both Mr Blair and Mr Mandela said they believe that the best way to resolve Zimbabwe's crisis is a campaign of diplomatic pressure led by the current South African president, Thabo Mbeki.

Mr Mugabe, 76 and in power for 20 years, challenged the farmers to take up a British offer of sanctuary and leave Zimbabwe. Around 20,000 of 70,000 white Zimbabweans are eligible for British citizenship. "There are 20,000 opportunities Britain has provided for their citizens. They are free to leave and we may assist them by showing various ways to leave the territory," he said. His address caused an immediate three-cent fall in the value of the rand in neighbouring South Africa, where fears of a spill over of unrest from Zimbabwe have pushed the currency to record lows. At least 18 people have died in 10 weeks of land invasions and political violence in Zimbabwe related to the coming elections. The opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) poses the biggest threat to Zanu-PF's 20-year-old rule and has built its campaign on Mr Mugabe's handling of the economy. The latest killing occurred on Monday night when an MDC supporter was beaten to death by suspected Zanu-PF followers. Police today also confirmed that three MDC members were killed in late March, although their deaths were not been made public until now. Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, backed Britain's policy towards Zimbabwe during an hour-long meeting with the Prime Minister, Tony Blair in London today. Mr Mandela is believed to fear that land-related violence in Zimbabwe could spill over to South Africa. Both Mr Blair and Mr Mandela said they believe that the best way to resolve Zimbabwe's crisis is a campaign of diplomatic pressure led by the current South African president, Thabo Mbeki.

fields.headline: Witch-hunt without justification
fields.standfirst: Journalists and academics have united to condemn the security services' pursuit of the former MI5 officer David Shayler, writes Paul Foot.
fields.trailText: Journalists and academics have united to condemn the security services' pursuit of the former MI5 officer David Shayler, writes Paul Foot.
fields.body:
It's not often I find myself on the same side as the editor of the Sun, but he and I, together with more than 100 journalists and academics, signed today's advertisement in the Times about the Shayler affair. The advertisement calls on the attorney general, Lord Williams, to stop legal proceedings against journalists on the Guardian and the Observer.

These journalists, including the editors of both papers, have been ordered by a high court judge to hand over any unpublished tapes, letters or emails they may have received from David Shayler, the former MI5 agent now on the run in Paris. The journalists and their papers have applied for a judicial review to annul the judge's order. If they lose, and then refuse to hand over the documents, they will be liable to prosecution under the Official Secrets Act, and to heavy fines or imprisonment.

The letter I signed recognised the "need to protect national security" but went on: "governments in this country have for too long protected the security forces with excessive and punitive secrecy".

One fatuous example was the legal ban on Spycatcher, an autobiography of a crazed rightwing MI5 agent who boasted how he plotted, bugged and burgled his way across London in a political campaign to discredit the elected government.

But perhaps the best contemporary example is the Shayler story itself. David Shayler left MI5 because he was shocked at the incompetence and reaction he found there. He has tried his best, without much success, to convey this shock and horror to the British public. These attempts landed him in a French jail and an application to the French authorities to extradite him to Britain so he could face an official secrets trial here.

The application was contemptuously refused by a French court, and Shayler was freed. Ever since, he has done his best to expose the more ludicrous operations of MI5, including their brilliant idea to assassinate President Gadafy of Libya.

The security services have kept up their witch-hunt, and are now attempting to intimidate any media which support their prey. All this would be quite laughable, were it not for the judicial attack on two newspapers who refuse to cow-tow to the security services' vendetta against a former colleague with the nerve to tell the truth about them. There is no justification whatever, save petty revenge, for this vendetta, and it is high time the government stopped supporting it.

webTitle: Stun, Shove and Hop, Skip and Jump

fields.headline: Stun, Shove and Hop, Skip and Jump
fields.trailText: THAT KLINSMANN FEELING
fields.body:
THAT KLINSMANN FEELING

Tottenham sign world-class foreigner. Bet you never thought you'd read that again. The Fiver certainly didn't, but our mild scoffing was roughly stuffed down our agog throats today when Dynamo Kiev striker Sergei Rebrov revealed his move to Tottenham "should be signed and sealed" within the next two weeks.

"They managed to find a common language with me," said Rebrov today in Esperanto. "It's just a matter of whether the two clubs can agree a fee." The price is expected to be around £11m, which would eclipse the in-no-way-wasted £6m Spurs paid to a highly-amused Newcastle for Les Ferdinand. "I am looking forward to playing in England. I like it better than Italian football, although I can't explain why," enthused Rebrov, making you wonder - not for the first time - about his judgement.

Spurs fans will be delighted enough with this signing, but the fact that their club beat Arsenal in the chase for the 26-year-old should put a north-London cherry on the Ukrainian cake. Arsene Wenger's transfer policy wouldn't stretch to Rebrov's £25,000-per-week contract, and, like another high-profile striker the week before, Highbury saw a coveted player disappear down a less parsimonious road. If Rebrov falls over tomorrow with knee knack, we'll know who's been paying the hitman.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A FIVER FOR EUROPE

Sign up now for the Euro, the Fiver's special Euro 2000 sibling. Brought to you in association with Breathe, the Euro will keep you up to date with everything that goes on in the lowlands this summer. To subscribe, send a mail to euro2000-request@footballunlimited.co.uk with 'subscribe' in the subject line.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WHEN PUSH COMES TO SHOVE

Pundits are lost for words after last night's encounter between Arsenal and West Ham failed to become the naughtiest match in history. Many commentators had expected Patrick Vieira to take Neil Ruddock out with a machine gun, while others thought John Moncur would achieve the unique feat of snapping six ligaments with one challenge. These hopes were false however, and disconsolate punters were left to make do with 10 bookings, one red card, a disputed winner and a shove on the ref.

Not that 'Appy 'Arry Redknapp was complaining. Oh, hang on a second, he was. "My players felt they have been cheated, had been robbed of a result they deserved and I felt the same," said the cheeky chirpy cockney in various tenses today, explaining away Marc-Vivien Foe's manhandling of referee Paul Durkin in injury-time. "There was no fighting in the tunnel, or anything like that," 'Arry went on as if scrapping under a roof was somehow worse.

The Hammers must wait until the FA read Durkin's match report to find out whether they will become the fifth Premiership club charged with failing to control their players this season. But 'Arry knows his boys were in the right. "We went to Highbury with a real odds-and-sods team and we deserved to come away with something", he said today. "Three of my players were in tears in the dressing room because they were so disappointed. They had a right go." And therein, the Fiver would like to venture, lies the problem.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I don't trust you. You did something to us in Marseille. You had a debt the day of the match at the Velodrome Stadium. You were paid off by Marseille" - The words of Monaco manager Claude Puel, according to his keeper Fabian Barthez. Barthez claims Puel wrongly accused him of taking bribes after he played a stinker in Monaco's 4-2 league defeat by OM. Puel denies the allegations. Now that's psychological warfare.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE WEDNESDAY FLUTTER

Imagine Ryan Giggs roller-coasting down the wing, Don Hutchinson and Roy Keane bossing the midfield... and Fulham's Maik Taylor in goal. Are you drooling yet? Well England boss Kelvin Koogan certainly was when TaLk SpoRT asked him to pick a player he would have in his England side from each of the home countries.

Now for most of us the answer would be blindingly obvious: "We'll have Ryan Giggs thank-you-very-much and the rest of you can piddle off". But not Kelv. Oh no. Just look how deftly he's able to hop, skip and jump over piddling matters like international law, all-known footballing logic and sheer common-sense.

HOP! Kelvin shows an ingenious disregard for the 1922 partition of Ireland by picking Roy Keane in his four nations team.

SKIP!! The England boss says that the player he most wants to pick for Euro 2000 is not Beckham or Owen but Don Hutchinson. "It's very difficult to pick him up," Koogan reveals. "He can do the little things and he works at pace too," he adds, perhaps telling us more than we need to know.

JUMP!!! "I would take the keeper from Fulham, Maik Taylor, because he's the best taker of a cross I've ever seen in my life," explains Koogan, failing to make clear whether Taylor's an astute crucifix-stealing thief, a rival to Beckham down the right-flank or simply a much better player than a Southampton reject is ever entitled to be.

At the moment England are 10-1 for Euro 2000. But with Kelv in this kind of form those odds are certain to drop. Get your bets on now.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Spurs want Mark Viduka to partner Sergei Rebrov at White Hart Lane next season. The Scottish player of the year would cost £8.5m, but his agent claims that the Australian international will not be leaving Celtic.

Bobby Robson is likely to make a £5m bid for Wimbledon's Jason Euell this summer. He watched the former England Under-21 star in the Dons' defeat against Bradford last weekend.

The most famous Iranian footballer in the world could be on his way to Leeds. Ali Daei, who plays for Hertha Berlin, is likely to leave the club this summer and told the press: "I know Leeds are interested in me and I see my future as being in England."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Liverpool will not be leaving Anfield in the foreseeable future. Chief executive Rick Parry says the club will extend the capacity of the current stadium to between 60,000 and 70,000 instead.

Aage Hareide has ruled himself out of the running to become the new manager of Wimbledon. Hareide, currently in charge at Danish side Brondby, said: "I have a contract with Brondby that runs until 2002 - and there will be no breaking that contract."

Craig Burley and Derby assistant manager Billy McEwan have been charged with disrepute by the FA for comments made to match officials after the Rams' match with West Ham last month.

Blackpool boss Steve McMahon is interested in taking over as coach of Australian side South Melbourne. The Age newspaper, based in Melbourne, says agents acting on behalf of the former England midfielder have contacted the club expressing a "serious" interest in the vacant post.

Tony Vidmar has agreed a one-year extension to his current contract which will tie him to Rangers until 2002.

Hearts have secured the longest-running sponsorship deal in Scottish football by extending their contract with Strongbow for a ninth successive year.

Ken Friar has stepped down as Arsenal's managing director, to take charge of the club's new stadium plans. Keith Edelman will be his replacement.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: On Side (11.10pm)

Dion Dublin risks his neck by walking down that dodgy-looking ramp.

ITV: The Big Match (7.30pm)

Des Lynam surveys the wreckage of his career while Bayern Munich v Real Madrid play in the background.

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm, 9.30pm, 12.15am)

The latest in futter.

***'** ** *** ******! (10.15pm, 4.15am)

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm)

Duncan McKenzie tries to reminisce about the seventies without resorting to that anecdote about him jumping over a mini. He fails.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

Chat.

webTitle: Cook, the truth, his spies and our freedom

fields.headline: Cook, the truth, his spies and our freedom
fields.standfirst: Without accountability, our security services are liable to further mislead ministers and undermine our democratic rights, says Judith Vidal-Hall, editor of Index on Censorship
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 4.45pm: Without accountability, our security services are liable to further mislead ministers and undermine our democratic rights, says Judith Vidal-Hall, editor of Index on Censorship
fields.body:
The British government's continued persecution of Martin Bright and the editors of the Guardian and Observer is clearly an affront to any notion of freedom of the press. Freedom of expression is a right guaranteed under European and international law. Its limitations deal with incitement to violence, and more relevantly in this case, the security of the state.

David Shayler's revelations, and their subsequent publication in the British press, have left Britain in no danger of sinking beneath the waves.

MI5's lies however have certainly endangered the state, or at least one state employee, a Mr Robin Cook, foreign secretary. His claims to parliament that there was no truth in Shayler's 'Gadafy assassination' tale have been subsequently discredited.

It can only be assumed that Mr Cook was misled by intelligence briefings. And there, the fable of secret service accountability falls down.

A nation can have secrets and still maintain itself a democracy. However, place those secrets under the guard of an unaccountable intelligence agency and, by definition, a democratic shell hides a rotten core. The press exists to police government: to probe for lapses, deliberate or not, in its probity, its consistency.

This government and others before it have claimed that the security services are effectively controlled, that somewhere in the corridors of Westminster and Whitehall legitimate democratic management takes place. Time and time again, disaffected employees and, occasionally, tenacious journalists have revealed this cosy, very British, accountability to be at best superficial, at worst wholly and deliberately inadequate.

Once again, rather than regarding press revelations as a wake-up call, this government has chosen to shoot the messenger.

Well, the government is wrong: wrong in principle, wrong in law. The world has embraced freedom of expression and freedom of the press not because such rights make life easy for government, but because it is only through transparency and accountability that government ever be legitimate.

It's obvious why governments oppose transparency, and why this particular government so opposes freedom of information - it will make life harder for them. It may even mean that they can't launch murderous operations abroad with impunity. Well, tough. Get used to it.

The government can try to gag the British press, it may even succeed. It might even use some of Jack Straw's anti-squeegee merchant legislation to prevent samizdat roadside distribution, as happened during the glorious pig's ear that was Spycatcher.

But no government can gag the web. Click on the link below and you'll discover more than you ever wanted to about the internal operations of the security services. More than Robin Cook, at least.

Index on Censorship

fields.headline: Information deficit
fields.standfirst: Bureaucratic cock-ups and confusion within social services can put youngsters into unnecessarily risky situations, reports Jan Parker
fields.trailText: Bureaucratic cock-ups and confusion within social services can put youngsters into unnecessarily risky situations, reports Jan Parker
fields.body:
When Helen was placed in care earlier this year, the adolescent residential unit that received her was warned of her troublesome behaviour. "The primary concerns were about the way she behaved, running away from school and home," says Marie, manager of the unit. "No child protection issues were brought to our attention."

She soon began to suspect what lay at the root of Helen's problems. "Helen began placing herself in dangerous situations with men, in how she would relate to them," she explains. "Only after she was discharged from the unit did information arrive to say that her three uncles had been convicted of sex ually abusing children and baby-sat her regularly."

Social workers must sometimes move at such speed that gathering detailed information about a child's history is impossible. But not in this case, says Marie. "The information was well known, but was simply not passed on. We had to deal with behaviour we didn't fully understand and wasted valuable time that could have been spent better supporting the girl. It should be possible to get known information to us within days, at most, but sometimes it takes weeks."

It's a story with which Helen Lewis, of the National Children's Bureau, is all too familiar. In a three-year research project into ways of improving the health of "looked after" children and young people, she spoke to a foster carer who received a child on Friday evening, took her on fun-fair rides with her family on Saturday and on Monday morning was told the girl suffered seriously from epilepsy. Other carers were not told of children's serious food allergies, behavioural or mental health problems, known medical conditions and required medication.

Beyond the obvious health risks, failure to recognise or meet even basic health needs can compound a vulnerable child's sense of their own lack of worth. Worse, it can mean vital missed opportunities to spot signs of abuse or other serious problems.

"Yet in social services, health has had a very low priority," says Lewis. "Also, many people are still working with an illness model, rather than a holistic approach which looks beyond physical health and includes the mental and emotional health of the child."

While the priority placed on health needs varies hugely between areas, the NCB study and the testimony of frontline workers highlight common areas of concern, with confusion over responsibility and even policy between agencies and departments, children denied basic eye and dental checks, missing immunisations and annual medicals, given insufficient health information, particularly on sexual health, and even refused registration with some GPs. The number of serious conditions misdiagnosed or overlooked until adoption medicals must raise questions not only of why children are slipping through the net, but whether in some areas the net exists at all.

A recent Oxfordshire study showed that two-thirds of teenagers in care had a psychiatric disorder, rising to a rate of 19 in every 20 for children in residential homes.

Many of the children entering care have been abused or neglected, yet access to support and therapy through the child and adolescent mental health service is limited to only those in very greatest need - and even then it can mean a six-month wait for assessment and a further six-month wait before treatment even begins.

Another alarming twist in an overstretched and under-resourced process leaves long-term mental health treatment often denied to children until they are in stable placements - the very thing their condition makes extremely hard to find. "We have to start thinking about how we address the current distress of the child," says Dinah Morely, of the children's mental health charity, Young Minds. "Somehow, services have to be more fleet of foot."

The government's consultation document, Promoting Health For Looked After Children, gives hope that at least some of these issues will be addressed. Its key recommendations include ensuring that "looked after" children are registered with GPs, improved liaison between health authorities and social services, speedier transfer of information to care placements and a designated nurse and doctor responsible for young people in care in every area.

 Jan Parker is co-author of Raising Happy Children (Hodder & Stoughton, £9.99). Some names in this article have been changed to protect children's identities. fields.bodyText: When Helen was placed in care earlier this year, the adolescent residential unit that received her was warned of her troublesome behaviour. "The primary concerns were about the way she behaved, running away from school and home," says Marie, manager of the unit. "No child protection issues were brought to our attention." She soon began to suspect what lay at the root of Helen's problems. "Helen began placing herself in dangerous situations with men, in how she would relate to them," she explains. "Only after she was discharged from the unit did information arrive to say that her three uncles had been convicted of sex ually abusing children and baby-sat her regularly." Social workers must sometimes move at such speed that gathering detailed information about a child's history is impossible. But not in this case, says Marie. "The information was well known, but was simply not passed on. We had to deal with behaviour we didn't fully understand and wasted valuable time that could have been spent better supporting the girl. It should be possible to get known information to us within days, at most, but sometimes it takes weeks." It's a story with which Helen Lewis, of the National Children's Bureau, is all too familiar. In a three-year research project into ways of improving the health of "looked after" children and young people, she spoke to a foster carer who received a child on Friday evening, took her on fun-fair rides with her family on Saturday and on Monday morning was told the girl suffered seriously from epilepsy. Other carers were not told of children's serious food allergies, behavioural or mental health problems, known medical conditions and required medication. Beyond the obvious health risks, failure to recognise or meet even basic health needs can compound a vulnerable child's sense of their own lack of worth. Worse, it can mean vital missed opportunities to spot signs of abuse or other serious problems. "Yet in social services, health has had a very low priority," says Lewis. "Also, many people are still working with an illness model, rather than a holistic approach which looks beyond physical health and includes the mental and emotional health of the child." While the priority placed on health needs varies hugely between areas, the NCB study and the testimony of frontline workers highlight common areas of concern, with confusion over responsibility and even policy between agencies and departments, children denied basic eye and dental checks, missing immunisations and annual medicals, given insufficient health information, particularly on sexual health, and even refused registration with some GPs. The number of serious conditions misdiagnosed or overlooked until adoption medicals must raise questions not only of why children are slipping through the net, but whether in some areas the net exists at all. A recent Oxfordshire study showed that two-thirds of teenagers in care had a psychiatric disorder, rising to a rate of 19 in every 20 for children in residential homes. Many of the children entering care have been abused or neglected, yet access to support and therapy through the child and adolescent mental health service is limited to only those in very greatest need - and even then it can mean a six-month wait for assessment and a further six-month wait before treatment even begins. Another alarming twist in an overstretched and under-resourced process leaves long-term mental health treatment often denied to children until they are in stable placements - the very thing their condition makes extremely hard to find. "We have to start thinking about how we address the current distress of the child," says Dinah Morely, of the children's mental health charity, Young Minds. "Somehow, services have to be more fleet of foot." The government's consultation document, Promoting Health For Looked After Children, gives hope that at least some of these issues will be addressed. webTitle: 'Racists think it's open season for attacks'

fields.headline: 'Racists think it's open season for attacks'
fields.standfirst:
Campaigners say 'hysteria' over refugees fuelling rise in race crime in second city

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A man who had his face covered in petrol and set alight in a racially-motivated attack was released from hospital in Birmingham yesterday amid warnings that such violence was on the increase.
fields.body:
A man who had his face covered in petrol and set alight in a racially-motivated attack was released from hospital in Birmingham yesterday amid warnings that such violence was on the increase.

The 24-year-old, who is black, was left with burns to his face and right arm after he was attacked by three men as he walked home in the Northfield area of the city. The man, who has yet to be named, had just dropped off his girlfriend at the city's Royal Orthopaedic hospital. Witnesses told police they were woken by the screams and that one of the attackers had a skinhead haircut.

Yesterday Maxi Hayles, of the Birmingham Racial Attacks Monitoring Unit (Bramu), blamed the Conservative party's demonising of refugees and minorities in the run-up to this week's local elections for the attack.

He said: "When you have William Hague trumping up emotive language like 'flooding' and 'bogus' it doesn't help. People develop these nationalistic feelings and they think its open season, that they have been given the green light. But things are not looking good for us on this side."

Mr Hayles was joined by Tony Robson of Searchlight, the anti-fascist magazine, who said: "There have been more attacks. The hysteria over asylum seekers and refugees has made things worse."

Abuse

Bramu has recorded a 100% increase in the number of reported race-related crimes since last August. It believes the numbers are related to the publication of the Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence. Since August the Bramu caseload has increased from 120 to 240: they believe this is as a result of negative racist feeling stirred up by those opposed to Macpherson.

"We have had a vast increase in racial harassment," said Mr Hayles. "There's a great incidence of violence but most of the cases are to do with racial abuse."

West Midlands police last night urged caution when interpreting figures. Chief Inspector Paul Diehl said the 50% increase in the reporting of racially-motivated crime was as a result of increased confidence in the police since the Macpherson report's publication.

"These are all serious incidents but the majority are at the lower end of the scale in terms of racial abuse," he said. "What we have seen is an increase in the number of people who feel confident in reporting to us."

Over the past year there had been 13 race-related violent incidents. One of them had been the attack last March on the boyfriend of the British Olympic gold medal hope Ashia Hansen, who was stabbed by a racist gang. Chris Cotter, 28, who is white, was knifed in the back and face by a gang of up to five men outside the black triple jumper's home. One of the attackers said: "We warned you not to mix with niggers."

Ms Hansen, 28, had received a hate letter related to the attack. Written in letters torn from a magazine, it said: "You were lucky last night. We won't make the same mistake again." In the days running up to the attack Mr Cotter had received racially abusive calls on his mobile phone.

Organisations such as Searchlight and the Anti-Nazi League have observed a marked increase in rightwing activity in the West Midlands and neighbouring areas.

On Easter Sunday 40 members of the National Front marched through Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, not far from Birmingham. They had earlier been banned from marching through Worcester.

Campaigners believe some of the attacks could be linked to the presence of such movements. Sunday's attack took place not far from the King's Norton ward being contested by the area's British National Party candidate, Jeff Astbury.

Posters

At first, King's Norton seems an unlikely place for such a candidate. In most of the streets the bungalows are neat, the lawns manicured and all is in blossom. But the lamp-posts are tied with posters saying: "Vote British National Party: British freedom, British identity."

Alongside, Conservative party posters offer a man who boasts: "Born local. Lives Local. Works local." Other truncated posters use the "born local" phrase as their theme.

It was here, a few years ago, that stickers were found on bus stops warning: "Niggers Beware! Combat 18 in the area." And it is not far from here that Marie (not her real name) lives with her two children. Aged nine and seven, they are not allowed to go out because their mother - who is eight and half months pregnant - is too scared to let them.

"I have had my tyres slashed. I have had paint on my car. My little girl had her mouth cut open from a little boy outside. She had her bike tyres cut by a little boy with a knife," she said. "I just keep them inside now. They have been called racial names - just common names like nigger. I have had rubbish through my letterbox and dog mess around my door. It's depressing really."

Sometimes Marie gets in the car and takes her kids for a "go on the swings". Yesterday, in the King's Norton park, one nine-year-old girl from a mixed-race family was blithely swinging through the air. On a bench her babysitter, who was white, said the girl "gets the usual abuse".

"She doesn't seem to get it as bad because she's dark and doesn't look as mixed race as the other mixed-race kids," she said. "They call her blackie and stuff like that."

Catalogue of Hate

May 1999 A 53-year-old man is beaten up in a Birmingham park by a young man who asked him: "Are you a Jew?"

June 1999 Two Birmingham youths who took part in a racist attack on an Asian shopkeeper and his family are sentenced to nine months in custody

September 1999 A man is jailed for 12 months after hurling racial abuse during an attack on an Asian shopkeeper in Brownsover, Warwickshire

October 1999 A Sutton Coldfield man admits a racist attack on an Asian brother and sister as they walked through the town centre. He called police racist names when arrested

December 1999 A young mother and her 10-year-old daughter are forced to flee their Birmingham council home after racists terrorised them for weeks

January 2000 Children flee a burning mosque in Birmingham after arsonists set the rear of the building alight

March 2000 Chris Cotter, boyfriend of British Olympic hope Ashia Hansen, is knifed in the back and face by a racist gang outside the black triple jumper's home

webTitle: US courts free internet firms from libel laws

fields.headline: US courts free internet firms from libel laws
fields.trailText: Internet service providers in the US were yesterday celebrating a supreme court ruling that gave them full protection against any libellous or abusive message sent over the web.
fields.body:
Internet service providers in the US were yesterday celebrating a supreme court ruling that gave them full protection against any libellous or abusive message sent over the web.

Advocates for free speech backed the US ruling, which puts internet service providers (ISPs) on the same footing as telephone companies as message carriers.

Stewart Baker, a partner at Steptoe & Johnson, a Washington law firm, said US companies that operate in Britain, such as America Online, could now apply to domestic courts if they were held liable under British laws. "This is not going to disappear as a legal issue," he said.

British law is still unclear on the issue. Two months ago Demon Internet paid Laurence Godfrey, a physicist and university lecturer, £15,000 plus legal fees of around £250,000 because he was the subject of allegedly libellous bulletin-board postings.

Although an out-of-court settlement, the Demon case was widely interpreted as a warning to British ISPs and web publishers. Within days of the settlement, British ISPs closed two websites - a gay site called Outcast and an anti-censorship site that claimed that Outcast's closure had been "Godfrey's first victim".

Mr Baker said the British position could harm free speech on the internet as it gives an economic incentive for companies to withdraw messages as soon as a complaint is made, whether or not they are libellous.

"If they leave the message up they will either pay damages or lawyers," said Mr Baker. "If they take it down, nothing happens."

In the US on Monday, the supreme court upheld a previous ruling against a former boy scout who sought damages from the ISP Prodigy.

Alexander Lunney sued Prodigy after an impostor used his name to send threatening and profane messages to some of his neighbours in Westchester county. At the time, in 1994, Mr Lunney was 15 years old. One of the emails, sent to a local boy scout troop leader, was headlined: "HOW I'M GOING TO KILL YOU."

Following complaints from the recipients, Prodigy told Mr Lunney it was terminating his account "due to the transmission of obscene, abusive, threatening and sexually explicit material". But Mr Lunney was not even a Prodigy member.

A ruling by the New York court of appeals supported Prodigy's defence that it was not liable for messages sent over its system. "The public would not be well served by compelling an [ISP] to examine and screen millions of e-mail communications, on pain of liability for defamation," it said."We are unwilling to deny Prodigy the common law qualified privilege afforded to telephone and telegraph companies."

A disappointed Robert Lunney, the father of the plaintiff, criticised "the imperfect world" of the US legal system. "You and I can be the victim of something like this tomorrow _ The courts have given the internet providers full immunity," he said.

A Demon spokesperson, defending the company before its settlement in the Godfrey case, said: "If someone insulted you in a pub, would you sue the pub owner for housing the defamatory remark?"

fields.headline: Spider in the web
fields.standfirst:
As far as the internet goes, America is the land of the free. But Britain certainly isn't
Free speech on the net: special report
fields.trailText: As far as the internet goes, America is the land of the free. But Britain certainly isn't
fields.body:
The US Supreme Court underlined the worrying differences regarding freedom of expression on either side of the Atlantic by ruling yesterday that internet service providers are not responsible for libellous remarks made in emails or on internet bulletin boards.

This move is in direct contrast to a British ruling last month, which put UK internet companies on the same footing as newspaper publishers, making them liable for defamatory comments made on their systems. The UK position has the potential to be seriously damaging. It will clamp down further on free speech as UK internet service providers seek to limit their liabilities.

But the story of internet control does not end there. When you send an email to a friend, how many people do you expect to read it? For most, the notion of our private web-based conversations being tapped is more alien than the belief that our telephone calls are being recorded or our bank accounts monitored.

Yet many countries around the world, including the UK, are stepping up their surveillance of the internet and our use of it. Why? The answer given by the Home Office for building a £25m email surveillance centre at MI5 is that it is worried about the explosion in the use of the internet by the world's assorted villains and fraudsters.

By insisting that service providers such as America Online and Freeserve install tracking software, however, the government will be able to read everything that passes over the internet. Its powers include a general warrant to study emails and websites visited.

In some ways, surveillance should hardly surprise us. From Watergate to Squidgygate and beyond, we have become accustomed to the idea of phone tapping, even if we would never expect it to happen to us. The new problem with the internet is its scope - allowing the authorities to chart everything we do online and everywhere we go .

The Foundation for Information Policy Research believes the government's new powers will lead to a "culture of suspicion by association".

Meanwhile, a study of 186 countries published by Freedom House, a US organisation, says more and more governments are either controlling access to the web or increasing surveillance.

The worst abuses outlined in Censor Dot Gov were found, not surprisingly, in the countries that are regularly censured for human rights violations. So-called "cyber dissidents" have been imprisoned in China after circumventing the national internet service provider, run by the government.

They are known to have tracked down people who have sent emails or other messages regarding the Falun Gong, a semi-religious movement based on exercise and meditation. The official internet channel also filters out any unwelcome news from abroad.

In Burma, the government's "cyberspace warfare centre" hacks into computers that receive or send "forbidden messages". Owners of a computer face a 15-year jail sentence if they fail to report possession.

In Russia, the appointment of Vladimir Putin as acting president increased concerns over surveillance last year. One online service provider was temporarily stopped while the successor to the KGB, the security service, began forcing internet service providers to install surveillance equipment.

Insisting that individuals use a state-run internet service provider to log on, are 20 countries. Penalties for not doing so - by using call phones or faxes to circumvent the government channel for example - include imprisonment and harassment.

The 20 are China, Burma, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Cuba, Iran, Iraq, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Libya, North Korea, Saudi Arabia, Sierra Leone, Sudan, Syria, Tajikistan, Tunisia, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan and Vietnam.

The report found a total of 45 countries restrict internet access in some form or other. This includes a recent law passed in Australia designed to prevent access to websites peddling pornography.

As a foreword to the report says: "The explosion of news and information on the world wide web is tempting governments - developed and developing, politically free and not free - to consider restricting content on the internet."

Australian lawmakers will be as horrified as the Home Office to be mentioned in the same context as Chinese brutality. But there is a direct correlation.

Everyone believes that pornography can be harmful and that criminals must be caught. But what if everyone, or at least the state, felt the same way about yogic flyers? Or people wearing orange? The report quotes a Saudi spokesman saying that access to the internet in Saudi Arabia would be delayed until technology was available "to bar access to information contrary to Islamic values and dangerous to our society".

Leonard Sussman, co-ordinator of the annual press freedom survey, points out that many of the restrictions used by governments around the world used "the pretext of protecting the public from subversive ideas or violation of national security - code words used by censors since the 16th century".

webTitle: Internet regulation 'a threat to civil liberties'

fields.headline: Internet regulation 'a threat to civil liberties'
fields.trailText: A debate on internet regulation, sponsored by Guardian Unlimited, passed a motion that any attempt by the government to police the internet is unworkable and a severe threat to civil liberties.
fields.body:
A debate on internet regulation, sponsored by Guardian Unlimited, passed a motion that any attempt by the government to police the internet is unworkable and a severe threat to civil liberties.

The Beyond Control debate at Oxford University last Friday heard that the internet should not be subject to greater regulatory control than traditional media outlets. But the large majority of the audience who supported the motion when asked to vote before the debate, was reduced after the arguments were heard.

Supporting the motion, professor Nadine Strossen, president of the American Civil Liberties Union (Aclu), said she did not want an end to all regulation, but resisted regulation unique to the internet.

Against the motion, David Kerr, chief executive of the Internet Watch Foundation (IWF), charged with regulating internet service providers, made a case for "sensitive regulation".

Ms Strossen reported that in the United States, the Aclu has successfully challenged eight laws infringing cyberspace on the grounds that "cyber speech should enjoy the same high level of freedom as the print media.

"We are simply demanding the government honour the same speech protective standards that the US supreme court has upheld in the traditional print media,"

Governments must "never regulate speech just based on some speculative fear that it might, sometime in the future, have some anti-social impacts," she said. ''Censorship, like charity, should begin at home, but unlike charity it should end there".

Supporting Ms Strossen, Yaman Akdeniz, director of the British free speech pressure group Cyber Rights & Cyber Liberties, explained how British lawyers had recently used the threat of prosecution under the 1996 Defamation Act and the UK's stringent libel laws to remove websites from servers.

Service providers had been scared into action by such threats after Demon Internet paid a substantial payment to Laurence Godfrey, an academic who claimed he was defamed by two anonymous internet postings. Demon paid out more than £230,000 in damages and fees to end the court action earlier this year.

Mr Akdeniz described the government's new regulation of investigatory powers bill, which could imprison people for two years if they fail to hand over "keys" to encrypted internet texts, as "one of the most outrageous pieces of legislation introduced in this country."

But Mr Kerr, whose IWF is charged with monitoring and, where necessary, recommending the removal of pornography from the internet, argued that "censorship is not synonymous with policing on the net."

He put forward a persuasive case that "we all lose from a lack of policing on the net." He said: "The greater threat to civil liberties is if governments do not find workable ways of policing the internet by reasonable and cooperative means and they fall back on the more traditional and oppressive authoritarian styles of regulation."

He highlighted the role of the IWF in providing "workable co-regulation" between government and industry different from traditional policing. The IWF assess the legality of pornographic internet content reported to it by the public, notifying the internet service provider concerned and the police about any potential legal breaches. Last year, it informed ISPs about more than 11,000 potentially illegal pornographic images they were inadvertently publishing on the net.

Joining Mr Kerr to argue against the motion, John Abbott, director general of the National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS), highlighted the difficulties of policing the internet. "The internet is a wonderful tool and a magnificent opportunity," he said. "It brings us all together. But it also brings together people who are better kept apart.

"The internet is a potential facilitator of anarchy," he argued, highlighting the role of criminals in misusing the internet, which "damaged people" and "trampled on the rights" of the vulnerable. Democratic governments exist to protect the rights of its citizens. "Is it right that the government should turn a blind eye to the misuse of the internet?"

The reduced majority in favour of an unregulated internet at the end of the debate reflected some confusion in the debating chamber over the meaning of the motion. Mr Kerr and Mr Abbott argued it implied an opposition to any regulation of the internet, while Ms Strossen maintained it simply opposed any rules for the internet which went beyond those already used to regulate broadcast and print media.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: Relentless crying can push any parent to the limit, says the latest NSPCC poster campaign.So what is the best strategy for dealing with a baby who won't stop screaming?
fields.trailText: The question: Relentless crying can push any parent to the limit, says the latest NSPCC poster campaign.So what is the best strategy for dealing with a baby who won't stop screaming?
fields.body:
Camille San Lazarro Lecturer, paediatric forensic medicine, Newcastle University

First, know it isn't personal: this baby isn't crying because of your parenting. Once you believe that, it's easier to deal with it without hurting him. Check he isn't hungry, wet or uncomfortable; if not, put him down in a safe place and go out of the room. My best tip is to do some vacuuming: this creates what we call a "white noise" - in other words, one that won't disturb your baby - and it also drowns out the sound of his cries. You'll be able to do something positive with your time and that will expend some of the negativity you're feeling. When you turn the vacuum cleaner off you'll feel better, and the chances are that the continuous droning will have lulled him to sleep.
Verdict: Vacuuming

Julie Shemield Mother of two, Cry-sis helpline volunteer

My two children both seemed to cry all the time and it's hell on earth. There is no magic answer, but there are certain things you can experiment with. For example, try tilting the cot so that the baby sleeps with his head higher than his feet; winding the baby as often as possible while you are feeding him; or changing the type of teat you're using if your baby is bottle-fed. But perhaps the best tip I can offer is to believe that it isn't going to last: it feels like it's forever, but it will stop. And you will enjoy being a mother when they're older - I really wasn't happy as the mother of babies, but as they got older life just got better and better.
Verdict: Look to the future

Eileen Hayes Author of Crying, published by Pan at £5.99

Soldiering on alone is a bad idea, because eventually you'll snap - anyone would. Listen to the advice you're given and try possible solutions, but bear in mind that different things work for different babies: try to tune in to yours to find out what kind of baby she is, and what she'd like. It might help you to know that research shows that the peak time for crying is six weeks, and that crying always improves after three months; so even if your baby is still crying a lot, she won't be crying as much after that. Also, studies show some babies are just cryers - it's not that they're "bad" or "difficult". Don't feel a failure because your baby is crying a lot, and don't try to go it alone.
Verdict: Get help early on

Melanie Every spokeswoman, Royal College of Midwives

If you feel you're getting near breaking point, you have to get out of the room: just put the baby down somewhere safe, and walk away for a while. You've got to put some space between yourself and that intense crying. Baby-shaking doesn't usually happen out of the blue - there's almost always a build-up, and the important thing is to recognise when things are getting too much. Don't be ashamed of admitting that and talk to your midwife, health visitor or GP about it. You needn't be worried that they'll try to take the baby away from you: what all these professionals want to do is support you within your family - not break the family up.
Verdict: See a professional

John Cameron counsellor, NSPCC telephone helpline

Call a helpline - we're here, even at 3am. When I get someone on the line in a terrible state with a baby crying in the background, the first thing I get them to do is talk about themselves. Sometimes the reason they're near breaking point is to do with something else going on in their life. Then I move on to the crying and try to suggest strategies relevant to the baby's age and circumstances. If a parent says they've shaken their baby, once I've established that the baby isn't in need of urgent medical treatment, I talk to them about what that can do: you can cause brain damage and even death. I don't believe any parent wants to do that to their child, and I'd try to give them the support they needed not to do it again.
Verdict: Call a helpline

Mark Moorhead Father of Christian, six, Joseph, four, Madeline, 11 months

Both our boys had terrible colic from around three weeks to 12 weeks - they'd cry for two hours every evening. It was horrendous; you'd try everything you could think of, and they just went on and on and on screaming. With Christian, we tended to stay all together in the same room in an attempt to give one another moral support, but with Joseph we tried looking after him in shifts, which worked better. One of us would hold him for 20 minutes or so while the other went upstairs or outside to cool off, then we'd swap over. It felt like it was going to last forever at the time, but one night, as if by magic, it stopped - and Madeline didn't behave in the same way at all.
Verdict: Take it in shifts

webTitle: Crash, bang, wallop - what an ugly picture

fields.headline: Crash, bang, wallop - what an ugly picture
fields.standfirst: The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: I hit a little boy the other day. Fortunately, we're related. I say fortunately because, he being my son, will forgive me - children are so reasonable that way. There does, however, remain the problem of forgiving myself.
fields.body:
I hit a little boy the other day. Fortunately, we're related. I say fortunately because, he being my son, will forgive me - children are so reasonable that way. There does, however, remain the problem of forgiving myself.

This is not really a guilt thing. I'm not in favour of smacking, nor am I devoutly against it. I see it in the same way as I regard prawn cocktail crisps - a bad thing, but such is life. The trick is to regret it properly. That's what Italian mothers do, isn't it? Forever whacking and slapping out of fury and frustration then, minutes later, clutching their bruised bambinos to their bosoms, tears of tenderness falling upon small heads.

Yes, I can cope with my remorse for the four hard thumps I landed on the back of my six-year-old son Billy, upstairs in the guest room of my elderly widowed mother's house. Four thumps that left him howling behind the same set of curtains I howled behind when I was six; four thumps that left me purged of anger yet flooded with shame. All that, I can handle. It's the horror of comparison that is difficult to bear.

By this, of course, I mean the comparison that will be made by Billy and his siblings between my erratic, brittle and occasionally, er, emotionally corporal model of parental discipline and the pious, pussyfooting alternative regime applied at the children's "other home" by their mother Dilys and plonker of a so-called other dad, Chris the Pillock.

Even as my palm flew towards the flinching vertebrae of my own flesh and blood I felt Jed's arrows of disapproval as he looked on: his cowering younger brother, my pathetic resort to brute power. Then, as I sat back on the bed, I contemplated grimly the unfolding scene downstairs; my firstborn, Gloria, fired up with the special sanctimony of early adolescence, informing her stepmother, Angie, that smacking is "inappropriate", or some other bullshit euphemism of the type Dilys deploys for terrible behaviour; Angie firmly explaining that there's an important difference between taking the odd swipe when a red mist descends and dedicated child abuse; and, of course, granny in the kitchen getting into a tizz.

I could be harsh and blame the whole, hellish episode on granny: if she hadn't been driving me completely round the bend, I wouldn't have got so angry with Billy. But granny cannot help it. She's been in a tizz ever since Dilys left. The upbringing granny gave me was utterly orthodox. So how is she meant to cope with the bizarre mutation that is her son's family?

"But Joseph, those poor children," she frets, checking under the drinks coasters for dust. "They don't know where they're going to be from one day to the next. They must be so upset." Straining to stay calm, I tell granny things I sometimes almost believe."At least this way they haven't lost a parent. "

Granny is doubtful and wants to know much more about Chris: "He sounds like a strange sort of chap. All those weekends in the forest without any women. What does he get up to?" This is the hardest part. "Oh, don't worry, mum," I reply airily. "Chris is a bit eccentric, but the boys think he's great fun. He's not, you know, weird or anything."

But something always happens to convince granny that her grandchildren are going off the rails. If it's not Gloria dying her hair pink, it's Jed and Billy horseplaying right above our heads. Bang! Crash! The whole ceiling vibrates. "Oh Joseph," worries granny, "what are they doing now?"

This was the familiar script to which we once again conformed the other day. As usual, I strode upstairs. As usual, the boys had managed to fall out, Billy wailing accusations, Jed denying them. As usual, my nerve ends frayed by granny's endless flapping, I lost my cool. "Will you shut up, Billy?"

"But he kicked me!"

"All right. I'll sort it out. But will you just shut up for now?"

"He kicked me, and all you can say is shut up! I hate you!"

Snap.

"I said, shut up !"

One thump, two thumps, three thumps, four. Half an hour later, Billy was cradled in my arms. He didn't hate me any more. But what would he tell Dilys?

fields.headline: Can he play football?
fields.standfirst: Alex is nine and has cerebral palsy. In this fortnightly column, his mother describes life with a disabled child.
fields.trailText: When I was little, my parents tried to order an omelette on holiday in France. The waiter stubbornly refused to understand what they said. I had just started learning French at school and brattishly piped up, "Une omelette!"
fields.body:
When I was little, my parents tried to order an omelette on holiday in France. The waiter stubbornly refused to understand what they said. I had just started learning French at school and brattishly piped up, "Une omelette!"

"Ah," he exclaimed, beaming. "Une omelette!" I was so proud.

Alex didn't start uttering recognisable words ("Mum", "Bye", "No") until he was six. His speech is affected by poor muscle control, which affects his breathing, voice and ability to move his tongue, lips and jaw - quite an obstacle given that it takes as many muscles to talk as for a ballerina to dance.

Now, two years later, I'm over the moon that my son can chat with me with increasing fluency, but there's one rather devastating setback - a few close friends and I are the only people who understand him. Words that seem clear to me - ("Gockolate" is something nice to eat, "mozak" is what you dance to, and who would "Tony Bear" be if not the prime minister?), are incomprehensible to other people.

A respectable lady I knew with cerebral palsy was once refused service in an off-licence because they thought she was drunk - she had an unsteady gait and talked with difficulty. People are also apt to assume that, like the inept foreigner, Alex needs to be talked to as if he has a mental age of two. I get impatient on his behalf and intolerant of those who won't give him time to speak, or get into such a panic that they won't understand him that - surprise, surprise - they don't.

I find myself having to be an echo for him, interpreting as he goes along. People often think I'm making it all up - and continue talking to him as if he is much younger than he is. His delayed language development also means that he isn't familiar yet with basic social rules.

"Why does that lady look/smell/ talk funny?" he'll ask, in front of someone, and I wonder whether to interpret honestly or cover up.

But the oddest thing is that his mouth movements seem far more suited to French than to English. Yesterday he astonished our French lodgers with an absolutely perfect "Bonne nuit!".

fields.headline: Nursery rules
fields.standfirst: You won't damage your child by going out to work, according to the latest research, as long as the care is first class. But what is good childcare, asks  Luisa Dillner
fields.trailText: You won't damage your child by going out to work, according to the latest research, as long as the care is first class. But what is good childcare, asks Luisa Dillner
fields.body:
First, the good news. Mothers no longer need to feel guilty about going out to work, according to the latest American survey. Our children, even those under 12 months old, will not be harmed as long as the quality of childcare is good. But there, for many parents, is the rub. How do you actually recognise good childcare?

Colette Kelleher, director of the Childcare Trust, says it is possible to come up with an objective definition of "good" childcare. Research shows the higher the quality, training levels and pay of staff, the better the outcome for children in terms of emotional and educational growth. "For pre-school children in particular, but for all children to some degree, consistency of care is crucial," she says.

"Children need stable adults who will see them through transitional periods. It's not rocket science: if you pay people well and respect them, they are likely to stay in their jobs and be positive in the role they play in your child's development."

When visiting nurseries, Kelleher advises parents to ask how much staff earn, how long they usually stay for and whether they have a key worker system, where one carer is responsible for your child. "You don"t want a lot of different people holding your baby," she says. "Rooms should be roomy with natural light and small, quiet areas for babies, and there should be a garden because outdoor play is important."

Kelleher is on the panel for Early Excellence Centres, a scheme set up by the government to encourage innovative nurseries. By the end of this government's term there should be about 40 such centres across the country.

"We have learned that instead of separating out nursery education and childcare it is better to provide a seamless package of care so children get educated and looked after in one place. Otherwise you can get a child taken to the local nursery school for two and half hours and then picked up by someone to go to another nursery for the rest of the day. It's not ideal for a child to go through three different care arrangements before lunch. In other European countries and in Scandinavia care and education are done in one place."

A survey of 60 children from Early Excellence Centres found that those between the ages of three and four said their friends at nursery were more important than who was looking after them. "Good quality nurseries give children the chance to foster friendships and allow them to play independently. You should ask the nursery staff if they let the children go into the garden to play when they want to and whether they can get themselves a drink from the fridge. A good nursery is set up so children have choices and adults facilitate rather than dominate."

Meal times were also important for the children. "Eating should take place in a convivial atmosphere and be a time for children to interact."

Francis McGlone, senior research officer at the Family Policy Studies Institute, says that much research from the US has involved childcare schemes of unusually high quality. "The childcare has been intensive and exceptional in some of these studies," he says.

Well-off families may be able to pay for high staff ratios and nurseries that provide music, art and educational skills but the government's working family tax credit (which has a childcare tax element) may not provide for such high quality care."
