"In Scandinavia the training of childcare workers is on a par with teaching and takes three or four years," says Anne Longfield, director of Kids' Clubs Network. "They specialise in areas of child care such as babies or child psychology. Working with children is seen as a profession and training is pitched somewhat higher."

The age of the carer, though, may not be crucial, especially where young workers are part of a team. "What's important is the balance," says Longfield.

"You need the people looking after your child to have judgment, sensitivity, empathy and to be fun. You are more likely to have good judgment with maturity but younger people can be lively, fun and supportive of children. They may also find it easier to empathise with older children."

webTitle: The big brother I never knew I had

fields.headline: The big brother I never knew I had
fields.standfirst: Two months ago,  Amy Fleming  discovered that her mother had given up a son for adoption. Now 36, he wanted to meet her - but could she welcome him into the family?
fields.trailText: Two months ago, Amy Fleming discovered that her mother had given up a son for adoption. Now 36, he wanted to meet her - but could she welcome him into the family?
fields.body:
Two months ago, my sister and I acquired a new brother. He is 36 and, up until the moment he arrived in our lives, my sister and I had assumed we were our mother's only children.

I arrived at my mother's flat one evening to find her looking anxious. "I've had some extraordinary news," she said. A pause. "I'm just going to have to come out and say it." Another pause, during which I silently pleaded that there hadn't been a sudden death. My mother drew breath: "When I was 16, Brendan [her former boyfriend, now a family friend] and I had a baby boy. I gave him up for adoption and now he's written to Brendan."

My first reaction? Relief that it wasn't bad news - and excitement. "Oh, my God," I said. "That's amazing. It's like in a film." Then: "You're a dark horse." (From her home in Australia, my sister used almost exactly the same words when she heard the news.)

It must be rare for very young parents who gave away an unplanned baby still to be in touch 36 years later, but Brendan and my mother remain good friends. My sister and I used to play with his daughters when we were children and he is my sister's godfather. It also defies the odds that my mum, Brendan and their son have ended up living in the same city - a city in which none of them grew up.

Later that night, my mother handed me the letter. It was calm, honest and gently informative: "My name is Tim Cumming. I was born in 1963 and adopted early in 1964. When I was 16, my father gave me my original birth certificate. I was christened Brendan Robert Quinn and I'm one of a family of four adopted children. Last week, I received my adoption records from Father Hudson's in Coleshill and . . . learned about my origins and the circumstances of my birth."

He wrote about his life, his adoptive parents, his wife and baby girl, what little he knew of his origins and what had led him to trace his birth parents. "After Natasha [his daughter] was born, and seeing her through her first months of life was so amazing, I found myself thinking more and more about my own birth."

He wrote that he had been given two letters my mother had written to the nuns where he was born and that "her handwriting is cranky like mine". At the end of the typed letter there was a sample of his own handwriting and it did look remarkably like my mother's - and my own.

On reading his words, I instantly felt a connection to him - we all did. The letter also made me cry. Tim could not have had any idea what kind of response he would get; when he wrote the letter now in my mother's hand, he didn't even know whether she was alive.

I also felt sad that my mother had worried about her lost son all these years and that my sister and I, now 27 and 25, had never been able to comfort her. She says now that she didn't tell us (or anyone other than my father) about her first child partly because there had never been a right time, but mainly because she had completely "buried" the memory. So much so that when Tim's letter arrived she was momentarily confused, thinking, "How can this be from him? Babies can't write letters." Yet she also says that the lottery numbers she used every week combined all three of her children's birthdays. Buried, yet not really forgotten.

There was no question of me disapproving of what my mum had done. If I had got pregnant at 16, I wouldn't have thought twice about having a termination but abortion was illegal in 1963 and my mother's family were practising Roman Catholics. The eldest of six children, she was doing A levels and planned to go to university. I have no doubt that she did what was best for all involved.

I urged Mum to call Tim that night and they arranged to meet the following weekend. They met in a cafe, drank wine, spent seven hours trying to fill in all the gaps. Tim has since described to me, via email, his first glimpse of mum: "I remember walking up the stairs . . . and your mum was sitting there. I knew it was her and sort of laughed, and it was just great to be alive."

There had been no problem recognising each other since they looked so much alike. A few days after their reunion, I contacted Tim myself by email. "Although up until last week, I had no idea you existed," I began "I am thrilled, now, that you have found us. I only wish you hadn't left it so long." I told him a bit about myself and added: "I'm very excited/nervous about meeting you."

I was on alien territory here. We were, after all, technically strangers and one isn't naturally equipped to deal with new brothers appearing out of the blue. I had to remind myself that Tim was also meeting other new relations and that there was his adoptive family to consider, not to mention his wife and baby.

On the surface, I don't feel jealous or threatened by his arrival, but there have been a few visceral pangs. At first, I felt put out that Tim had given my mum her first grandchild. I felt uneasy, too, when I first saw how like my mother and my sister he looks. I am fair, like my father, and take after his family; my sister is brown-haired, as is my mother, and much more like her in ways that I'm not. And here was Tim, another brown-haired child. I was afraid the three of them would form a cosy little gang and I would feel left out.

Despite his very recent arrival, I also feel twinges of possessiveness towards Tim. For instance, I try to reassure myself that he'll be closer to me and my sister than to Brendan's daughters (we are his mother's children, after all). And occasionally subconscious feelings surface. A week after Tim appeared, a friend of my mother's told me mum was worried about how I was coping. I confronted her: "Mum, I'm completely fine about Tim . . . "

"But," she interrupted, "the first thing you said to me after I'd met Tim was: 'Do you still love me?'." I had no idea I'd said it. I had arrived home drunk after a night out with friends and had just made lots of jokes, or so I had thought.

Two weeks after my mother and Tim met, I went with her to visit him at his home. I stood on the doorstep, clutching a bunch of tulips and a bottle of champagne, half wanting to turn around and run.

Inside, we were all nervous and unable to focus on details (Tim had to open the baby gate every time I needed to go to the loo) but, considering the circumstances, the meeting was remarkably relaxed.

The second time the three of us met, I found it frustrating. Tim and my mother were caught up in learning about each other and going over ancient family history, and I suddenly just wanted to go out and "play" with my new big brother. I wanted him to be a kid with me rather than one of the grown-ups.

We met up alone one evening, drank lots of red wine over dinner and, although nervous, were able to talk honestly about our lives and feelings. There was a sense that if this new acquaintance was going to be a close relation, we may as well begin by showing our true colours. Even when you are strangers, sharing a mother creates a link that can become a bond.

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.trailText: In the United States, 21m children under 16 are online, and not a week goes by without reports of men luring little girls they met on the internet on dodgy dates. So worried parents are doing what worried parents have always done - they are spying on their kids. But where once they leafed through the pages of juvenile diaries, now they are logging on to their computers after hours.
fields.body:
In the United States, 21m children under 16 are online, and not a week goes by without reports of men luring little girls they met on the internet on dodgy dates. So worried parents are doing what worried parents have always done - they are spying on their kids. But where once they leafed through the pages of juvenile diaries, now they are logging on to their computers after hours.

Known as "mommy hackers", mothers in particular are reading their children's email and surfing websites favored by teenage sons. The results, says Parry Aftab, a New York lawyer and author of The Parents' Guide to Protecting Children in Cyberspace have knocked parents sideways.

"I hear from parents every day who hack into their children's computers and are stunned to discover that their children are visiting porn sites, or emailing complete strangers."

But while Aftab understands why mommy hacking is on the rise, she disapproves of it and is calling on parents to try another way of monitoring their children's online habits.

Aftab has drafted a contract for parents and children to sign and then post beside the family computer. It delineates a child's rights online, and bans mommy hacking.

"Spying on your child only creates tension and animosity," she warns. "But if you have ground rules for the internet, it creates trust between parent and child."

Aftab's contract has been available on www.cyberangels.org for two months, and already, 50,000 US parents have downloaded it. Children sign up to 20 provisions, including; "I will not give my name, address, telephone number, school or my parents' names, address or telephone number, to anyone I meet on the computer" and "I understand that some people online ... pretend to be kids, when they're really grown-ups. I will tell my parents about people I meet online".

There are also promises not to buy products without permission or send sexually suggestive pictures or messages. Aftab says the contract seems to be working better than standard cyberpatrol/filter software. "Children sign it and then really do live up to it. And they feel good because they know mommy will no longer hack into their computer.

"But I also tell parents, if children won't sign it, unplug the machine. You are the parents, you set the parameters."

webTitle: Police admit breaking law on anti-China protests

fields.headline: Police admit breaking law on anti-China protests
fields.trailText:
The Metropolitan police today admitted they broke the law in their handling of demonstrators during the state visit of Chinese president Jiang Zemin last October.
 
Police parked their vans in front of anti-China demonstrators on the Mall as the president was escorted to Buckingham Palace to meet the Queen. Police adopted the same tactics at a protest outside the Chinese embassy two days later on October 21.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police today admitted they broke the law in their handling of demonstrators during the state visit of Chinese president Jiang Zemin last October. Police parked their vans in front of anti-China demonstrators on the Mall as the president was escorted to Buckingham Palace to meet the Queen. Police adopted the same tactics at a protest outside the Chinese embassy two days later on October 21.

Human rights groups, unhappy with China's human rights record in Tibet, were outraged that President Jiang was entertained by the Queen and prime minister during his visit.

In a high court case brought by the Free Tibet campaign, the police agreed to a declaration that "it was unlawful for individual officers to remove banners and flags from people solely on the basis that they were protesting against the Chinese regime". A carefully-worded additional declaration stated "that it would be unlawful to position police vans in front of protesters if the reason for doing so was to suppress free speech".

Police lawyers had been set to contest a move by the pressure group to launch a judicial review that challenged police methods during the five-day state visit on the basis that police actions amounted to the suppression of legitimate public protest.

But Mr Justice Burton was told that, while there was still a substantial factual dispute between the two sides, the police were prepared to agree to the granting of the two declarations.

Campaign solicitor Julie Holden said after the brief court hearing in London that, had the case gone ahead, one of the main issues would have been whether officers acted individually in removing banners from the protesters or whether they were following orders. A police internal review rejected claims of political pressure.

In a Commons debate on the London May Day riots yesterday, shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe said: "A lot of people will be perturbed by the contrast in the policing methods used during the visit of the Chinese president, when the mildest demonstration was restrained, and what happened yesterday when there was considerable restraint before intervention took place."

Free Tibet campaign director Alison Reynolds said the court declaration contradicted the results of the police internal review. She called on the police to explain how the review came to defend as "policy" what was now admitted to be unlawful.

"We took this case to court because, like many members of the public, we believed the police action during the state visit was unacceptable and unlawful," she said. Useful links

fields.headline: Rights mess
fields.standfirst: Thousands took to Britain's streets on May Day to protest about global capitalism. If a new bill in parliament becomes law, they could all be labelled terrorists. Gibby Zobel reports
fields.trailText: Thousands took to Britain's streets on May Day to protest about global capitalism. If a new bill in parliament becomes law, they could all be labelled terrorists
fields.body:
The Home Office is far from happy about new-labour.com. The spoof internet site is dedicated to one thing the government isn't keen to shout about - the most significant change in terrorist law in history.

It is redefining "terrorism" so that it will put people who, for example, dig up genetically modified crops in the same frame as an IRA bomber, by introducing the concept that property damage is such an act. It would mean someone who commits a crime for ideological reasons would have less rights on arrest than someone who commits a crime for profit and greed.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, voted against the prevention of terrorism bill which set up emergency provisions for Northern Ireland in 1974. Scheduled to last six months, they have endured a quarter of a century. Now they are to be broadened and brought wholesale into UK legislation permanently.

At the heart of the bill, introduced on December 2 last year, is the new definition, copied verbatim from the FBI. The bill defines terrorism as follows: "The use of serious violence against persons or property, or the threat to use such violence, to intimidate or coerce a government, the public, or any section of the public for political, religious or ideological ends."

Labour MP Alan Simpson says: "We are witnessing a global resurgence of citizens movements, saying, 'If governments can no longer protect our rights, we shall have to do so ourselves.' It's sad that we've chosen this moment to redefine terrorism. Potentially, it turns activist movements into terrorist movements. It's a catch-all bill that will net, if not all the members of the house, some fairly prominent members of it."

MPs went ahead and voted themselves terrorists anyway, passing the bill by 210 votes to one in March. The debate saw cross-party harmony between a few MPs, but it was only Labour backbencher Paul Flynn who voted against. Conservative MP Douglas Hogg was apopleptic of his dislike of hunt saboteurs, but he insisted: "They are not in any ordinary sense terrorists." The bill is due to go through the committee stages of the Lords this month, and is likely to be law by summer.

"The act is an attempt to silence all opposition to the rule of profit over people by labelling it terrorist," says a newly-formed group, Prevent the Terrorism Act (PTA), set up in Brighton, East Sussex. "You only have to look at how the stalking laws were used. The protection from harassment bill was designed to protect women from being stalked. Surprise, surprise, the very first people to be prosecuted under the act were animal rights activists".

So who could be affected? If the proposed new powers had been in place over the last 20 years, they could have been enacted against those who campaigned against the poll tax, the miners' strike and apartheid. The law makes it an offence to support, by word or deed, an armed struggle in another country. Supporting Nelson Mandela would have been illegal.

Translate that to today and watch out if you are a supporter of the Ogonis in Nigeria, Amazonian Indians, Kurds, the Tamil Tigers, Burmese activists or Tibetan freedom fighters.

A statement by the civil rights lobby group, Liberty, says: "There is a real danger that refugees and others who have fled repressive regimes to the safety of this country will become a legitimate target of the police merely because they support the overthrow of that regime, even if they themselves are opposed to violence."

At the sharp end in domestic issues are animal rights activists. Clause 3 of the bill allows for proscription, or banning, of organisations such as the Animal Liberation Front. But some are not fazed by this. "It doesn't really matter what the law is, it is what they do behind your back, whether it's the police, Arni [the Animal Rights National Index police database] or Special Branch," says one animal rights activist, who didn't want to be named. "I've been obviously followed by cars but whether it's blatant or they are thick I'm not sure. We recovered a tracking device from one of our vehicles."

The most likely effect of widening the legislation and bringing it over to the mainland permanently will be for information gathering and harassment, say campaigners.

In 1985, the Tory home secretary, Leon Brittan, admitted that the law was used to "gain information through questioning people. The vast majority of those questioned under the act did not have access to legal representation." Paul Hill, one of the Guildford Four, was the first man to be arrested under the 1974 terrorism laws. He was wrongly jailed for 15 years.

In December last year, the Human Rights Commission in Northern Ireland found six instances where the new bill contravenes the incoming Human Rights Act. There are bound to be a raft of cases, despite Home Office insistance that the bill complies.

"It is particularly galling for Greenpeace to be labelled terrorists," says spokesman Jim Thomas. "We have been at the end of real terrorist activity - the blowing up of the Rainbow Warrior. The real terrorists are companies which release long-term damaging crops into the environment without choice."

Domestic terrorism laws in place for years in Italy have led to "eco-terrorism" being common currency in the tabloids. "People are scared of us, " says one, "People now think of us as terrorists. It's too late in Italy."

Luke Anderson, an activisit against GM foods, says: "The government is creating a private security service for transnational corporations." As a prominent campaigner, he is aware that, under Clause 54 of the bill, if someone is "directing at any level" a group of people who commit a terrorist act they would face life imprisonment. Although it is extremely unlikely he would ever face such a charge, the fact that it will exist on the statute book is a pointer to the future.

Journalists reporting on direct action could be caught by Clause 18, which carries a five-year sentence for failure to report information, received professionally, which may lead to a terrorist act.

A glimpse of government complacency came during the committee stages in the Commons. Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, championed as a rising star of the Blair government, when justifying the 28-day authorisation period for stop-and-search zones in which terrorist activity is suspected, casually remarked that it is because "it is one of my favourite numbers".

Neither Clarke nor Jack Straw, could allay the charge that the bill paints with a brush far too wide.

fields.headline: Negative vibes
fields.standfirst: Tom Johnson felt quite fine - till he found himself playing the lead role in a video nasty
fields.trailText: Tom Johnson felt quite fine - till he found himself playing the lead role in a video nasty
fields.body:
Feather me knock with a down! Even the simplest words wouldn't rearrange themselves into a well-known phrase or saying. My head was spinning, my thoughts were in overdrive, the mental video of my life was on fast forward.

The hospital doctor, having examined me and told me to put my clothes back on, had stood silently, stroking his chin thoughtfully. At last, he spoke.

"There's no easy way to say this," he mumbled. My stomach immediately started doing an Olga Korbut gymnastics display. I wish it'd been like the movies and I'd be able to help him out of his dilemma with a stoical: "Tell me straight, Doc - I can take it." But for most of us, life ain't like the movies. In truth, I just didn't want to hear what he had to say. But he said it anyway.

"I don't want you to be alarmed, but looking at the symptoms I think you ought to consider having an HIV test. I'm not saying for one moment that you are HIV-positive, but at least a test would help to eliminate that possibility."

I'm not knocking the doctor or his manner. He's right - there is no easy way to say it. But as for not being alarmed?

All I could think of was telling him there must be some mistake. I just wanted to water down everything I'd told him.

Yes, I admit that I had originally gone to the GP because I'd been slightly concerned (ever so slightly, mind you) that my lymph glands were a little bit (in fact, hardly at all) swollen.

Yes, I'd lost weight. But I'd lost that about a year ago when I was in a lot of pain prior to a back operation. And I hadn't put it back on because I'd been swimming almost every day since then to strengthen the back. I was probably the fittest physical wreck in the building.

And, yes, I had woken up in the night sweating a few times. But that's probably because my life's been pretty stressful of late. And anyway, the central heating in my gaff is so far up the spout that the climate fluctuates between Saharan and Himalayan.

But, it was too late for that. What could I do but go for the test?

Fortunately, I stumbled - the only way to describe how I got round to the sexual health clinic at the east London hospital - on two diamonds. The two counsellors at the clinic were real gems.

Paul was the first to talk to me, before the test. He gave the impression that he would have sat there with me for as long as it took- even though the packed waiting room was an obvious indication that he was massively overworked. He patiently and gently made me aware how ignorant I was - like so many others, I suspect- of the nature of the virus, exactly how and when it can or can't be transmitted, and of the way we delude ourselves on the issue of safe sex. But somehow he was able to make me hopeful that suicide wasn't the only option. I even managed an unintentional pun. I thanked him for his time and care, and said I now had a positive attitude towards taking the test. Oops!

The test was the same as any other blood test. The results would be ready by the next afternoon, but I would have to attend the clinic to get them. Obviously not something they'd want to give over the phone.

I was a still a bit shaken as I left, but generally OK. I was fine, I kept telling myself. Nothing to worry about. Only part of a process of elimination. I know there's nothing wrong with me.

Sod's Law applied when I eventually got in to work several hours late. Most of the afternoon was spent editing an article on the source of Aids. Thank you, Sod!

I didn't suffer a sleepless night (No sweat, Doc. Honest). Then in to work the next morning and a mumbled explanation around lunchtime that I had to nip off for some appointment or other.

Still no sweat on the bus. But the 10-minute walk from the bus stop to the clinic was, without hyperbole, the longest journey of my life. If I'd walked any slower I'd have been done for loitering.

The fast forward button had been turbo charged. The video didn't miss a single aspect of my future life waiting for full-blown Aids to develop. I won't go through it frame by frame - just close your eyes and imagine all the people you'd have to tell and how you'd do it - but somewhere in each one of those frames was a glimpse of my two lovely young children.

Now life was like a movie - watching a weepie in the cinema, when you try to pretend your sniffles are just a bit of a cold.

Fortunately, I only had to wait five minutes before I was called in by the clinic's other diamond geezer, Vince. This time, the counsellor didn't beat about the bush. The test, he said, was negative.

Vince was as gentle and patient as Paul had been. We talked about a lot of things I can't remember- but I know I'll never forget.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
Whenever I give an after dinner talk I try to squeeze in a little extra rehearsal time by disappearing before the arrival of the Black Forest gateau. But last month, at the University of Central Lancashire, I'd barely risen from my seat when the vice-chancellor leaned across eagerly and asked if I'd met his professor of journalism.

His enthusiasm was understandable. I'd already heard that the university's department of journalism was one of its crowning glories. No other course received so many applications and there were currently over 650 students busily learning how to research and write for newspapers, radio and television.

The man who has worked this miracle is Peter Cole, who was deputy editor of the Guardian until 1988, and had gone on to be the launch editor of the Sunday Correspondent.

Why, I wondered, had such an accomplished journalist given it all up for an academic career? Did he really believe journalism could be taught? He admitted that he'd been as cynical as his fellow journalists about the idea.

"They still tell me that whenever they get an application from anyone who's done media studies they immediately bin it. But I tell them that although we do media studies here, the emphasis is upon how to be a journalist and not upon the products of journalism."

So, how did he react when the press savaged media studies? "We're victims of a smear campaign, much like sociology in the 1960s. Not that people in media studies have always helped themselves. Their work has too frequently been based on hostility to the media, a belief in conspiracy."

Cole is obviously proud of running such a successful journalism course and equally proud that 100% of his postgraduates get jobs in the industry. Only occasionally does he miss the culture of the newsroom, and even then he reflects that nearly every senior editorial person he knows is now "incredibly worried about all the young people around them who are already making it. And when they're not worrying about that they're wrestling with the implications of the web".

His one regret is that former colleagues still regard academic life as a soft touch and keep asking him how he intends to spend his three-month summer holiday.

 Laurie Taylor visits Preston and talks to Peter Cole about teaching journalism in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed: The Larger Map (4pm today).

webTitle: Risky move into the fast lane

fields.headline: Risky move into the fast lane
fields.standfirst: Lynn Hanna on the council that won't wait for the government to take the lead on car chaos
fields.trailText: Lynn Hanna on the council that won't wait for the government to take the lead on car chaos
fields.body:
As John Prescott could testify, transport can be a sadly unsexy subject. Park-and-ride sites, shuttle buses, even supertrams, have failed to raise the public pulse rate. Most people prefer to crawl to work in their cars - until they have to pay for the privilege.

In Nottingham, that prospect has come much closer. Along with 12 other areas covered by 25 local authorities, the council is about to grasp the nettle that has already stung the government. Under its powers when the transport bill becomes law this autumn, the council plans to tax some of the 60,000 work parking spaces in the city.

Congestion is already costing Nottingham companies. Traffic grew by 12%, twice the national average, in the 10 years after 1988. A hundred thousand commuters flock to the centre every morning, often from affluent suburbs outside the city boundaries, while inside a city with pockets of severe poverty, half the households don't have a car.

Taxing workplace parking will make money available for egalitarian public transport - £4m in the first year, the council calculates. And it won't deter the two million regular shoppers who finance the thriving city centre, as indiscriminate taxing for road use might have done, the council says.

In his wood-panelled office overlooking the pedestrianised city centre, the council leader, Graham Chapman, is unmoved by protests. "Business has a public and a private face, and the private face is very sanguine and sensible," he says. "I'm finding that the firms who think two years ahead don't like it. The ones who think 10 years ahead are fairly in favour."

The more sanguine side of business is represented at Nottingham's commuter planners club, set up by the council five years ago. All of the city's large employers are represented, and many encourage staff to walk, cycle or go by bus. These are the organisations that will bear the brunt of the new tax, since small businesses will be exempt. Boots, which has its headquarters in Nottingham, runs 60 staff buses, a car sharing pool and cycle facilities, at an annual cost of £350,000.

The company opposes a tax on its 5,000 parking spaces, although the council plans to discount existing "green travel" expenditure. "It's an ill-conceived idea, a tax on coming to work," says a Boots spokesman. "We accept that it's more than likely to happen, but the local authority needs to work very closely with employers." Boots will pass on the cost to its employees. Others are undecided. There are many more rumblings in the commuter planners club.

If staff pay, how will it affect the lower paid workers? Will it discriminate against women with children? Some even fear that companies will move out, or that charging will deter newcomers."It could tip the balance between being in or out of town," says Nick Ebbs, a commercial property consultant. "In the long term if the strategy works and you have invested in public transport the city is a more attractive proposition. But there is going to be some serious pain in the short term."

These are issues that inflame Chapman, a bus passenger since his "grotty old Montego" caught fire. An initial annual charge of £170 for each parking place is unlikely to cause mass migration of city companies, he says. Neither will employees start job searching over a daily parking charge of 70p. All the money raised will be ring-fenced for public transport, and the council will lure commuters with a supertram, more bus lanes, electric shuttle buses and suburban rail lines. Chapman has sympathy, however, for companies who fear the tax will cause an administrative burden. The city has set up a partnership with employers to examine all aspects of implementation.

The government wants public transport to be improved before charging starts. Participating councils have been given extra cash, £1.2m in Nottingham's case, to start the process. The council wants companies to try electronic barriers linked to smart cards that could be used for parking or public transport.

Chapman isn't too angry that the government has passed on its problems. For the first time in his political life he has more cash than he asked for - and expects more.

"In an ideal world, I would have preferred it to be done by central government," he says. "We know it's not going to be electorally popular, but I'm absolutely convinced that eventually people will understand it."

Bold words for a councillor with local elections looming. The government is unlikely to be as brave.

An initial annual charge of £170 for each parking place is unlikely to cause mass migration of city companies, he says. Neither will employees start job searching over a daily parking charge of 70p. All the money raised will be ring-fenced for public transport, and the council will lure commuters with a supertram, more bus lanes, electric shuttle buses and suburban rail lines. Chapman has sympathy, however, for companies who fear the tax will cause an administrative burden. The city has set up a partnership with employers to examine all aspects of implementation. "In an ideal world, I would have preferred it to be done by central government," he says. The government is unlikely to be as brave.

fields.headline: Red for go
fields.standfirst: Veronique Mistiaen on how comapnies are benefiting from losing staff in an emergency
fields.trailText: Veronique Mistiaen on how comapnies are benefiting from losing staff in an emergency
fields.body:
It began the usual way, with a late night phone call. "Are you available? Are you interested?" an urgent voice asked. "Yes," Nicola Adams answered without hesitation. The next morning, the 25-year -old public health engineer told her boss at Ove Arup she'd be away for three months. She packed her bags and boarded the first flight to Mozambique, to her "other life".

Adams is one of more than 1,000 professional engineers, environmental health workers, water specialists and, more recently, logisticians, project managers and accountants, who are members of Engineers for Disaster Relief - or RedR. They are ready to leave families and secure jobs for three to six months to go on emergency missions with frontline humanitarian agencies such as Oxfam and Médecins sans Frontières, in regions devastated by war, floods, earthquakes and other disasters.

In Mozambique, Adams is tackling temporary housing and water purification for thousands of refugees. Last year, she worked with Oxfam in Albania, preparing water and sanitation facilities for refugees. It was her first mission. "Setting up the camps was a daunting task because of the state of the refugees and the local resources available," she says. "I had to learn very quickly."

Like Adams's boss at Ove Arup, many firms feel they benefit by letting their staff work overseas either on unpaid or subsidised leave, as it provides them with unmatched level of experience.

Murray Dale, 30, a hydrologist with the Babtie Group in Scotland, spent three months last summer assessing water and sanitation conditions in Tanzania's camps for Médecins sans Frontières. "It gave me experience I just couldn't get elsewhere in designing schemes, and more responsibilities," he says.

There are bigger challenges, Dale adds. "You have to get on quickly with a team of people not just from different backgrounds but different countries, and spend nearly 24 hours a day with them in a confined and often tight-security environment. You have just three months, so you need to get everything in place right away, and when things go wrong, the pressure rises quickly."

Adjusting back to normal life after a very intense experience abroad might also be difficult. "For you personally, it was a life-changing experience," Dale says. "But you soon find out that people aren't that interested. They'll listen for a few minutes, then want to tell you about football scores."

RedR was founded in 1979 by Peter Guthrie, a British engineer who worked for Oxfam in Vietnamese refugee camps in Malaysia. He saw that engineers could make an important contribution to emergency work, along with medical people, but that relief agencies had a hard time recruiting them. Back in England, he decided to create a register of specialists who were available and suitable for humanitarian relief work.

Prospective RedR members are carefully screened not only for their professional experience but also commitment to humanitarian work and, more importantly, personal qualities. Jerome Oberreit, RedR recruitment and placement manager, says: "We are looking for people who are flexible, able to work in a team and under pressure, relate well with people from different cultures and adapt to different environments."

They also have to be able to take on responsibilities quickly, deal with bureaucracy and corruption, and understand the mandate of the organisation they work for, he says. Roughly half of the applicants are turned away.

To prepare its members - the majority are young men in their late 20s and early 30s - for the specific needs of humanitarian work, RedR has also developed short, intensive training courses. They include "hard" technical subjects, such as water supply and power generation, and "soft" subjects, such as personal effectiveness, community mobilisation and managing people.

There are currently about 200 RedR members in the Balkans, Sierra Leone, East Timor, Sudan, Tibet and many other countries, and the charity is increasingly trying to bring training courses on site and recruit local experts abroad - so far in Africa, eastern Europe and Asia. "The idea is to have people who know the area, the system and the problems," Oberreit explains. "They are able to cope better with the language and culture, and they can hit the ground faster. It's not just north helping south, but south helping south."

 RedR, Engineers for Disaster Relief, 1 Great George Street, London SW1P 3AA (tel:020-7233 3116; info@redr.demon.co.uk; website: www.redr.org

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Orkney council is to launch a safety campaign to educate people how to use a zebra crossing in the capital, Kirkwall, as it is the first to be installed on any of the islands.
fields.body:
Safety first: Orkney council is to launch a safety campaign to educate people how to use a zebra crossing in the capital, Kirkwall, as it is the first to be installed on any of the islands.

Soft option: Plans to recruit Rottweilers to Lothian and Border police force have been scrapped because the dog chosen as the first trainee proved to be too friendly.

Terrible teens: Staff at an animal welfare centre in Lothian, Scotland, have been flooded with calls for help from owners of terrapins, bought during the 1980s' Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles craze and which have now grown so big they can smash the glass in their tanks.

Beyond belief: Two committed Christians have resigned from their jobs at a plant nursery in Sandown, Isle of Wight, because the owners have introduced feng shui techniques in an attempt to improve the tomato harvest.

Pigs may swim. . . The fire brigade was called out to rescue a rare-breed Gloucester Old Spot pig after it strayed into a neighbouring garden in Charlbury, Oxfordshire, and jumped into the swimming pool.

Lice surprise: A woman who had £400 snatched from her in a street robbery had it returned after cub scouts found the stolen purse while hunting for woodlice under logs in a Sheffield park.

Casting the net: Sunday morning services at a village church in Gorsley, Gloucestershire, are to be transmitted live on the internet.

Trial run: Members of a local theatrical group have booked Gloucester crown court for the staging of two performances of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, Trial by Jury.

Planted evidence: A thriving marijuana plant has been discovered underneath an iron grating directly outside the magistrates court in Wakefield, Yorkshire.

Naughty girl: Police have told a woman in Moniaive, Dumfries and Galloway, to tone down a window display of her collection of Barbie dolls after complaints that some of them are showing too much leg.

False hope: Waxwork limpets have been installed on the seashore at Purbeck, Dorset, as part of scientific research into bird attacks on the molluscs.

Party poopers: An over-40s soccer team from Middlestone Moor, Durham, has been relegated after having 24 points deducted because the 40th birthday party of one of their players was reported to the league.

Stick-in-the-mud: The warden of a woodland park near Newton Abbot, Devon, called in police to arrest a woman for taking away a stick she had been throwing for her dog.

Short list: Volunteers for an identity parade at Merthyr police station, south Wales, were offered free hair cuts because the suspect was reported to have a close-cropped style like David Beckham's.

fields.headline: Cross fired
fields.standfirst: Charles Secrett can hardly wait as London prepares to vote in the mayoral election
fields.trailText: Charles Secrett can hardly wait as London prepares to vote in the mayoral election
fields.body:
One of the most exciting political events of my lifetime takes place tomorrow. The election for mayor of London is a major step on the long march towards devolving political power to localities, cities and regions - a key test for encouraging the participatory politics of sustainable development. And this election will put the environment where it truly belongs: at the heart of politics.

Environmental priorities can no longer be dismissed as an optional extra by party machines. A decent life for every Londoner (but particularly the poor) demands that helping solve unbearable environmental problems - congestion, pollution, energy waste, fuel poverty, and rub bish mountains - is central to the mayor's strategic responsibilities.

No doubt the candidates' minds have been wonderfully concentrated by the coalition of seven NGOs - including the Cycling Campaign, London Wildlife Trust, RSPB, CPRE and Friends of the Earth - working to make this political race as green as we can.

Air pollution in the capital regularly exceeds national and international safety guidelines; annually, hundreds of people die prematurely as a result. Traffic levels continue to soar, with 8m car journeys now made every day. London is a noisier city than Berlin or Paris. The city produces nearly 14m tonnes of waste every year, with 70% going straight to landfill. Londoners recycle just 11% of their waste - a far worse record than other major European cities. Of all London's energy, 70% comes from burning fossil fuels. And we belch out 60m tonnes of CO 2 annually.

As 60% of energy for heating is wasted because of poor energy conservation, Londoners pay tens of millions of pounds extra in bills annually. Worst of all, in 1998-99, over 5,000 fuel poor people died because they were cold and damp.

Every candidate appears to understand, to differing degrees, that public transport must be improved and car use discouraged. And, thankfully, they seem to recognise that looking after London's environment does not conflict with stimulating the capital's economy. Indeed, London's continuing economic success depends on developing a sustainable economy and high quality of life. Let's hope the new mayor persuades the recalcitrant City to do the same, or companies will relocate. There are huge opportunities for modernising investments and job creation in energy conservation and renewables, waste minimisation and recycling, and in public transport.

London is a city rich in green space, but that space is constantly threatened by greedy developers. It must be protected - and extended - as vital for everybody's quality of life. London needs balanced communities, where housing, social, leisure and retail facilities are within easy reach. Housing needs should be met by building on brownfield sites and by using existing buildings more efficiently.

Because London has been deprived of city government for so long, we have all but forgotten that our great river is an important natural asset. The Thames could be used to a far greater extent for mov ing goods and people, because water transport costs less than road transport, cuts congestion and reduces energy consumption and pollution. The Thames and its tributaries also provide space for tranquil recreation, and their diverse habitats are so crucial to wildlife.

I'm going to resist marking every candidate's manifesto with a green scorecard, tempting though it is. Besides, I'm confident the people who really matter - the electorate - will get it right. I've always wanted to see an important British election where the candidate who makes environment a top priority does well. Fingers crossed, that moment will arrive tomorrow.

 Charles Secrett is director of Friends of the Earth.

fields.headline: Fight to the death
fields.standfirst: The great and the good of Victorian Bradford lie in the city's Undercliffe cemetery. Not for the first time, reports John-Dominic Clare, their last resting place is threatened by local strife
fields.trailText: The great and the good of Victorian Bradford lie in the city's Undercliffe cemetery. Not for the first time, reports John-Dominic Clare, their last resting place is threatened by local strife
fields.body:
The stone cross to the memory of James Law, former mayor of Bradford, is massive. So large, in fact, that parish councils the length and breadth of England would give anything to have it in their town square or village green.

Yet it serves as the gravestone for one man. And it is just one among hundreds of such grandiose monuments in Bradford's Undercliffe cemetery, itself one of Britain's least known and most spectacular monuments to the industrial revolution, and one which is now under threat.

The wool barons buried here can no longer admire panoramic views across the city, but their descendants still marvel at the gothic majesty of the tombs their new found wealth bought them. The grandest look like a forest of church spires thrusting up to heaven with stern, almost accusing fingers.

Back in the land of the living, the accusing fingers belong to the trustees of this ornate necropolis, and they are pointed at Bradford city council, which has ceased all funding of the cemetery. The trustees fear that, starved of funds, Undercliffe will return to the vandalised, crime-ridden jungle it was less than 20 years ago, when the company that had owned it since 1854 went under.

When an attempt to sell it to Bradford metropolitan council failed, the whole 25 acres went to a property developer for just £5, becoming an overgrown hangout for glue sniffers. It was saved after locals caught the new owners bulldozing the graves and selling the kerb stones - a scandal which led the council to purchase the cemetery and sponsor a three-year restoration project.

Since 1989, the running of the site has been left to the dedicated volunteers of the Undercliffe Cemetery Charity, supported, until this year, by a council grant. But Bradford's Labour administration now says the charity has enough money in the bank for a couple of years and the elderly volunteers can no longer expect a blank cheque.

Instead, Ian Greenwood, the leader of the council, wanted to see them to get on their bikes and supplement the income from burials and film crews - the film Billy Liar and ITV's Band of Gold were both shot there - with gardening work. Colin Clarke, one of the trustees, says: "It's incomprehensible. Twenty years ago, the feeling was that this place could be left to rack and ruin, and that feeling is creeping back. We are always hearing about regeneration and improving the environment, and this is a wonderful place in a deprived area. It must benefit everyone."

Clarke has thrown everything he has into this Highgate cemetery of the north. Each day is spent with four or five other volunteers on a never-ending round of gardening and grave maintenance.

And when he gets home to the house where he and his wife keep the old cemetery company records, the phone calls start: women's institutes wanting him to give a talk; schools wanting to visit the cemetery; people from across the globe, keen to delve into their family history. What better place to delve than Undercliffe, which boasts a complete cross section of 19th century society, from barons and knights, down through architects and doctors, to those who went to their graves recorded as "cripples" or "imbeciles".

And where Highgate has Marx, so Undercliffe has Bob Cryer, Labour MP for Bradford South, who died in 1994 and whose gravestone reads: "Socialist, parliamentarian, iconoclast and lifelong rebel."

But the highlight for most is the Illingworth mausoleum, built to resemble an Egyptian temple, complete with columns, Sun God carvings and two guardian sphinxes -the targets of a failed theft some years back. The Illingworths are long gone, as is the bronze door that once guarded their rest. Instead, a padlocked gate allows the charity to use the mausoleum as a secure lock-up and to keep out the junkies.

Clarke says: "It is a source of great satisfaction to us that we have made this a place where people like to come, and we've done this with no help whatsoever from anyone - just four or five elderly gentlemen. The bottom line is, the leaders of the current administration were not around 20 years ago when the place a wreck and we were campaigning to save it, but I can see history repeating itself."

Ian Greenwood counters: "What I said to them was they need to look at income generation and they need a business plan. I'm not talking rocket science but simple things any voluntary organisation could do, but they refused point blank, saying the council should pay.

"I am still well disposed towards the cemetery. It's a wonderful place and needs maintaining, but I don't accept that any voluntary group set up as a trust can just say: 'We will carry on in the way we always have', and effectively blackmail the council."

fields.headline: Double dealing
fields.standfirst: Are they really two-headed monsters out to deprave and corrupt children? Henrietta Boyd looks beyond tabloid headlines to examine why the government has fudged the issue of gay and lesbian couples being allowed to adopt
fields.trailText: Are they really two-headed monsters out to deprave and corrupt children? Henrietta Boyd looks beyond tabloid headlines to examine why the government has fudged the issue of gay and lesbian couples being allowed to adopt
fields.body:
A group of adopters and foster carers are exchanging views and experiences. Their conversation ranges from the strains of coping with very challenging behaviour through to the pleasures of watching a child succeed for the first time. They laugh, they groan, they sympathise and encourage. There is no mistaking the enormous level of commitment they all feel towards the children in their care. Each member of the group also happens to be gay or lesbian.

According to the tabloid press, these are the two-headed monsters who will corrupt and deprave vulnerable children. Flak from politicians, church leaders and the media has made many adoption and fostering agencies reluctant to publicise their willingness to recruit lesbians and gay men - at a time when there is a dire shortage of people willing or able to take on the complex needs of children in public care.

Anyone reading certain newspaper reports in the run-up to last week's "adoption summit" at Downing Street, could be forgiven for thinking that adoption by gay men and lesbians was high on the political agenda. Headlines in the Sunday Times announcing "Blair to let gay couples adopt" and the Sunday Express's story "Blair ready to lift the ban on gay adoption" suggested a major shake-up in adoption practice. However, no specific mention of gay adopters was made by the health minister, John Hutton, in his statement following the summit meeting of key representatives from the adoption field.

Like many reports of adoption issues, this story was a red herring. Under current legislation, gay people can adopt. But like any unmarried couple - heterosexual or gay - only one partner can legally become the adopter (with the partner being carefully assessed in the adoption procedure). And while it is true that very few gay and lesbian people are currently adopters, the prime minister would be hard-pressed to find any local authority which actively "bans" gay and lesbian carers. The reasons why gay men and lesbians fail to become adopters - or indeed foster carers - are far more subtle.

Helen Cosis Brown, director of postgraduate diplomas in social work at South Bank University, London, specialises in foster care and issues around sexuality. She says: "We have a real crisis in not having enough good quality carers. The types of people who are able to manage these children's needs are going to be extraordinary people, so we need to look at every individual who has the capacity to do this."

Cosis Brown says that studies in England and the US have shown that there is no difference in emotional development, relationships with peers or sexual orientation between children who grow up in heterosexual or homosexual households. She plans to research outcomes for children who are placed from the care system, and to examine the way agencies utilise gay and lesbian carers.

"My feeling is that only a tiny minority of adoption and fostering agencies would refuse to assess lesbians or gay men, but the ways people fail to get through the process are likely to be more subtle," says Cosis Brown. "I think this is because of the anxieties homosexuality provokes in some people.

"Assessment processes get skewed because the social worker is either over-focusing on sexuality or ignoring it all together through embarrassment. But you can't ignore it because someone's homosexuality impacts on their life as a carer. You need to establish whether they can manage homophobia constructively. Responding angrily may be fine if it's just you - but as a foster carer you often have to put the child's needs before your own."

Dr Stephen Hicks is co-editor of the book Lesbian and Gay Fostering and Adoption: Extraordinary Yet Ordinary. He has also carried out research into the attitudes of social workers and found that they were often concerned about whether gay men and lesbians could act as role models.

"They wanted to know whether lesbians were anti-men or whether gay men could be considered as a role models of masculinity," he says. "I did find that social workers were less inclined to place under-11s because they felt younger children might be 'influenced'. I also got some social workers saying it was OK to place disabled children with gay men and lesbians because they 'wouldn't understand'."

Social workers were also concerned about whether they would be able to get gay men or lesbians approved by their adoption or fostering panels - the body of people who make the decisions about whether individuals are suitable.

The composition of these panels means that elected members or representatives from outside organisations may have strong political or religious views which could conflict with the local authority or voluntary agencies' own equal opportunities policies.

"Even when panels are trying to be liberal, you come across some strange things - like them asking which one of a gay couple is maternal and which one is paternal," says Hicks. "One panel even asked whether a gay couple would be able to do the laundry.

"Nobody is claiming that all gay men and lesbians are going to make wonderful carers, but there are some very gifted lesbian and gay carers around. Richard and Paul (not their real names) are a couple in their 50s and have been together for 28 years. Despite Richard's extensive experience as a children's social worker, they found it very difficult to find an agency prepared to place a child with them. Through an extremely tortuous route, they became long-term foster carers for Patrick, a disturbed and angry 10 year old.

Now aged 14, Patrick has benefited greatly from the stability Richard and Paul provide. The couple both come from close-knit families and Patrick enjoys having grandparents and aunts and uncles.

"We have been able to offer him a great deal of commitment, love and devotion," says Richard. "He had a lack of belief in himself and saw himself as a bad person. He has gradually learned that he is worthwhile and lovable and he is much more hopeful about the future. He's our only child and he's extremely special. He really needed to be special to someone."

He says that several members of the group have experienced harassment because of negative stories in the press, and he believes that many local authorities are cautious about recruiting gay and lesbian carers because of possible reactions from local councillors and the media. The Children's Society certainly received media criticism when it announced last year that it was dropping its ban on gay and lesbian carers.

For those charities who have adoption and fostering projects, there is always the fine balance between meeting children's needs and keeping donors and trustees happy - especially when the charity has strong links with major religious organisations.

Barnardo's recently changed its policy to be more welcoming towards gay people. "In the past, we would take up gay and lesbian applicants but their approval had to go through an extra level of senior management," explains Anne van Meeuwen, Barnardo's principal policy officer.

"Now we have become more child-centred. We recognise there are people in a range of family structures who have something very positive to offer to children with challenging backgrounds. "A lot of the young people are quite damaged. They often have families who are physically or emotionally abusing them, and they may have been attacked at school or had prejudiced social workers. Claire and Yasmin (not their real names) are the adopters of two girls, aged four and 12. They both have extensive experience of working with children. "Adoption agencies tend to place Asian children outside their area so that a child won't be identified by other members of the community. fields.headline: Deadly error
fields.standfirst: A year ago a young woman with a history of drug use hanged herself while locked up alone in a prison cell. Her parents tell Michael Simmons why they hope her death will help others
fields.trailText: A year ago a young woman with a history of drug use hanged herself while locked up alone in a prison cell. Her parents tell Michael Simmons why they hope her death will help others
fields.body:
The recently decorated living room of the Herod family's home in Suffolk is filled with paintings and light. The hall is filled with memories of their daughter, Jenny. As you come in the front door, nearly 20 photographs of her, from babyhood up, have been mounted in a single frame. On a shelf below, there are files of letters and documents, one containing her criminal record. There is a vase with a single daffodil in it.

Tomorrow, it will be a year since Jenny hanged herself in a cell in Holloway prison. Because it was a bank holiday, some of the staff were off duty and she had had to be put in a single cell. When the staff came back on the Tuesday, she was to have been moved to a dormitory. At the inquest, the prison officer on night duty reported that he had handed over all the prisoners in his care. There was no mention that one of them was dead.

Vicky and Steve had spent the holiday weekend at their caravan. For three days running, Vicky says now, she was in "a black hole", unaccountably and uncharacteristically depressed. And on the Monday night, when they got back home, Steve tossed and turned most of the night, crying out in his sleep.

Jenny was six days short of her 22nd birthday. Although she was in prison, again, life seemed suddenly to be looking up for her. Since her teens, she had been on and off drugs - soft drugs, then heroin, stealing even from her parents to finance the habit. Now she thought she had kicked it, and she had been offered her first job, as a care assistant for young people with severe learning and behavioural problems. Just a few days before her death she had written her friend a six-page letter, spelling out her excitement on jolly yellow notepaper.

She was in prison on remand for allegedly driving without tax or insurance, and she had a record of car offences and petty theft. "She had no job history," says her mother, "but with disabled children she was fantastic. She worked for a fortnight at Windmill school [for disabled children] in Cambridge and it was the best fortnight of her life. You could say she was a lovely girl who got side-tracked."

Before the act of hanging herself, she scribbled an affectionate note to her boyfriend, also a heroin addict, telling him to "take care". On the same piece of paper was another note, to her parents. Vicky has kept it in another of her files. "I thought I had got my life together, but it's been taken away again," Jenny wrote. "I can't handle prison any more; I can't keep you worrying any more. You need to get on with your lives . . ." Inside the flap of the envelope, she had written: "I'm sorry. I love you both. God bless XXX."

Specialists who work with people coming off hard drugs say Jenny should never have been left alone because it is then that they are at their most vulnerable.

The prison service pulled out what stops they could: they drove Vicky and Steve down the M1 to Holloway and back, and the governor took them round the prison. They prayed in the prison chapel, paused to visit the garden, but turned down an invitation to see the cell where Jenny died. Vicky also felt unable to talk to the duty officer of the night in question. "He was a big, burly fellow and I thought he was as tough as they come," she recalls, "but when Steve spoke to him he burst into tears. He cared, too."

The Herods were offered no counselling to see them through their grief. Somehow, they manage to keep a stiff upper lip, though Vicky concedes she doesn't know how she'll be on the anniversary of the death.

But she talks readily about it all. She feels that she is still, as she always was, in some sort of telepathic contact with Jenny. "I'm quite sure Jenny's happier now than she ever was," she says. "Whenever I think of her, she is smiling."

As she sees me to the door, past all the pictures and the shrine with its single daffodil, she expresses the hope that "some good" will come out of it all - that other parents will perhaps see the warning signs, and that ways of dealing with drug addicts might improve.

This same gracious charity is not conveyed in an angry letter she keeps from one of the inquest jurors. He wrote: "People like Jenny should not be in prison in the first place, and I like to feel that the magistrate who committed her back to Holloway is fully aware of the consequences of his action . . . I don't think any of us were convinced by the prison's version of events. What, for example, does one make of the log of the officer who reported at 7.15am that he had handed over all the prisoners in his care when one of them was dead?"

The coroner's verdict? Death by misadventure.

Desperate for help

 There were 91 suicides in British prisons last year - the highest number ever recorded; 56 of these were people on remand.

 So far this year there have been 27 suicides (17 on remand).

 The case of Jenny Herod will be discussed at length in the summer issue of the Howard League magazine, HLM. The league's report on prison suicides, Desperate Measures, costs £10 and can be obtained from the league at 020-7249 7373 (website: www.howardleague.org).

 The Samaritans (0345-909090; website: www.samaritans.org) have so far set up listening schemes in 94 British prisons.

 Another helping group is Inquest (tel: 020-8802 7430).

fields.headline: Baby food
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about sugar rich yummies for toddlers on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about sugar rich yummies for toddlers on the net.
fields.body:
1. Baby food may be giving toddlers a sweet tooth, the Consumer's Association warns.

2. Far from being a safe choice for parents, the stuff in jars is packed with sugar and starches that potentially damage fragile infant teeth.

3. A survey of 420 baby foods found that nearly 40% of all foods contained sugar or fruit juice and 60% of breakfast cereals contained added sugars.

4. Which?, the association's magazine, also found that a further 40% contained starch additives which can stop food separating and, importantly for the manufacturer, bulk it out.

5. But now you can buy it organic. Few parents stay calm in the face of food crises and, as a consequence, sales of green baby foods have rocketed.

6. Babies are much more sensitive to pesticide residues than adults and many parents suspect there is a strong link between between pesticides in food and allergies - although this is not proven.

7. Salt is another problem. Last July an inquest found that a three-month-old baby had died because he had been fed salt-rich solid foods too soon.

8. His parents started with baby rice but then moved on to Ready Brek and mashed potato and gravy, because the cereal alone was six times cheaper. His body contained 9g of salt - 18 times what is recommended for a baby.

9. A report from an independent food watchdog found more sugar in a Nestle Fruit Stick and Boots Teddy Bear biscuits than you get in a jam tart.

10. So the big question: should you buy baby foods or make your own? Heinz offer a handy comparison chart for the confused parent.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Any questions? Send them to the.boss@guardian.co.uk.
fields.trailText: I recently foolishly entered an argument with a knowledgeable friend about the football-playing history of top flight managers. With absolutely no proof to back up my case, I tried to tell him that it is possible to enter football management at a respectable level without having played the game. Now, after much brain-wracking I am beginning to wish that I hadn't, as there's a tenner on it. Can you help? asks Matthew May.
fields.body:
I recently foolishly entered an argument with a knowledgeable friend about the football-playing history of top flight managers. With absolutely no proof to back up my case, I tried to tell him that it is possible to enter football management at a respectable level without having played the game. Now, after much brain-wracking I am beginning to wish that I hadn't, as there's a tenner on it. Can you help? asks Matthew May.

You might be able to wangle out of the bet by pointing out that although Gerard Houllier played for Le Tourquet between 1973 and 1976, they weren't in the top flight of French football. But we can't think of anyone who has never played the game at all but has still gone on to manage at a respectable level. Email the.boss@theguardian.com if you know better.

Whatever happened to Scott Oakes, who played for Luton and helped knock my beloved West Ham out of the FA Cup quarter-finals in 1994? He was supposed to be some kind of wunderkind, but it seems that he's just disappeared. Any ideas? asks Matt Stevens.

Scott Oakes, son of Showaddywaddy guitarist Trevor, was one of several young players (including John Hartson, Ceri Hughes and David Greene) who rose to prominence during Luton's stirring 1994 Cup run, which saw them brush aside Newcastle and West Ham before losing a Wembley semi-final to Chelsea.

Oakes, a versatile midfielder, was seen as the pick of a very good bunch, but since then his career has stalled. His time at Luton became plagued by injury and ended after an unsavoury incident when he was booed off the pitch by Luton fans after the team failed to stave off relegation to the Second Division. As a result Oakes refused to sign another contract and, in 1996, he approached his former manager David Pleat for a chance at Sheffield Wednesday. After a successful trial he was signed for £450,000.

But Oakes, now 29, has found first team chances few and far between, and is almost certainly heading out of Hillsborough in the summer. Perhaps, like several other FA Cup wunderkinds (remember West Ham's Stuart Slater?) he wasn't quite as good as we first thought.

Five European cities have had two teams in the European Cup semi-final. Name them. challenges Shane Logan

The cities in question are Milan, Madrid, Glasgow, Moscow and, believe it or not, Dundee.

AC Milan and Internazionale have both won the European Cup - the only rivals in European football to both achieve this feat. Madrid is the only other city to have supplied two finalists - but while Real have lifted the trophy eight times, rivals Atletico must make do with one final defeat. Celtic's 1967 win and appearance in the 1970 final trumps Rangers, who have never got further than the semis.

Moscow (Spartak and CSKA) and Dundee have only produced semi-finalists: that's if you count CSKA Moscow's participation in an eight-team two-group stage which preceded the 1993 final as a semi-final appearance. Both Dundee clubs have got to the semis for sure, and both fell to Italian opposition: United lost to Roma in 1984, while Dundee succumbed to Milan in 1963.

Whatever happened to former Everton player Robert Warzycha? asks Garth Green

The Polish wing wizard captivated the Goodison Park faithful from 1992-4, scoring nine goals in 90 games. But when he was released by Everton, aged 30, his career at the top level looked over. He moved to PMSC Fordan (25 games, 12 goals) and then Kispest-Honved F.C. in the Hungarian first division, but by 1996 he had made the last of his 47 appearances for the Polish national team and was staring retirement in the face.

But that year the Major Soccer League was formed, and Warzycha became the Columbus Crew's first 'discovery player' (foreign signing). Despite admitting that his family's only knowledge of the US was from watching westerns, he quickly settled in the Mid-West college town and became a firm favourite with fans and fellow players. He was one of the top players in the inaugural season was selected for the MLS All-star game in 1997.

In 1998, tragedy struck when his nine-year-old son Bartosz was diagnosed with cancer. But the club started the Warzycha Family Fund to help manage the financial burden of the treatment, and he made a full recovery. Robert, now 36, is still at the Crew, and has started six games this season, scoring one goal. He is also sixth all-time on the MLS assist chart with 32.

Only three players have come on as a substitute in an FA Cup final and scored two goals. Who are they? asks Paul Cowell

Ian Rush and Stuart McCall both scored a brace after coming off the bench in the 1989 final between Liverpool and Everton. Ian Wright repeated the trick a year later for Crystal Palace against Manchester United.

Can you help?

I can recall transfers taking place between Manchester Utd and just about every top side in England - except Liverpool. Have the two clubs ever concluded a transfer deal. If so, when and involving whom? (And if not, why not?) asks Kevin Smith. Answers to the.boss@theguardian.com.

Last week we asked which three Manchester United players captained England in the same international match. Even FA statistician David Barber isn't sure - although if it did happen, it is likely to have occurred during Bryan Robson's reign, he says. But it is not, as many of you have suggested, the Morocco-England 1986 World Cup match, when an injured Robson was replaced as captain by Ray Wilkins who was then sent off - because Wilkins was at Milan at the time and there were no other United players past or present on the pitch. Again, if you can help, mail us.

Knowledge Unlimited archive
fields.bodyText: I recently foolishly entered an argument with a knowledgeable friend about the football-playing history of top flight managers. With absolutely no proof to back up my case, I tried to tell him that it is possible to enter football management at a respectable level without having played the game. Now, after much brain-wracking I am beginning to wish that I hadn't, as there's a tenner on it. Can you help? asks Matthew May. webTitle: A memo to Dalmiya the magician

fields.headline: A memo to Dalmiya the magician
fields.trailText: Mr Dalmiya, what went wrong? Your success in 1997 could have been scripted in Bollywood. An Asian president of ICC, who would have thought it? In fact, it was a feat so remarkable that I thought you were some kind of magician, or a jadoogar as we say in Asia. Your business dealings and friendships were murky, but you had our support simply because of your origins. Your wish to globalise cricket struck a chord with our hunger to see more of our stars and the game we love. But, as you know, Bollywood scripts have a twist, invariably dramatic or ludicrous. Your fall from grace is both of these.
fields.body:
Mr Dalmiya, what went wrong? Your success in 1997 could have been scripted in Bollywood. An Asian president of ICC, who would have thought it? In fact, it was a feat so remarkable that I thought you were some kind of magician, or a jadoogar as we say in Asia. Your business dealings and friendships were murky, but you had our support simply because of your origins. Your wish to globalise cricket struck a chord with our hunger to see more of our stars and the game we love. But, as you know, Bollywood scripts have a twist, invariably dramatic or ludicrous. Your fall from grace is both of these.

Alas, it is too late to rescue the credibility of your presidency: throwing of one sort or another has seen to that. But I would argue that you werenÕt all bad. It was important for ICC to have a different face, a new accent, a fresh impetus, and break the tradition of imperial rule. You provided all of that. Globalisation, too, was the right policy. You knew that cricket could not flourish as an exclusive club in our shrinking world. And now that the match-fixing disease has blighted your vision of globalisation, does that mean your vision was wrong? I donÕt think so.

The glut of one-day internationals is deemed suicidal, a mere pandering to the avarice of gambling-mad Asians, but the critics forget a crucial point: there are millions of Asians, and others, who do not bet and do want to watch these games. Sure, there are too many tournaments, but that could be put right. A World Cup every two years, with seedings based on a league table compiled from the results of all intervening one-day internationals. How does that sound? The countries might not all play the same number of games, but statistics have advanced way beyond averages and strike rates, and such a system would be eminently possible. That, at least, would be a grand achievement before you step down.

Your failings, however, are well versed. Weak leadership and scheming are regular accusations, so much so that it will be a shock if anything substantive emerges from ICCÕs two-day moot. Indeed, you spent the first day getting your fellow administrators to absolve you of any wrongdoing. I buy the argument that scrutiny must start at the top. But the players are at the top of the sport, and it is their misdeeds that are foremost in our minds, not your legal squabbles. Even so, Jagmohan Jadoogar, what does it mean to be cleared by your colleagues? It amounts to little more than a hill of beans, as Bostonians put it, and I know how much you love North America. The same hill of beans as it did when, in their shameful hurry, the ECB, ACB, Fakhruddin, and Chandrachud cleared their own countrymen. The same hill of beans as it does when policemen, doctors, and lawyers exonerate their colleagues. A true reckoning requires an independent inquiry.

But where to start? The amnesty is a difficult but sensible suggestion. Bravo, though your intentions may not be honourable. One lesson from years of mud-slinging in Asia is that only tiny specks of mud stick, without the adhesive qualities of proof. And proof doesn't mean a shock result, a woeful shot, a fielding blunder, or a long hop. It requires evidence: a tapped phone-call, a secret video, or an unaccountable bank account. Proof, in that sense, is rare; innuendo is limitless. An amnesty is one way of shining a light.

Let's look to North America again for another lesson. The Washington Post is well known for going big on stories only when the evidence comes from two unconnected sources. That could be a way forward in ICCÕs investigation. Two such examples spring readily to mind: Manoj Prabhakar, Aamir Sohail, Aqib Javed, Mark Waugh and Shane Warne all have stories to tell about the 1994 Singer World Series in Sri Lanka; and Chris Lewis and Stephen Fleming both accuse Ashim Kheterpal of approaching them during last yearÕs Test series. A beginning, at least.

Abraham was asked for a sacrifice; we want the same from you - transparency and the truth even if it hurts. Not just a declaration of no conflicts of interest, but a declaration of all financial interests, though you, like Hansie Cronje, must feel like David taking on the Goliath of world opinion. Abraham and David, names to conjure with Jadoogar, while sharks and Mafia circle menacingly; Hansie knows them well too, being a religious soul, but in my native tongue, Jadoogar, Abraham and David become Ibrahim Dawood - which just happens to be the name of the alleged mafioso whom the Delhi police were tracking when they stumbled upon a South African accent. Time is short, Mr Dalmiya, and history will not be kind.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is editor of the World Health Organisation Bulletin. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on wisden.com and Cricket Unlimited and every month in Wisden Cricket Monthly. Next Wednesday, Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View
