webTitle: Editors unite against order on Shayler documents

fields.headline: Editors unite against order on Shayler documents
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: National newspaper editors today call on the government to stop attempts by the police special branch to force the Guardian and Observer newspapers to hand over documents they may have relating to the former MI5 agent David Shayler.
fields.body:
National newspaper editors today call on the government to stop attempts by the police special branch to force the Guardian and Observer newspapers to hand over documents they may have relating to the former MI5 agent David Shayler.

In a half-page advertisement printed in the Times, more than 150 journalists, lawyers, academics and MPs have condemned the government for threatening the freedom of the press by pursuing the newspapers through the courts.

Signatories to the petition, which calls on the attorney general to stop the proceedings immediately, include David Yelland, editor of the Sun, Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, and Ben Bradlee, vice-president of the Washington Post.

Today's development has added to the clamour for the government to drop the action brought by special branch, which is trying to prosecute Mr Shayler under the Official Secrets Act.

In March an Old Bailey judge ordered the newspapers to hand over any documents and emails relating to Mr Shayler, after the Observer published a front page report claiming that he had named two MI6 agents and the Guardian published a letter written by the former MI5 agent, who is living in exile in France.

In a case that has serious implications for press freedom, Judge Martin Stephens said any material the newspapers might possess could help police in their attempts to prosecute Mr Shayler.

The newspapers have applied for judicial review of the decision and have vowed to take the case all the way to the European court of human rights if necessary.

According to today's advert, if the newspapers lose the case Alan Rusbridger, editor of the Guardian, Roger Alton, editor of the Observer, and the Observer journalist Martin Bright could face prison sentences.

"We are shocked that the government should allow these intimidatory proceedings to go forward into the courts," the advert says. "The freedom of information and expression are inextricably linked together as a bedrock of democracy.

"The attorney general, the government's legal adviser, has the power to stop these proceedings at a stroke. We call upon him, the prime minister and home secretary to bring these proceedings to an end. The principles at stake are of the greatest importance in this country. They have to be upheld for the sake of pluralist democracy and media freedom all round the world.

"We recognise the need to protect national security. But governments in this country have for too long protected the security forces with excessive and punitive secrecy. Other democracies subject their security agencies to public scrutiny and accountability without risk to national security. Our citizens must be able to pursue legitimate inquiries into the activities of the security forces without fear."

As well as bringing condemnation from journalists, academics and MPs, the case has sparked bitter disputes at the highest levels of government. Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, and Peter Hain, Foreign Office minister, have let it be known that they are horrified by the action.

fields.headline: Labour faces election blues
fields.standfirst: The Tories look set to gain hundreds of council seats tomorrow, but the results will do little to help predict the outcome of the next general election, writes Peter Hetherington
fields.trailText: The Tories appear on course to repeat last year's European election success by polling more votes than Labour in tomorrow's local elections, with councils from Solihull to Southend likely to change hands.
fields.body:
The Tories appear on course to repeat last year's European election success by polling more votes than Labour in tomorrow's local elections, with councils from Solihull to Southend likely to change hands.

But while William Hague is poised to proclaim a great victory over the government in contests outside London, a low turnout - and the relatively small number of seats at stake (3,360) - means few conclusions can be drawn about the outcome of the general election, likely next year.

That will not stop the Tory leader claiming he has touched the popular mood by playing a law and order card which has highlighted the issues of "bogus" asylum seekers and rural crime.

Since last year's local elections, the Tories have made modest advances after overtaking the Liberal Democrats to become the second party of local government once again. According to the local government chronicle elections centre at Plymouth University, they have made 34 net gains while Labour has taken only one seat. The Lib Dems have been losing ground to the Tories in the south and gaining seats from Labour in the north.

The centre calculates that if this pattern is repeated tomorrow, Tories will gain 350 seats on the 152 local authorities where elections are being held. This should give them control of a further 10 councils. But since 131 local authorities are only choosing a third of their councillors, there is little likelihood of wholesale changes in council control.

Mr Hague should take particular comfort in one small part of England. Due to boundary revision, seats on all six district councils in Surrey are being contested. The Tories control one authority. They should control all six by Friday. If they don't, any Tory revival will appear extremely fragile.

After dismally low turnouts last year, which dropped below 20% in many inner city wards, Labour's main battle will be persuading sceptical supporters to vote.

Although the party is nearly 20% ahead of the Tories in opinion polls, every election since 1997 has seen Labour struggling to convert those ratings into votes. But it can take comfort from the fact that opposition council gains give little pointer to the outcome of a general election. During Neil Kinnock's period as Labour leader, for instance, the party always outpolled the Tories in local elections. But the hapless Mr Kinnock could not unseat Margaret Thatcher or John Major.

webTitle: 'The voters of London are about to commit one of the greatest follies of modern times'

fields.headline: 'The voters of London are about to commit one of the greatest follies of modern times'
fields.standfirst:
On the eve of the first ever election for a London-wide mayor, the national
newspapers show a rare unanimity in their leader and opinion columns. The
independent Labour renegade Ken Livingstone, say the pundits, will win the
election - and he will be a disaster. Here is a selection of what the papers
say:
fields.trailText: The Financial Times: 'Many will vote for Livingstone as a symbolic thrust at the centralising power of Tony Blair's government'
fields.body:
The Financial Times: 'Many will vote for Livingstone as a symbolic thrust at the centralising power of Tony Blair's government'

"Tomorrow, five million Londoners are likely to elect a mayor who will be the least suitable of the four main candidates. The reasons are depressingly clear. First, Ken Livingstone, the Labour party renegade standing as an independent, makes people laugh. He can even raise a smile in the financial sector with his anti-capitalist nonsense. Second, the other candidates have failed to shine... The third reason for 'Red Ken's' dominance of the campaign is protest. Many will vote for him as a symbolic thrust at the centralising power of Tony Blair's government... Mr Livingstone might yet turn into a better administrator than is suggested by his utterances or his record as leader of the former Greater London Council. But the dangers are obvious.....Mr Livingstone's priorities, in short, are likely to be: number one, self-aggrandisement; number two, Ken's political future."

The Mirror endorses Steve Norris: 'To vote Dobson is pointless'

"The voters of London are about to commit one of the greatest follies of modern times. Tomorrow they will elect Ken Livingstone as their first mayor. And they will do so because they think he's 'a good laugh who'll give that Tony Blair a hard time'. What a dismal and misguided reason to elect this dangerous buffoon to such high office... This mayoral election has been a shambolic and pathetic joke from start to finish. But we still believe that every Londoner should vote tomorrow. To vote Dobson is pointless. To vote Livingstone is unthinkable. And the Lib-Dem candidate Susan Kramer is clearly out of her depth. So The Mirror is left with only one unbelievable alternative. Because, on the balance of everything we know about the four main candidates, it is Stephen Norris who appears the least risky and most capable bet for London... So we, Labour's most loyal ally in the press, are actually urging Londoners to vote TORY. We hope Tony Blair reflects on this decision as he reads his Mirror this morning. And feels utterly embarrassed by forcing us into it."

The Daily Telegraph: 'Mr Livingstone is all too likely to make a bad mayor'

"In London, the big issue has been Mr Livingstone, and, in a vain attempt to tackle him, all the main candidates - including the Conservative, Steve Norris - have chosen to follow his agenda of 'minority rights'. There has been some discussion of the Tube, but by and large the campaign has been remarkable for the lack of debate on substantive issues among the mayoral candidates... None of the main candidates - including Mr Norris - has made any convincing attempt to come to grips with Londoners' anxieties or explain how the city could, or should, be run. To that extent, it has been a bad campaign and at the end of it, unfortunately, Mr Livingstone is all too likely to make a bad mayor."

The Daily Express endorses Steve Norris: 'Steve Norris is not perfect but he is sensible'

"Labour's Frank Dobson is a decent man. But he was so clearly shoe-horned into running that everyone has seen that his heart is not in it... Susan Kramer, the Lib-Dem nominee, has impressed with her dedication and sparkiness. She is a serious politician with constructive proposals about transport, her speciality, and many other issues. But the Lib-Dems are never going to garner enough support to make her a realistic contender. That leaves Ken Livingstone and Steve Norris... Mayor Ken would be a disaster. He is a skilled media operator, who is a past master at political deception. For all his supposed modernity, he remains stuck in the agitprop politics of the Eighties, an oppositionist whose policies unravel on close scrutiny, who draws most of his allies from fringe activists. Crucially, he would discredit the very idea of elected mayors. Steve Norris is not perfect but he is sensible and has experience and conviction... What matters is the merit of each candidate and how they would promote the idea of elected mayors. On that basis, the Daily Express endorses Steve Norris."

The Sun endorses Steve Norris on because of the mayday rioters: 'A vote for Ken is a vote for them'

"We have seen the appalling aftermath of May Day, when anti-capitalist jobs took the centre of London by storm. These are the same scum to whom Livingstone was happy to give his support the last time they attacked our capital. A vote for Ken is a vote for them... The Sun doesn't like telling people how to vote in London tomorrow. But we have to say: Stick to your party allegiance. If you're Labour, vote for Frank Dobson. If you're Tory, vote for Steve Norris. With your second vote, put an X against any name except Livingstone."

The Evening Standard endorses Steve Norris: 'Any Londoner who cares seriously about the governance of this city will cast a vote for Steve Norris'

"A vote for Mr Livingstone is a vote for opposition - his natural forte - rather than for responsible government... To vote for Mr Livingstone tomorrow demands belief that he will show a consistency and maturity which have escaped him for the past 55 years. Perhaps it was always inevitable that the first holder of a new elective job, the value of which no one can yet properly know, would be drawn from the rear ranks of politics, its exhibitionist fringe, rather than its solid centre. We remain impenitent supporters of the mayoral idea, and live in hope that the next contest, four years on, will produce the top-rank figure this city needs and deserves. But if Mr Livingstone wins his expected triumph tomorrow, only the likes of Mr Ali G will have real cause to celebrate. Any Londoner who cares seriously about the governance of this city will cast a vote for Steve Norris."

fields.headline: Lockerbie suspects deny bombing charges
fields.standfirst: Libyan defendants say they will name 'real bombers' as trial opens and Gadafy pledges to accept court's verdict
fields.trailText:
Two Libyan men today pleaded not guilty to charges that they were involved in the Lockerbie bombing of PanAm flight 103 in 1988, as Colonel Muammar Gadafy pledged to accept the verdict of the Scottish court in the
Lockerbie trial.
fields.body:
Two Libyan men today pleaded not guilty to charges that they were involved in the Lockerbie bombing of PanAm flight 103 in 1988, as Colonel Muammar Gadafy pledged to accept the verdict of the Scottish court in the Lockerbie trial.

On the opening day of the trial, more than 11 years after the December 1988 bombing that killed 270 people, the court heard that lawyers acting for Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi, 48, and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, 44, would produce evidence that would incriminate others for the world's worst ever airline bombing,

The clerk to the specially-convened Scottish court sitting in the Netherlands read a list of Arabic names of people he said the defence would claim were the real Lockerbie bombers, including members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, and members of another group called the PPSF.

It took 20 minutes to read the indictment against the defendants and the clerk of the court then announced that both men were pleading not guilty to all charges.

The first witness in the trial was then called - Heathrow-based air traffic controller Richard Dawson, 52, from Taplow, Bucks. The packed public section of the courtroom watched through a bullet-proof screen as Mr Dawsonwas questioned by Lord Advocate Colin Boyd QC, who is heading the prosecution team.

The two men are being tried at Camp Zeist near Utrecht, under special arrangements agreed with the Libyan government.

The Libyan leader, Col Gadafy, pledged in an interview with Sky News to accept the verdict but dismissed as "absurd" a suggestion that the two Libyans accused of the bombing were acting under his direct orders.

Asked in an interview if he would accept the verdict as "fair and just", he said: "All parties have agreed to accept the rule of the law, the rule of the court."

The trial, expected to last at least a year, is being held at a former US air force base at Camp Zeist, near Utrecht. The trial is being held under Scottish law, but with three judges instead of a jury.

All 259 passengers and crew and 11 residents of Lockerbie died when a PanAm Boeing 747 disintegrated in mid-air and crashed on the Scottish town on December 21, 1988.

The two suspects are accused of murder, conspiracy to murder and violation of the Aviation Security Act. They have pleaded not guilty, deny working as secret service agents and say they were just employees of Libyan Arab Airlines.

Responding to a suggestion that the two suspects were acting under his direct orders, Col Gadafy said: "It is an absurd question that should not have been asked."

Col Gadafy said the court would try the two Libyans only, and that they should bear individual responsibility for the bombing if they were found guilty. After the verdict there should be no further investigations into his own actions or those of Libyan officials.

"By and large the responsibility as far as this matter is concerned is an individual one. The court is sitting to judge them, not whether they are...Libyan agents."

"The court is sitting to try them whether they are guilty or not guilty, whether they have done the act or not. The court is not concerned...whether they belong to Libyan intelligence or not."

The agreement under which the two defendants were handed over for trial was that the court would try them on the allegations concerned with the destruction of Flight 103, he said, adding: "If you go further than that we shall come to an endless chain."

He added: "I have confidence that the problem of Lockerbie will come to an end."

Col Gadafy said Libya had "no connection" with Lockerbie and therefore did not know who the perpetrators were. It was known that the United States had many enemies and had committed "grisly" crimes. Anyone who wanted revenge against the US could have carried out the Lockerbie bombing, Col Gadafy said.

America had shot down an Iranian passenger airliner before the Lockerbie disaster, he went on, adding: "Those people who were killed by America, they have their own families and relatives, they may take revenge.

"This does not mean that Iran as a state or the Iranian government is convicted or condemned."

Col Gadafy said he was "sympathetic" to all the relatives of the victims of the Lockerbie disaster - along with the relatives of victims of the 1986 raid on Libya, and victims from Iran, Palestine and Lebanon.

"I am sympathetic to all the relatives of all these victims and I pray for them," he said.

"I have confidence that the problems of Lockerbie will come to an end and will be finished so that we will be turning over a chapter which has been with us ever since the cold war."

The trial is expected to start today with eyewitness accounts of how flight 103 fell from the skies. Civil Aviation Authority officials, police officers and local people who saw the disaster unfold were likely to be among the first witnesses giving evidence.

Elsewhere in the interview, Col Gadafy accused British intelligence of plotting to kill him, saying: "It is a known fact that British intelligence recruited stooges for agents to assassinate me.

"And it is also a known story that the bomb that was thrown at me by an agent who was recruited by British intelligence."

Col Gadafy also pledged Libyan cooperation to find the killer of Pc Yvonne Fletcher, who was shot dead outside the Libyan People's Bureau in London in 1984. Relations between Britain and Libya were now "good", he added.

webTitle: In brief, and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief, and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Brat pack siblings kiss and make up, N'Sync go cinematic, American Pie star tipped for Spiderman role, Tom Hanks' junior eyes Anakin, Robin Hood gets the Disney treatment, Fight Club Fincher's latest project, and the latest casting news
fields.body:
Good news for fans of the 80s brat pack estranged brothers Charlie Sheen and Emilio Estevez have kissed and made up. The duo have recently starred together as porno-movie-making brothers in the film Rated X. Says Sheen, "we had come out of really not having a relationship for 10 years and then suddenly boom, we are friends again... There were patches of time when we wouldn't speak for several months and now since doing the movie we speak every day, several times a day." To which Estevez replies, "Charlie, if you would stop calling me, I would appreciate it. I have a life to lead."

Teeny-pop boyband N'Sync are making a musical movie - about themselves. The group, whose new album No Strings Attached recently shattered opening day and week sales records in the US, will appear at Cannes Film Festival to announce details of the picture. The news dampens speculation that the toothy entertainers were set to star in a remake of Grease 3 with fellow bubblegum popster Britney Spears.

Adding to feverish speculation in filmdom, the Radio Times reports that Sam Raimi has cast American Pie's Chris Klein in his big-budget take on Spider Man. Klein recently visited the director on the set of current project The Gift, and is thought to be one of only two actors - the other is Cider House Rules star Tobey Maguire - being the role of Peter Parker, the nerdy student who acquires supernatural strengths after being bitten by a spider.

Into that other casting fervent - over the role of Anakin Skywalker - yet another name has been pitched - that of Tom Hanks' son Colin. Reports suggest that the 22-year-old has been spotted on George Lucas's Skywalker Ranch numerous times and had a reading with Natalie Portman this weekend. Fansite TheForce.net seems to credit the rumours, citing 'rather convincing proof' before concluding, from bitter experience presumably, that "we'll all just have to wait and see". Hanks junior, who is dating a lady by the name of Busy Philips, made his film debut in That Thing You Do - directed by his dad.

Disney are to produce an animated reworking of the story of Robin Hood - or, more specifically, of his sweetheart Maid Marian. Mouse House talent is currently at work on the cartoon, called Marian and Robin, in which childhood friends Marian, Robin and Sam - who grows up to be the Sheriff of Nottingham - decide to rob the rich and give to the poor at Marian's suggestion. The studio describes the project, bewilderingly, as "Ever After meets Young Guns".

Casting couch

Fight Club director David Fincher is to helm Pathfinder, in which, according to reports at Ain't It Cool News, a CIA agent escapes a Serbian prison and learns that his former cell mate, a brilliant Serb spy, has liberated a war crimes general and hijacked a payload of plutonium.

Susan Sarandon, Tobey Maguire and Green Man star Michael Clarke Duncan will get animated in Like Cats and Dogs, a live action and cartoon feature. Directed by Antz helmer Larry Guterman, the film tells the story of a young pup who saves the world from a gang of shifty cats.

Billy Crystal is to star in and produce Pals. The hilarious (it says here) Oscar host and actor will play a prison inmate posted with a respectable family as part of a community work programme, only to find the family is in fact more corrupt than his fellow cons.

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland peace process was in confusion last night after Tony Blair failed to reach agreement with his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, to allow a fresh round of talks.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland peace process was in confusion last night after Tony Blair failed to reach agreement with his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, to allow a fresh round of talks.

After more than seven hours of negotiations with the province's main political parties in Downing Street, Mr Ahern underlined the differences between London and Dublin when he said that the talks, scheduled to take place in Northern Ireland tomorrow, might be called off.

His remarks contrasted with an upbeat view from Downing Street, where the prime minister's official spokesman announced that the two prime ministers would reconvene with the political parties tomorrow at Hillsbrough Castle, Co Down.

Mr Ahern said that he would talk to Mr Blair by phone today, but added he was "not sure" if they had "reached the point where we can hold those [Hillsbrough] discussions".

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, played down any differences. "I can't predict precisely at this stage what the travel movements of the [British] prime minister are going to be, but he's very engaged in this," said Mr Mandelson. "We have made progress, we have been able to narrow the differences between the parties, and it's that that has justified the involvement of the taoiseach and the prime minister today."

Relations between Mr Blair and Mr Ahern were strained when Mr Mandelson suspended the power-sharing executive this year, although ministers in London and Dublin insist both have worked hard to repair relations. The conflicting signals came after Mr Blair and Mr Ahern held talks at Downing Street with Ulster Unionists, the SDLP and Sinn Fein.

The two governments had hoped to forward new proposals that would see emphasis on IRA decommissioning reduced, so long as the IRA could be persuaded to make a strong statement to re-assure Ulster Unionists about its future intentions. The governments were hoping David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, could be persuaded to take one last gamble with his party's ruling council, and again enter government with Sinn Fein without prior IRA decommissioning.

There is an urgency to make progress before May 22, the second anniversary of the referendums ratifying the Good Friday agreement; the date is hugely symbolic, because it had at one stage been hoped that decommissioning would be complete by then.

A mood is growing that the issue of decommissioning, first raised by Sir Patrick Mayhew, then Northern Ireland secretary, in 1995, is the wrong test on which to gauge terrorists' intentions; the security forces insist that decommissioning would not in itself mean the threat of violence was gone for good.

Michael McGimpsey, one of Mr Trimble's ministers before the executive was suspended after 72 days, said last night that if there was a better way than decommissioning to reassure Unionists, his party was prepared to listen. He said the outlook was more positive than negative.

In the Irish Republic, relatives of "disappeared" IRA murder victims watched as the final search for their remains began. Police at one dig said it would be "slow and painstaking", a view repeated at four other sites.

· Two Catholic barristers yesterday won a high court action in Belfast over their refusals to make a declaration to serve the Queen in order to become Queen's counsels.

Seamus Tracey and Barry Macdonald applied for judicial review of the retention by the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, of the declaration to "well and truly serve Queen Elizabeth II" after the Bar Council had said it should go. The pair do not now automatically become QCs, though it is thought they will be appointed when it is announced that the declaration is to be dropped.

fields.headline: Spider in the British web
fields.standfirst: Fear of costly litigation will force users elsewhere, writes Guardian Unlimited editor David Rowan
fields.trailText: You might think, for all the talk of e-envoys and dotcom equity options, that Britain's internet economy had all but caught up with America's. Not quite. They, after all, enjoy the First Amendment and a legal culture that promotes the free expression of diverse opinions. We remain constrained by libel laws that have been directed at newsagents and magazine distributors as well as publishers. Legal challenges here are already attempting to extend this culture to online publishing. We cannot afford to pretend this is sustainable in the global information society.
fields.body:
You might think, for all the talk of e-envoys and dotcom equity options, that Britain's internet economy had all but caught up with America's. Not quite. They, after all, enjoy the First Amendment and a legal culture that promotes the free expression of diverse opinions. We remain constrained by libel laws that have been directed at newsagents and magazine distributors as well as publishers. Legal challenges here are already attempting to extend this culture to online publishing. We cannot afford to pretend this is sustainable in the global information society.

The Prodigy case establishes that internet service providers (ISPs) are not liable for libellous communications that they may inadvertently propagate. They are merely allowing other people's messages to be exchanged. As a result, American ISPs need not fear endless court cases should they fail to monitor every email and web page that passes through their servers. A sensible conclusion, you might think, in an era when information has become the prime global currency.

Compare that to the out of court settlement reached in Britain two months ago between Demon Internet and Laurence Godfrey, who received £15,000 (plus legal costs of around £250,000) for being the subject of allegedly libellous bulletin-board postings.

The Demon case has widely been interpreted as a warning to British ISPs and web publishers. Within days of the settlement, British ISPs had shut two websites - a gay site called Outcast, and an anti-censorship site that dared to claim that Outcast's closure had been "Godfrey's first victim". Why? Fear of costly litigation. As the Internet Freedom campaign group has noted, the very threat of libel action has "opened the floodgates for every ISP to censor its customers whenever something remotely controversial is said".

The weakness of such a conservatively British approach is that the internet does not need Britain - its users will simply find other, global routes to the information they seek. If our libel laws, or the fear of lawyers' letters, serve to limit how people communicate in this new era, then there are plenty of foreign places web users will happily go. If ISPs in this country are perceived to run a greater risk of libel litigation than their foreign competitors, then the business will move a click away.

Maybe Tony Blair should gather a few of his legal friends together for his next fireside internet chat on the No 10 website. He might remind them that the old-fashioned ways of doing things do not always translate to the new economy. After all, our good old security services have still not managed to silence David Shayler or Richard Tomlinson, whose messages hosted on foreign servers still find web users in the UK.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Summer's on its way, and so are lots of professional footballers by the looks of things
fields.trailText: Newcastle are ready to spend £5m on Wimbledon's Jason Euell. According to the Sun, Bobby Robson watched the 23-year-old against Bradford on Sunday - at the same time as checking out Dons keeper Neil Sullivan, who is available on a free transfer this summer.
fields.body:
Newcastle are ready to spend £5m on Wimbledon's Jason Euell. According to the Sun, Bobby Robson watched the 23-year-old against Bradford on Sunday - at the same time as checking out Dons keeper Neil Sullivan, who is available on a free transfer this summer.

The Mirror reports that George Graham is stepping up his bid to sign Dinamo Kiev striker Sergei Rebrov. The Spurs manager hopes to sign the Ukranian international next week, but even if he succeeds, he could still lose Steffen Iversen - whom the paper claims is a target for Leeds.

While other papers concentrate on Rebrov, the Daily Express believes that Spurs' real strike target is Celtic's Mark Viduka and that an £8.5m deal has all but been agreed for the Scottish player of the year.

Iranian striker Ali Daei is another player tipped for a move to Leeds. The Daily Mail believes that David O'Leary is prepared to spend £3m on the 31-year-old, who is quoted as saying: "I know Leeds are interested in me and I see my future as being in England."

According to the Daily Star, Chelsea are willing to sell Tore Andre Flo - if the price is right. The paper quotes Gianluca Vialli as saying: "I would let Tore go, but not for £8.5m. If somebody was to make us an offer we couldn't turn down then we would be happy to sit down and do business."

Planet Football reports that the French national goalkeeper Fabian Barthez has asked to be put on the transfer list at his club AS Monaco. Barthez has fallen out with coach Claude Puel after he allegedly accused the keeper of throwing a recent match with Marseille.

webTitle: Meet the woman at the centre of Cronjegate

fields.headline: Meet the woman at the centre of Cronjegate
fields.trailText: When Bronwyn Wilkinson, communications officer for the United Cricket Board of South Africa, picked up the phone at 2.45am on the morning of April 11, the world turned upside-down. It was Goolam Rajah, the South African team manager, phoning from Hansie Cronje's hotel room. He told Wilkinson that it was "really urgent" to get hold of Ali Bacher for Hansie - he didn't have to explain why. Cronje's subsequent conversation would destroy his career, and throw world cricket into turmoil.
fields.body:
When Bronwyn Wilkinson, communications officer for the United Cricket Board of South Africa, picked up the phone at 2.45am on the morning of April 11, the world turned upside-down. It was Goolam Rajah, the South African team manager, phoning from Hansie Cronje's hotel room. He told Wilkinson that it was "really urgent" to get hold of Ali Bacher for Hansie - he didn't have to explain why. Cronje's subsequent conversation would destroy his career, and throw world cricket into turmoil.

Wilkinson was completely stunned. "I had honestly believed that he had nothing to do with it. I'd previously sat down with Hansie and Dr Bacher and he [Hansie] had denied it, and I'd just been completely baffled by the story. I knew about the '96 offer [when the South African team turned down $250,000 to throw a one-day international against India, at Bombay] which Hansie had talked about in an interview two years ago, but I had never heard the remotest rumour about any South African player. It was an unbelievably bad day."

At seven that morning Wilkinson confirmed to the horrified South African press corps that Cronje had been removed from the squad. She then met Dr Bacher (the UCB's managing director) in Durban, where they saw the South African team and Bacher confronted each player in turn about any involvement with Cronje: "It was very tense, the team were still trying to absorb what was going on". At one o'clock, Wilkinson, the new captain Shaun Pollock, Percy Sonn (the UCB's president) and a "totally shattered" Bacher faced the media at that press conference. She had been in the job a month.

Perhaps only Gavin Hamilton has had a more fiery baptism in South African cricket, but no-one disputes Wilkinson's class. Though only 33, she is one of the most successful journalists in South Africa. "She could have practically walked into any job in the South African media," says one journalist who has worked there.

In the early 90's she worked on The Star, one of South Africa's biggest daily papers, as a crime and political reporter - "the two mostly dovetailed in those days". In 1993, her career was blown slightly off course: in August she was shot in the elbow by a sniper. "it was only a percussion wound," she says. (Only?) Shortly afterwards she discovered that she was pregnant: "It was a big year for me." She transferred to a desk job, from where she covered the lead-up to the 1994 elections, and when she returned from maternity leave that August (after giving birth to a son, Matthew), moved to the sports desk of the Saturday Star and Sunday Independent. She was made sports editor in 1996, and remained there until early 1999 when she was appointed the editor of TML's Sportsday, the first daily sports paper in South Africa.

Her appointment was a landmark in South African newspaper history. Wilkinson was the first South African woman to edit a national daily paper, and the almost-simultaneous appointments of Paula Fray to the editorship of the Saturday Star and Lakela Kaunda to the Evening Post (an Eastern Cape paper), meant that a male-dominated industry had three female editors. Wilkinson also made an effort to recruit black staff to her small editorial team. "It was something that I specifically wanted to do, there were lots of young black sportswriters working on bigger papers, but I was able to give them more senior roles."

After six months, the paper folded, because of financial difficulties and the itchy feet of shareholders. Wilkinson was dismayed: "I loved it, it was a very big challenge and I still think it had great editorial." She freelanced for a while before joining the UCB at the beginning of March this year. Her role is a new one, though Chris Day had previously been employed as a consultant, and her department is just that - her . So when the Cronje story broke she was bombarded. "I quite enjoy pressure, but I never, ever thought I'd get pressure like that. One day I took over 465 calls and the demands on my time have been utterly outstanding.

"I said to someone on a radio station that I would like to go back to every police and political spokesperson who I spoke to when I was a reporter, and say that I now realise my call wasn't the only one they had to take. Maybe every journalist should have to work as a spokesperson. I think the fact that I was a journalist helped a lot. I know journalists' requirements. With the Hansie story there were so many rumours I just tried to give out as much information as I could. Hopefully with more facts, there are fewer rumours."

Cricket, the game with bat and ball, was forgotten. "The thing that I really found quite stunning was that from the time the Australian media landed [for the one-day series] up until the first game at Durban, not one journalist asked me a cricket question. Not one had asked me for a possible squad. It was really, really strange. We were about to start what for the South African public and players was an enormous series, but they [the journalists]; were all working flat out on the Hansie story."

Cronje has not been in contact with Wilkinson, his team's nerve centre, for a while. (She hasn't been singled out. Teammates, too, have been given the cold shoulder.) She feels she got to know him quite well, especially during those intense few days before he was sacked. Does she think that the transcripts are true? "I honestly don't know. I haven't heard them. [Though] I don't believe any police force in the world would release anything unless they were pretty sure what they were doing."

Her world has quietened down a little, for now, until the judicial enquiry is announced. Which is good news for her second husband, Chris. They only married in January and within three months he found himself looking after Matthew, now five, whom he is in the process of adopting, while his wife virtually disappeared for three weeks. She is extremely grateful: "In most families that would mean that the five basic food groups would include Kentucky Fried Chicken and McDonalds, but not with Chris, he's been great."

Wilkinson's husband is a financial services consultant, and a former magistrate. A suitable match for an ex-crime reporter. "Our experiences have served us very well in the last couple of weeks," she says wryly. And she intends to use them again. She hopes, eventually, to write a book about the whole Cronje story. So perhaps one day we will learn the real truth, however much the ICC procrastinate.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. The Women's Page returns next Tuesday.

webTitle: Four Weddings star John Hannah slates British film industry

fields.headline: Four Weddings star John Hannah slates British film industry
fields.trailText: In the same week as the Film Council announced an overhaul of domestic film production, actor John Hannah has weighed in to badmouth the British film industry.
fields.body:
In the same week as the Film Council announced an overhaul of domestic film production, actor John Hannah has weighed in to badmouth the British film industry.

Hannah, who will soon be seen in a remake of 70s TV series Mr Benn, said of the cartoon adaptation, "it's a great script - really wonderful. But at the moment it looks like it will be financed out of Britain. Which is unfortunate." The Four Weddings star continued: "anything British with any kind of originality it seems that the financiers get very nervous about In this country there is no money for development, which means that a lot of British movies get made that just aren't ready and don't have a good enough script. People are rushing and don't take enough care."

Cynics might argue that originality is not usually Hannah's top priority: the actor has just picked up £1m for his part in The Mummy 2, and can be seen this week in the irksome Circus, which has been dismissed in many quarters as a rip-off of Lock, Stock

fields.headline: Clintons seek uniform censorship system
fields.trailText: US President Bill Clinton and wife Hillary have suggested a unified system of classification for film, video games and records, in a move designed to help parents control their children's access to a 'pop culture filled with gratuitous sex and violence'.
fields.body:
US President Bill Clinton and wife Hillary have suggested a unified system of classification for film, video games and records, in a move designed to help parents control their children's access to a 'pop culture filled with gratuitous sex and violence'.

Said the President, speaking yesterday at a White House conference about the current confusion of contradictory systems: "I try to sort it all out, but when I see it, it's like you need a dictionary [to do so]."

Legislators are keen to accommodate the first couple's wishes. Former Republican presidential candidate John McCain has now introduced a bill proposing a uniform labelling system for movies, video games and music products.

But the Motion Picture Association of America is resisting the move: "a similar-type bill was overwhelmingly defeated in the House," thundered MPAA chief Jack Valenti, helpfully pointing out that "movies are not cigarettes."

fields.headline: Barca ripped to shreds
fields.standfirst: Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Valencia 4 - 1 Barcelona
fields.body:
A brilliant exhibition of attacking football last night took Valencia to the verge of their first European Cup final and deflated the hopes of their Spanish rivals and tournament favourites Barcelona.

Again Louis van Gaal's team must overcome a large deficit at the Nou Camp next week, this time after conceding three first-half goals and a fourth seconds from the final whistle by Claudio Lopez.

The real damage was done as Valencia scored twice in as many minutes just before the interval through Miguel Angel Angulo and Gaizka Mendieta's penalty. Angulo had also put the hosts ahead after only 10 minutes with a rising drive and the same striker was brought down by Carles Puyol for the spot-kick.

If Valencia needed any reassurance it came in that 10th minute as they made a start reminiscent of their lightning opening against Lazio in the quarter-final. As a cross was only half-cleared, Angulo fired powerfully into the net with Ruud Hesp utterly beaten.

Five minutes later Barcelona's erratic Dutch goalkeeper almost allowed a simple back-pass to roll over the line.

Rivaldo, playing just behind the front trio in Van Gaal's preferred 3-4-3 formation, interrupted Valencia's advances with two powerful shots from the right which just cleared the bar. Barcelona's trademark patient passing brought them back into the game and they equalised after 27 minutes. Boudewijn Zenden delivered a low, tantalising cross which tempted Mauricio Pellegrino to intervene. But the centre-back slid the ball into his own net.

But this was merely the prelude to another Valencia storm. Angulo hit his second, jabbing home Kily Gonzalez's low cross at the near post after 43 minutes. The home celebrations redoubled as Mendieta scored from the spot seconds before the interval.

Valencia's coach Hector Cuper remained cautious. "In football there are always surprises. There are 90 minutes left and I can't afford to be euphoric." Van Gaal said: "I don't believe we're out as there's still one game left. It's very difficult but not impossible."

webTitle: Grant defends beleaguered Bridget Jones star

fields.headline: Grant defends beleaguered Bridget Jones star
fields.trailText: Grant defends beleaguered Bridget Jones star
fields.body:
Fellow actors in the forthcoming adaptation of Helen Fielding's ubiquitous Bridget Jones' Diary have moved to defuse bad feeling surrounding the casting of American starlet Renée Zellweger as the eponymous British heroine.

The British press have been sniffy about the casting, citing Kate Winslet, Helena Bonham-Carter and Emily Watson as actresses who ought to have been preferred for the role. Zellweger has courted further resentment with her high-handed approach to the project, which included, according to reports, refusing to test for the film, on the assumption that she was celebrated enough to be offered the part unseen.

Fielding - who has distanced herself from the film - registered only lukewarm enthusiasm for its star, saying "I've never met Renée, but I'm told she's very funny and learning to speak English with an English rather than
Texas accent."

But Zellweger's co-star Hugh Grant leapt to her defence between the covers of Entertainment Weekly this week. "I've met Renée a couple of times, and she is bang-on," says Grant, demonstrating his mastery of street slang. "She's very funny, and she's been living in England a long time now, mastering the accent. It'll be a triumph. I know it will."

webTitle: Writing couplets in praise of singlets

fields.headline: Writing couplets in praise of singlets
fields.trailText: A writer who composes couplets in praise of singlets was yesterday appointed poet in residence for the Great North Run, Britain's most popular half-marathon.
fields.body:
A writer who composes couplets in praise of singlets was yesterday appointed poet in residence for the Great North Run, Britain's most popular half-marathon.

And while Andy Croft ponders his feet and metres in preparation for this year's event in October, a fellow poet, Clare Pollard, will be cutting and shaping a poem created after a residency last month in a hairdressing salon in Durham.

Both posts are funded by New Writing North, the literary development agency for the north of England.

"Running is a good time for rehearsing ideas in your head," said Mr Croft, who has completed 30 half marathons and plays for a hopeless five-a-side soccer team (Methuselah's Losers) in Middlesbrough.

"There is a terrific rhythm which helps you do the scramble-shuffle of words, ideas and feelings. It's a bit like doing the ironing or decorating - it liberates one side of the brain. You look spaced out, and perhaps you are."

Mr Croft, 43, said that the media tended to concentrate either on the star athletes at the front of the run or those in funny costumes at the back, but there were 40,000 entrants for the 13.1 mile course along the Tyne from Newcastle to South Shields. His aim will be to celebrate the enthusiasts in the middle who train, sweat and try not to give up. "It's about doing it, getting up off the couch and having some pain," he added.

Although he will not be composing during the run (which might destroy his chance of beating his best time of 1 hour 49 mins), Mr Croft, a literary critic and author of 18 football stories, hopes to produce running quotes for T-shirts and the Tyneside metro, a schools poetry pack, and an epic work to mark the day.

"It needs to be a big poem for a big event - something running to several hundred lines. A short poem like a haiku would be bit silly, and I'm long winded by nature."

He hopes the poem will be heard on Radio 3 or used for a film about the 20-year-old run.

Meanwhile, staff at the Toni and Guy salon in Durham are preparing to hear the new poem by Ms Pollard, a Cambridge undergraduate, which will be premiered among the salon's lacquers and lotions on June 3.

"I was really worried about the residency," said Wendy Buttleman, the salon's manager. "I'm not really into poetry at all, but I found it really interesting. She spoke to all the staff and clients and seemed to fit in everywhere. And she helped make the tea, do the laundry and sweep the floor."

fields.headline: Sartre and me
fields.standfirst: The darling of the 60s is this decade's has-been. But is France's famous philosopher and author due for a revival?  Richard Eyre thinks he deserves it
fields.trailText: In this country, Jean-Paul Sartre is as unfashionable as loon pants. So it is hard to imagine a world in which, as Iris Murdoch said after she briefly met Sartre in 1945 in Brussels, "His presence in the city was like that of a pop star. Chico Marx, who was there at about the same time, was less rapturously received."
fields.body:
In this country, Jean-Paul Sartre is as unfashionable as loon pants. So it is hard to imagine a world in which, as Iris Murdoch said after she briefly met Sartre in 1945 in Brussels, "His presence in the city was like that of a pop star. Chico Marx, who was there at about the same time, was less rapturously received."

When I was a student in the 60s, Sartre didn't have poster status - his pipe, glasses and air of bad-temper kept him off walls that celebrated Che, Brigitte Bardot and James Dean - but few student bookshelves lacked a (largely) unread copy of his exegesis of existentialism, the 632 page Being and Nothingness. From the little we (I) read, we understood only what suited us, but, growing up in a world still scarred by global war and haunted by the Holocaust and the Bomb, it was not hard to grasp a philosophy predicated on the absolute absence of God. If we understood Sartre superficially, we understood him sufficiently to corroborate our feelings of confusion about our sexual and political identity. "First of all, man exists," he said, "turns up, appears on the scene, and, only afterwards, defines himself." That seemed to describe our condition pretty accurately, and his argument for the reality of "nothingness" hit the mark as far as student life was concerned.

Although Sartre's philosophy remained more talked about than read, his novels were popular (Roads to Freedom was serialised by the BBC) and his plays were much performed. In fact, it was practically a legal obligation in the 60s for student drama groups to perform Huis Clos. The play is a philosophical game, written in response to three actors who asked Sartre for a piece in which all the characters would have equal status, the same number of lines, and remain onstage throughout the action. (What is it about French theatre? Cocteau wrote The Eagle Has Two Heads for the actor Jean Marais, who told him, "I want to do three things in a play - I want to be silent in the first act, I want to cry with joy in the second, and I want to come down a long staircase in the third.")

Sartre was attracted to the theatre (and fiction) because theatre thrives on metaphor - a room becomes a world, a group of characters becomes a whole society - so plays tend to be about how we live and why we live. In the theatre Sartre was obliged to characterise and animate his philosophical and political propositions, test theory against flesh and blood. And he was obliged to condense and distil his ideas. "The metaphysician who could not say anything unless he said everything was compelled in the theatre to give his message briefly," said Iris Murdoch, "and as Sartre unfortunately could not do everything, as opposed to thinking everything, he found the theatre, where he had undoubted talent, a sympathetic place to drop into." What's more, Sartre liked the fact that theatre happens in the present tense: "You can't write a play without urgency in it," he said, "and this urgency comes back to you because it is felt by the audience."

I appeared in two of Sartre's plays as a student actor, and I became familiar with all of them. In time they became theatrically extinct, but fashion in the theatre is as cyclical as in music, even if the cycles recur more slowly. Around the time that we had a success with Cocteau's Les Parents Terribles at the National, our then literary manager, Giles Croft, scratched an itch in my memory by suggesting that I look at Les Mains Sales (Dirty Hands). It is a noirish political thriller, set in a fictional east European country ("Illyria") in the dying days of the second world war. A young man is commissioned by a revolutionary Socialist Party to assassinate the leader of a rival faction, who is held to be diluting the party's principles by forming a coalition government with liberal and right wing parties. The play was better than I remembered it from the 60s: perhaps the distance of history and the collapse of communism made its concerns resonate more strongly. But it didn't demand to be performed and I forgot about the play until several years later.

Two years ago I spent the greater part of the year on a film which was never made. This is a familiar condition for anyone who flirts with the film industry, but the involvement of Glenn Close and Meryl Streep seemed a reasonable assurance of a green light at the end of the tunnel. When the film was cancelled I found myself with a continent of unexplored time, and at Jonathan Kent's suggestion I looked again at Les Mains Sales. My re-reading of the play coincided with the peace negotiations in Northern Ireland and with rancorous bickering between Old and New Labour. "Principle", "pragmatism" and "power-sharing" were words that rained down from all directions, while the metaphor of "dirty hands" was invoked on a daily basis. It seemed that perhaps Sartre's play was a play for today.

Les Mains Sales was first performed in 1948, and was widely interpreted as an attack on communism. While Sartre clearly intended to indict the unscrupulousness of the communist party, it is part of the virtue of the play that the "attack" is equivocal. Infuriated that his play was being used to castigate the left, he forbade further performances in 1952. Partly it was the debate between means and ends, purity and opportunism that attracted me to the play, but it was just as much its exploration of class, of sex, and of growing up. Like Hamlet, Hugo, the play's protagonist, grows up to grow dead. In making my version of the play, I've filtered Sartre's play through my own sensibility: the title of The Novice reflects my view that the play is as much about innocence as about belief and expediency.

Sartre has become an unfashionable playwright, a largely unread novelist, and is scorned as a misogynist: Angela Carter once commented, "There is one question that every thinking woman in the western world must have asked herself at one time or another. Why is a nice girl like Simone de Beauvoir sucking up to a boring old fart like Jean-Paul Sartre?" The old fart may be regarded as irrelevant as a philosopher, but for me his concern with our disposition to evade responsibility and to lie to ourselves - our "bad faith" - is as active a notion as when I first came across it. And in an age when we appear to believe nothing except celebrity, I can't think that a writer who says that we define man only in relation to his commitments is entirely redundant.

Just before Christmas of last year, I arrived in Paris on the Eurostar. To my astonishment, the magazine kiosks were plastered with photographs of Sartre. The pop philosopher Bernard Henri-Levy - a cross between Michael Ignatieff and Bob Geldof - had pronounced that Sartre had been resurrected as man and philosopher. Recently, I have heard that there is to be a Place Sartre-De Beauvoir near his favourite cafe, Les Deux Magots. What is more, Richard Attenborough is said to be making a film about De Beauvoir's affair with Nelson Algren. Is it Anthony Hopkins, Dustin Hoffman or Brad Pitt for Sartre? Oh yes, and they are doing a play by him at the Almeida.

The Novice starts previewing at the Almeida, London N1 (020-7359 4404), tomorrow.

webTitle: British war veterans condemn Hollywood's revisionist history

fields.headline: British war veterans condemn Hollywood's revisionist history
fields.trailText: British second world war veterans are enraged by Hollywood plans to remake the 1955 film of Pat Reid's book, with Americans in the leading roles
fields.body:
British second world war veterans are enraged by Hollywood plans to remake the 1955 film of Pat Reid's book, The Colditz Story (see our 14 April news story). 'Americans couldn't break out of Colditz', ran the headline in yesterday's Independent, 'but they've escaped with the screen rights' - in yet another example of the US entertainment industry rewriting the conflict to embellish its own role in its resolution.

The new version, to which Miramax have recently acquired the rights, is to star Tom Cruise, Ben Affleck and Matt Damon as US prisoners attempting to escape from the notorious prison - despite the fact that no US servicemen were at the camp when those attempts took place.

Kenneth Lockwood, 88, secretary of the Colditz Association, who spent over four years at the prison, said he was 'a bit nervous' about the new film. "I wish they wouldn't do it. If they show Americans leading the escape from Colditz I'm inclined to laugh... I disapprove strongly of rewriting history. Usually they've got a good story in its own right and it doesn't need any dressing up because the facts are more interesting and exciting than fiction.

"Previous evidence of American film-making of war stories is not all that good", Lockwood adds. "I mean, they had Errol Flynn winning the war in Burma when there was no American involved in that operation at all." Similarly, The Great Escape starred US star Steve McQueen in a film that should have been about Britons tunnelling free from a German camp; while Spielberg's Saving Private Ryan saw the US take on the Germans single-handedly on D-Day.

The latest offender is the submarine drama and current US chart-topper U-571, which shows the Americans, and not the Brits, capturing the Germans' Enigma decoding device.

Lockwood condemns the film as "a distortion of history. They should be more responsible. Money - that's all it's about. It's about how much they can get."

webTitle: London and Frankfurt stock exchanges to merge

fields.headline: London and Frankfurt stock exchanges to merge
fields.standfirst: Follow the FTSE100 on Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The London and Frankfurt stock exchanges have agreed to merge, creating Europe's largest stock market and a powerful regional counterweight to Wall Street, the London Stock Exchange announced today.
fields.body:
The London and Frankfurt stock exchanges have agreed to merge, creating Europe's largest stock market and a powerful regional counterweight to Wall Street, the London Stock Exchange announced today.

The London exchange and Germany's Deutsche Boerse would each own 50% of the new entity, which is to be called iX, for International Exchanges. Its headquarters are to be in London.

Under the merger agreement, shares in blue chip companies would be traded in London, while shares in high-tech firms would be traded in Frankfurt, the London Stock Exchange announced.

The Anglo-German union includes a formal cooperation agreement with the technology-heavy US Nasdaq market. The London exchange did not give specifics on this linkup with Nasdaq but said it did not involve mutual ownership.

The merger brings to a climax two years of fitful efforts by the London and Frankfurt exchanges to combine. They began trying in 1998 to form the hub of a pan-European stock market and later enlarged their plan to include six other national stock markets.

The ambitious effort foundered when London and Frankfurt apparently failed to agree over issues of ownership and the type of trading platform to be used in a regional exchange.

The two exchanges have resolved their differences over technology by adopting Frankfurt's Xetra trading platform, the London exchange said.

The head of the Deutsche Boerse, Werner Seifert, is to become chief executive while chairman of the London Stock Exchange, Donald Cruickshank, would become chairman of the merged stock market.

webTitle: Grand Prix star escapes jet crash

fields.headline: Grand Prix star escapes jet crash
fields.standfirst: Delights and dangers of the high life
fields.trailText: British racing driver David Coulthard yesterday walked away from the mangled wreckage of a burning plane after a private jet he was on board crashed, killing two people.
fields.body:
British racing driver David Coulthard yesterday walked away from the mangled wreckage of a burning plane after a private jet he was on board crashed, killing two people.

The pilot and co-pilot of the Learjet, named last night as David Saunders and Dan Worley, died after attempting an emergency landing at Lyon airport in France. Coulthard, 29, his fiancee, Heidi Wichlinski, and his trainer, Andrew Matthews, had an extraordinary escape, suffering only slight injuries.

Coulthard left hospital after tests and was planning to race in this Sunday's Spanish Grand Prix in Barcelona.

The chartered jet, owned by the chairman of Rangers football club, David Murray, took off at lunchtime from Farnborough airfield in Hampshire en route to Nice in the south of France. At 1.30pm British time, the jet touched down on one of the two runways at Lyon Satolas airport after the pilot had radioed saying he needed to make an emergency landing because of engine trouble.

An eyewitness said the plane was on fire as it approached the airport. It's wing tip hit the ground and the jet somersaulted, ripping off the cockpit. Then, said the eyewitness, there was an explosion. The three passengers scrambled out of a rear cabin window as the flames took hold.

Airport director Bernard Chaffange said: "The plane was on fire at the hind part of the passenger cabin. The fore part of the cabin was totally destroyed.

"They managed to get out of the plane themselves immediately after the crash and were picked up in an ambulance and taken to hospital for a check-up."

Mr Worley lived in Glossop, Derbyshire. He has a one-year-old daughter Johana and his wife, Ann, is expecting a second baby.

Last night, Scottish-born Coulthard was believed to be recovering at his home in Monaco. He is in second place in the Formula One championship after winning the British Grand Prix 10 days ago.

In a statement released through McLaren, the team he races for, Coulthard said: "Obviously I'm relieved that Heidi, Andy and myself are unhurt, but I would like to express my deepest sympathies for the families of the two pilots.

"It is inappropriate for me to go into details of the accident, but we were lucky to walk away."

His manager, Iain Cunningham, said he expected the driver to race on Sunday. "He would only stop if he had been injured and could not get over it. I don't think that is what has happened."

An investigation, led by French authorities, is under way. Because the jet was registered in the UK, the Air Accident Investigation Branch dispatched two staff to the scene.

The Learjet has two engines made by the US firm Garrett and has become the plane of choice for wealthy movie stars and businessmen.

David Learmount, of Flight International magazine, said: "If you had problems with an engine, if you shut it down, you would have zero problems flying the plane.

"This was not a simple engine failure."

In October 1999, US golfer Payne Stewart died after the Learjet he was on was believed to have suffered a catastrophic decompression. It flew out of control for 1,500 miles at 45,000ft before crashing.

fields.headline: From bard to worse
fields.standfirst: Celebrity brainbox Carol Vorderman explains away her slim grasp of Shakespeare's works by pronouncing him "dull as ditchwater". But she's not the only one who doesn't know her Ophelia from her Othello. As the bard slips off the syllabus,  John Sutherland  asks why his stock is sinking, while Michael Billington offers you the chance to show off your Shakespeare, just like Carol
fields.trailText: Celebrity brainbox Carol Vorderman explains away her slim grasp of Shakespeare's works by pronouncing him "dull as ditchwater". But she's not the only one who doesn't know her Ophelia from her Othello. As the bard slips off the syllabus, John Sutherland asks why his stock is sinking
fields.body:
Carol Vorderman, alas, failed her £1m (or £250,000, to be exact) test. But she can console herself with the thought that her performance on a celebrity version of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire on Monday night at least enhanced her celebrity. For long after this infuriatingly gimmicky programme is buried, Vorderman will have earned eternal fame in the dictionary of great philistinism with Henry Ford ("History is bunk"), Kingsley Amis ("Filthy Mozart") and Bobby Fischer ("Girls are a waste of time").

Explaining afterwards her failure to recognise Sir Toby Belch as a character from Twelfth Night, Vorderman declared she found the work of William Shakespeare "dull as ditchwater". Is it? One has to make allowance for pique. (And why, I've sometimes wondered, is ditchwater considered all that dull - duller, say, than tap water, Grolsch, or three-day-old Nescafe?) And, of course, you would have to know Shakespeare's plays to know he was duller than Oscar Wilde or Andrew Lloyd Webber.

But it was such an easy question; all over the country viewers must have been yelling the answer at their screen. As a test of literary knowledge it was only one up from "Is Hamlet a place or a prince?", "Who kills Desdemona?" or "Is Henry V a war criminal?" (OK, I'll come clean: the last is the title of my latest book.)

It would be nice to think that Vorderman - who is to all appearances a well-educated woman by the standards of the day - might have been getting in a feminist smack against one of Shakespeare's men behaving badly. Belch, as his name indicates, really is a pig; Shakespeare could as well have called him Fart. But you would have to be very feminist to risk the derision of a nation to make such a point.

For the observer of cultural drift and change, Vorderman's anti-Shakespeareanism is sadly symptomatic. She is a child of the time (from which play is that a quote, Guardian reader?). The bard's stock is sinking.

It is now possible to get a degree in English in the US and Britain without having studied a single play by Shakespeare (in my department, I'm happy to say, you won't graduate unless you know all 39 well enough to take a six-hour exam on them - but we're very old-fashioned).

It's difficult to find a British A-level board that will let you do English without knowing at least one Shakespeare text inside out but, with persistence, you can do it. And with the new half A-levels coming along ("A/S", they're called) you'll certainly be able to detour round the bard.

It's a threshold moment in the subject. In the US, if you skim through the college catalogues, you'll see that the author who has replaced Shakespeare at the centre of the curriculum is Toni Morrison.

I don't know, but I suspect that if Vorderman had been asked "In what novel does Paul D feature?", she would have known the answer without thinking twice ("Beloved!") and gone home with her barrow-load of money (all for charity, of course). And who would dare say, in this day and age, "Toni Morrison is crap"?

Why do we deify Shakespeare? Why is he what Matthew Arnold called our "touchstone" - the gold standard of literary excellence? The answer that would have been given 100 years ago is that his works are a fountain of great truth about the human condition. "To be, or not to be?" - what thinking person has not pondered the question? "Plate sin with gold, and the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks": true at all times, in all places. "This above all else, to thine own self be true": as good advice now as it was 400 years ago.

The argument was revived two years ago by Harold Bloom, who argued in Shakespeare: The Invention of the Human that before Shakespeare came along we weren't homo sapiens. He gave us the equipment with which to understand ourselves and to become ourselves. Bloom's book was a bestseller. But it was, surely, a ludicrous proposition. Would Chaucer, for instance, have been a more human writer had he read the 39 plays?

Our defence of Shakespeare would, I think, be more modest. He wrote such wonderful English. No one has ever done such beautiful things with our beautiful language.

Just published and being reviewed at the moment is a book by this country's most distinguished living literary critic, Frank Kermode. As I understand it, Kermode's line in Shakespeare's Language is eminently commonsensical. He eschews the currently fashionable admiration for the complicated expression of some of the late plays (glance at the opening speech of Measure for Measure to see how complicated Shakespeare can be) and locates the greatness of Shakespeare in the limpid English of the dramatist's middle period. The best Shakespeare is the Shakespeare we understand best.

The evidence from the classroom, meanwhile, carries both dispiriting and encouraging messages for those of us who care whether others care about the bard. I've been teaching Shakespeare for 30 years. Students, of course, make the same kinds of howler that they always have and always will. They'll talk about Macbeth's "unforgettable line, 'Is this a knife I see before me'", or write, as one did recently for me, "Ophelia approaches Hamlet, in spite of his railings". Nowadays it's an unusual school leaver who knows more than the two plays set for A-level.

But in many ways today's undergraduates see things that their predecessors didn't - and which, frankly, I didn't see until quite recently. It was, for example, a woman student who pointed out to me the interesting fact that Portia, at the end of The Merchant of Venice, has been married for three days and is still a virgin (women notice these things). Gender, Race and Queer Theory have unlocked aspects of Shakespeare which speak to us and our time. Lisa Jardine's probings about Cordelia's mother (and mothers in general in Shakespeare) create an entirely new - and for my money, exciting - Lear. After the Holocaust, The Merchant of Venice is a much more problematic "comedy" than it ever was for Coleridge; as is Othello after Stephen Lawrence. And it is our generation, and notably its youngest echelon of critics, who have explored the gay Shakespeare (why is Portia still a virgin? Because, plausibly, Bassanio is really in love with Antonio). The miracle of Shakespeare is that, as Jan Kott once put it, he is always our contemporary.

Shakespeare, it has to be said, can be deadly dull. It's not his fault, but ours. Four hundred years ago the ear of the English populace was an organ trained by obligatory attendance at church, where you would listen, willy nilly, to two-hour sermons. They were world-class listeners, the Elizabethans and Jacobeans. Our ears, trained by three-minute MTV clips, short-burst cellphone conversations and Harold Pinter's silences can't handle long Shakespearean periods. By the end of the speech (and sometimes the sentence) we've forgotten the beginning. Which is why, if truth be told, most of us get much more out of reading his plays than watching them in the theatre (particularly if, as in the Globe shrine-theatre on the South Bank, you have to stand three hours in the drizzle).

But, 400 years on, no one is going to be watching reruns of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? Will they still be reading Toni Morrison? Perhaps. Will they still be performing Shakespeare, and studying him? Nothing is more certain.

John Sutherland is professor of English at University College London and author of Is Henry V a War Criminal? published this week by OUP at £4.99.

Know your Shakespeare? Take the Billington test

Be warned - in the style of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire, the questions increase in difficulty.

1: What is the name of the giggling, do-it-yourself, gentlewoman-joker in Twelfth Night?

a Carol Vorderman

b Carol Smillie

c Denise Welch

d Maria

2: Which Broadway musical is based on The Comedy of Errors?

a Kiss Me Kate

b West Side Story

c The Boys from Syracuse

d A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum

3: Who says, in Henry VI Part 2, "let's kill all the lawyers"?

a Benedick

b Dick the Butcher

c Dick the Shepherd

d Dick Whittington

4: "How oft when men are at the point of death have they been merry." Who is speaking?

a Romeo

b King Lear

c Falstaff

d Frank Dobson

5: Who bragged of "stuffing the ears of men with false reports?"

a Cleopatra

b Lady Macbeth

c Rumour

d Alastair Campbell

6: Who of the following has never played Hamlet?

a Sarah Bernhardt

b Frances de la Tour

c Angela Winkler

d Vanessa Redgrave

7: What in Shakespeare is meant by the "bed-trick"?

a Sleeping with the enemy

b Sleeping three to a bed

c Sleeping with someone in the guise of another person

d Sleeping toe-to-head

8: Who tried to convert the Mayor of London to his party?

a Richard II

b Richard, Duke of Gloucester

c Henry IV

d Tony Blair

9: Who puts out Gloucester's eyes in King Lear?

a The Duke of Albany

b The Duke of Cornwall

c The Duke of Argyll

d The Duchess of Westminster

10: Which politician quoted Ulysses' speech on "degree" in Troilus and Cressida to Conservative Way Forward to prove that Shakespeare was a Tory?

a William Hague

b John Redwood

c Michael Portillo

d Margaret Thatcher

Answers: 1 (d), 2 (c), 3 (b), 4 (a), 5 (c), 6 (d), 7 (c), 8 (b), 9 (b), 10 (c). Score one for the first question, two for the second and so on up to 10. Fewer than 10 points: You're eminently qualified to be a TV presenter; 10-45 points: You are a good Shakespearean; 46-55 points: A professorship is yours for the asking.

webTitle: Seabed cracks threaten tidal wave in Atlantic

fields.headline: Seabed cracks threaten tidal wave in Atlantic
fields.trailText: US scientists have discovered cracks at the bottom of the North Atlantic which they believe may augur an underwater landslide, sending tidal waves more than 20ft high towards North Carolina, Virginia and the US capital, Washington.
fields.body:
US scientists have discovered cracks at the bottom of the North Atlantic which they believe may augur an underwater landslide, sending tidal waves more than 20ft high towards North Carolina, Virginia and the US capital, Washington.

The cracks were found about 80 miles east of Chesapeake Bay, a popular weekend resort for Washingtonians.

Their existence and potential for disaster were reported in the May edition of the journal Geology, but the scientists who came across them said that they were unsure how old the fissures were.

"These cracks, together with evidence of past landslides in the same area, indicate that the sea floor could slump, or slide downhill like an avalanche, triggering the waves," said Neal Driscoll, a scientist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and one of the authors of the report.

A team of oceanographers and geologists is scheduled to mount an expedition to the site on Saturday to explore the cracks.

They will use sonar equipment to determine the urgency of the threat.

Underwater landslides, in which large chunks of the seabed fall into fissures, can be triggered by changing water temperatures and the sudden release of methane gas frozen within the ocean floor.

Such a landslide in the Grand Banks under the North Atlantic sent a 40ft tidal wave washing over the Newfoundland coast in 1929, killing 51 people.

Another huge wave, also known as a tsunami, hit Papua New Guinea in 1998, causing 2,000 deaths.

Mr Driscoll, one of the scientists who identified the cracks, said that people living along the US eastern seaboard had become accustomed to hurricanes but had little experience of tidal waves, which could be just as devastating.

"Virginia, North Carolina and the lower Chesapeake Bay would be most at risk," he said.

fields.bodyText: US scientists have discovered cracks at the bottom of the North Atlantic which they believe may augur an underwater landslide, sending tidal waves more than 20ft high towards North Carolina, Virginia and the US capital, Washington. The cracks were found about 80 miles east of Chesapeake Bay, a popular weekend resort for Washingtonians. Their existence and potential for disaster were reported in the May edition of the journal Geology, but the scientists who came across them said that they were unsure how old the fissures were. "These cracks, together with evidence of past landslides in the same area, indicate that the sea floor could slump, or slide downhill like an avalanche, triggering the waves," said Neal Driscoll, a scientist at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and one of the authors of the report. A team of oceanographers and geologists is scheduled to mount an expedition to the site on Saturday to explore the cracks. They will use sonar equipment to determine the urgency of the threat. Underwater landslides, in which large chunks of the seabed fall into fissures, can be triggered by changing water temperatures and the sudden release of methane gas frozen within the ocean floor.
