fields.headline: A place in the Sun
fields.standfirst:
Too high a price can be paid for it

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The next election is a year or more away, but the campaign has already begun. The struggle is on for the hearts and minds of the British electorate. More immediately, though, the struggle is on for the hearts and minds of the tabloid newspapers.
fields.body:
The next election is a year or more away, but the campaign has already begun. The government keeps coming up with sweeteners for groups whose allegiance it covets; the Conservatives are fashioning themes to enthuse the faithful while luring those who defected last time back to the fold. The struggle is on for the hearts and minds of the British electorate. More immediately, though, the struggle is on for the hearts and minds of the tabloid newspapers.

William Hague's response to the Tony Martin case, following closely on his assaults on "bogus" asylum seekers, has delighted the paper which, both because of its circulation and because of its politically uncommitted readership, matters most to the party leaders: the Sun. Never able to come to terms with the fall of Margaret Thatcher, it finally went off John Major not long after Black Wednesday and has rarely had much time for the Tories since.

Mr Major's attempts to woo it back in time for the last election were repulsed with contempt. Yet over the past few days, it has written about the Tories with glowing enthusiasm. And no wonder; for Mr Hague has started talking Sun language. There can be no more convenient tactic for getting the Sun on your side than saying exactly what it tells you to say: and that is what Mr Hague is now doing.

It is carefully not abandoning Tony Blair - yet. But he is on probation. A front page leader on Monday, under the heading Mayday, Mayday, said the government was in crisis over Rover, the NHS, asylum seekers and law and order. The economy apart, Mr Blair was in trouble. He had failed to fulfil expectations. People were feeling let down. Meanwhile - "as the Sun was the first to point out" - Mr Hague was maturing into a credible threat to Blair. "We live in interesting times," it concluded.

The Sun has always been hugely important to Mr Blair. As Hugo Young reported three years ago: "The day before the election I interviewed Mr Blair . . . nobody, he vigorously insisted, should underestimate the matchless importance to his victory of the endorsement he received on the first day of the campaign from the Sun."

So anxious was he to gain the favours of the paper which had savaged Neil Kinnock in 1992 that he was not ashamed to grovel. Since the Sun remained vehemently anti-Europe, he began to represent himself as a Euro-sceptic. A piece appeared under his name headed "Why I love the pound". Another, published in English editions only, expressed his pride in St George's Day.

The Sun's May Day blast has put him back in a similar posture. Yesterday, it published his 975-word riposte. Mr Blair, it boasted, had given up his bank holiday to pen a defence of himself against the paper's indictment. It had even been supplied with Mr Blair's handwritten text-proof that this job was too important to be left even to Alastair Campbell. In saying the government had done nothing except to create a strong economy, the Sun, the PM complained, had been "more than a little unfair". How they must have cringed at Wapping in the face of such a stinging rebuke.

That Mr Blair should feel the need to respond to a newspaper blast with such querulous urgency demeans both him and his office. It is also inept. In politics, as in war and in sport, it is always a fatal mistake to let the enemy see you are scared. What Mr Blair did on bank holiday Monday suggests a political leader frightened both of the Sun and of the Tories. The Sun summed it up with the single word headline: "Rattled". That is clearly the case. But he ought to have hidden it from the world.

fields.headline: End of the world
fields.standfirst:
Just why did a group of film buffs converge on a remote Scottish hotel last weekend? A clue: it might have involved a spot of witchcraft and human sacrifice. Elisabeth Mahoney on the return of the dreaded Wicker Man
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Just why did a group of film buffs converge on a remote Scottish hotel last weekend? A clue: it might have involved a spot of witchcraft and human sacrifice. Elisabeth Mahoney on the return of the dreaded Wicker Man
fields.body:
'You wouldn't want to be around here on May Day, not the way you feel", says Willow (Britt Ekland) to Detective Howie ( Edward Woodward) in The Wicker Man. She means on Summerisle, the film's imaginary Scottish island, where pagan-hedonism is the way of things and especially so on May Day. If strip-me-Willow's welcome to the officer of the law in her father's hostelry is to dance a naked dance of erotic possession singing "Heigh Ho! I am here" through the walls, you can imagine what this frisky community might get up to on the high day of their Phallus-luvin' religion. It doesn't, needless to say, involve a trip to B&Q.

Ah yes, the DIY superstore - how I'm longing to be transported there, magically, as I step into the bar of The Ellangowan Hotel in Creetown, near Dumfries, at the start of the May Day Bank Holiday weekend. I'm here to meet the participants on a Wicker Man weekend, a film fans' convention being held at what was the location for the interior of the Green Man pub in the film. Worryingly, given the film's subject matter (human sacrifice, orgies in graveyards, putting frogs in your mouth to cure a sore throat) the term "re-enactment" has been used in pre-publicity for the event and I'm assured of a group sing-a-long around a bonfire at the very least. I'll be the only person in the throng of over a hundred fans not to know all the words, and the film doesn't exactly portray a welcoming attitude to outsiders (the Summerisle gang burn theirs to death).

In fact I needn't have worried. Less a gang than a committed huddle, Wicker's World in Creetown extends to a handful rather than tens of fans, and there are song-sheets too. The nerdy, geeky excess I was dreading is largely absent, and the whole affair is a bit like waiting for a delayed train, but with a good crowd. You might only have one thing in common, but it's amazing how long you can stretch it out for. In the Ellengowan's bar, we notch up 10 hours of Wicker chat: we discuss nothing else, and there's a temptation to throw in a wild topic ("what will Tony and Cherie call the baby?") just to see how they cope.

Instead, I sit and absorb Wicker things. What I presume to be a happy, idyllic world of shared interest turns out to be just like any other, with in-fighting as rife among Wicker Man fans as in any fan base. I've heard about Trekkie tantrums and Dr Who spats, but I'm shocked to hear of running battles between authors and editors, one fan and another, given that the world of the film is so free from the cynical constraints of capitalism. Ingrid Pitt, one of the film's stars, won't do a book about it, she has said, because "there's too much Mafia involvement". The disputes here are on a smaller scale but we have to keep certain parties apart lest Wicker Wars begin - not easy over a small round table when you're all sharing crisps. "Some of the bollocks that's going on," says one fan, Peter, "it's mad."

The pub, however, doesn't even pretend to be free of such vulgar considerations as hard cash. Despite flogging its Wicker connections, when push comes to shove (10 fans versus the rest of a busy bar on a holiday weekend), we're left out in the chill of nerd-dom. Yes we can watch the director's cut of the film, but only with the sound turned down and the jukebox turned right up (if you know the film and the song, imagine Britt's scene with a Steps soundtrack). Gone is the older daytime crowd with their stories about what Edward Woodward was really like or just how many catering vans stood outside - now no one wants to talk Wicker except at our table.

The people around me, however, are mainly bright, intelligent and - well, it has to be said - normal people. The guys seem to be here for a fairly relaxed swapping of tales (like the one about John, the organiser, and Peter, travelling to the Summer Isles thinking the place really existed, only to find a barren, craggy place. "We had a terrible journey back, fighting and everything", recalls Peter) and the display of Wicker World kudos. But I'm intrigued to find two young women, Emma and Louise, here, especially as they talk about other things and don't flood me with their fan credentials. "You come to find out things about things you like, but it's also just a weekend away somewhere nice", says 22-year-old Emma after our first location visit to the, um, baker's oven (don't remember it? maybe you blinked). "And", she adds, like she's suddenly solved the mystery, "it's not Magaluf, is it?"

There is a screening of The Wicker Man at the National Film Theatre this evening, followed by a discussion with members of the cast and crew. Details: 020 7928 3232

fields.headline: Banks block Rover rescue
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The eleventh hour rescue bid for Rover proposed by John Towers's Phoenix consortium is being frustrated by the refusal of any British high street bank to grant a £200m overdraft facility.
fields.byline: Paul Murphy, Mark Milner  and Kevin Maguire
fields.body:
The eleventh hour rescue bid for Rover proposed by John Towers's Phoenix consortium is being frustrated by the refusal of any British high street bank to grant a £200m overdraft facility.

With some 24,000 Midlands jobs at risk, the consortium is now understood to have turned to North America in search of financial support, holding emergency talks with US and Canadian banks.

The intransigence of the British banks, including HSBC, Barclays, NatWest and Lloyds, has astonished the Towers camp and sparked a fresh volley of accusations over the conduct of trade secretary Stephen Byers. He has made personal pleas to several potential lenders for support, but has been rebuffed.

While the banks declined to comment yesterday, one Towers aide claimed that Mr Byers's intervention had actually led to the breakdown of discussions. "Relations just died. It was extraordinary," he said.

BMW warned last week that unless it could find a buyer for Rover by the end of the month it would close Rover's Longbridge plant.

All the high street lenders have carried out studies on the impact of Longbridge's closure on their own banking business in the region, given the inevitable carnage amongst hundreds of small Midlands businesses and the financial damage to many thousands of individual customers.

It has been pointed out that while granting an overdraft facility to Phoenix would be a risky proposition for any lender, the net effect for a big British bank, given the jobs and businesses safeguarded, would be substantially reduced.

Mr Towers, a former chief executive of Rover, met BMW executive director Hagen Lüderitz in London yesterday for talks which were described as "very detailed and positive". A BMW spokesman said his group agreed with Mr Towers's summary of the talks and said that a further meeting had been agreed.

Under the advice of accountants Deloitte & Touche, the Phoenix plan is understood to rely on a £400m up-front payment from BMW, together with redundancies being paid for by the German car manufacturer.

Additional working capital would be raised through the sale of existing unsold Rover stock - the value of which is put at "hundreds of millions."

Though the government is prepared to provide support for the Phoenix bid there is no provision for any government funding or debt guarantees in the business plan, with the Towers camp resigned to the fact that any such help would fall foul of the European authorities.

But on the assumption that Longbridge will remain lossmaking for a further three years, the Phoenix consortium needs an estimated £200m overdraft facility to run the business once the initial cash injection is exhausted.

BMW played down reports that venture capitalists Alchemy Partners had sought to reopen negotiations after the abrupt collapse of its deal to takeover Longbridge late on Thursday.

Having been ground down by the weeks of politicking, Alchemey boss John Moulton's patience is said to have finally snapped over BMW's refusal to pick up the pension liability for sacked Rover workers.

Mr Moulton is thought to have received a frosty response from Birmingham city council when seeking indicative planning approval to redevelop land at Longbridge.

Yesterday there were reports that Alchemy had contacted BMW to outline the terms under which it was prepared to resume talks, but BMW said: "We have finished our talks with Alchemy. We don't see any reason to reopen them."

BMW also denied there was any pressure on the group's chairman, Professor Joachim Milberg, to resign. Unions representing workers at the Longbridge plant have been publicly backing the Phoenix plan since it was first launched since it held out the prospect of maintaining volume car production in the Midlands.

But privately union leaders remain dubious about Mr Towers's chances of success, concerned at the lack of news on funding. "We are still sceptical about the Towers bid. A lot of workers think he is going to rescue them," one senior of ficer said.

"The fear is they have been led up the garden path and the consortium hasn't got the money.

"If the backers are in place he should reveal them. Not even Downing Street knows who they are."

But Sir Ken Jackson, head of the AEEU engineering union, said: "The signs are that BMW are serious about talking with Phoenix. The atmosphere is definitely different to last week. It's up to Phoenix to demonstrate to BMW that they have the cash."

webTitle: Freeman gets radio 'Oscar' for 40 years of broadcasting

fields.headline: Freeman gets radio 'Oscar' for 40 years of broadcasting
fields.standfirst: Sony Radio Awards
fields.trailText: The veteran DJ Alan Freeman last night braved severe arthritis to collect a lifetime achievement award at the radio industry "Oscars". Freeman, 72, struggled on to the stage at the Grosvenor House hotel in London, with the aid of a zimmer frame, to collect the Sony award in recognition of his 40 years in broadcasting.
fields.body:
The veteran DJ Alan Freeman last night braved severe arthritis to collect a lifetime achievement award at the radio industry "Oscars". Freeman, 72, struggled on to the stage at the Grosvenor House hotel in London, with the aid of a zimmer frame, to collect the Sony award in recognition of his 40 years in broadcasting.

The former BBC Radio 1 DJ, now a presenter on Radio 2, thanked the Radio Academy, which conferred the accolade. He said: "I'm glad I lived to get it."

He received a standing ovation from the audience, which included the culture secretary, Chris Smith, the BBC director general Greg Dyke, and senior broadcasting figures.

Mr Smith, a guest presenter, had to endure abuse from the artist Tracey Emin, who was also there as as guest. The culture secretary tried to ignore her shouts by saying: "It's nice to be here despite the heckling."

Mr Smith presented the station of the year title to Roger Lewis of Classic FM, who said: "This represents accumulative efforts of a remarkable group of people.

"We have 10m listeners a month, which is unprecedented for classical music. This is pure reward."

The culture secretary also presented the Sony gold award to Ralph Bernard, chief executive of Classic FM, who has been in the radio industry for a quarter of a century.

Mr Bernard said: "To achieve something like this after so long in the industry must be something which everybody dreams about."

The BBC, however, swept the board, with 17 out of a possible 24 awards. The biggest upset of the evening came when the breakfast programme at Kiss 100, the London dance music station, beat Radio 1's Zoe Ball to the title of best morning music programme.

Pete Tong won the broadcaster of the year award, while Roger Phillips of BBC Radio Merseyside beat John Humphrys and Andrew Neil to the news broadcaster of the year award.

There was controversy when the TV presenter Jonathan Ross made a tasteless joke about disabled people. He was booed and heckled by members of the audience.

Event award: The Open (Radio 5 Live);
sports award: Super Sunday (GLR);
news award: Late Night Live, Soho Bomb (Radio 5 Live);
speech award: The Evacuation, The True Story (Radio 4);
comedy award: Blue Jam (Radio 1);
short form award: Woman's Hour Inserts (Radio 4);
drama award: Plum's War (Radio 4);
music presentation award (stations with an audience of 500,000 to 12m): Bam Bam Breakfast (Kiss 100);
music presentation award (stations with a UK audience): Jonathan Ross Show (Radio 2).

fields.headline: Blair vents outrage at rioters
fields.standfirst:
PM calls on families and friends to name and shame the culprits

May 2K: special report
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday led a chorus of political outrage against rioters who damaged shops and defaced national monuments in Whitehall during the May day anti-capitalism demonstrations - and called on friends and family of the culprits to identify their photographs.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday led a chorus of political outrage against rioters who damaged shops and defaced national monuments in Whitehall during the May day anti-capitalism demonstrations - and called on friends and family of the culprits to identify their photographs.

As the inquest into police tactics got under way, Ken Livingstone's main rivals in the fight to become London's first elected mayor seized on the confrontation to highlight his own ambiguous attitude towards the use of direct action in politics.

In the Commons home secretary Jack Straw defended the non-confrontational tactics deployed by the Metropolitan police. He said two official agencies responsible for the Cenotaph and Sir Winston Churchill's statue - both daubed by the protesters - had declined to board them up.

But though the Royal Parks Agency admitted it had rejected advice to board up statues in Parliament Square, English Heritage claimed the Metropolitan police had advised it not to board up the Cenotaph. It complained that no extra police had been provided to protect the monument despite assurances that they would.

Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, condemned Monday's violent disruption of what had been billed as a peaceful demonstration by "guerilla gardeners." Twelve people were still in hospital yesterday, almost 100 were arrested and the likely bill put at £500,000.

Downing St and the Home Office appeared reluctant to accept demands that such a demonstration be banned next year. "There's a long tradition that people in this country are entitled to demonstrate lawfully, but that right should not be abused in this way," Mr Blair said. But he added: "this kind of thing cannot happen again."

With No 10 calling for the rioting minority to be named and shamed - via photographs and TV film taken during the attacks on McDonalds and other targets - Tory leader William Hague rounded on Mr Livingstone. "After those riots yesterday are we going to have a mayor of London, when the bricks are being thrown, whose heart of hearts is with the rioters not the police?

"This is what we are going to have if we have Ken Livingstone as mayor ," said Mr Hague.

All sides piled in. Frank Dobson's campaign will today place a full-page advert in London's Evening Standard, directly linking the disfigured Cenotaph with Mr Livingstone's earlier pro-direct action remark. "Worried about the cost of Livingstone? You should be," reads the caption.

The independent frontrunner in tomorrow's mayoral election - when up to 5m Londoners can vote - again insisted that he had urged supporters to stay away and has always been opposed to violence.

"The police action concentrated on isolating the small minority of determined wreckers and thugs intent on violence and damage to property from any peaceful protesters," he said in a statement.

"Throughout the four days (of demonstrations) the police thereby set the tone that London both upholds the right to peacefully demonstrate and that it will clamp down with the full force of the law on those who threaten mayhem in the capital.

"This is precisely the tone that should be set for policing in London. I congratulate all those responsible for planning and executing this operation in the Met, " added Mr Livingstone who even praised Churchill as the greatest premier of the 20th century.

But the computer search engines deployed by the rival campaign HQs did not have to look far to find remarks made by the former Greater London Council leader in which he said: "I have always been in favour of direct action" and "if it puts us outside the law, the laws are wrong and we have a right and duty to fight them."

Amid continued outrage, Reclaim the Streets issued a statement yesterday insisting the attack on the monuments had been separate from its "guerrilla gardening" action, but defended it all the same.

"We respect and celebrate all those people who are, and have been, prepared to stand up to fascism, imperialism and dictatorship," said RTS activist John Jordan.

"That said, we do not necessarily celebrate the generals and the ruling class that sends people to their deaths in order to protect the privileges and control of the few.

"The abhorrence of sending millions of men to their deaths in the trenches dwarfs the stupidity of any possible slogan on any possible piece of stone." Others said that though the media had distorted Monday's event, it had still been worth doing.

There is talk of another protest in September to tie in with a meeting of the International Monetary Fund, and another May day event next year.

The first of those arrested at the protest appeared in court yesterday. They included Alan McAlve, 38, a bed-maker, from Rochester, Kent, who was jailed at Horseferry Road magistrates' court for 90 days after admitting using threatening words or behaviour.

He was jointly charged with warehouse worker Brendan Farnan, of Lansbury Drive, Hayes, west London, who was given 14 days in prison, suspended for 12 months.

British Telecom telephonist Richard Stephens was jailed for 14 days after admitting using threatening words or behaviour. The court heard he threw a plastic bottle at police in riot gear from the plinth of Nelson's column.

webTitle: Gent rolls out new team in Germany

fields.headline: Gent rolls out new team in Germany
fields.standfirst:
Vodafone
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Chris Gent, the chairman of Vodafone AirTouch, yesterday stamped his authority on the newly merged Mannesman operation when he installed international director Julian Horn-Smith as its head and appointed several leading German businessman to its board.
fields.body:
Chris Gent, the chairman of Vodafone AirTouch, yesterday stamped his authority on the newly merged Mannesman operation when he installed international director Julian Horn-Smith as its head and appointed several leading German businessman to its board.

Mr Horn-Smith replaces Mannesmann chief executive Klaus Esser, who steps down from the company at its shareholder meeting on June 5.

Mr Esser, who is expected to pocket at least £20.5m on his departure, will take up the non-executive deputy chairman role at Vodafone.

Vodafone also announced it had appointed Henning Schulte-Noelle, chairman of German insurance company Allianz, to its board as non-executive director together with Jürgen Schrempp, chairman of car maker Daimler Chrysler.

Joseph Ackermann head of investment banking at Deutsche Bank, joins the board in the same position.

At the time of €170bn (£99bn) merger, Vodafone announced it would give several of the non-executive directors from Mannesmann's supervisory board representation at Vodafone.

Analysts had been expecting Mr Horn-Smith's appointment to the top Mannesmann position given his successful track record in forging Vodafone's global strategy. He has been responsible for the company's arms in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

webTitle: Badger on the loose, but the newt man stays away

fields.headline: Badger on the loose, but the newt man stays away
fields.trailText: The home secretary made a statement yesterday about the bank holiday riots in London. MPs were angry, shocked and baffled.
fields.body:
The home secretary made a statement yesterday about the bank holiday riots in London. MPs were angry, shocked and baffled.

They were angry and shocked about the violent demonstrations, but utterly baffled by Ann Widdecombe's hair.

For a white stripe has appeared at the top of those shining ebony tresses, exactly like the marking on a badger's nose.

My colleague from the Mail suspects that she has neglected to dye her roots for a week or so, and that the Black Prince's battle helmet effect will soon be restored.

My own guess is that she has decided to let it grow and so come out as a mild, loveable white-haired old lady. She will soon appear in the chamber with knitting.

The Times thinks that she must have been daubed on her way to work by a passing anarchist. That theory would be borne out by the "Die, Tory Scum" graffito painted on her back. (I made that up.)

Anyhow, the shadow home secretary had had to sit through the experience of hearing Jack Straw make a statement most of which was loudly cheered by the Tories, and by nobody else at all.

"The vandals desecrated the Cenotaph and defaced the statue of Sir Winston Churchill ..." said Mr Straw in that faintly nerdy, niminy-piminy voice he adopts for the most serious matters.

"Disgraceful! disgraceful!" shouted the Tories. It must be fun for them to get a good old fashioned "disgraceful!" out now and again. Try it yourself; it does clear the lungs after lunch.

"Criminality and thuggery masquerading as political protest!" Mr Straw continued, to loud Tory cheers.

"Without the millions who gave their lives to defend our freedom," he went on, and only a fool would disagree with him there, though the sight of the Tories mouthing "yah, yah, yah!" was faintly disturbing, if not quite as odd as Old Nan Widdecombe whom I firmly believe I heard say "yum, yum!"

She herself did not receive the same courtesy from the Labour benches. Possibly it's because Labour MPs perceive that she is slightly to the left of the home secretary, on some issues at least, and so feel obliged to jeer anything which sounds slightly intolerant, even of anarchists with sticks and balaclavas.

She asked for "exemplary sentences" and they jeered as loudly as they would if she'd called for them to be burned publicly in Parliament Square. When she echoed Steve Norris, and suggested May Day demos be banned, they chortled with glee at the crash of the fascist jackboot. This sort of thing suits both sides. It pleases Labour MPs who are uneasy about Jack, and makes her seem more hardline than she is.

There was one surprising absentee from the House. Ken Livingstone was, I suppose, too busy campaigning to turn up for this rare event: a statement about London.

Perhaps he was wise. If he had been there, his colleagues would have done to him what the demonstrators did to Churchill.

"The Livingstone approval will be given to these activities if the people of London can be conned into voting for this smarmy charlatan," said Gerald Kaufman. Betty told him to withdraw the words.

"I do so at your instruction," he said, which is MPs' code for "I do no such thing."

Joan Ryan, a Labour MP from Enfield, got away with going further: she more or less accused Ken of fomenting the whole thing. "It is absolutely clear that he advocates rebellion!" she said.

It would be astounding to the millions of people who are going to vote for Ken tomorrow to learn how much his colleagues utterly and unconditionally loathe him.

Meanwhile, Frank Dobson sat silent and smiling through the whole hour. He has almost given up; two days from the end, he has found peace on his own private planet.

webTitle: Wilkinson sits on yet another fortune

fields.headline: Wilkinson sits on yet another fortune
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Wilkinson, the man widely credited with the creation of Freeserve, may be about to make another dot.com fortune after his latest venture, Sports Internet, confirmed it had received a takeover approach that could value his stake at about £120m.
fields.body:
Peter Wilkinson, the man widely credited with the creation of Freeserve, may be about to make another dot.com fortune after his latest venture, Sports Internet, confirmed it had received a takeover approach that could value his stake at about £120m.

A statement from the company confirmed it was in discussions with a mystery party that "may or may not lead to an offer being made for the company".

Analysts were last night betting that BSkyB, which is determined to build a market- leading portfolio of sports, news and entertainment websites, was behind the approach, despite reports that cable television rival NTL has also expressed an interest. Both companies refused to comment.

Freeserve, which already has an option over a small equity stake in Sports Internet, has been mooted as another possible bidder.

Shares in Sports Internet, which operates the Planetfootball.com websites, OPTA sports statistics and an off-shore betting company, closed 80p higher at 712.5p, valuing the group at £242m. The shares peaked at 887.5p earlier this year.

Sports Internet only joined the alternative investment market in March 1999 and last May handed over shares worth £24m plus £650,000 in cash to Mr Wilkinson to take control of Leeds-based Planetfootball.

He now holds 44% of the company that designs, builds and maintains a portfolio of websites for Premier League clubs including Aston Villa, Leeds United, Newcastle United and West Ham.

If the deal goes through it will complete a remarkable two years for Mr Wilkinson. Even before the value of his Sports Internet shares increased by £100m, he was counting a newly made multi-million pound fortune.

In August 1998 he received £25m when Planet Online, a company he had founded just three years earlier, was sold to Energis, the telecoms group, for £75m.

He then engineered Dixons' hugely successful Freeserve internet access service which the retailer set up with Energis. Mr Wilkinson has a lucrative royalty deal linked to traffic generated by Freeserve's 1.8m plus users.

Mr Wilkinson, who lives near Harrogate with his wife and four children, has two other businesses - a computer distributor, Storm, which he used to jointly own with Yorkshire property tycoon Paul Sykes, and VData, an offsite data storage organisation.

He guards his privacy closely, rarely talks to journalists and dislikes leaving his native county. He describes himself as "a typical Yorkshireman - a Scotsman without the generosity".

The potential sale of Sports Internet will come as little surprise to Mr Wilkinson's friends to whom he has talked colloquially about "boshing this thing out quickly".

Sports Internet was set up by former Leeds United chief executive Chris Akers. His stake is valued at £14m. Last night he refused to comment.

webTitle: Lone socialist proves an unlikely hero

fields.headline: Lone socialist proves an unlikely hero
fields.standfirst:
Devolution, one year on: As the anniversary of elections nears on Saturday, how has the Edinburgh parliament performed so far?

Devolution in Scotland: special report
Devolution in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: There could be no less likely a saviour for the Scottish parliament than Tommy Sheridan. The sole representative of the Scottish Socialist party, who took his oath of office with a raised fist, last week brought the ruling Labour-Liberal Democrat executive to its knees.
fields.body:
There could be no less likely a saviour for the Scottish parliament than Tommy Sheridan. The sole representative of the Scottish Socialist party, who took his oath of office with a raised fist, last week brought the ruling Labour-Liberal Democrat executive to its knees. And in so doing he showed, on the anniversary of devolution, that the parliament could work the way Scotland promised it would.

The issue was warrant sales, a uniquely Scottish and widely hated system of debt recovery where debtors' homes are entered, often forcibly, and goods seized and sold at auction.

Mr Sheridan, who was jailed eight years ago for opposing their use on poll tax evaders, introduced the parliament's first private menber's bill to have them abolished. Three parliamentary committees - the supposed linchpin of Scotland's new political set-up - backed his move, but the executive opposed it, preferring to hold off until alternate measures were in place.

In a stormy debate, with Mr Sheridan urging MSPs not to abandon the poor and Labour backbenchers threatening a revolt, the executive were forced to allow the bill to go through. The first defeat; the first real sign that the system could work.

And not a moment too soon, after a year remarkable for all the wrong reasons: the soaring cost of the new parliament building, ministers' mishandling of the section 28 issue, the crisis over tuition fees, a lobbying scandal, senior advisers sacked and chastised, and humiliation for Labour in Ayr.

"The Sheridan bill was an example of how differently things can be done compared with Westminster," said John Curtice, pollster and professor of politics at Strathclyde University.

"In Westminster, the bill would have been introduced on a Friday and would have been killed by the government quite easily. At Holyrood, it showed that some of the distinctive procedures of the parliament were beginning to have an impact."

There has been a second seismic event to mark the parliament's first year. A routine medical test discovered a faulty aortic valve in Donald Dewar's heart, requiring major surgery.

There is plenty of goodwill for the first minister, still viewed as the father of the nation for his delivery of devolution, but there are also very real questions over whether he will run for a second term. Speculation over a successor has revealed a fair selection of credible candidates, a good proportion of them women.

"The Dewar succession struggle is changing everything," said Tom Nairn, director of the centre for Scottish and Irish studies. "And the prospects for this in terms of the identity of the parliament are rather good.

"No doubt great efforts will be made to promote someone suitably grey to succeed Mr Dewar, but I don't think it's going to work.

"What people wanted from the parliament was a sense of difference, a new departure. There is a dynamic which is forcing its way through, and that is nowhere more noticeable than on the gender side.

"The contrast with Westminster is unmistakeable. In Holyrood, women have moved into the front rank, and some are serious contenders for succeeding Dewar. That only happens when things are really changing."

But they may not be changing fast enough for the public. The most recent poll suggests continuing apathy towards the devolved body. About 27% think it is doing a good job, 34% believe it is doing a bad job, but 38% don't care how it's doing.

"By the standards of the other devolution experiments - Wales and the London mayor - it's going well," said Prof Curtice. "Polls show people are not antagonistic towards it, but they are saying what's this body doing? People are underwhelmed but not seriously upset, and still prepared to give it a chance."

The main problem, according to Geoff Scobie, a Glasgow University psychologist, is that few Scots have felt the parliament's impact. "People have not yet seen any benefits coming directly from it.

"But a new system takes time to bed down and make decisions that have a direct effect on people's lives. It's only when the issues become significant and important that politics regains its imperative."

But the parliament has been the making of the opposition parties. The Scottish National party and the Conservatives have flourished under devolution. The Tories, routed in Scotland in 1997, won 17 seats through proportional representation and took Ayr in the parliament's first byelection.

The SNP has embraced devolution with unexpected vigour. Party rhetoric on independence has been toned down, bringing suggestions that it is backtracking on its core commitment. Party leaders, however, say they need the parliament to persuade Scots to make the jump to full autonomy.

Richard Holloway, bishop of Edinburgh, said Scots should need little encouragement to champion their parliament. "It came in with unreasonably high expectations, so there was bound to be a bit of 'the party's over' feeling. There was a whining spirit that came in too soon.

"But in spite of all that, they dug in and they are beginning to create a kind of authentic Scottish political culture which excites me. Not just in the way they are distanced from Westminister, but a kind of social, cultural, ethical climate - significant attempts to create a liberal multicultural ethos that show brave and imaginative leadership.

"There is something of a Scottish neo-enlightenment going on: there is a lot of good Scottish poetry, film making, novels. And while the parliament is not the cause of that, politics is an important part of it."

Scottish parliament elected. Coalition deal signed between Labour and Liberal Democrats.

June

Parliament hits the ground strolling. First topics of discussion: MSP allowances and holidays, and allocation of commemorative medals.

July 1

Queen opens the parliament and it assumes full legislative powers for devolved matters.

September

Lobbyists for PR firm, Beattie Media, are taped claiming access to senior Labour ministers.

October

Communities minister Wendy Alexander announces plans to repeal section 28, launching one of Scotland's biggest moral debates.

December

Tony Blair vists parliament for first time and insists devolution is working. A week later Labour is humiliated in Ayr byelection, coming third behind Conservatives and SNP.

fields.bodyText: There could be no less likely a saviour for the Scottish parliament than Tommy Sheridan. The sole representative of the Scottish Socialist party, who took his oath of office with a raised fist, last week brought the ruling Labour-Liberal Democrat executive to its knees. And in so doing he showed, on the anniversary of devolution, that the parliament could work the way Scotland promised it would. The issue was warrant sales, a uniquely Scottish and widely hated system of debt recovery where debtors' homes are entered, often forcibly, and goods seized and sold at auction. Mr Sheridan, who was jailed eight years ago for opposing their use on poll tax evaders, introduced the parliament's first private menber's bill to have them abolished. Three parliamentary committees - the supposed linchpin of Scotland's new political set-up - backed his move, but the executive opposed it, preferring to hold off until alternate measures were in place. In a stormy debate, with Mr Sheridan urging MSPs not to abandon the poor and Labour backbenchers threatening a revolt, the executive were forced to allow the bill to go through. The first defeat; the first real sign that the system could work. And not a moment too soon, after a year remarkable for all the wrong reasons: the soaring cost of the new parliament building, ministers' mishandling of the section 28 issue, the crisis over tuition fees, a lobbying scandal, senior advisers sacked and chastised, and humiliation for Labour in Ayr. "In Westminster, the bill would have been introduced on a Friday and would have been killed by the government quite easily. At Holyrood, it showed that some of the distinctive procedures of the parliament were beginning to have an impact." There has been a second seismic event to mark the parliament's first year. A routine medical test discovered a faulty aortic valve in Donald Dewar's heart, requiring major surgery. There is plenty of goodwill for the first minister, still viewed as the father of the nation for his delivery of devolution, but there are also very real questions over whether he will run for a second term. Speculation over a successor has revealed a fair selection of credible candidates, a good proportion of them women. "The Dewar succession struggle is changing everything," said Tom Nairn, director of the centre for Scottish and Irish studies. "And the prospects for this in terms of the identity of the parliament are rather good. "No doubt great efforts will be made to promote someone suitably grey to succeed Mr Dewar, but I don't think it's going to work. "What people wanted from the parliament was a sense of difference, a new departure. There is a dynamic which is forcing its way through, and that is nowhere more noticeable than on the gender side. "The contrast with Westminster is unmistakeable. In Holyrood, women have moved into the front rank, and some are serious contenders for succeeding Dewar. That only happens when things are really changing." But they may not be changing fast enough for the public. The most recent poll suggests continuing apathy towards the devolved body. webTitle: Knutsford wants to be in investor relations

fields.headline: Knutsford wants to be in investor relations
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Asda
Sainsburys
fields.trailText: Knutsford, the bid vehicle which six months ago was being touted as a saviour for the ailing retailers Marks & Spencer and Great Universal Stores, is about to make its long awaited first investment - in a privately-owned, unnamed online investor relations business.
fields.body:
Knutsford, the bid vehicle which six months ago was being touted as a saviour for the ailing retailers Marks & Spencer and Great Universal Stores, is about to make its long awaited first investment - in a privately-owned, unnamed online investor relations business.

Confirmation that the shell company is in takeover talks comes almost six months after a group of businessmen led by former Asda boss Archie Norman took control, promising to buy up and turn around an underperforming retailer, with money no object.

Mr Norman, along with hi-fi stores millionaire Julian Richer and property financiers Nick Leslau and Nigel Wray, were linked to a series of audacious swoops on targets ranging from M&S to Storehouse, Sainsbury and Argos owner GUS.

A Knutsford spokesman confirmed yesterday that the company was working on a deal to buy an online investor relations business operating in Europe and North America. The talks come four months after Knutsford surprised the stock market by launching, and ultimately abandoning, a £500m-plus bid for Wassall, the mini-conglomerate.

In January Knutsford signalled that it was scaling down its ambitions and widening its range of potential targets beyond the retail sector when Mr Norman, a Conservative MP, was appointed to the shadow cabinet as a spokesman on the environment, transport and the regions.

The Knutsford spokesman denied the company was changing its strategy again. "When Archie Norman answered William Hague's call we signalled that he would take a less prominent role and there would be a strategic rethink,"he said. "We said at the time we would look at e-commerce opportunities, a subject that is particularly dear to Mr Wray's heart."

The latest talks were about a sum "significantly lower" than the amount Knutsford would have needed to pay for Wassall.

Knutsford shares, which peaked at 270p when Mr Norman and his associates took charge, yesterday closed unchanged at 80p.

webTitle: Bacteria inoculation for babies could curb asthma

fields.headline: Bacteria inoculation for babies could curb asthma
fields.trailText: Asthma, a curse of modern times, could be drastically reduced by an inoculation programme to expose babies to bacteria they are deprived of in the hygienic homes and hospitals of the 21st century, leading scientists believe.
fields.body:
Asthma, a curse of modern times, could be drastically reduced by an inoculation programme to expose babies to bacteria they are deprived of in the hygienic homes and hospitals of the 21st century, leading scientists believe.

Within two years, John Warner, of the department of child health at Southampton university, one of the UK's leading specialists in childhood asthma, plans to start clinical trials on newborn babies.

Within 10 years, the programme, if successful, could be extended nationwide and would cut the asthma rate from the current 20% of children to the 5% it used to be 20 years ago.

All the evidence in asthma research is beginning to point the same way, he says - that our relatively sterile lives fail to expose the baby at the right time to bacteria that should flourish in the bowel and kickstart the immune system to fight off allergens.

"The theory gains credibility with every new piece of research that comes along. To delay any longer before starting these intervention trials is wasting time," said Professor Warner yesterday.

He plans to start within a year by feeding bacteria to babies of a few weeks old. "We'll do it with the bacteria normally present in your bowel.

"It would eventually get into the baby, but rather more slowly with our hygienic conditions. Either we could give it to them on a spoon or squirt it in with a syringe."

He accepts that clinical trials on very young babies are highly sensitive, but points out that they are already given the harmless lactobacillus organism in neonatal intensive care units to help strengthen their immune systems.

The inoculation trials might feature a tuberculosis type bug. The BCG, he explained, has already been given to small babies to protect them in areas where TB is rife. "It only causes problems in profoundly immunodeficient individuals," he said.

There is less and less dispute that the absence of dirt in our lives is responsible for the dramatic rise in asthma rates, he said. Although the rates are rising in developing countries too, the asthmatics are among the more affluent and those who have adopted westernised lifestyles.

Professor Warner's research plans, announced at a conference organised by the Air Action Appeal charity, based at Southampton university, yesterday, follow the discovery by his team and another in the US of a molecule present in bacteria cells called CD14.

It is this molecule that they hope to stimulate by introducing helpful bacteria. They have also discovered that the foetus be comes sensitive to allergens as early as 20 weeks gestation, picking up the mother's allergies through the amniotic fluid. It raises the possibility that immunising the mother could also prevent asthma in the baby.

Dr John Harvey, of the British Thoracic Society, said he agreed that the introduction of bacteria to babies through inoculation could help reduce asthma rates.

"We know a lot more now about the way our immune system works in early life and how it has an effect on switching on allergic responses and how these can be damped down. There's a lot of evidence that modern lifestyle is one of the main reasons for this huge increase in asthma prevalence.

"Modifying the way our immune system is reared in the early months is going to be the way forward."

fields.headline: Sensation's over, now it's Apocalypse
fields.standfirst: Royal Academy sheds fuddy-duddy image by upstaging opening of Tate Modern with controversial show focusing on beauty and horror including swas Royal Academy of Arts
fields.trailText: First he brought the world Sensation, the most controversial art show of the last decade, which left politicians on both sides of the Atlantic spluttering with rage.
fields.body:
First he brought the world Sensation, the most controversial art show of the last decade, which left politicians on both sides of the Atlantic spluttering with rage.

Now Norman Rosenthal, the Royal Academy's flamboyant impresario, may have surpassed himself with a new exhibition called Apocalypse, featuring "the extremes of horror and beauty", including a sculpture of the Pope being hit by a meteorite.

With the timing of a true showman, Mr Rosenthal yesterday managed to upstage next week's opening of the new Tate Modern by announcing that the centrepiece of the RA's big autumn show would be a vast panoptical work in the shape of a swastika by the Chapman Brothers called F****** Hell.

Jake and Dinos Chapman were branded "perverts" by the mayor of New York, Rudi Giuliani, for their morphed mannequins of girls in the Sensation show and their mutilated bodies hanging from trees inspired by Goya's Disasters Of War.

'Spellbinding'
Mr Rosenthal said he was "floored" when he first saw the new work, which depicts the horrors of the 20th century through a series of gruesome tableaux using 10,000 tiny figures, many dismembered, arranged around a central, smoking volcano.

"It was like looking at a latter day Hieronymus Bosch. I fell backwards when I saw it - it's spellbinding. I think the Chapmans will be major, major artists. Others might think it's a piece of shit, but I doubt it," he said. "It's a big, big thing. You can look at it for hours and hours, the detail and craftmanship is amazing. When I first went to see it they were almost bankrupt, they didn't even have a dealer, but I realised immediately that we could build an amazing show around it. It's Brueghel, Pasolini and Bosch; they are all there."

He also defended Maurizio Cattelan's Pope, which shows the ageing John Paul II smashed into the ground by the meteorite but still clutching his crozier.

"Cattelan is a Catholic and this comes from a long tradition depicting the moment of revelation that goes back to Botticelli. It's perfectly valid to show the Pope like this because he has been a force both for good and bad. People who do good, can also be bad. Let's remember his views on birth control and the effect that has had on the spread of Aids."

Mr Rosenthal also enraged the academy's rump of more conservative members by declaring that it "had to change to rid itself of its fuddy-duddy image", hinting that even its summer show may no longer be sacrosanct.

"The new Tate changes the whole structure of things. The Royal Academy will have to adapt to that," he said. "I want to put on one major exhibition of contemporary art every year, to bring the RA back to what it was in the 18th century, when it was a defender of contemporary art."

Boycott
Such comments are a red rag to the academy's watercolourist wing. Several artists, led by Craigie Aitchison, resigned from the RA in protest at Sensation three years ago, although the show was a hit with the public, who flocked to Piccadilly in their tens of thousands.

It later went to Berlin and New York, where it was a big success, despite Mayor Giuliani's call for a boycott and threats to withdraw the grant from the gallery which staged the show.

Mr Rosenthal's co-curator, Max Wigram, said they wanted to put on "a meaty, dramatic show that pushed the public to the extremes of what we think of beauty and horror". He admitted some people might have trouble with some of the artists' work, particularly the photographer Wolfgang Tillmans, best known for his shots of his late lover urinating on a chair and masturbating. "He sees beauty in difficult subjects which some people might find unacceptable," he said.

Mr Rosenthal denied that they had set out deliberately to shock. "It's not about shocking people, though it is about shock. There is a kind of aesthetic to shock which is not a respectable subject in England. People tend to take the use of shock for granted in literature, theatre and film but not in art, which they more associate with the pretty, pretty aspects of the still lifes.

"Well, we are trying to change that, to open with some of the best works in the world from the extremes of horror and beauty. People did not come to the Sensation show to mock or to be shocked, but to be engaged and they were. We hope it will be the same in September."

Mr Rosenthal warned that the Tate Modern on the South Bank was going to change the "whole structure of things. The Royal Academy will have to adapt or ... well, it cannot be the same. You cannot pretend the Tate Modern doesn't exist."

He said he sensed things were changing within the notoriously conservative RA. "This is not the time to say what will happen to the summer show, but I feel something is in the air. I may be the academy's black sheep which they indulge terribly, but I think the election of Phillip King as president showed that change. There is a huge audience for contemporary art out there and we are going to have to embrace it."

Figures released yesterday showed the RA's Monet In The 20th Century was the most popular charging art exhibition ever held in this country. More than 739,300 visitors saw it last year, helping to push the gallery's annual attendance to a record 1.4m.

Artists with a mission to shock

Jake and Dinos Chapman
The enfants terribles of Britart, they enraged the mayor of New York, Rudi Giuliani, with their sculptures of dismembered bodies hanging from trees - a homage to Goya's nightmarish Disasters Of War. Their vast installation, F****** Hell, which uses 10,000 figures grouped into the shape of a swastika, is the centrepiece of the new show.

Maurizio Cattelan
His Pope John Paul II being hit by a meteorite is sure to anger more devout Catholics, and will be displayed in "such a way to make it difficult to attack". The Italian artist first came to prominence with his humorous works, including Picasso in Roy Lichtenstein's Kitchen.

Darren Almond
Young British artist, who also featured in Sensation. He will be displaying the bus shelters at Auschwitz, which the local council gave him on condition that he made them new ones.

Mike Kelley
Californian installation artist who has become a hero to the bad boys and girls of Britart. As well as using battered toys, he has made dolls from his own excrement, an idea picked up by the cult US adult cartoon TV show, South Park.

Jeff Koons
Another American icon who has become rich and famous by embracing and subverting kitsch ornaments. Married the Italian porn star La Cicciolina (The Little Plump One) and made a gaudy ceramic of them making love.

Tim Noble and Sue Webster
A London couple, new on the scene, who create silhouetted self-portraits from piles of rubbish.

Angus Fairhurst
An artist too weird, "too subtle and too intelligent", the curators claim, to be collected by Charles Saatchi, who dominates the Britart scene.

Luc Tuymans
The only painter in the show, and regarded as one of the best artists working in Europe now. Belgium-born, his muted, small-scale, ethereal pieces deal with child abuse and the Holocaust.

Wolfgang Tillmans
German-born photographer living in London. His unorthodox nude studies are not for the easily shocked, though there is a curious innocence about them.

Richard Prince
New Yorker who uses advertising images like the Marlboro Man to make joke pictures.

Gregor Schneider
Described by the show's curators, as "the next big thing, a new Joseph Beuys", Schneider has built a series of rooms and strip-lit cells within his home in Germany that bring on "all kinds of paranoias".

Mariko Mori
Slightly kooky Japanese artist who uses computers to cast herself as a pop star or cyber girl. She had made a large, transparent "dream temple" for the show which she will "bless" when it opens. A sphere inside the temple will show a 3D film.

Chris Cunningham
British film-maker who did some of the special effects for Alien 3 and directed music videos for Bjork, Portishead and Madonna. His work is a collaboration with musician Richard James from Aphex Twin.

Angus Fairhurst An artist too weird, "too subtle and too intelligent", the curators claim, to be collected by Charles Saatchi, who dominates the Britart scene. Luc Tuymans The only painter in the show, and regarded as one of the best artists working in Europe now. Belgium-born, his muted, small-scale, ethereal pieces deal with child abuse and the Holocaust. Wolfgang Tillmans German-born photographer living in London. His unorthodox nude studies are not for the easily shocked, though there is a curious innocence about them. Richard Prince New Yorker who uses advertising images like the Marlboro Man to make joke pictures. Gregor Schneider Described by the show's curators, as "the next big thing, a new Joseph Beuys", Schneider has built a series of rooms and strip-lit cells within his home in Germany that bring on "all kinds of paranoias". Mariko Mori Slightly kooky Japanese artist who uses computers to cast herself as a pop star or cyber girl. She had made a large, transparent "dream temple" for the show which she will "bless" when it opens. A sphere inside the temple will show a 3D film. Chris Cunningham British film-maker who did some of the special effects for Alien 3 and directed music videos for Bjork, Portishead and Madonna. His work is a collaboration with musician Richard James from Aphex Twin.

fields.headline: Lockerbie trial warning
fields.standfirst:
University of Glasgow Lockerbie trial briefing
Lockerbie trial documents (Libyan site)
fields.trailText: Two Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing go on trial for mass murder in the Netherlands this morning after stern warnings from Scottish court officials that the unique event would not be allowed to descend into a media frenzy.
fields.byline: Ian Black and Gerard Seenan, at Camp Zeist
fields.body:
Two Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing go on trial for mass murder in the Netherlands this morning after stern warnings from Scottish court officials that the unique event would not be allowed to descend into a media frenzy.

As relatives of the 270 victims began arriving at Camp Zeist, legal sources said the first prosecution evidence would come from police officers and air accident investigators who were at the scene on December 21 1988.

Nearly 12 years after the worst act of terrorism in British history, endless diplomatic wrangling and intrigue, final preparations were being put in place at the former US air base near Utrecht, declared Scottish territory for the duration of the trial.

"I've got sort of a numb feeling and a good deal of anxiety over what might happen," said Daniel Cohen, whose 20-year- old daughter was one of the 190 Americans killed when Pan Am flight 103 exploded over the Borders town.

Families expressed little expectation that the trial, expected to last at least a year, would answer all their questions about the disaster.

"I am hoping for justice and truth, but I don't think we'll get either," said Rosemary Wolfe, whose step-daughter Miriam, 20, died over Lockerbie.

Jim Swire, spokesman for British relatives, said: "It's been a ghastly 11 years. We expect the fairest obtainable verdict as to whether these two individuals are guilty or innocent."

The accused, Abdelbaset al-Megrahi, 48, and Al-Amin Khalifa Fhima, 44, face charges of murder, conspiracy to murder and violation of the Aviation Security Act.

Prosecutors say they were Libyan intelligence agents who concealed a Semtex bomb in a Toshiba radio-cassette recorder inside an unaccompanied suitcase on a plane to Frankfurt. The suitcase was transferred in London onto the doomed New York flight.

The two, who have pleaded not guilty, deny working as secret service agents and say they were employees of Libyan Arab Airlines in Malta.

The indictment, which will be read out for the first time in court today, mentions by name several other members of Libyan intelligence, including two senior officers, Said Rashid and Ezzadin Hinshiri.

Lawyers for the two accused have made clear that their main defence will be to incriminate members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command. Allegations have also been made of involvement by Iran and Syria.

Failure to convict would leave the British and US governments in the embarrassing position of having pushed hard for a trial, compromised over the venue, and seen the rehabilitation of the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy.

Col Gadafy agreed to the UN-brokered deal to hand over the two defendants last April, apparently basing his decision on clear signals that two individuals, not his regime, would be in the dock.

In recent months he has been wooed by the European Union, while western oil companies have beaten a path to his door.

John Grant, a Scottish law professor, warned against expecting too much when the three judges - there is no jury - choose one of three verdicts: guilty, not guilty or not proven.

"One of the sad things is that families may not get the definitive answer some think they're going to get," Mr Grant said. "This is not about who ordered the bombing of Pan Am 103, it's only about whether these two guys did it."

fields.headline: Looking for corpses
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A fresh search for the bodies of the disappeared has begun in Ireland. Few of us recognise the names of these IRA victims since their stories rarely made front-page news at the time. London editors often found Ireland "dull, dull, dull". But speaking as an Englishwoman who lives far from the troubles, I find Ireland worse than dull. It is wearing.
fields.body:
A fresh search for the bodies of the disappeared has begun in Ireland. Few of us recognise the names of these IRA victims since their stories rarely made front-page news at the time. London editors often found Ireland "dull, dull, dull". But speaking as an Englishwoman who lives far from the troubles, I find Ireland worse than dull. It is wearing.

What is really depressing is that we are involved in this miserable saga at all. I was 13 when I first heard an IRA bomb go off in London. Since then I've seen friends injured and killed. Philip Geddes was the only child of a Polish father whose whole family was wiped out in the second world war. We were at university together, worked together and he shared a flat with a girlfriend. He died, at the age of 24, when the Harrods bomb exploded in December 1983. What had he done to deserve that?

We English live in a tolerant, multicultural society. Reading about the hatreds and violence of Northern Ireland is like being forced to read hard-core pornography. At first it shocked, but as the years have passed it has merely become relentless.

Yesterday's renewed search for the disappeared is a reminder that the IRA have killed more Catholics over the past 27 years than either loyalists or the security forces. Besides the mother who committed the sin of comforting a dying soldier, there are a few drug dealers who hadn't paid the IRA their cut.

Although their apologists deny it, the IRA are racketeers. The newspapers carry a constant stream of reports on how the IRA smuggle cigarettes, drink, livestock and drugs. They take protection money from taxi drivers and builders. They are involved in fraud and linked with organised crime in the US. In places like South Armagh they regard gangsterism as the Sicilian mafia do: part of a grand tradition of thumbing their nose at the state. What chance for peace when war is so profitable?

Most people mellow with age. Some terrorists find a life, get out and reject violence. Others stay because they must. Gerry Adams and Martin McGuiness may long to spend more time at their dachas in Donegal, but it's dangerous and difficult for a don to retire.

Some might never wish to. It is hard to imagine Tom "Slab" Murphy, the former IRA chief of staff and pig dealer who lives alone save for a brother on his farm in South Armagh, settling down to write novels.

There is no way all the illegal weapons in Ireland are going to be given up. We are going to have to wait for them to rust first. To that end we must be as ruthless in pursuing peace as others are in perpetuating war.

In England we are aware that those who ruled our - or our compatriots' - ancestors have bequeathed us obligations to the Irish. We are told that without us to police them, they will massacre each other. It seems to be our duty to protect them from each other for as long as the majority in Northern Ireland wish it.

Every Catholic baby born there arrives with an English blessing on its head, because that majority has hitherto been Protestant and unionist.

Those people are sometimes presented as our kith and kin. But since the best-known unionist is Ian Paisley, my generation tend to see them as we once saw the Boers in South Africa, as bigots with ugly accents. It's difficult to warm to that image: nevertheless, judging by the poor quality of loyalist terrorists only the lowest and stupidest Protestant takes to murder. The same cannot be said of the nationalists.

Raised as we were on Terry Wogan and the TV series, The Irish RM, many of us have a rather whimsical image of Catholic Ireland. But there is nothing whimsical about the IRA. Both brilliant and terrifying, its members bombed party conferences, took on the might of a regular army and disembowelled three years olds out shopping for Mother's Day.

Much as we hate to believe it, the IRA could not function without widespread support. As with Arkan's Tigers or the KLA this support springs from a desire to right wrongs and a wish to support family and community.

That sounds romantic, but if the IRA is nourished by the past, it is also consumed by it. It fuels the bitterness that validates their authoritarianism and their killing. So it destroys the thing they purport to love: the vision of a happy and free people.

We have faith in our state. When the Irish have faith in theirs, terrorism will wither away and tolerance find its opportunity. Meanwhile the old story runs and runs. What pleasure do we find in reading about it? None, but we do so nonetheless, sometimes with pity, sometimes with anger, and even, despite everything, with hope.

comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Lockerbie: at last the trial begins

fields.headline: Lockerbie: at last the trial begins
fields.standfirst:
Some call it a charade, but Cook and Mandela achieved a huge feat

Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: Nearly 12 years after the event, the chilling story of the Lockerbie bombing finally gets its first ever full airing today when three Scottish judges open proceedings in a unique court on a Dutch air base. Many people believed this day would never come.
fields.body:
Nearly 12 years after the event, the chilling story of the Lockerbie bombing finally gets its first ever full airing today when three Scottish judges open proceedings in a unique court on a Dutch air base. Many people believed this day would never come. And many still doubt whether the truth of the biggest act of mass murder in British history - and one of the most devastating instances of terrorism in modern times - will be told or the real culprits be punished.

The two Libyans in the dock at Camp Zeist are described by the prosecution as members of their country's intelligence service, though both deny this. Unsurprisingly, their lawyers have indicated that the main defence will be to incriminate others, such as members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, originally suspected of involvement.

But the trial is certain to revisit other theories. Iran, Syria, as well as the PFLP-GC, will put in appearances. So will the story of the USS Vincennes, which shot down an Iranian civilian airliner over the Gulf, and the 1986 US-British bombing of Libya, in which Colonel Muammar Gadafy's adopted daughter died. "Locker A," Gadafy once called that, in a telling hint at what lay behind "Locker B."

In the face of such confusion, it is imperative to get to the bottom of what happened to Pan Am 103. Since December 1988, Lockerbie has become a cottage industry: books and films have appeared; websites are devoted to it. The media presence at Zeist will be intense. Glasgow University academics will be on hand to explain Scottish law.

But Lockerbie seems destined to leave enduring mysteries - about bomb fragments, timing devices, luggage labels, witness identification and, perhaps above all, the shadowy role of intelligence agencies. Even if the accused are convicted, the court is unlikely to hear clear answers to the key questions - motive, and the chain of command in Tripoli, though the star prosecution witness, a Libyan defector living under a new identity in the US may deliver.

Getting the men into custody was a huge feat. It owed most to Nelson Mandela's friendship with Gadafy and to Robin Cook, who recognised that a radical shift was required if the deadlock was to be broken, and had the sense to let Mandela and Kofi Annan do the heavy lifting. Persuading the Americans to go along was a triumph. Yet the deal contained an implicit promise: two individuals, not an entire regime, would be in the dock. For Libya the prize was an end to pariahdom as irksome UN sanctions gave way to business as usual, especially oil business.

So was it all a cynical ploy to let the big fish off the hook while leaving the small fry to take their chances on ending up in the UN wing of Glasgow's Barlinnie prison? Up to a point, yes, though no more cynical than the way states routinely draw lines under each other's crimes after a decent interval.

Lord Copper's interlocutors should consider other arguments too. The French, it is true, did things differently. In the case of the UTA plane downed by a suitcase bomb over Niger in 1989, killing 170 people, they made do with a trial in absentia and convicted, among others, Abdullah Senussi, then head of Libyan intelligence, and Gadafy's brother-in-law. Compensation was paid and Franco-Libyan relations restored. Full marks for Parisian honesty. Nil for justice.

Britain did the same over WPC Yvonne Fletcher, shot dead from inside the Libyan Peoples Bureau in London in 1984, and obtained blood money for her family last year. But no one was ever punished for her murder.

Critics of the Lockerbie trial need to ponder this question: if people who put bombs on planes are not brought to book - because they were "only" obeying orders - what chance is there that a future bomber will disobey? To follow the small fry/fall guy argument is to make the best the enemy of the good - and to abandon any pretence that impunity matters.

Two years before Pan Am 103 came down, Nezar Hindawi, a Syrian agent, persuaded his pregnant (and unwitting) Irish girlfriend to carry a bomb onto an El Al Jumbo at Heathrow. He richly deserved the 45 years he is now serving. Surely it is better that terrorists be pursued in the courts rather than by blind revenge? The US raid of 1986 - still the most likely reason for Lockerbie - was retaliation for a Libyan bomb attack that killed American servicemen in a Berlin discotheque.

Will Camp Zeist be a charade? Not for relatives of the victims who desperately need to know why their loved ones died. Journalists and pundits have had a dozen years of field days with this extraordinary story. It is now the turn of the bereaved families to hear in full what the governments claim to know - and for the court to decide. Full justice may well be impossible to achieve. But the truth is still worth having.

ian.black@theguardian.com

webTitle: Ken adds spice to life, but politics is more than that

fields.headline: Ken adds spice to life, but politics is more than that
fields.standfirst:
Polly Toynbee looks back in embarrassment on her own demonstrating days
May 2K: special report
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Politics is not fun. Voting tomorrow? Consider then that politics is for making dull things work - making trains and drains run, schools and hospitals work, catching criminals, trading deals with foreigners, preventing poverty, looking after the old and sick. None of that is very exciting.
fields.body:
Politics is not fun. Voting tomorrow? Consider then that politics is for making dull things work - making trains and drains run, schools and hospitals work, catching criminals, trading deals with foreigners, preventing poverty, looking after the old and sick. None of that is very exciting. If all worked well we should hire politicians to get on with it the way we hire others to keep the water, gas and electricity flowing, dull stuff unless something goes wrong. Let the politicians plough the fields of administration while the rest of us use our energies on more creative things - making money, bringing up children or communing with a life of the mind, the heart and the arts.

The last century saw swathes of humanity hurtled to destruction through investing too much in politics. As God died those who sought the meaning of life in wrap-around political systems soon found themselves crushed to death by the monstrous boa constrictors they had created. Yet we still suffer a hangover from those times, an eerie void. You hear young people yearning nostalgically for the simplicity of the old days with something to fight for. The Spanish civil war was the great ideological adventure holiday of the previous generation. How some of us envied fathers who had been there.

As this week marks the 25th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam war, you hear some kids saying with longing "What did you do in the great anti-war demos, ma?" Well, I say, yes, I was there near the front in Grosvenor Square, face squashed up against a police horse's backside when they burned the flag outside the US embassy. Was it bliss to be alive and so on? No, not now. Now I look back less in anger than embarrassment.

Real babies were being napalmed while we in our flares and afghans fought at the battle front against a row of London bobbies (sorry, fascist pigs). What's more, after Kosovo I'm not even sure we were right. Or if we were I am a lot less sure that the Americans were wholly wrong. Any lost war is a war not worth fighting, but maybe there was more nobility in the attempt than we ever considered then. But that's another story - at the time there was a pleasing clarity of vision.

Here at the start of a new century there is no shortage of great causes - third world debt, global warming, world trade, starvation, nuclear proliferation - but there is a hole in the heart of politics where ideology used to be. How much duller things are with no God and no isms, how technocratic, run by men and women with no rhetoric (or when foolishly attempted it's a toe-curling anachronism). Still steeped in the old ways, how eagerly they in the Commons and we who comment on them drum up every minor issue, harrumphing and inflating any small thing into some great ism whenever we can. Oh, call back yesterday, bid time return!

In this frame of mind the voters of London will elect Ken Livingstone, he who is all our yesterdays personified. Viewed through rose-tinted spectacles, he fell before the wall fell, so much more fun those Maggie v Ken days. Tory and labour tribes alike are giving him their x's for old time's sake. Where's the anger, the clash, the panache now? Hague isn't worth hating, Blair is bland, democracy is bloodless, so vote for fun. Why not? What's the risk? "Baring their bum at the emperor" one insider said yesterday glumly. The whole country's in an arsey mood, intent on giving the government a bloody nose.

At it's most extreme, it's the mood the eco-rioters caught too as they planted that lovely green punk turf on Sir Winston's head in a gesture far more arresting and imaginative than anything that won the Turner prize in recent years. One way or another a lot of people still want politics to be fun.

What a luxury that is, how lucky we are, though at this point to mention Aung San Suu Kyi or Ken Saro Wiwa is like telling children to eat their crusts in the name of the starving of Ethiopia. But here we are with the best government we've had in years and all anyone wants to do is tweak its nose for fun. So secure are these voters in Labour's continuing power that they think they can afford fun and jam on it too.

When challenged with their frivolity, Ken voters tend to turn defensive: "Well it's all Blair's fault. If he hadn't tried his control freakery on London it never would have happened." It's a plausible excuse but bunk nonetheless. They'd have voted Ken come what may. They're bored, bored, bored with basically good dull government.

When was politics last exciting to these dilettante voters? Why, exactly three years ago on the night of May 1. They were the ones who whinged all through the campaign that they probably wouldn't bother to vote. What's the point? Blair's a Tory, nothing to choose between the parties, yawn, yawn.

But when it happened suddenly everyone burst out singing and dancing and whooping and throwing their New York Yankees base ball caps in the air shouting "Portillo, Portillo!" It was briefly cool but it was just a passing fad, a postmodern thing. The madness cooled in no time as the government settled down to do the very dull things it said it would do in the very dull manifesto no one bothered to read.

So in the last three years the New Deal unfolded, snatching billions of pounds from the fat cat utilities to rescue 250,000 destitute young people from the scrap heap. Poor families on income support have £1,500 a year more. Child benefit got its biggest rise ever, as did one million poor pensioners who got £20 a week more. Families got 70 a week for childcare. Hereditary peers were removed (well, almost). Today reading and maths levels are rising in primary schools, half of all pupils will go into higher education in 10 years' time and the NHS is about to get more money than it quite knows how to spend. What dull stuff.

But still, there's plenty to satisfy the need to complain too. Easy to ponder Blair's cowardice on the euro and proportional representation or his wrong-headedness on freedom of information, asylum seekers, prison numbers and a whole lot more in Jack Straw's domain. Oh yes, there's plenty to keep the old angry fires burning.

There will never be a government to please us all. In other words, yes, there are plenty of plausible excuses to vote for Ken. All around the metropolis people who should know better wrinkle their noses and say they're sick of Labour, such a disappointment. Voting for Ken will teach Blair a lesson.

The real lesson is that even good governments need flashy gestures. It's not enough to plod on with what works in the backroom, the shop window has to dazzle too. Ken knows how easily these jaded fair-weather friends are bought with baubles. So, if you are going to vote Ken, have fun but just don't pretend to be serious as well.
