fields.bodyText: Politics is not fun. Voting tomorrow? Consider then that politics is for making dull things work - making trains and drains run, schools and hospitals work, catching criminals, trading deals with foreigners, preventing poverty, looking after the old and sick. None of that is very exciting. If all worked well we should hire politicians to get on with it the way we hire others to keep the water, gas and electricity flowing, dull stuff unless something goes wrong. Let the politicians plough the fields of administration while the rest of us use our energies on more creative things - making money, bringing up children or communing with a life of the mind, the heart and the arts. The last century saw swathes of humanity hurtled to destruction through investing too much in politics. As God died those who sought the meaning of life in wrap-around political systems soon found themselves crushed to death by the monstrous boa constrictors they had created. Yet we still suffer a hangover from those times, an eerie void. You hear young people yearning nostalgically for the simplicity of the old days with something to fight for. The Spanish civil war was the great ideological adventure holiday of the previous generation. How some of us envied fathers who had been there. As this week marks the 25th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam war, you hear some kids saying with longing "What did you do in the great anti-war demos, ma?" Well, I say, yes, I was there near the front in Grosvenor Square, face squashed up against a police horse's backside when they burned the flag outside the US embassy. Was it bliss to be alive and so on? No, not now. Now I look back less in anger than embarrassment. Real babies were being napalmed while we in our flares and afghans fought at the battle front against a row of London bobbies (sorry, fascist pigs). Still steeped in the old ways, how eagerly they in the Commons and we who comment on them drum up every minor issue, harrumphing and inflating any small thing into some great ism whenever we can. At it's most extreme, it's the mood the eco-rioters caught too as they planted that lovely green punk turf on Sir Winston's head in a gesture far more arresting and imaginative than anything that won the Turner prize in recent years. One way or another a lot of people still want politics to be fun. What a luxury that is, how lucky we are, though at this point to mention Aung San Suu Kyi or Ken Saro Wiwa is like telling children to eat their crusts in the name of the starving of Ethiopia. But here we are with the best government we've had in years and all anyone wants to do is tweak its nose for fun. It's a plausible excuse but bunk nonetheless. They'd have voted Ken come what may. They're bored, bored, bored with basically good dull government. fields.headline: AT&T cuts forecasts and jobs
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: AT&T, the US telecommunications and cable group, disappointed investors yesterday when it cut sales and profits forecasts for this year, blaming increased competition.
fields.body:
AT&T, the US telecommunications and cable group, disappointed investors yesterday when it cut sales and profits forecasts for this year, blaming increased competition.

Shares in America's largest telecommunications company fell more than 12% yesterday morning to $42 3/8 as it reported a 13% decline in first-quarter operating profits.

The company announced 6,200 job losses as part of a $2bn cost-cutting drive. AT&T, which is attempting to expand from a strong position in the US long-distance business to fast-growing markets for high-speed and wireless services, said increased competition had led to lower prices in the first quarter.

Consumers were increasingly turning to discount calling plans and wireless telephones while businesses were adopting high-speed data network services.

In a call to analysts, Michael Armstrong, AT&T chairman, said the company would take further steps to hold on to customers and attract new ones.

"We know what to do and how to do it... We will reignite growth." Analysts were disappointed that AT&T was not further along in integrating MediaOne, the cable television company it is buying. AT&T partly blamed regulatory hold-ups.

Speaking on CNBC, a US cable programme, Mr Armstrong said the merger had been held up because "there are a few things going on at the department of justice and federal communications commission" - a reference to the action against Microsoft, as well as planned mergers in the media and cable industries.

AT&T had been expected to complete the merger by early April. Instead, Mr Armstrong said yesterday, it was unlikely to do so until later this summer, further delaying savings expected from merging the two Denver-based businesses.

The company pulled off the biggest initial public offering in US history last week when it span off 16% of its wireless group. The offering raised $10.6bn, to be used for expanding the wireless business.

Mr Armstrong's comments hurt the share prices of other long-distance telecommunications companies yesterday when he described the consumer business as a "mature" one. Shares in Sprint, MCI WorldCom and Qwest Communications fell.

Declining demand led AT&T to reduce its forecast for revenue growth from between 8 and 9% to 7%- 8% this year. It cut operating earnings by about 2 cents a share.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Internet time, as we are repeatedly told, moves at a faster pace than that occupied by the rest of us - like dog years, seven of theirs to every one of ours.
fields.body:
Internet time, as we are repeatedly told, moves at a faster pace than that occupied by the rest of us - like dog years, seven of theirs to every one of ours.

Little surprise then that the market should give credence to suggestions that T-Online, Germany's largest internet service provider, may be preparing a friendly bid for Freeserve. Consolidation, normally a sign of a maturing market, has begun to grip the internet industry already.

Any takeover would need the agreement of Dixons, the high street electrical goods group which still owns 80% of the company.

Freeserve shares climbed 10% on the rumour to 392p, which if nothing else was a welcome fillip for the company which has seen its value halve since rivals forced the introduction of unmetered access. Shares in Dixons were 7.25p higher at 267p.

The FTSE 100 index continued its modest recovery closing 46 points higher at 6,373.4 - its third consecutive rise - helped by a rebound among media and internet stocks.

BSkyB led the way, up almost 11% to £16.85, Reuters was 62p better at £12.03, Pearson, owner of the Financial Times, was marked up 134p to £23.28 and Baltimore Technology soared 11% higher to £70.80.

Baltimore still has some way to go however before re gaining the heady levels of £126.50 it reached at the beginning of March.

The Techmark 100 index closed up 4.2% at 3,825.31.

Other hi-tech stocks benefiting from the overnight rally on Nasdaq included Psion which raced ahead almost 16% to £43.70, and Arm Holdings which ended the session almost 10% higher at 715p.

Many investors though were fixed on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee which meets tomorrow and is expected to increase interest rates yet again.

Volume was well below average at 1.4bn shares traded, although that was also the hangover from another bank holiday.

A clue to the strength of consumer demand was given by Next, the fashion retailer which said like-for-like sales were up 3% during the first 13 weeks of its financial year. Shares in the company inched 2.5p higher to 505p.

It failed to lift other retail stocks however. Monsoon was flat at 57.5p as was House of Fraser at 42.5p. Among the supermarkets, Tesco was 1.5p lower at 217p and Sainsbury gained 1p to finish the session at 335.75p.

Alliance & Leicester was the biggest faller among leading stocks and closed almost 6% lower at 597p.

fields.headline: Paramilitary cold war hots up
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: As Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, the taoiseach, were stepping up attempts to salvage the Good Friday agreement in Downing Street yesterday, republican and loyalist paramilitaries were continuing their cold war.
fields.body:
As Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, the taoiseach, were stepping up attempts to salvage the Good Friday agreement in Downing Street yesterday, republican and loyalist paramilitaries were continuing their cold war.

There may be ceasefires, but peace is relative in Northern Ireland.

Yesterday's toll included a 22-year-old Roman Catholic man shot four times just before dawn as he lay in bed in Dungannon, Co Tyrone. He was said to be in a serious but stable condition last night in hospital.

The masked assailants, believed to be from the IRA, first beat him with a baseball bat and hammer, fracturing his skull. They then subjected him to the latest tactic in the IRA's ongoing campaign of summary justice, the so-called cruxification.

Paul Macdonald was one of four men who left Dungannon in August after the IRA ordered him out of Northern Ireland for what it called anti-social behaviour. But he decided to risk it and returned for the birth of his daughter, Nicola, now four months old

In a bedroom awash with blood, Mr MacDonald's partner, Yolanda Hamilton, who suffered injuries in the attack, said: "It was unbelievable. They beat him, shot him, and then beat him again with a sledgehammer. He is lucky to be alive."

His blood drenched the purple carpet and spattered up the walls. Even a bedside photo of Ms Hamilton's son, Paul, six, was smeared.

She found him cowering under the bedclothes after the masked men had gone. She said he was traumatised.

Loyalists were up to similar law enforcement work. They used a baseball bat to beat up a 21-year-old Protestant man behind a Salvation Army hall in Lisburn, Co Antrim. He suffered a broken arm and leg.

A Catholic family was packing up from the estate in Larne, Co Antrim, where they had lived for 27 years, with the Ulster Defence Association suspected of two attacks in as many days.

His car was petrol-bombed on Monday, and a nail bomb was thrown at the house yesterday.

The UDA blames the father for pulling down its flags, increasingly predominant in even mixed estates in the town.

He denied being responsible yesterday, and said he was not prepared to put his partner and his two-year-old son at further risk. He said: "The paramilitaries are trying to take over this town. The whole atmosphere is terrible. We are getting out while we still have the chance. Peace? Don't make me laugh."

Nor is sectarian violence confined to loyalist attacks on Catholics. Protestants and an Orange Hall have been targeted in a recent campaign in Rathfriland, Co Down. Republicans are suspected.

And Orangemen in Dublin, who were planning their first march in the Irish capital since 1937, this week called off the event. They said they were subjected to a campaign of sectarian intimidation.

Punishment attacks are on the increase again. There are, though, marked differences between the approach of loyalists and republicans.

Loyalist attacks have continued steadily. Until April 23 this year, RUC figures show they carried out 19 shootings and 24 assaults, compared with 14 shootings and 43 assaults in the same period last year. There have been several more incidents in the past week. The RUC admits its tally is incomplete.

But the IRA stopped all punishment shootings after Sinn Fein issued a strong denunciation of them during George Mitchell's successful review of the agreement last November. While there were five assaults, there was not a single punishment shooting for five months.

They began again in March, after Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, had suspended the devolved government, and have continued apace.

There are suggestions the republican leadership has sanctioned a return to such violence to relieve internal tension over the failing peace process.

The RUC's figures for the period to April 23 collate 15 shootings since the resumption seven weeks ago, and 13 assaults. That compares with 12 shootings and 22 assaults in the period up to April 23 last year. The IRA is also believed to have drawn up a death list of five drugs dealers. One assassination bid was foiled last week.

Two men from Newry, Co Down, have left after receiving death threats from Direct Action Against Drugs, an IRA front group which killed nine dealers during its 17-month first ceasefire.

The IRA last year murdered dealers Brendan Fegan and Paul Downey in the border town.

Irish police also fear paramilitary war is close in Dublin. Republicans are suspected over two weekend murders in the city. Each victim was believed to have links to drugs. But they appear to have been murdered because they flouted terrorists' authority.

Pat Neville, a father of six, was shot twice in the head on Saturday in an apparent Irish National Liberation Army revenge attack. One of its members, Patrick Campbell, 22, from West Belfast, was butchered in a battle with drugs dealers in West Dublin last October.

Tommy Byrne, 41, was killed as he drank with friends on Sunday evening outside a Dublin pub. He had beaten up the IRA's officer-commanding in the city in a fight two years ago, and fled Ireland after he was told he would be killed.

Detectives said he returned from Spain recently, after making a financial offer to the IRA leader. He was apparently lulled into believing the deal was acceptable recompense.

webTitle: Bid boost  Ports operator says £1bn is not enough

fields.headline: Bid boost  Ports operator says £1bn is not enough
fields.trailText: Shares in Associated British Ports rose by 20 per cent yesterday after confirmation that it was facing a £1bn bid from Nomura, the Japanese investment bank.
fields.body:
Shares in Associated British Ports rose by 20 per cent yesterday after confirmation that it was facing a £1bn bid from Nomura, the Japanese investment bank.

A deal is still being considered for the company which owns 22 ports and handles a quarter of UK shipping. But the ABP board thought its price was undervalued. It confirmed that it had received an informal approach from advisers to a third party and advised shareholders not to take action but to await developments.

ABP is one of the "old economy" companies to be targetted by private finance groups, anxious to look for bargains in the wake of the sudden surge in new technology and media groups. Its share price has been in decline for the past year, having sunk from 375p to 264p at the end of last week.

It has been involved in a sluggish growth, although its chief executive, Bo Lerenius, is credited with a re-organisation of its ports operation. It has been forced to write off £80m from an American venture. Nomura would be interested in 3,000 acres of land which ABP is selling off. City sources last night ruled out a management buy-out.

ABP operates big ports like Southampton and Immingham, Humberside, and smaller ones such as Troon in Scotland and Whitby in North Yorkshire.

webTitle: Next puts more starch in the linen

fields.headline: Next puts more starch in the linen
fields.trailText: Bad news yesterday for those who had written off Next as the Biba of the 1980s. The clothing retailer that just won't lie down bounced back more than strongly enough to offset dismal April weather and maintain a sales boom that has been under way for at least the first seven weeks of the year.
fields.body:
Bad news yesterday for those who had written off Next as the Biba of the 1980s. The clothing retailer that just won't lie down bounced back more than strongly enough to offset dismal April weather and maintain a sales boom that has been under way for at least the first seven weeks of the year.

If that timespan sounds less than impressive, remember two things. First, Next's figures yesterday gave the lie to the idea that terrible weather keeps the punters indoors. Second, the numbers proved that the Next name is far from defunct - no mean achievement given the number of times since 1987 we have written off the chaps who gave us the double-breasted linen suit.

Funnily enough, it is the previously pessimistic analysts who may have been expected to try to disown their pasts as Miami Vice fans who are most enthusiastic for Next. Last night they were stressing that sales growth had not slowed since Next reported a 3% like-for-like rise for the first seven weeks of the year. They said it was the first real evidence from the clothing sector of how the weather was affecting sales.

"It's a relatively strong statement," said Matthew McEachran at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, someone we would not dream of slandering as a crumpled linen suit man. "This takes Next... through the period of wet weather and [the] non-comparable Easter period, so it's pretty reassuring."

The shares rose 1.5%, by 7.5p to 510p. They have underperformed the retail sector by 15% in the past six months with a price/earnings ratio of 12 (sector average of 14.4), but all signs are that this may go the way of the crushed lime-green T-shirt.

The group said overall sales at Next Retail were up 9.5% and at the mail order arm, Next Directory, 8% ahead of the previous year.

Yesterday's announcement was made to allow Next to brief institutional shareholders on its performance before its annual meeting on May 17. What the institutional bods make of it is a matter for them, but it would be a shame if 30-plus fund managers decided to ditch their pasts and give Next the long goodbye.

"It's a relatively strong statement," said Matthew McEachran at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, someone we would not dream of slandering as a crumpled linen suit man. "This takes Next... through the period of wet weather and [the] non-comparable Easter period, so it's pretty reassuring." The shares rose 1.5%, by 7.5p to 510p. They have underperformed the retail sector by 15% in the past six months with a price/earnings ratio of 12 (sector average of 14.4), but all signs are that this may go the way of the crushed lime-green T-shirt. The group said overall sales at Next Retail were up 9.5% and at the mail order arm, Next Directory, 8% ahead of the previous year. Yesterday's announcement was made to allow Next to brief institutional shareholders on its performance before its annual meeting on May 17. What the institutional bods make of it is a matter for them, but it would be a shame if 30-plus fund managers decided to ditch their pasts and give Next the long goodbye.

fields.headline: Slug & Lettuce
fields.trailText: Once considered a highly promising operator of yuppie bars, Slug & Lettuce has stagnated over the past few years.
fields.body:
Once considered a highly promising operator of yuppie bars, Slug & Lettuce has stagnated over the past few years.

An attempt to expand in northern England has proved tricky and the company's shares have been as flat as a pint of stale stout. They rose 10p to 178.5p yesterday, having peaked at 302p in 1998.

Under pressure from institutions, Slug & Lettuce's management has been looking for a deal to gain size and financial muscle. After aborted discussions with Break for the Border and the Old Monk Company, the group yesterday revealed it was negotiating a merger with Po Na Na, the Ofex-listed chain of exotic nightclubs.

A tie-up has obvious attractions. Po Na Na runs late-night bars, usually in basements, often with a Middle Eastern theme and names such as Souk and Fez. These could be located below branches of Slug & Lettuce, providing an all-in-one night out. One such arrangement exists in Bristol.

Slug & Lettuce brings to the party a full stock market listing, a strong brand and respected management. Its managing director, Sheila McKenzie, was the brains behind the successful Pitcher & Piano chain.

Po Na Na pays lower rents for its basements and is therefore more profitable - it made £1.7m last year on sales of £11m.

The big variable, however, is the licensing law. Some kind of liberalisation has been promised by the government, though how opening hours will be affected is uncertain.

In a situation where pubs and clubs are allowed to open late, there would be obvious problems with the two brands cannibalising each other's customers.

Any deal is likely to be an all-paper transaction and Po Na Na will get the upper hand; with 41 outlets, its market value is £41m, against Slug & Lettuce's £25m.

Any offer for Slug & Lettuce is likely to be in the region of 180p to 190p. Institutions will jump at the chance to liven up the business.

webTitle: BA's new chief mixes it with his edgy employees

fields.headline: BA's new chief mixes it with his edgy employees
fields.standfirst: Lord Marshall's latest find is expected to cut jobs
fields.trailText: Rod Eddington of British Airways spent a large part of yesterday, his first day at work as chief executive, speaking to cabin crew on the Boeing 747 which brought him from Sydney to London.
fields.body:
Rod Eddington of British Airways spent a large part of yesterday, his first day at work as chief executive, speaking to cabin crew on the Boeing 747 which brought him from Sydney to London.

BA executives called it "feeling the pulse of the company," saying that they had known nothing like it for the past four years, the time which Mr Eddington's predecessor, Bob Ayling, was in the job.

If Mr Ayling had been on the plane, he would probably have quietly remained in first class with his head in his papers, nervous of mingling with the staff. But Mr Eddington's new colleagues say that he is built differently. They say he puts people first.

Cabin staff on board his jumbo yesterday would have been made aware of his presence.

Mr Eddington, who was chief executive at Cathay Pacific and executive chairman of Ansett, Australia's second airline, says: "I have very much focused on the people issues as well as the business strategy issues. The two have to work together, but I have always recognised that people are a key differentiator in this business."

His priority on arrival will be to meet as many people as possible in the business, although his first official act was to launch business fare reductions of up to 50% for domestic travel within the UK.

A BA insider made light of the move. "It looks good, except that we don't have many people flying business class in Britain."

A fund of goodwill exists within the company for Mr Eddington, and staff have quickly renamed BA as "British Australian" airlines. But Mr Eddington will have to overcome an overtly cautious attitude by his 63,000 employees, who feel that they were largely ignored under the Ayling regime.

This is highlighted in a spoof notice to Mr Eddington going round BA, purportedly signed by Mr Ayling. It says: "The objective of all dedicated company employees should be to analyse thoroughly all situations, anticipate all problems, have answers for these problems, and move swiftly to solve these problems when called upon. However, when you are up to your arse in alligators, it is difficult to remind yourself that your initial objective was to drain the swamp."

Well though he might want to get on with staff, Mr Eddington is facing considerable problems at BA, the most pressing of which is how in the long term he will be able to turn round the huge losses the airline will be announcing within three weeks.

BA's results have been so well trailed that when they arrive they will not take the City by surprise, if only because analysts believe that the company has already put in train a positive plan to get the company back on its feet. Smaller planes and an increased emphasis on the business traveller are the weapons to take the airline forward, BA's board has decided.

But a loss of around £200m does not look good for the airline, and the unions feel that Mr Eddington will wield the cost-cutting axe which Mr Ayling palpably failed to sharpen while he was chief executive.

As the new man, Eddington does not have to take the responsibility for the heavy losses, a duty which will fall squarely on the shoulders of BA's chairman, Lord Marshall. Nevertheless, Mr Eddington will very soon have to consider how BA can be raised from the trough into which it has fallen.

Mr Ayling once admitted that he had failed to rid BA fully of its old status as a state-owned company, and he quickly backed away from a confrontation with cabin crew which cost BA £125m in lost revenue.

Mr Eddington comes to BA with a more no-nonsense reputation than Mr Ayling enjoyed. He was involved in a cabin crew strike at Cathay in 1993 over working conditions, and he brushed with the pilots in 1994 over expatriate pay. There have also been labour related instances at Ansett.

BA has a large staff which will almost certainly have to be reduced over the next five years. Mr Ayling achieved staff cuts largely by early retirement and voluntary redundancy. The unions are worried that Mr Eddington might adopt a tougher approach, at the same time trying to im prove morale, a delicate balancing act.

The airline's board and shareholders will see his main task as being to restore profitability and lift the share price, which at least is now comfortably over 300p. City analysts stress that he will also have to deal with BA's debt mountain. Debt is depressing equity returns because of the high interest payments associated with high capital spending and poor cash flow.

Mr Eddington became available for the job once it became known that Rupert Murdoch's News Limited had sold its 50% stake in Ansett to Air New Zealand. Lord Marshall wanted somebody in place quickly. In Mr Eddington, he may well have found the ruthless hand in the velvet glove for which he has been looking.

fields.headline: It came from outer space
fields.standfirst:
The South Africans have called in Nasa to identify two metal balls that farmers say fell from the sky. It's not the first time man-made junk has come hurtling out of orbit, says James Meek, and it certainly won't be the last

Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: The South Africans have called in Nasa to identify two metal balls that farmers say fell from the sky. It's not the first time man-made junk has come hurtling out of orbit, says James Meek, and it certainly won't be the last<
fields.body:
Somewhere up in the airless cold of space is a piece of British rubbish, at least 10cm long, aimlessly whizzing round the earth. Neither Major Perry Nouis, of US Space Command in Colorado, which is tracking it, nor Richard Tremayne-Smith, of the British National Space Centre, were sure off the top of their heads yesterday what exactly it might be. But it's up there, our own humble contribution to the hazards of space shipping.

One of the signs of being a powerful, technologically advanced country these days is the ability to pollute space. In the cosmic litter stakes, we are small fry - one fly-dumped heap of junk in orbit, compared with more than 3,000 items of space trash tagged to the US and 2,500 from the countries of the former Soviet Union. But we can be proud that we still have the science clout, and the money, to leave one piece of high-tech mess in the cosmos, putting us on a par with Germany.

There's a lot of space in space. Enough, governments and space businesses have always reckoned, to sling satellites into orbit, use them and abandon them with the insouciance of a householder tipping an old washing machine on to the pavement. But even the dumping of old washing machines is, in theory, regulated by law. And old washing machines aren't travelling at 17,000 miles an hour. At that speed, even a discarded Mars Bar wrapper would smash through the delicate hull of a space station like a missile.

A few years ago, engineers inspecting a space shuttle after its return from orbit discovered that a speck of paint which had flaked off another, unknown terrestrial spacecraft had penetrated the shuttle's windscreen. The windscreen is eight inches thick. The speck of paint had penetrated five inches. No wonder the shuttle, when in orbit, flies with extreme caution - upside down and backwards.

US Space Command is now tracking more than 8,000 pieces of human-made space junk in orbit around earth. That doesn't mean there are only 8,000: it's just that the organisation's radars can't pick out anything smaller. There are an estimated 70,000-150,000 garbage tiddlers, between one and 10cm, swirling through the space lanes, and millions of dust-sized particles generated by the daily grind of human spacework.

Space shuttles have already had to shift their orbits nine times to dodge dangerous bits of debris. Some of the ducking and weaving is the result of a kind of delayed boomerang effect. Nasa astronauts are at risk from objects such as spanners and gloves which their colleagues carelessly let go years earlier.

Despite the danger, the only significant collision in space so far between one man-made object and another was the 1997 Mir incident, when a pleasant but stressed-out cosmonaut, Vasily Tsibliyev, accidentally steered an unmanned cargo tug loaded with soiled underwear into the space station.

There is really only one large, permanently manned object in space large enough to present a reliable target for the swarm of high-speed tools, dead satellites, flotsam and jetsam: Earth itself.

Much of the space junk now in orbit is destined to end its days in a plume of flame as it slows to below the magic 17,000mph figure needed to sustain its orbit. It arcs into the upper atmosphere, bumps against the thickening air like a speeding car scraping a crash barrier, heats up, begins to burn, and disintegrates before it reaches the ground.

Only the largest objects, such as satellites, spent rocket boosters and, in one particularly egregious instance of chaotic cosmic tipping, an entire space station - Skylab, which crashed into Australia in 1979 - ever reach the ground. There is no recorded case of anyone ever being hurt by a piece of falling space debris. The chances of being killed by something of human origin falling from outer space are less than of winning the lottery jackpot twice.

That said, they do fall, and with surprising frequency. The white-hot, 70lb metal sphere that buried itself with a loud boom in the soil of Pieter Viljoen's vineyards in South Africa recently, only 50 yards from where a group of employees was working, followed by a second, bigger, rectangular lump of metal elsewhere in the country the following day, was only one of the more prominent in a series of artificial heavenly strikes which has averaged one a day for 40 years.

Since the space age began with the launch of the Soviet Sputnik in 1957, more than 16,000 objects of human origin have reentered the earth's atmosphere, with 325 larger than 1m across before atmospheric friction kicked in. Most have landed in the sea, though that does not always prevent them being found. Recently, the US announced a piece of an Ariane rocket had been washed up on its shores, while Japan had found a large chunk of a US rocket booster emerging from the surf.

Tremayne-Smith said that a mysterious crash in the Highlands last year, which originally provoked mutterings about UFOs, had almost certainly been the return to earth of a Russian upper stage booster rocket.

What made the Skylab episode different was that the space station's imminent demise was forecast weeks in advance, allowing plenty of time for panic to build up in the generous swathe of the earth's surface where Nasa predicted it might fall. A similar, more justified anxiety was caused by the predicted crash in 1983 of a Soviet Cosmos satellite - the craft had a nuclear power pack, and parts of it were scattered over northern Canada, where they were laboriously tracked down and gathered in.

Most crashes happen without warning. In 1997, a pair of objects similar to the two that came down in South Africa barrelled into the ground in Texas. One landed only 50 yards from a farmhouse in Georgetown. Like the South African debris, they were thought to have come from a US Delta II rocket.

The world champion at inflicting space debris on its own citizens was the USSR, which rained rocket boosters on its necessarily uncomplaining people from the launch site of its Baikonour cosmodrome in what is now the independent country of Kazakhstan. The launches continue - many now funded by western operators - but the Kazakhs, and southern Russian territories, which have suffered the same problem, have begun to complain loudly. Near another launch site, Plesetsk in the north-west, falling rocket parts are so common that people have used them to repair country cottages or build sledges.

For governments and the space industry, however, the issue of the steadily increasing amount of space junk in orbit is more pressing than the amount that falls to earth. Indeed, a safe burn-up in the atmosphere is considered a good result for a redundant satellite, bettered only by the more expensive option of parking it in a higher, "graveyard" orbit. Talk is increasingly of obliging satellite operators to build safe disposal into their programmes.

For Steve and Verona Gutowski, who owned the Texas farmhouse near where one of the 1997 Delta rocket parts fell, the impact was eerily reminiscent of countless extraterrestrial arrivals, from War of the Worlds onwards. They were awakened in the small hours by the barking of their dogs; they saw a large glowing object had landed in their hayfield. It was so hot that the soil around it was baked hard. Sure enough, it wasn't long before the UFO enthusiasts began to flood in.

If it ever turns out that the UFOs have been buzzing us all this time, perhaps their banal message is nothing to do with invasion or offers of ancient extraplanetary wisdom. Perhaps their opening gambit, as they fling open the hatch, furiously shaking a mangled piece of our space scrap, will be: "Excuse me, did you drop this?" They will call it space rage.

webTitle: Howells steps up pressure to curb social exclusion

fields.headline: Howells steps up pressure to curb social exclusion
fields.trailText: The government will this week step up pressure on the private sector to attack poverty and social exclusion, as a new report calls for social responsibility demands to be made on smaller companies as well as multinationals.
fields.body:
The government will this week step up pressure on the private sector to attack poverty and social exclusion, as a new report calls for social responsibility demands to be made on smaller companies as well as multinationals.

In the wake of the latest anti-capitalist demonstrations, Kim Howells will make his first major speeches since being appointed minister for corporate social responsibility in March. He will set out his priorities at two conferences on Thursday, stressing the responsibility of the business world to contribute to social justice.

Mr Howells is expected to stress that businesses can benefit from behaving responsibly towards employees, communities and the environment. The department of trade and industry minister is likely to link social responsibility with the government's key industrial theme of competitiveness.

He will introduce a report from the Institute for Public Policy Research arguing that businesses of all sizes should be engaged in countering social exclusion.

Following controversies such as Barclays' branch closures and BMW's sale of Rover, the minister's speeches will be watched closely for indications of how interventionist the government is prepared to be.

So far it has shied away from putting a legal requirement on directors to take account of social and environmental issues. But Mr Howell's new responsibilities, on top of his corporate and consumer affairs brief, are aimed at pushing these issues up the business agenda.

The IPPR report will call for more attention to be paid to the social responsibility of smaller companies. Most attention has typically focused on controversial multinationals such as Nike and Shell.

Ella Joseph of the IPPR says smaller companies are engaged in their communities and can be important in overcoming social exclusion.

She argues that there are business benefits in what she describes as "corporate social engagement".

In her report: A Welcome Engagement, Ms Joseph says that any private sector approach to social exclusion must include smaller companies as they account for more than half the country's jobs.

The report sets out a series of tasks for the new minister. It says he must act as a focal point within government, collect data on corporate engagement, promote the benefits to business and highlight best practice.

 Shell cancelled 62 contracts last year and walked away from one joint venture because of breaches of its business principles, mainly on health, safety and environmental issues. The oil company also fired four employees who were found to have received bribes worth a total of $153,000.

The figures are revealed in the Shell report: People, Planet and Profits, the third annual report on the group's social and environmental performance.

The figures are revealed in the Shell report: People, Planet and Profits, the third annual report on the group's social and environmental performance.

fields.headline: Publicis confirms Y&R talks
fields.trailText: Publicis, the Paris marketing services group, yesterday confirmed talks had been opened which could lead to a merger with Young & Rubicam to create the world's fourth largest advertising business.
fields.body:
Publicis, the Paris marketing services group, yesterday confirmed talks had been opened which could lead to a merger with Young & Rubicam to create the world's fourth largest advertising business.

Publicis said the group's board had mandated its president, Maurice Levy, to "explore the possibility of an agreement with Y&R". The US agency is understood to have approached Publicis about 10 days ago to escape the clutches of WPP, the London-quoted marketing services group run by Sir Martin Sorrell.

Y&R chief executive Tom Bell is thought to favour a deal with Publicis because it would be more a merger of equals. Mr Bell has been in his job only since the beginning of the year and is said to be reluctant to give up control.

WPP yesterday confirmed that its discussions with Y&R had broken down over the weekend and the US group, which has frustrated investors by its lacklustre share price, may find itself under increasing pressure to do a deal. A strongly worded addendum to the Publicis statement suggested that any conclusion of the discussions is some way off. "Rumours of an imminent agreement are premature" it said suggesting that the alternative to the WPP deal is less secure than Y&R would like.

Sir Martin is understood to have been angered by last minute demands made by Y&R including a clause which would have granted the business autonomy from WPP for another year. Shares in WPP yesterday closed down 35p at £10.

Publicis sources said the French group was under no pressure to do a deal because of the strong growth of the business. It has grown aggressively through acquisition and last year profits increased by 42%. "We have good reason to hope that things move forward but we are just at the beginning of the process," said one insider. WPP is understood to not have ruled out a return to the negotiating table.

A pairing of Publicis and Y&R could cause difficulties of client conflict, most notably between Ford, a client of the US group, and Renault, a key client of the French, though consolidation in the industry has caused some large advertisers to reduce their opposition to such conflicts.

webTitle: Lab test Barclay brothers back biotech float

fields.headline: Lab test Barclay brothers back biotech float
fields.trailText: The reclusive Barclay brothers, whose business empire spans the Scotsman newspaper group and Ritz Hotel, are to make a rare foray on to the stock market by floating a biotechnology company that is developing a drug designed to combat thrombosis.
fields.body:
The reclusive Barclay brothers, whose business empire spans the Scotsman newspaper group and Ritz Hotel, are to make a rare foray on to the stock market by floating a biotechnology company that is developing a drug designed to combat thrombosis.

Trigen Holdings is only the second company that multi-millionaires David and Frederick have brought to market, following the flotation of London Clubs International in 1994. Their association with LCI ended because of a potential conflict of interest caused by purchase of the Ritz and its casino operations.

The brothers have invested a total of £9.5m in Trigen, which was spun out of the Thrombosis Research Institute in 1992, and they have full control.

Close Brothers, the nominated adviser to the issue, expects the company to be valued at about £80m when the shares come to market on May 22. The Barclays' holding is likely to bediluted to about 75% following the float and they have pledged not to sell their shares for 18 months.

An estimated £15m will be raised from the issue and used to speed its drugs' arrival on the market. A small number of shares will be available to retail investors.

Trigen is focused on prevention and treatment of the blood clotting, called thrombosis, and disorders of blood vessels. The condition is one of the most common causes of heart attacks and strokes.

Trigen is pinning its hopes on TRI 50b, which is about to enter phase III trials. Intravenous and oral versions have been developed and chief executive Sanjay Kakkar (pictured) wants to ally with multinational companies to exploit its commercial potential.

AstraZeneca and 3D Pharmaceuticals of the US are also developing drugs to combat thrombosis but Dr Kakkar claimed: "With our links to the TRI we're ahead of the pack".

The Barclays' link with Trigen stems from a long term friendship with Dr Kakkar's father, Professor Vijay Kakkar, who is director of the TRI.

The brothers will be represented on the Trigen board by Philip Peters, a former investment banker who also sits on the board of Scotsman Publications and Ellerman Investments, holding company for the Ritz and other Barclay family properties.

webTitle: Straw attacks charity plea for gifts to asylum seekers

fields.headline: Straw attacks charity plea for gifts to asylum seekers
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, has criticised a charity appeal for toy donations for children of asylum seekers, saying it is based on a serious misunderstanding of the asylum voucher system.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, has criticised a charity appeal for toy donations for children of asylum seekers, saying it is based on a serious misunderstanding of the asylum voucher system.

More than eight boxfuls of toys have been received by the National Asylum Support Service (Nass) in response to the appeal by the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture.

The appeal was launched after it became clear that the new asylum regulations meant toys were not included in the official definition of "essential living needs" when the Home Office calculated that a child under 16 needed £26.60 a week.

The charity world fears that Mr Straw will start counting the value of donations to asylum seekers in the form of clothes, pots and pans, school uniforms and travelling expenses against their weekly voucher allowance, and deduct the value of these items from the allowance.

Neil Gerrard, Labour MP for Walthamstow and chairman of the Commons all party group on refugees, has tabled an early day motion calling on MPs to support the appeal.

The Nass headquarters in Croydon, south London, has set up special arrangements to pass the toys on to asylum seekers.

Mr Straw has written to Helen Bamber of the medical foundation to say that it is a serious misunderstanding to believe his measures "deprive the children of asylum seekers".

He said: "The regulations point out that toys are not to be treated as essential living needs. That provision is to ensure that families are not regarded as destitute simply because they cannot afford toys

"It does not prevent asylum seekers from purchasing toys with their vouchers/cash. And it certainly does not prevent [donations of] toys to children of asylum seekers."

webTitle: Barclays throws cold water on US bid for Hyder

fields.headline: Barclays throws cold water on US bid for Hyder
fields.trailText: A US takeover bid for Hyder, the Welsh-based utility, was thrown into doubt last night when Barclays withdrew its financial backing amid speculation that it had been "nobbled" by a rival bidder.
fields.body:
A US takeover bid for Hyder, the Welsh-based utility, was thrown into doubt last night when Barclays withdrew its financial backing amid speculation that it had been "nobbled" by a rival bidder.

Hyder would be broken up under plans outlined yesterday by Western Power Distribution (WPD), an electricity provider owned by Pennsylvania Power and Light and Southern Company.

The American group said it would sell Hyder's Welsh water business, Dwr Cymru Cyfyngedig, to a non-profit making organisation, a move clearly aimed at soothing concerns of the water regulator.

Yesterday morning the non-profit vehicle established to take control of Dwr Cymru Cyfyngedig said it was backed by Barclays Capital. But by the afternoon Barclays had pulled out amid whispers it had faced relentless pressure not to undermine the position of Nomura Securities of Japan, which tabled its own agreed £2.3bn offer for Hyder on April 18.

A spokesman for WPD insisted later that alternative financial support would be obtained shortly and its plans remained on track.

"It's disappointing but it's not a major problem. We have plenty of others to turn to and a beauty parade is going on now," a spokesman said.

Nomura denied it had put pressure on Barclays. A spokesman said: "It was them [WPD] who put pressure on Barclays. We just suggested we would like them to work with us and they agreed."

Barclays Capital would not comment on the speculation but insisted that it was not working on any bid.

Earlier, shares in Hyder had soared as WPD formally signalled it would join the bid battle. WPD said it would "seek a recommendation from Hyder's board at a premium to the current offer".

WPD is proposing to retain Hyder's electricity operations, which would fit alongside its own electricity distribution business in south-west England.

The water business would go to the non-profit making trust, while management and operations would go to United Utilities, which controls a similar business in north-west England.

WPD could not buy Dwr Cymru Cyfyngedig without facing an inquiry from the competition commission, which automatically investigates all water industry mergers worth more than £30m.

fields.headline: Addicts denied fair trial
fields.standfirst: Flood of new appeals expected after Strasbourg court ruling on right to silence
fields.trailText: The appeal court is likely to face a flood of applications to reopen cases after the European court of human rights in Strasbourg ruled yesterday that two drug addicts who refused to answer questions in the police station were denied a fair trial.
fields.body:
The appeal court is likely to face a flood of applications to reopen cases after the European court of human rights in Strasbourg ruled yesterday that two drug addicts who refused to answer questions in the police station were denied a fair trial.

The Strasbourg court ruled that the judges who threw out an appeal by William and Karen Codron against their convictions for supplying heroin were wrong to take it upon themselves to decide that their conviction was safe even though the trial judge's direction to the jury was defective.

The ruling means that the appeal court can no longer follow its longstanding practice of putting itself in the jury's place and deciding that the judge's error would have made no difference to the verdict. If the judge's directions to the jury are not adequate, the appeal court cannot correct them but must quash the conviction.

The couple were convicted in 1995 and sentenced to four years in prison for supplying heroin after police observed them passing packages to their next-door neighbour in their south London council block across the balcony which joined the two flats.

When they were taken to the police station they refused to answer questions on the advice of their solicitor, who argued that they were not fit to be questioned because they were suffering heroin withdrawal symptoms. The doctor who examined them at the station disagreed. At the trial the jury was told why they had not answered police questions.

The judge directed the jury that they could draw "adverse inferences" from their silence under questioning even if they accepted the defendants' reasons for not answering the questions.

The appeal court criticised this direction but nevertheless ruled that the conviction was safe.

The seven Strasbourg judges unanimously held that the couple's right to a fair trial was violated, and ordered the UK government to pay £15,000 for their costs and expenses.

They said the court had "no means of ascertaining whether or not the applicants' silence paid a significant role in the jury's decision to convict".

Since juries did not give reasons for convicting "it was impossible to ascertain what weight, if any, was given to the applicants' silence".

The jury should have been directed that it should draw an adverse inference only if it believed the defendants had no answer or none that would stand up to cross-examination. Since the jury was not properly directed, the imperfection in the direction could not be remedied on appeal.

Mary Cuneen, associate director of the human rights group Liberty, which backed the Strasbourg application, said: "The judgment affirms the fundamental importance of the right to silence in the criminal trial process. Any attempts to erode this right must be treated with the utmost caution.

"In future, courts will have to be extremely careful in drawing inferences.

"The court of appeal will have to change its approach when considering appeals to consider not only whether the conviction as a whole is safe but also whether it is fair in terms of article 6 [of the European Convention on Human Rights, which guarantees the right to a fair trial]."

Inroads on the right of silence brought in by the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act of 1994 have proved a minefield for judges and are bound to provoke a wave of challenges in the English courts once the Human Rights Act comes into force next October.

Before then suspects had an absolute right to refuse to answer questions either in the police station or in court, but the act allowed juries to draw adverse inferences from silence in appropriate circumstances.

The human rights court held in 1996 that silence is not an absolute right, but another four cases on how far safeguards must extend are pending in Strasbourg.

fields.headline: Baby food health warning
fields.trailText: Baby foods bought in high street shops contain high levels of sugar and carry misleading labels, the Consumers' Association warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Baby foods bought in high street shops contain high levels of sugar and carry misleading labels, the Consumers' Association warned yesterday.

A survey of 420 baby foods, which compared jars, chilled and dried baby foods made by leading manufacturers, found that nearly 40% of all foods contained sugar or fruit juice and 60% of breakfast cereals contained added sugars.

Which? the association's magazine, also found that a further 40% contained starch additives which can stop food separating.

Because they absorb water, some critics believe that starch additives are used to bulk out the food. In addition, six savoury meals were found to contain glucose syrup, a form of sugar.

Breakfasts by leading brands such as Farleys and Milupa were sweetened with added sugar, while dried meals by Sainsbury's and Boots contained starches.

Which? highlighted the Baby Organix and Simply Organic Baby Food from the Original Fresh Babyfood Company as not containing any starches or sugars.

The survey also found that some products had meaningless phrases on their labels such as "specially formulated" and "wholesome ingredients", while others, such as some fruit yoghurts, were found to contain only fruit flavouring. Government health guidelines recommend that baby food should usually be free from, or low in sugars, including those from fruit juice.

Graham Jacobs, the editor of Which? said: "Bought baby foods are convenient and easy to use, but should be part of a mixed weaning diet that includes home-made foods. In our comparison of brands we found a lot of added sugars and starches."

He added: "Check ingredients carefully to see exactly what you're getting. Our results show it's clearly worth comparing brands and ranges."

The report urges mothers and fathers to prepare home- made baby food whenever they can so they can control what goes into it.

A report from the food commission found earlier this year that small children's teeth are at risk from some biscuits specially designed for babies and toddlers.

The report found that the biscuits are sweeter than jam tarts or doughnuts and urged parents to look carefully at the small print and ignore the highly sweetened brands.

The food commission survey found 50% sugar in Nestle Fruit Stick and 37% in Boots Teddy Bear biscuits, compared with 36% in a jam tart.

Traditional Farley's Rusks were found to have more sugar than a chocolate digestive.

fields.trailText:
Cruise workers killed in Hawaii
Sharon Smith, 28, and Claire Breasley, 27, were killed in a car crash on the island of Maui in Hawaii, while on a night ashore from a cruise liner. Ms Smith, from Birmingham, was a dealer in the ship's casino, and Ms Breasley was the ship's photographer.

They were with four Turkish waiters from the ship, two of whom were also killed. The hired car's driver, Davut Duman, 30, has been charged with negligent homicide.

You're a hit, Mrs Robinson
Hollywood star Kathleen Turner's run as Mrs Robinson in a West End production of The Graduate has been extended by six weeks.

The play has broken all box office records at the Gielgud Theatre.

GM re-trial for Lord Melchett
The crown prosecution service announced yesterday that it will seek a retrial of Lord Melchett and 27 others on charges of conspiracy to commit criminal damage to GM crops.

The peer, executive director of Greenpeace, and his co-defendants were cleared of theft at Norwich crown court last month, but the jury failed to agree verdicts on charges of criminal damage and theft.

Three hour wait for ambulance
Greater Manchester ambulance service is investigating why it took three hours for a vehicle to arrive in response to a GP's "one-hour urgent transfer to hospital" call early on Saturday.

Winifred Whittaker, 84, from Chadderton, who had a heart condition, was dead on arrival at hospital; the service called the family twice, once to warn of delay and later to inquire as to the woman's condition.Helen Carter

webTitle: New Film Council to 'shamelessly' back British blockbusters

fields.headline: New Film Council to 'shamelessly' back British blockbusters
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The new Film Council will be "shameless" in trying to do deals with Hollywood studios that ensure that British movies are seen in the multiplexes.
fields.body:
The new Film Council will be "shameless" in trying to do deals with Hollywood studios that ensure that British movies are seen in the multiplexes.

Its chief executive, John Woodward, said the new body, launched yesterday to oversee the spending of £50m a year of lottery and government money, would make no apologies for concentrating on commercial films.

"We are interested in films that really can play in cinemas on a Friday night, and we will not be backing films whose natural home is on television," he said.

Council chairman Alan Parker, the director of Evita and Angela's Ashes, said the "little Englander" mentality had to be ditched if "we are to move away from the cottage industry that we all currently work in".

He said the industry had to embrace Hollywood backers and also work more closely with European producers, who were increasingly moving into English-language film and seeing Britain as a bridge into the American market.

The British Screen office in Los Angeles, which tries to lure American films to shoot in the UK, was being expanded, he said, and £4.2m will be set aside to help European co-productions.

Nearly half of the £22m the council will invest, however, will go into 10 to 12 populist British films a year.

Mr Woodward said the council could invest up to £8m in a single project if they thought it was good enough. A further £6m will go into script development and into improving the "patchy" training industry writers and executives now get.

Even so £5m - more than twice what the British Film Institute was previously allowed to spend - will be set aside for encouraging arthouse films and bringing on new talent.

webTitle: Man on flight 'given pill and robbed'

fields.headline: Man on flight 'given pill and robbed'
fields.trailText: A Japanese businessman was drugged into a coma and robbed during a flight to Britain, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A Japanese businessman was drugged into a coma and robbed during a flight to Britain, a court heard yesterday.

Osamu Shimizu was taken to hospital from the Rome-to-Gatwick Alitalia flight last September, after a sleeping drug was slipped into his airline coffee, Chichester crown court was told. Bruno Saputo, from Rome, denies drugging and robbing Mr Shimizu of £135.

The hearing is a trial of issue, in which jurors must decide only what Saputo's actions had been, not his intentions. At a hearing last month Mr Justice Sessions declared him unfit to be tried.

Yesterday the jury heard that Mr Shimizu was so heavily drugged that a doctor on the flight could not wake him, and he was comatose when taken to the East Surrey hospital in Redhill. Forensic analysis of his coffee cup revealed the sleeping drug flurazepam.

Alison Barker, prosecuting, claimed that Saputo had put the drug into the coffee while Mr Shimizu was in the toilet.

Mr Shimizu said he had noticed a white film on his half-drunk coffee but had drunk it anyway. In a statement read to the court he said: "It is deemed rude and bad mannered in Japan if you leave any drink or food at the table."

Within minutes he felt sick and light headed and later collapsed, the jury heard.

Saputo was then seen taking the man's jacket from an overhead locker and going through the pockets, Miss Barker said. He was arrested and found to be carrying £135, the amount Mr Shimizu reported stolen.

No evidence was offered by the defence. Saputo has not formally entered a plea, but when interviewed by police he denied drugging Mr Shimizu and stealing his money.

The jury was told that Saputo, who has been in custody since the flight, had refused to go into the dock or the courtroom yesterday. The case continues.

webTitle: MoD rules out action over recruit's death

fields.headline: MoD rules out action over recruit's death
fields.trailText: A Royal Marines officer will not face criminal proceedings or a court martial over the death of a 16-year-old recruit on a training exercise, the Ministry of Defence said yesterday.
fields.body:
A Royal Marines officer will not face criminal proceedings or a court martial over the death of a 16-year-old recruit on a training exercise, the Ministry of Defence said yesterday.

The recruit, Nathaniel Burton, drowned in October 1998 while crossing Crazy Well Pool on Dartmoor with other members of 748 troop from the commando training centre, Lympstone, Devon.

He had been on the 30-week training course, which is considered to be one of the toughest in the world, for 11 weeks.

At an inquest in March 1999 coroner Brian Hall-Tomkin recorded a verdict of accidental death on the teenager, who was crossing the pool with a buoyancy aid made from his rucksack wrapped in a poncho.

The coroner said at the hearing that Lieutenant Nathan Martin, who was commander of 748 troop, did not have to read his statement aloud as investigations into the incident were under way.

The MoD said yesterday that no proceedings, internal or external, would be taken against Lt Martin - who is now a captain - or anyone else following a "full and detailed" investigation.

A spokesman said: "The evidence in the investigation has all been carefully considered by the crown prosecution service, the health and safety executive and the internal prosecuting authority to see if there was any evidence for a prosecution against any individual, and the answer was no."

Mr Burton's mother, Lynne Kellow, from Bradninch, east Devon, said after the inquest that she did not blame anyone for her son's death.

He had always wanted to be a Royal Marine and they all knew training had to be hard to achieve the green beret, she said.

"There is no way we want to point the finger of blame at anybody," said Mrs Kellow.

"We have no doubt that the training as it stands is entirely necessary. We want everybody to know that we cannot view Nathaniel's death as anything but accidental."

fields.headline: Signalman 'drunk in box'
fields.trailText: A railway signalman was found snoring in his box surrounded by ringing phones, buzzing alarms and a possible smell of alcohol, with three trains stuck outside in front of a danger signal locked at red, a court heard yesterday,.
fields.body:
A railway signalman was found snoring in his box surrounded by ringing phones, buzzing alarms and a possible smell of alcohol, with three trains stuck outside in front of a danger signal locked at red, a court heard yesterday,.

Drivers of early morning commuter services eventually left their cabs to discover the scene at Horbury near Wakefield, West Yorkshire, where Andrew Westmoreland was only woken after ambulancemen yanked at his uniform belt. Wakefield magistrates heard the signalman had said that he wanted to go home and have a sleep. He then did just that, followed by police.

Westmoreland, 36, denies being drunk in charge of the signal box on August 31 last year, drinking on duty and drink-driving. The court heard he was found to have more than four times the legal driving limit of alcohol in his blood.

Westmoreland told the court he felt sick shortly after arriving for work. "I started vomiting. The next thing I knew I was laid out and an ambulance was there."

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: Hospital gets ex-patient's father barred
fields.trailText: Great Ormond Street hospital has obtained a high court injunction to stop a man entering its grounds or harassing doctors who cared for his son before he died aged 16.
fields.body:
Great Ormond Street hospital has obtained a high court injunction to stop a man entering its grounds or harassing doctors who cared for his son before he died aged 16.

Barry Suddell, whose son Jay died in 1996, faces a fine or a jail sentence if he enters the hospital, and has also been told not to distribute posters and leaflets as part of a campaign accusing doctors of manslaughter and conspiracy.

The hospital went to the high court after Mr Suddell entered its cardiac unit in March and shouted abuse at staff and patients.

He is also alleged to have threatened and taken photographs of the four doctors who treated his son during the two weeks he received treatment before his death.

The hospital obtained the injunction against Mr Suddell, from Rainham, Essex, on March 20.

Jay, who was born with a congenital heart defect which occurs in about four of every 10,000 births, underwent heart surgery at Great Ormond Street as a baby in 1980. He was readmitted to the hospital in 1996 after he began coughing blood, but died 12 days later after surgery.

A spokeswoman for the hospital yesterday denied reports that the trust and the doctors - John Deanfield, a cardiologist, James Taylor, a consultant paediatric cardiologist, Ian James, a consultant anaes thetist and Robert Yates, a paediatric intensive care consultant - were planning to sue him for damages.

She said: "The hospital has tried to help this man and we have carried out thorough investigations into his case more than once over the years, which have found nothing wrong in the way his son was treated."

She added: "We have a counselling service to help families in these situations, but it was felt this man had gone too far. He had photographs of the doctors and was accusing them of conspiracy to manslaughter and medical negligence. The doctors were concerned for their safety and the decision was made to obtain the injunction."

Jay's heart defect, which can now be corrected by surgery, meant that the two main arteries taking blood away from the heart were transposed.

The hospital spokeswoman added: "He was fine up until 1996 then he became unwell again. He had an operation, but despite all the efforts of the doctors he died."

After his death, a coroner decided that an inquest was not required.

Commenting on the injunction, Robert Creighton, the hospital's chief executive, told the Evening Standard: "My responsibility is to ensure the safety of our patients and our staff. We have never done anything like this before and I think it must be quite rare."

He added: "He appeared one evening when patients were still in the waiting area and started to abuse individual staff and the hospital."

Mr Suddell insisted yesterday that he had done nothing wrong and that his son had been the victim of medical malpractice.

He said: "They are making me out to look like a thug. I am not a thug. How can I be harassing the doctors when they do not even know what I look like?"

He added: "I have spent the last three and a half years trying to get people to listen to my story and no one has even had the decency to try and get back in touch with me.

"My son was 16 years old and as fit as a fiddle. They told me he was all right. Then he died and I found out he needed a full heart and lung transplant. They are trying to cover it all up."

The hospital's spokeswoman said that it had in no way been "pro-active" in bringing the injunction.

She said: "We did not wish to publicise this story - it is such a sad affair."

webTitle: Only a tree can stop Ken now

fields.headline: Only a tree can stop Ken now
fields.standfirst:
Imogen Walker has spent the past four weeks as Ken Livingstone's warm-up act. She reports from the campaign bus on the real dangers of running for mayor

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Imogen Walker has spent the past four weeks as Ken Livingstone's warm-up act. She reports from the campaign bus on the real dangers of running for mayor
fields.body:
Every day I talk face-to-face with thousands of people. Sometimes I ask them questions that are none of my business. Normally they smile and wave back at me, sometimes they hang out of upstairs windows. But things only really start to take off when a 54-year-old man in a shabby Columbo-style raincoat takes over. Because I work the microphone of Ken Livingstone's campaign bus.

We have a purple open-topped double-decker bus equipped with a PA system and "Hoot4Ken" written on the side, and for the past three and a half weeks we have been driving around London playing loud music, dancing and talking to the people on the street. When Ken is there, obviously he does the talking but when he is not, I do.

Actually, there are three of us (myself, Toby and Dave) who do the talking. It's more difficult then you might think - it was such a shock to hear my voice booming back at me while startled pedestrians tripped over their own feet that I trailed off into silence and it took five minutes to pluck up the courage to start again. Luckily, repeating myself isn't a problem, because we're always on the move. Of course, we have to improvise when the bus comes to a stop. One woman came out of her house to where we had been parked for 15 minutes to say she would vote for Ken there and then if we would just change the bloody song.

We're always surrounded by television cameras. It is incredible how an intelligent person's mind can go blank when you have three cameras stuck up your nose and no script.

And we can't legislate for the weather. One rainy day I was up on the top deck doing my thing with my colleagues dancing around behind me. We were getting a good reaction, which tailed off a little when it started to hail, but I carried on. When I looked round to see if the others were enjoying it as much as I was, I found they had all disappeared downstairs.

Somebody also has to stand at the front and look out for low-flying trees. We shout "Tree!" when we see one coming. Ken is actually the best. More than one Londoner has been startled to hear him say: "This is Ken Livingstone, your independent . . . tree!"

There are remarkably few hostile reactions to the bus, but it does happen. One immaculately dressed middle-aged woman made a gesture I haven't seen since school. Most of the aggression we get doesn't really seem to be aimed at Ken; I suspect the people who are sticking two fingers up at the men are the same ones who want me to take my top off.

I'm most baffled by people who try to pretend the bus isn't there. They can see us, we know they can see us, but they keep walking, looking neither right nor left as though there is nothing unusual happening.

The bus is a unique vantage point. I have seen several naked men who have got out of bed to see what's going on. Ken's only remark last time it happened was: "You're not wearing any clothes, sir."

I dream about the campaign now - wherever I am if a car hoots nearby I automatically smile and wave. But it has opened my eyes to another side of the city. I've made contact with thousands of people of all ages, races, creeds and political viewpoints, people whom I would never have met before. They have been overwhelmingly friendly, even those who will not be voting Livingstone in the election tomorrow, and as someone who has often accused London of being unfriendly I am glad to have seen that.

I like to think that I was able to use my position at the mic to perform a small public service. While passing the second-floor window of a friend of mine, I said: "Brodie Smithers, do your dissertation - and the rest of you, don't forget to vote." If only Ken had been running while I was doing my finals.

webTitle: Blair dashes off reply to 'unfair' Sun

fields.headline: Blair dashes off reply to 'unfair' Sun
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The prime minister betrayed nervousness over the battering Labour is receiving from the tabloid press by spending part of his May day bank holiday penning a three-page letter to the Sun rebutting the paper's claim that his government was losing its grip.
fields.body:
The prime minister betrayed nervousness over the battering Labour is receiving from the tabloid press by spending part of his May day bank holiday penning a three-page letter to the Sun rebutting the paper's claim that his government was losing its grip.

Mr Blair complained in his hadnwritten letter - scribbled at Chequers, his weekend retreat - that the claim that Labour had done nothing in government was "more than a little unfair".

Mr Blair said: "Yes, there is a lot to do. But there has been a lot done."

Downing Street continues to see the Sun as vital to its electoral success, so much so that Mr Blair decided he could not trust one of his factory of ghost writers to draft the piece.

The Sun replied yesterday in a second editorial, claiming it had "rattled" the prime minister and "struck a raw nerve".

It added: "Only the Sun can have such an effect on politicians. Sun readers are very important people. We don't take back one word of our attack on him."

Mr Blair is sharply at odds with the paper over Europe, likely to be one of the big issues of the general election.

webTitle: EU's prof to get lessons in plain speaking

fields.headline: EU's prof to get lessons in plain speaking
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Romano Prodi, whose rambling speeches as president of the European Commission have perplexed the world's media, is to be schooled in the art of the soundbite by an former BBC journalist.
fields.body:
Romano Prodi, whose rambling speeches as president of the European Commission have perplexed the world's media, is to be schooled in the art of the soundbite by an former BBC journalist.

A whispering campaign against him culminated last month in a wild claim that the two British commissioners, Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten, were plotting to overthrow him. At the centre of the claim was the accusation that Mr Prodi's presentation skills left much to be desired.

Although commission insiders stressed that Emma Udwin, a former BBC political journalist, will also help other commissioners to be more media-friendly, they admit that Mr Prodi needs special help.

"It's true that he is not a Bill Clinton-style communicator but a professor who speaks in a discursive way," a source said. "He's not the world's most natural communicator."

A television news editor in Brussels was less diplomatic. "We told him that he had 60 seconds to describe the EU's enlargement process, but at the end of 60 seconds he had barely finished introducing himself. It was a disaster."

Mr Prodi's rather faltering English is also an issue, others say, but the real problem is that he addresses the media as if he were lecturing his former students in Bologna.

In a world where soundbites can make or break a politician's image, Mr Prodi's delivery is not good enough. "Without a clear script he tends to ramble and go off at a tangent. This means that whatever message the commission is trying to get across is diluted," an EU diplomat commented.

Ms Udwin will have to make sure that he keeps his foot out of his mouth in television interviews. As a Briton with experience of EU affairs, she will be aware that past talk of a European army and calling the commission a "European government" had Eurosceptics in Britain foaming at the mouth.

Mr Prodi's rather faltering English is also an issue, others say, but the real problem is that he addresses the media as if he were lecturing his former students in Bologna. In a world where soundbites can make or break a politician's image, Mr Prodi's delivery is not good enough. "Without a clear script he tends to ramble and go off at a tangent. This means that whatever message the commission is trying to get across is diluted," an EU diplomat commented. Ms Udwin will have to make sure that he keeps his foot out of his mouth in television interviews. As a Briton with experience of EU affairs, she will be aware that past talk of a European army and calling the commission a "European government" had Eurosceptics in Britain foaming at the mouth.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Norway braced for big strike
Norwegians were queueing at food and liquor stores yesterday to lay in supplies before an indefinite strike by 82,000 workers starts this morning. It has been called by unions partly in anger at high pay rises for executives.
fields.body:
Norway braced for big strike
Norwegians were queueing at food and liquor stores yesterday to lay in supplies before an indefinite strike by 82,000 workers starts this morning. It has been called by unions partly in anger at high pay rises for executives.

The sectors due to be hit include hotels, construction, road haulage, and many domestic ferries. But oil production and international ferries are unaffected. The strikers have rejected a pay offer of 3.5%-4%. [Reuters, Oslo]

Explosions in Baghdad
Six rockets have been fired at a residential quarter of Baghdad, injuring eight civilians and damaging several houses, the Iraqi News Agency reported yesterday. It blamed Iranian agents.

INA said the attack took place on Monday evening but did not give the location. At around the same time, a mortar attack on Iran's national police headquarters injured several people in Tehran. An Iraq-based group, Mojahedin e-Khalq, claimed responsibility. [Reuters, Baghdad]

Ho Chi Minh colleague dies
One of Vietnam's most prominent 20th century figures, Pham Van Dong, has died, it was announced yesterday. Aged in his 90s, he passed away on Saturday, a day before the anniversary of the communists defeated US-backed South Vietnam on April 30 1975.

He was prime minister in Hanoi for more than 30 years to 1987. An intellectual, he was considered close to Vietnam's revolutionary leader Ho Chi Minh. His obituary appears in today's paper. [Reuters, Hanoi]

Nato command changes hands
General Wesley Clark handed control of US forces in Europe to General Joseph Ralston at a ceremony near Stuttgart, western Germany yesterday.

Gen Ralston formally takes over today as Nato's supreme allied commander. [Reuters, Stuttgart]
