fields.headline: Rebel threat to behead hostages
fields.standfirst:
Sabah Ministry of Tourism Development
Institute for Counter-Terrorism: Abu Sayyaf
fields.trailText: Abu Sayyaf rebels threatened to behead two of the foreign tourists among the 21 hostages they are holding in the hills of Jolo island yesterday if the Philippine army, which has surrounded them, does not pull back its troops.
fields.body:
Abu Sayyaf rebels threatened to behead two of the foreign tourists among the 21 hostages they are holding in the hills of Jolo island yesterday if the Philippine army, which has surrounded them, does not pull back its troops.

Yesterday about 100 armed rebels tried to break through the military cordon. At least one soldier was killed and six wounded, a spokesman, Colonel Hilario Atendido, said.

The fighting was continuing yesterday evening, the police said. There was no immediate word of rebel casualties.

Nur Misuari, the government's hostage negotiator, said that the army had told him that their encirclement of the area would remain in place.

The 21 hostages, who were kidnapped last Sunday from Sipadan, a Malaysian diving resort, have pleaded with the government to halt military operations in the area.

Abu Sayyaf is the smaller of two rebel groups fighting for a separate Islamic state in the impoverished Mindanao region.

Government troops were also involved in clashes yesterday with members of the larger group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), who occupied a main road near their base camp in central Mindanao. Officials said the bodies of about 70 MILF guerrillas had been recovered.

Announcing the threat to behead two hostages, Abu Escobar, an Abu Sayyaf leader, said the troops had moved so close to the hideout that the kidnappers could see them.

If the government did not pull back the soldiers, "We will surprise them," he said in an interview with a local radio station. "Maybe two heads for tomorrow."

Another group of Abu Sayyaf rebels, who are holding 27 hostages on the nearby island of Basilan, claimed two weeks ago that they had beheaded two of their captives, triggering a military assault on their stronghold.

So far the army has failed to find the hostages.

The Jolo hostages wrote to their embassies on Monday asking them to put pressure on the Philippine government to speed up the negotiations and remove the troops, in order to prevent further clashes and allow the kidnappers to obtain food.

Journalists who accompanied a doctor on Monday to the bamboo hut housing them were told by the hostages that they were suffering food shortages, fevers and infections.

The doctor later reported that most of the hostages were exhausted and dehydrated. She said she had told the rebels that two of their captives need to be in hospital.

About 70 heavily armed guerrillas, their faces masked, guarded the area, about 45 minutes up a rugged path from the nearest road in Talipao.

The hostages include tourists from Germany, France, South Africa, Finland and Lebanon, and resort workers from the Philippines and Malaysia.

Mr Misuari said the rebels refused to begin formal talks unless the troops were moved from the area. "They are demanding that government forces must withdraw from their present position to a safe distance," he said. "And as soon as that happens they are ready to open talks with me."

On Basilan, the army admitted yesterday that it was unable to find the 27 hostages after overrunning the main Abu Sayyaf stronghold. Ten soldiers died and 56 were injured in the attack.

The defence secretary, Orlando Mercado, said soldiers were searching the surrounding areas for the captives, who were among about 50 seized by the rebels from two schools on March 20 for use as human shields, after an attack on a military outpost.

The rebels subsequently released some of them.

webTitle: Scorn greets pledge on nuclear disarmament

fields.headline: Scorn greets pledge on nuclear disarmament
fields.trailText: A declaration by the five official nuclear powers of their "unequivocal commitment" to eliminate atomic weapons was roundly criticised by non-nuclear states and arms control groups yesterday as inadequate, vague, and contradictory.
fields.body:
A declaration by the five official nuclear powers of their "unequivocal commitment" to eliminate atomic weapons was roundly criticised by non-nuclear states and arms control groups yesterday as inadequate, vague, and contradictory.

The pledge by Britain, France, the US, Russia and China was issued on Monday night at the non-proliferation treaty review in New York, in an attempt to deflect critics who say they have failed to cut their arsenals quickly enough and negotiate in good faith to achieve the treaty's goal of a nuclear-free world.

The five promised their "unequivocal commitment to the ultimate goals of a complete elimination of nuclear weapons and a treaty on general and complete disarmament under strict and effective international controls". But they gave no timetable and the statement contained no specific commitments.

Hubert de la Fortelle, representing France at the conference, defended the statement by pointing in particular to a section that said none of the five was aiming its nuclear weapons at any specific state. Though broadly welcoming this as a confidence-building measure, diplomats and independent observers pointed out that the weapons could be re-aimed in minutes.

The statement also called for the "preserving and strengthening" of the 1972 US-Russian anti-ballistic-missile treaty. Yet Washington is trying to persuade Moscow to amend the treaty so that the US can build a national anti-missile shield. It says this is to protect it against "rogue" states such as North Korea.

Javier Solana, the EU's coordinator for foreign and defence policy, made it clear that Europe was concerned about the US plans. "If we feel we are not defended it may risk the beginning of decoupling," he said after talks with the Clinton administration about the US-European alliance.

Britain's UN representative, Sir Jeremy Greenstock, said the nuclear five's statement - the first of its kind - was designed to "boost momentum" at the four-week conference.

But Admiral Ramu Ramdas, a former commander of the Indian navy and a campaigner against nuclear weapons, called the statement a "damage control exercise by the nuclear states - nothing new at all." Without a framework or schedule, he said, the statement had no meaning.

Dan Plesch, director of the British American Security Information Council, a research organisation, said the statement contradicted leaked Washington proposals.

Documents described by the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists as draft Washington proposals call for the US and Russia to have "large diversified, viable arsenals of strategic offensive weapons" that enable them to deploy missiles with nuclear warheads "over the next decade and thereafter".

Greenpeace argued that the joint statement would heighten concern about nuclear arms by showing that the five's action on disarmament would be limited to platitudes.

Rebecca Johnson, director of the Acronym Institute, a disarmament thinktank, accused the five of "using buzzwords of 'unequivocal commitment' in the hopes that no one notices that they're not committed to the elimination of nuclear weapons any time soon".

Dave Knight, chairman of CND, said: "We have been waiting 30 years for the nuclear weapons states to fulfil their obligations under the NPT [non-proliferation treaty] and they are calling it their 'ultimate goal'. "How much longer do we have to wait until we get to 'ultimate'?"

Members of the New Agenda Coalition, a group of seven countries - including South Africa, Japan, and Mexico - pressing for specific commitments to nuclear disarmament, accused the five of not going far enough.

The statement also called on all the Middle East states which have not signed the NPT to do so soon. Israel is the only one, but it was not named.

Egypt wants a special envoy sent to the region to work on making it free of nuclear weapons - a goal sought by many countries concerned about Israel's nuclear arsenal, estimated to contain up to 200 warheads.

webTitle: Byers extends job rights to casuals

fields.headline: Byers extends job rights to casuals
fields.standfirst:
More about welfare reform
More about the minimum wage
The minimum wage explained
fields.trailText: New laws protecting part-time employees are to be extended to hundreds of thousands of temporary and casual workers, most of them women, under a government concession to be announced by Stephen Byers today.
fields.body:
New laws protecting part-time employees are to be extended to hundreds of thousands of temporary and casual workers, most of them women, under a government concession to be announced by Stephen Byers today.

After pressure from unions and equal rights groups, the trade and industry secretary has agreed to broaden the scope of the new rights to include part-time temps and agency workers such as nurses, secretaries and waitresses.

Originally, the government wanted to confine new rights granted under the European directive on part-time working to permanent employees.

The new definitition, to come into effect on July 1, means some of those most vulnerable to discrimination will be covered, including part-time home workers and agency workers. Mr Byers said: "This is a big shift which is about furthering the government's drive for better work-life balance."

The vast majority to benefit will be women, who make up 80% of Britain's 6m part-timers and dominate in sectors such as sales, catering, caring, nursing and checkout and clerking jobs.

All workers covered by the directive will have the right to the same hourly rates as comparable full-timers, as well as the same access to training and pro rata holiday, maternity and paternity entitlements.

Under government estimates, some 400,000 part timers currently suffering discrimination will be able to demand a better deal.

Trade and industry sources say "hundreds of thousands" more people will be covered by including all part-time workers rather than merely employees.

The concession was last night welcomed as "good news" by TUC sources, who have argued that workers suffering most discrimination would otherwise be excluded from new rights under the European directive.

However, unions will be disappointed that the government has rejected a further demand that part-time workers in jobs with no full-time equivalent should have a means of definining what rights a comparable full-timer would be entitled to.

The TUC argues that , because workers such as dinner ladies and cleaners are almost always employed part-time., they will not be able to point to full-time colleagues and demand the same rights.

The government has dug in its heels, arguing that in reality few businesses exist where all workers carrying out one job are part-timers. "These are rare cases," said a DTI source. "It was felt that the change would be overkill. We are trying to get the right balance here."

A CBI spokeswoman said extending the definition of people covered to include temporary and agency workers as well as employees was "unnecessary".

But she said the decision not to force companies to come up with a full-time comparison where some roles were only part-time was "a victory for the CBI".

fields.headline: Late diversion
fields.standfirst:
Livingstone laughs off campaign volunteer's attack

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: A self-styled "top Livingstone aide" who condemned him as a political loose cannon on the eve of tomorrow's mayoral poll went to ground yesterday, apparently unwilling to expand on criticism of his former boss.
fields.body:
A self-styled "top Livingstone aide" who condemned him as a political loose cannon on the eve of tomorrow's mayoral poll went to ground yesterday, apparently unwilling to expand on criticism of his former boss.

Mark Goddard, a 34-year-old freelance designer, wrote to a national newspaper describing how he had worked as a volunteer for Ken Livingstone's campaign for six weeks, but become disillusioned by his self-absorption and his "hell-bent" determination to pick fights with Tony Blair's government.

Mr Goddard, who had explained his disillusionment in a letter to the Times, refrained from touring TV studios yesterday to amplify his complaint and failed to return most press calls. Predictably Mr Livingstone, independent candidate for mayor since being expelled from Labour's ranks, laughed off what was clearly intended to be a last-minute embarrassment. "I didn't know who he was until I read in the papers he was a top aide of mine," he quipped.

As well as being a good joke the remark was also the kind of inattention to detail - or to staff organisation and volunteers - which prompted Mr Goddard to write his article. "Ken was very rarely on the bus and when he was he didn't really want to be there."

Though a political novice, dismissed by Livingstone aides as neither employed by the campaign nor in charge of its purple bus, Mr Goddard painted a picture of the candidate's weaknesses: a lack of organisation, and a reluctance to engage in policy discussion with eager volunteers.

"On television he comes over well. But when the camera goes off, it's a different matter," wrote Mr Goddard who also predicted that if Mr Livingstone wins outright he will claim a mandate to fight the government on issues like management of the London underground.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Unit trust sales reach record

Sales of unit trusts hit a record monthly high of £8.2bn in March, according to trade body Autif yesterday, spurred by a rush into technology funds by small investors ahead of the April 5 deadline for using up the annual Isa tax-free allowance.
fields.body:
Unit trust sales reach record
Sales of unit trusts hit a record monthly high of £8.2bn in March, according to trade body Autif yesterday, spurred by a rush into technology funds by small investors ahead of the April 5 deadline for using up the annual Isa tax-free allowance.

Total funds under management also jumped to a record £262bn from £255bn in February. But the figures mask a fall in Isa sales compared with sales of Peps last year. Net Isa sales in March were £2.3bn, 12% down on the £2.6bn in Peps sold during the "last Pep" bonanza of March 1999.

Autif said the bumper gross sales were offset by heavy selling of existing funds, as investors crystallised capital gains and switched out of "old economy" funds into technology and net funds.

$60m input for OmniSky
Rupert Murdoch's News Corp yesterday entered a joint venture with OmniSky Corp, a wireless internet service provider for handheld devices, to explore international opportunities for wireless internet services.

The media company said it invested $60m (£38.6m) in OmniSky as part of the wireless company's $75m financing arrangement.

Blue Circle clarifies stand
Cement maker Blue Circle was last night forced by the takeover panel to confirm that it was unable to substantiate statements in the press that it has the support of 45% of its shareholders following the hostile bid for the group by French rival Lafarge.

"The board of Blue Circle wishes to clarify that statements in the press that Blue Circle has the support of 45% of its shareholders should not be attributed to the company or its advisers," the company said.

It added, however, that the Blue Circle board was pleased to note the support from shareholders who had made public statements.

The deadline for acceptances of the £3.6bn hostile bid is 1pm today.

Oftel plans to relax rules
Oftel, Britain's telecoms regulator, said it was planning to relax the rules that govern the international telecoms market.

The regulator said five clauses in the standard telecoms licence were up for reconsideration to work out whether they were still needed in an increasingly competitive market . Consultation is open until June 28.

Wembley goes live
Wembley, the arena and exhibitions group, will launch a live music broadcast joint venture aimed at a global internet, terrestrial and non-terrestrial TV audiences. The venture includes venue owner the McKenzie Group, internet broadcaster Virtue Broadcasting, promoters Metropolis, MCD and SJM Promotions. The company said WembleyTV will start with some of the 2,000 events staged annually by the partners, beginning with August's V2000 music festival at Chelmsford and Stafford.

fields.headline: MPs condemn May demo 'thuggery'
fields.standfirst: May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: Politicians of all parties yesterday weighed in behind Jack Straw's condemnation of Monday's May Day demonstration as "criminality and thuggery masquerading as political protest" but proved divided over the tactics deployed by police.
fields.body:
Politicians of all parties yesterday weighed in behind Jack Straw's condemnation of Monday's May Day demonstration as "criminality and thuggery masquerading as political protest" but proved divided over the tactics deployed by police.

The police are reviewing their performance and ministers will consider any proposals, including whether to prevent future demonstrations getting into Parliament Square.

"Considerable resources" will also be devoted to tracing and prosecuting the culprits, Mr Straw assured MPs.

During exchanges in the Commons the home secretary repeatedly endorsed the Metropolitian police decision to avoid confrontation with the demonstrators where possible, while stressing that it was their operation decision, not his.

The crucial "fine judgment", he told MPs, was whether to let the demonstrations take place or risk seeing them spread into the West End. "Everyone in our democracy has a right to demonstrate peacefully but no one has a right to demonstrate violently," he added.

Mr Straw got caught in buck passing when responding to his Tory shadow's combative intervention, which included her dismay that so much disorder had been allowed to take place before police moved in.

Ann Widdecombe contrasted it to the tough tactics deployed when China's president Jiang Zemin visited London. But Mr Straw insisted that the royal parks agency, responsible for Sir Winston Churchill's statue, and English Heritage, which looks after the Cenotaph in Whitehall, had not taken police advice to board them up.

That version was challenged by Crispin Blunt (C. Reigate), who insisted that English Heritage had acted on police advice. In a statement later English Heritage said it had been told that a boarded up Cenotaph might be a "hiding place for bombs and ammunition." Police had not provided the extra protection promised.

Few MPs on either side appeared keen to defend the abstract right to demonstrate in Monday's manner. One Labour veteran, Dale Campbell-Savours , contrasted his own youthful protests in the 1960s with the "new brutality" in which balaclavas and helmets featured.

"I hope we never ban demonstrations. We must not go down that route in any way. But the police must have the powers to deal with people who are basically criminals," the MP said.

Mr Straw, a former president of the National Union of Students, had also been on many demonstrations in the past but every one had been peaceful. "Such a right of peaceful protest is the essence of a democratic society," he replied.

There were cries of "disgraceful" when Mr Straw described the damage to the Cenotaph and Oscar Nemon's statue of the wartime prime minister.

These were echoed in the Lords. When Lord Mackay of Ardbrecknish condemned the graffiti on the statue of Churchill he added: "He dealt with the greatest thug in the last century and I don't suppose a few people demonstrating how badly behaved they are would worry him too much."

Quote of day

Arthur Scargill. The NUM president is confident of doing well in the London assembly elections in which he leads an 11-strong squad of candidates for his Socialist Labour party. But he has some sharp words about fellow leftwinger Ken Livingstone. "I wouldn't vote for Ken Livingstone if he were running for mayor of Toytown," he said.

Bad day

We've got a home-made hovercraft - which is some chap's pride and joy - but in reality it's not classified as a boat.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: ...And Justice For All
fields.body:
...And Justice For All

(Norman Jewison, 1979)

9pm, 3.30am, Carlton Cinema

Al Pacino is a crusading lawyer who takes on a series of cases, including that of a judge charged with rape. Scripted by Barry Levinson and Valerie Curtin, the film aims to expose a murky world of plea-bargaining, with a few laughs along the way, but it cries out for a more forensic examination.

Cube

(Vincenzo Natali, 1997)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

Six strangers wake up one morning to find themselves trapped in a cube. They try to leave, only to find themselves in another. And another. A crafty, one-set, low-budget sci-fi, which, though never quite capitalising on the premise, still has a Rubik's-like pull.

Mystery Train

(Jim Jarmusch, 1989)

10.10pm, FilmFour

A Grand Hotel portmanteau movie for the landless and dispossessed. It's set in a seedy Memphis hotel where Screamin' Jay Hawkins and Cinqué Lee provide an hilarious, abrasive chorus to three tales: Far From Yokohama is about a pair of Japanese Elvis fans on a pilgrimage to the King's grave; Ghost concerns an Italian widow, her husband's coffin, and a garrulous young American woman; Lost In Space has punk Joe Strummer out boozing and shooting with Steve Buscemi and Rick Aviles: all finally interlocking in Jarmusch's charming, chaotic order of things.

The End of Violence

(Wim Wenders, 1997)

1.25am, Sky MovieMax

One of Wenders's stylish and enthralling American sojourns, an LA-set thriller in which Bill Pullman's shlock movie producer goes into hiding with a Mexican family after narrowly escaping an assassination attempt. The plot drifts from the devious to downright muddled, but there are lots of plusses: an engaging, oddball collection of characters, including an armed and dangerous Andie MacDowell, cop-cum-movie buff Loren Dean, stuntwoman Traci Lind and a shady Gabriel Byrne; a typically haunting Ry Cooder score, and a beautiful noir look, courtesy of cinematographer Pascal Rabaud.

webTitle: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Well, it looks like the good life's over for Dana Giacchetto, star accountant and all-round financial top boy for such Hollywood luminaries as Leonardo DiCaprio, Cameron Diaz and Matt Damon, as he faced indictment last week on charges of defrauding over $9 million from his celebrity clientele.
fields.body:
Well, it looks like the good life's over for Dana Giacchetto, star accountant and all-round financial top boy for such Hollywood luminaries as Leonardo DiCaprio, Cameron Diaz and Matt Damon, as he faced indictment last week on charges of defrauding over $9 million from his celebrity clientele.

Word from Manhattan Federal Court has it that Giacchetto, subject of innumerable puff-pieces in countless finance magazines over recent years, systematically used money to (deep breath) buy SoHo loft space for his offices; pay his hotel and entertainment bills; purchase computers, stereo equipment, art and clothes; and, perhaps most damagingly of all, lease a new Mercedes for an anonymous officer of the law. And, when certain clients noticed their accounts were looking somewhat withered, Giacchetto simply - so the story goes - paid them off with funds from less observant customers. Being held in custody until trial - after attempting to leave the country with $44,000 worth of first-class airline tickets and an altered passport - the hapless money-man is now looking at up to 35 years inside and fines running into the millions. Don't it just break your heart?

Meanwhile, hemp enthusiast and sometime film actor Woody Harrelson is back in action after putting together a lawsuit against insurance company Allstate for summarily abandoning their relationship with him when he called on their backing in another, entirely separate legal entanglement back in 1996. In the papers, filed late last week, Harrelson alleges Allstate breached contract when it withdrew funding from his defence against a suit filed by two tabloid photographers, with whom the actor scuffled on Martha's Vineyard when they began taking pictures of his then two-year-old daughter. No comment from either party as yet, but there will be. You can bet there will be.

fields.headline: Crime and punishment
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Johnny Carson once said that the best chat show hosts are neither good listeners, nor good talkers, but simply compulsive liars. Following the Carson principle, The Christine Hamilton Show (BBC Choice) should run and run. Hamilton first came to the notice of BBC executives by propping up her diminutive, corruptible husband on Have I Got News For You. Neil sat on her shoulder like a panto parrot as Christina fended off jibes with a stoic middle-England school-marminess. Her employment as a chat show host, a quirky Sister Wendy-type booking, was ultimately less surprising than it was depressing.
fields.body:
Johnny Carson once said that the best chat show hosts are neither good listeners, nor good talkers, but simply compulsive liars. Following the Carson principle, The Christine Hamilton Show (BBC Choice) should run and run. Hamilton first came to the notice of BBC executives by propping up her diminutive, corruptible husband on Have I Got News For You. Neil sat on her shoulder like a panto parrot as Christina fended off jibes with a stoic middle-England school-marminess. Her employment as a chat show host, a quirky Sister Wendy-type booking, was ultimately less surprising than it was depressing.

The theme of the show is a disgrace, yet somehow the BBC do not include themselves in the loop of shame. On her first outing, Hamilton "interviewed" the disgraced Kara Noble, the ex-Heart FM DJ who'd committed the beheadable crime of selling a 15-year-old topless photo of Sophie Rhys Jones. Hamilton was resolutely Paxmanesque, perhaps fearful that people might think she were purely a run-of-eight joke. Forgetting for one moment that that's precisely what she is.

Paul McGann is Fish (BBC1), following hard on the heels of the BBC's mega-flop, Badger. You'd think they'd learned their lesson with calling chiselled heroes after riverbank animals. "If I'm right," said a philosophical greasy-spoon owner, Fish's stereotypically unstereotypical confidant, "you're either a psychiatrist or a lawyer", so covering the available options on detective heroes (he's a lawyer).

Fish drives a black Citroen, keeping the windows open so his cheek bones can get a wind-tan. He's pursued relentlessly down country lanes by a cool jazz soundtrack, parping up at the first sign of a moody drive sequence. "One of these days," said his secretary "he's going to meet someone who refuses to be charmed by the good looks, and you know what they're going to do? They're going to shoot him."

Not, alas, in the first episode. Let's be clear about one thing. Fish is not likeable. He lacks even the existential angst of Cracker's Fitz, or the cold unapproachability of Morse. Like every other male TV hero of the last decade, Fish is a work-driven outsider with his home life in pieces.

There's a subtext to such dramas that's deeply reactionary. Namely, that it's perfectly acceptable for men to abdicate domestic responsibility because if you're a lovable bastard with a sexy Citroen, you're ultimately forgiven everything. Besides, there'll always be a woman who can't wait to play the 1950s housewife and pick up the pieces. Just as Christina has for Neil.

In spite of its shoddy title, Bad Girls (ITV) was a good deal less predictable. In Fish, children keep in contact with their parents via One-2-One love: business-mummy reading the bedtime story over a mobile phone from Dubai. In Bad Girls, mum's in prison, so there's more chance you'll get to see her on a regular basis.

"Do I detect the ever-so-faint whiff of corruption?" asked one of the baddest-of-the-bad to the bendiest of bent screws in the nick. You wouldn't have to be Columbo, or even Fish, to smell it.

Middle-aged officers with steel wool hair and dandruff on their epaulettes, were organising sex sessions in interview rooms (peeping through the key-hole). "Mad" Tessa Spall, star-inmate, crept up on screws with her Aids-blood-filled syringe, threatening them with infection. "She's doin' life for 'ackin 'er sister to bits", one of the lookers-on explained, helpfully.

Beyond the Porridge-era prison slang and the OTT characterisation, Bad Girls was full of surprises. In a prisoner mix-up that would do Group 4 proud, Mad Tessa gets to stab her way round the corridors while an old lady is banged up in solitary for looking suspiciously old lady-like.

If Fish was cliché dressed as flagship drama, Bad Girls was feminist fable stuck in the body of a trashy ITV serial. Here was a prison-full of women whose greatest crime was that they weren't listened to. Husbands came in for a quick grope. Guards wanted the same (even the female ones). In light of what of they faced "24-7", the violence and promiscuousness of the inmates were quite understandable weapons of last resort.

fields.standfirst: Sin Pattenden speaks to people at the Match Bar, London.
fields.trailText: Ken Whenn: "Hahahahahaha. I would have to say that I like watching the Channel Five Erotica, that's on Channel Five. Did I already say that? I liked that film by Sylvia Cristal in it, called Private Lessons, really good. She teaches some kid about sex. I have been drinking absinthe for four hours now, and I don't think it's had any effect. Hahahahah."
fields.body:
Ken Whenn: "Hahahahahaha. I would have to say that I like watching the Channel Five Erotica, that's on Channel Five. Did I already say that? I liked that film by Sylvia Cristal in it, called Private Lessons, really good. She teaches some kid about sex. I have been drinking absinthe for four hours now, and I don't think it's had any effect. Hahahahah."

Malcolm Stott: "I like the racing. Channel Four racing. I like to have a can of stout when I'm watching it, and some toast and pté. I like the news on Channel Four, yes, that's boring but my friends say I am quite boring hahahaha. I like Friends, because of the costumes, hahahaha. Do they have enough drinking on telly? No, not at all. That's all I'm prepared to say."

James Yeaps: "I like Davina McCall. I used to love Street Mates, that sort of thing. I think she's so sexy. I like Stars In Their Eyes. I tried to go on as Elvis, but they have a lot of Elvises apparently, and I look more like Buddy Holly. I was on Watchdog once, in the background of a curry-eating competition. It was raining and it was bollocks."

Trisha Ford: "Who are you? What do you want? I watch TV all the time, I watch it while I'm working, in the shop. What do I do? I work in a cafe, but quite a nice one. Are you a journalist? I hate journalists. Why? I don't know. They're worse than Germans. Rover factory, I don't know. I hate TV. Sorry, I'm a bit drunk. I really like, oooh, let me think... Michael Barrymore in Bob Martin, I think that's really funny. He's homophobic, isn't he? Great."

Maxine Burdage: "I like EastEnders. I tried to visit the set once, but I thought they filmed it at TV centre in Shepherds Bush. I stood outside and knew I was wrong. Have I had absinthe before? No, it's horrible. It makes you talk about EastEnders. I once met Rod Hull when I was ten, and he tried to bite me. Or was that the ostrich? Will you get me on EastEnders?"

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: •Anyone who remains baffled as to how America has become the world's dominant military, economic and cultural power has two simple choices open to them. You can either sit down and attempt to make sense of Paul Johnson's A History of the American People, in which my sane and rational friend translates ich bin ein Berliner as "I am a hamburger". Or you can reflect on Joseph M Brogan III and his lesson to us all.
fields.body:
Anyone who remains baffled as to how America has become the world's dominant military, economic and cultural power has two simple choices open to them. You can either sit down and attempt to make sense of Paul Johnson's A History of the American People, in which my sane and rational friend translates ich bin ein Berliner as "I am a hamburger". Or you can reflect on Joseph M Brogan III and his lesson to us all.

When the Diary offered £150 to the first reader to be photographed with Frank Dobson in an Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirt, this hard-up student crytallised the can-do spirit that has made the US what it is. He discovered that Dobbo was doing an on-line appearance at the Guardian, laid in wait for him outside this mesmerically hideous building . . . and pounced. Behold! "I got the shot by just asking him really," says the Third. "It was a fun experience. He knew about the contest and I think he was happy to get it over with!" We wish Joseph III a safe journey home later this month, and congratulate him for putting all those feckless, bone-idle British students to shame.

After yesterday's excitement when her "burgeoning assets" popped out at her 16th birthday, we need a day to recover before the next extract from www.ruthgledhill.com. However, it must be noted that the Times's religion correspondent now includes the following on her site. "Ruth's homepage wins its first award! ... Guardian Diary Website of the Month!"

I am surprised to note that, even while working "night and day" to save Rover jobs, Mr Tony Blair found time over the weekend to construct a 975-word hand-written letter of self-justification to the Sun, which has been beastly about him. How odd. For five years, this Diary has been in less than complete accord with Mr T . . . and not a word!

My colleague Richard Adams rings Downing Street to ask - and say what you will, we are not greedy - for a postcard. A long sigh ensues. "It must be a very, very thin day on the Guardian Diary, that's all I can say," says some insolent pup who refuses to give his name. "Cheerio."

Elsewhere in the Sun, my old friend Richard Littlejohn is obsessed with the convicted murderer Tony Martin, whom he apparently views as a hero in the mould of a granite-jawed homesteader played by Alan Ladd. Tremendous stuff. Richard became so carried away in explaining why it is correct to shoot in the back anyone poised to steal their ornaments that he forgot to mention being the recent victim of a burglary himself. Could you make it up? Perhaps, but would you have the energy?

There is nothing sadder than a one-issue politician, so it is good to see Dr Evan Harris refusing to become fixated on his job as Lib Dem spokesman on women's affairs. Evan has written to the leader of the Lords about a parliamentary chess match he is trying to set up. "Dear Lord Jay," it begins.

In succession to the BMW, the next Diary car will be a Rover 75. At least we hope it will. Early efforts to contact the press office fail when no one answers the phone. Few are immune from complacency during times of unusual stability, it's true, but it's a poor show when we're trying to do our patriotic duty.
fields.bodyText: Anyone who remains baffled as to how America has become the world's dominant military, economic and cultural power has two simple choices open to them. You can either sit down and attempt to make sense of Paul Johnson's A History of the American People, in which my sane and rational friend translates ich bin ein Berliner as "I am a hamburger". Or you can reflect on Joseph M Brogan III and his lesson to us all. When the Diary offered £150 to the first reader to be photographed with Frank Dobson in an Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirt, this hard-up student crytallised the can-do spirit that has made the US what it is. He discovered that Dobbo was doing an on-line appearance at the Guardian, laid in wait for him outside this mesmerically hideous building . . . and pounced. Behold! "I got the shot by just asking him really," says the Third. "It was a fun experience. He knew about the contest and I think he was happy to get it over with!" webTitle: Health risks to air passengers bring calls for stronger warnings

fields.headline: Health risks to air passengers bring calls for stronger warnings
fields.trailText: The department of health is to urge doctors to issue stronger warnings of the serious risks to health from frequent long haul flying, especially for people likely to suffer thrombosis.
fields.body:
The department of health is to urge doctors to issue stronger warnings of the serious risks to health from frequent long haul flying, especially for people likely to suffer thrombosis.

Officials yesterday admitted to the House of Lords science and technology committee that airlines, international aviation authorities and the government had undertaken little rigorous research on the health of the aircraft cabin environment. The committee is now undertaking such an inquiry.

The crossbench peer Lord Flowers said international organisations such as the Joint Aviation Authority seemed "gloriously irresponsible". It took up to 10 years to get agreement to improve the safety regime.

Lady Warwick, Labour, said there was little good scientific evidence on which to base recommendations for passengers.

The Conservative Lord Wade told Tom Hamilton of the civil aviation authority: "I would not have the faintest idea of whether I would be fit to fly, because you do not have any idea of what is required to be fit to fly."

Lord Methuen, Liberal Democrat, accused airlines, especially charter flights, of treating passengers like cattle.

Mr Hamilton and health and safety executive officials accepted that research was needed, since the average age, height and weight of passengers had changed, as well as the average length of non-stop flights.

Elizabeth Smales, from the Department of Health, said there was no hard evidence that deep vein thrombosis was worsened by the prolonged inactivity of flying, although 5% to 10% of cases could be caused by air travel. The biggest risks lay in surgery or being in hospital.

As long ago as 1940 it was observed that people sitting in deckchairs overnight in air raid shelters were five times more likely to get thrombosis than those lying in bunks, Dr Smales said.

She intended to improve the advice sent to health professionals on the dangers of air travel to passengers potentially at risk.

Health and environment department officials insisted that air conditioning had no role in the transmission of diseases. There had been one study in which an entire flight of passengers contracted flu, but that was after the plane had been stuck on the ground for four hours with the air conditioning off.

Filters to take out bacteria were of high specification. It was incorrect to claim that the air quality in the cockpit was better than in the cabin. There was no danger to frequent flyers from cosmic radiation.

fields.headline: Mugabe ready to call elections
fields.standfirst:
Cook vindicated as Commonwealth delivers stinging rebuke to Zimbabwe's unrepentant president
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe was facing growing international pressure last night after the Commonwealth launched a stinging attack on him for failing to uphold the rule of law during the occupations of white-owned farms.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt  in London and Chris McGreal in Harare
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe was facing growing international pressure last night after the Commonwealth launched a stinging attack on him for failing to uphold the rule of law during the occupations of white-owned farms.

As another member of the Zimbabwean opposition was beaten to death by supporters of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party, Commonwealth foreign ministers underlined their "deep concern" by sending the organisation's secretary general to Harare.

Don Mackinnon will tell President Mugabe that the intimidation of opposition politicians must end to ensure that the forthcoming elections in Zimbabwe are held in a free and fair environment.

The decision to send Mr Mackinnon to Zimbabwe came amid signs in Harare that President Mugabe will set a date for parliamentary elections within days. In a flurry of political activity, Zanu-PF's manifesto is expected to be launched today, signalling that the delayed ballot could be held in early June after weeks of land occupations and political violence that has claimed at least 15 lives.

Commonwealth ministers last night stepped up the pressure on the president when they agreed a hard-hitting statement that unequivocally condemned the farm occupations, which have been orchestrated by the government. After a day-long meeting in London the ministers "voiced their concerns over the ongoing violence, loss of life, illegal occupation of property, failure to uphold the rule of law and political intimidation in the run-up to Zimbabwe's parliamentary elections".

The ministers also called on the president to live up to his pledge to abide by the Zimbabwean constitution and hold elections "free of intimidation". During his talks with President Mugabe, Mr Mackinnon will discuss sending Commonwealth observers to monitor the elections.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, last night welcomed the Commonwealth statement, describing it as a "stinging criticism" of Mr Mugabe which would send a powerful message to Zimbabwe. "This shows that it is not just Britain criticising Zimbabwe or Britain having a post colonial [attitude] towards Zimbabwe," Mr Cook said. "What Mr Mugabe has to admit is that this has been expressed by the Commonwealth as a whole."

Foreign Office sources said last night that the statement represented a triumph for Mr Cook who lobbied the eight other members of the Commonwealth ministerial action group ahead of yesterday's meeting. There had been fears that the Commonwealth might temper its criticisms, but Mr Cook said that the statement included "all our conclusions".

As the ministers were meeting in London, however, there were reports of another death in Zimbabwe. The opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) accused ruling party supporters of abducting four of its activists yesterday and murdering at least one of them, Mathew Pfebve, 49, a retired policeman, near Mount Darwin, northeast of Harare. The three other men are also feared dead after they were dragged to a school and beaten.

"It was Zanu-PF thugs," said Mr Pfebve's brother, Elliot. "They came with iron bars and bricks. They also beat and hurt my 70-year-old father and left him for dead but my sister took care of him.

"The police post is 500 metres away from the school and they did nothing."

While the Foreign Office was delighted with yesterday's Commonwealth statement in London, Mr Mugabe may be more susceptible to pressure from neighbouring South Africa where President Thabo Mbeki has warned that the upheaval in Zimbabwe could spill across the border and destabilise the region. The two men are expected to meet at the end of the week.

Mr Mugabe and his cabinet met yesterday to discuss the failure of talks with the British government to resolve the land issue, and the election date.

A senior government source said the president would "set a date soon, within days". Mr Mugabe has apparently decided that with the opposition in retreat, and a plan under way to invoke special powers next week to begin formal land redistribution from white farms to poor blacks, the time is ripe for the vote.

The opposition MDC has already denounced the government for intimidation and other pre-election abuses, but has said it will still participate in the poll.

"The violence and intimidation by the ruling party have already ruled out the possibility of free and fair elections," said the MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai.

"The rural people are being beaten and intimidated. The urban people are being intimidated. The white farmers and the labourers have been brutally intimidated. With a nation that is frightened, elections cannot be free and fair."

The leader of the war veterans' organisation which has led the farm occupations, Chenjerai Hunzvi, has put further pressure on white farmers by demanding that their union withdraw contempt of court charges against him.

Mr Hunzvi is awaiting sentence on Friday for failing to obey a court order to tell his members to leave the occupied land, and to halt violence against white farmers and their black workers.

"As the leader of the war veterans, I have already been convicted of contempt of court charges over farm invasions. How do commercial farmers expect me to engage in serious dialogue with them if these charges remain? They must drop the charges immediately," he said.

Mr Hunzvi appeared in court yesterday on separate fraud charges over allegations of stealing £7,900 from a compensation fund for victims of the liberation war.

The farmers union reported new land invasions in several parts of the country. Five farms were seized in Masvingo, and two more in Mvurwi, northwest of Harare.

webTitle: Plea for India to rescue 40,000 Sri Lankan troops

fields.headline: Plea for India to rescue 40,000 Sri Lankan troops
fields.trailText: The Sri Lankan army was on the brink of its most catastrophic defeat in 17 years of bitter civil war with the Tamil Tigers last night, and reports said the country's president had asked India to evacuate 40,000 troops trapped by a rebel offensive.
fields.body:
The Sri Lankan army was on the brink of its most catastrophic defeat in 17 years of bitter civil war with the Tamil Tigers last night, and reports said the country's president had asked India to evacuate 40,000 troops trapped by a rebel offensive.

President Chandrika Kumaratunga's reported plea for help from India follows a series of stunning military advances by the Tigers during the past two weeks. They have now advanced to within 25 miles of the main northern town of Jaffna, which they fled five years ago. "Sri Lanka's first appeal has been to India," one official told a Sri Lankan TV station last night.

An official close to the Indian embassy, speaking on the condition of anonymity, yesterday confirmed that the Sri Lankan government had requested India's assistance. However, there has been no formal response from the Indian or the Sri Lankan governments.

A few hours before these reports, Ms Kumaratunga had met opposition leaders to brief them on the military crisis.

Tamil Tiger rebels took control of the key Elephant Pass military base on the northern Jaffna peninsula on April 22; the base had never before fallen to the rebels.

Eight days later the Tigers consolidated their hold on the peninsula when they captured another crucial military base, at Pallai.

The Tigers vowed three months ago to recapture Jaffna, their former stronghold, which they lost to government troops in 1995. The town can now be supplied only by military aircraft and most analysts believe its fall is inevitable. "It is not a question of when, but how," one defence expert said last night.

The rebels, who are fighting for a separate Tamil homeland in the north of the country, yesterday continued their offensive, unleashing an intense artillery barrage on the navy camp at Kilali, military officials and rebel sources said. "The attack is still going on, but we are holding on," said a naval official.

The defence ministry also said the soldiers were holding on to the camp, barely 15 miles south of Jaffna.

In an earlier surprise move, an important group of Buddhist monks, the National Sangha Council, called for Indian intervention to prevent Jaffna from falling into rebel hands. The monks, who are extremely influential in a country where 76% of the population is Buddhist, met an envoy from India at the weekend and appealed for military help from New Delhi.

In 1987, the monks strongly protested when Indian troops were sent to Sri Lanka to disarm the rebels under an agreement with Colombo. The troops withdrew three years later, after the Sri Lankan government said their stay should end, and the episode remains a humiliating memory for the Indian army. It also led to the 1991 assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, India's prime minister, by a Tamil suicide bomber.

"The government should make its first appeal to India. India may have good reasons to be reluctant to get involved in Sri Lanka. But Indians cannot remain aloof to what is happening across a few miles of sea on its southern coast," Sri Lanka's Island newspaper urged yesterday in in a leader comment.

Meanwhile, the International Committee of the Red Cross said the rebels handed over the bodies of 42 government soldiers killed in Sunday's fighting in Pallai.

The military said 14 officers and soldiers were killed and 222 others were wounded. The rebel's clandestine Voice of Tigers Radio maintained yesterday that only 10 of their combatants died. Independent verification was impossible.

fields.headline: No: 1628 Bridge
fields.trailText: Age: At least 380, in its earliest manifestations; about 100 in its modern form.
fields.body:
Age: At least 380, in its earliest manifestations; about 100 in its modern form.

Description: Fiendishly complicated card game riddled with confusing jargon and arcane rules, currently embroiled in scandal.

Oh, I know about this one - I'll fight your Charmander with my Pikachu. Not that card game, I'm afraid. Although it might as well be, for all most of us can make of the rules.

Try me. Put simply, players bid to win a stated number of tricks over six with a named suit as trump or with no-trump, and the highest bid becomes the contract after three consecutive passes end the bidding.

But what's the scandal? Are elderly ladies being mugged in the street for their rare cards? It's even worse than that. Pietro Forquet has been tested for drugs.

Not . . . Pietro Forquet! I knew you'd be appalled. The 75-year-old, Italy's most revered bridge player, has been tested under new rules making bridge an Olympic sport.

And the plan hasn't, um, come up trumps with his supporters? "Such a venerable figure can never have expected it would come to this," thundered the Italian daily Il Messaggero of the test, which took place on Friday.

Surely there are no poppers or downers among the rubbers and the dummies? Probably not, but all the same, Forquet and four fellow players have been tested for stimulants, narcotics, steroids and what are ever so sensitively referred to as drugs used by the elderly to "aid bodily functions".

The indignity! No wonder Italy's bridge players are incontinent with rage. Well, incontinent, anyway. Unless, of course, they really are taking drugs to aid their bodily functions.

What's the verdict on Forquet? Nobody knows: the great man is keeping his cards close to his chest.

Do say: "Ah - I see South has a rebid on his own suit, while North is raising hearts rather than playing on no-trumps. How very, very interesting."

Don't say: "Can't we just say whoever wins the next round is the winner and play Snap instead?"

webTitle: St Tropez clean-up hits stars' hangout

fields.headline: St Tropez clean-up hits stars' hangout
fields.trailText: The proprietor of La Voile Rouge beach restaurant lodged a formal appeal yesterday against the decision by St Tropez town council to shut down one of the resort's most celebrated institutions, a favourite holiday haunt of such stars as Sylvester Stallone and Mick Jagger.
fields.body:
The proprietor of La Voile Rouge beach restaurant lodged a formal appeal yesterday against the decision by St Tropez town council to shut down one of the resort's most celebrated institutions, a favourite holiday haunt of such stars as Sylvester Stallone and Mick Jagger.

The restaurant, built illegally on Pampelonne beach in the heady days of 1968 and tolerated ever since, has been caught by a council campaign to clean up St Tropez's increasingly shabby image.

La Voile Rouge's owner, Paul Tomaselli, 61, said he was challenging the legitimacy of the decision. "The committee that rules on such things was supposed to be elected by proportional representation, In fact, it was appointed by simple majority vote; that's illegal, and therefore all the committee's decisions are null and void."

But the council, fed up with complaints about the restaurant's loud music and the helicopters ferrying celebrities to and from a nearby helipad, is unlikely to let the matter rest.

"The courts will decide, but in theory all these beach bars and restaurants should be bulldozed," a spokesman said. "They are ugly, noisy, not terribly safe, and completely illegal. They have had a good run, but it is time to call it a day."

Mr Tomaselli's lawyer, Jean-Pierre Magnificat, said removing beach restaurants from St Tropez would be "like banning waltzes in Vienna or beer in Munich".

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The third of Professor Bill McGuire's Disasters In Waiting (9.0pm, Radio 4) was, unlike his previous examples, entirely man-made. In 1963 2,000 inhabitants of Longarone in north-east Italy drowned when millions of tons of water burst through the 3-year-old Vaiont Dam. Many had vigorously opposed the dam's construction, pointing to the frequency of landslides in the area. Sure enough, a huge chunk of Monte Toc fell into the lake behind the dam, to generate a catastrophic tidal wave.

Alternatively there's Daryl Hall's More Giants Of Soul (9.0pm, Radio 2), featuring Whitney Houston (pictured), queen of them all. Singing ran in the family, of course. fields.headline: The incredible journey
fields.standfirst:
Gypsy movie-making
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Film covers a much bigger world than you'd ever know from the multiplex listings. Last year in Cannes, for example, I watched stories about Orthodox Jews in Jerusalem, Kathakali actors in Kerala and drag queens in Barcelona, not to mention Belgian waffle sellers, Swiss call girls and pre-pubescent rat-fanciers in 70s Glasgow.
fields.body:
Film covers a much bigger world than you'd ever know from the multiplex listings. Last year in Cannes, for example, I watched stories about Orthodox Jews in Jerusalem, Kathakali actors in Kerala and drag queens in Barcelona, not to mention Belgian waffle sellers, Swiss call girls and pre-pubescent rat-fanciers in 70s Glasgow. It's almost beside the point whether the films are good or not: you are just relieved to get a break from London geezer- gangsters and LA cops.

But I would not want to present the pleasures of world cinema as spurious cultural tourism. The term "world cinema", in fact, is not much used these days - it was replaced by "art-house", which means films that are lucky to get a release. "World cinema" always had a tinge of National Geographic magazine about it.

However, there is something particularly exciting about a film that doesn't simply offer a burst of cultural difference, but actually creates a picture of the world as you've never seen it before. Such a film is Latcho Drom, which opens at the Barbican this week as part of The 1,000 Year Journey, a season of gypsy music and arts.

The French-based, Algerian-born gypsy film-maker Tony Gatlif shot Latcho Drom in several countries, with an almost entirely gypsy cast. In fact Latcho Drom is a film that, as American critic Jonathan Rosenbaum put it, "has no nationality at all". It is also a film without fixed genre: at once musical, documentary, travelogue, ethnographic essay and impassioned manifesto for a freer cinema and a freer life.

Gatlif's 1997 film Gadjo Dilo was a portrait of a Romanian gypsy village, ostensibly seen through the eyes of a French outsider, but really offering a community-eye view of his strangeness - the Frenchman being the "crazy foreigner" of the title. Update for Gadjo Dilo fans: Gatlif's follow-up, Children of the Stork, is a messy, apparently semi-improvised caper with a heavy nod to Godard, and is borderline unwatchable, except for one memorable gag about a film critic who literally rubber-stamps movies: "Rubbish", "Masterpiece", " Absolute masterpiece".

But Latcho Drom (1993) is, it is probably fair to say, unlike any film you will have seen. An impressionistic picture of the migrations of the gypsy peoples and musics through time and space, it is constructed as a series of musical interludes. It has hundreds, maybe thousands of characters, but the central character is the protean gypsy population itself. The whole film is staged as a single staggered journey from east to west: the wedding revellers in Rajasthan seem to evolve into the family taking a ferry to Istanbul, then into the band waiting for a train in Hungary. The Rajasthan sequence, lit by fires burning in tree trunks, is presented like a recollection of a distant Edenic past. From then on, it's clear that everything is a response to grief and exclusion. An old woman walks across a snowy landscape in Slovakia, and sings about the population wiped out in the Holocaust. The Romanian band Taraf de Haïdouks sing about the crimes of Ceausescu. The film ends with a woman's lament on a Spanish hillside, overlooking an urban landscape as barren as, but less hospitable than the Rajasthan desert.

Taraf de Haïdouks' concert at the Barbican the other night was a good metaphor for Latcho Drom's fluidity, and for the way that gypsy culture evolves throughout the film. The 12 members play in every conceivable combination - en masse, in threes, fours or fives, swapping accordions, violins and double basses, and playing with an extraordinary, controlled frenzy. The band comes in different permutations, but always plays with the same collective signature; the film covers different gypsy cultures, but always implies a unity.

Latcho Drom can be seen as a history lesson: the Barbican season, and Gatlif's film in particular, make a timely retort to Britain's latest wave of xenophobia. You might argue that Latcho Drom is romantic and impressionistic, that it doesn't offer commentary or analysis, but simply presents gypsy culture as some sort of eternal spirit. But for a film that barely deals in the spoken word, Latcho Drom conveys a very concrete sense of historical reality. And the fact that the film exists at all, flouting genres and national barriers, is of no small political importance. Its title means "safe journey": Latcho Drom is, you could say, the ultimate road movie.

Latcho Drom opens at the Barbican Cinema, London EC2, on Friday. The 1,000 Year Journey is at the Barbican till May 14. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

fields.headline: With this string I thee wed
fields.standfirst: The Emersons tell  Erica Jeal why good string quartets are like good marriages
fields.trailText: This month the Wigmore Hall and the Barbican will play host to one of the most successful groups, the New York-based Emerson Quartet, for a season covering all of Shostakovich's string quartets.
fields.body:
Vikram Seth centred his latest novel, An Equal Music, on a string quartet. It was just the way to follow up his mammoth family drama A Suitable Boy, drawing on the close yet precarious relationships that exist within quartets. The ties between members are often compared to marriages; quartets are even given "family" names - the Emersons, the Lindsays, the Vellingers - in the shorthand of the music world. Quartet musicians spend a vast amount of time with their colleagues - on the road, rehearsing, bickering, taking and doling out criticism.

This month the Wigmore Hall and the Barbican will play host to one of the most successful groups, the New York-based Emerson Quartet, for a season covering all of Shostakovich's string quartets. Taking its name from the American poet and philosopher Ralph Waldo Emerson, the Emerson Quartet dates back to 1976. Violinists Philip Setzer and Eugene Drucker both studied at the Julliard School under Oscar Shumsky, where they formed the Emersons. The present line-up, with violist Lawrence Dutton and cellist David Finckel replacing two members of the original four, was established in 1980. "They tried out 17 violists and one cellist," says Dutton. There's a viola joke in there somewhere - but then jokes about viola players are the music world's stock-in-trade.

Watching the four talk together gives an inkling of why they work so well as a group. No one person dominates the conversation; nobody talks over anyone else. They joke and banter and spark off each other irrepressibly.

Not all quartets work out so well. And when there's a split, the divorce can be messy. One young British quartet turned to the Musicians' Union for arbitration after the first violinist decided to leave. The leader took on the other three over the ownership of the quartet's name, a valuable asset associating it with a well-known 20th-century composer. Now that this matter has been sorted out, the violinist has put in a claim for compensation for lost earnings, saying that she was forced to quit. The others say she left of her own accord. The MU has still to decide who is in the right.

"You have to have the right balance," says the Emersons' Setzer. "We are compatible enough to be able to present something to the audience that is cohesive. But then, it wouldn't be very interesting if the four of us felt everything exactly the same way, and we could never have real discussions or arguments about the music."

Diverging ideas can bring a frisson to a performance, but in the Emersons' case differences run only so deep. "We don't have fundamental personal or musical disagreements," says Finckel. "In our rehearsals there's a lot of debate, but when we listen back to tapes and hear ourselves play we always agree on whether it was good or bad. I can't imagine how it would work if you worshipped at different temples musically. Maybe in your own playing you'd be looking for something that the person sitting next to you didn't really like. But we don't have that problem."

Getting through the first few years isn't a guarantee of a long career together. Peter Manning, now leader of the Royal Opera House Orchestra, was the first violinist in the Britten Quartet, formed in 1986. Manning's experiences have given him firm ideas about what makes quartets tick. With a few years of "tireless energy" and "a sense of group adventure", his quartet had established an international career and won a recording contract with EMI. Yet eventually all the rehearsing and touring began to seem less of an adventure and more of a chore. After 10 years together they decided to split. "It's a monkish pursuit," Manning says. "The fact that anyone stays with a quartet for more than two seasons is a miracle."

For the Brittens, their contract with a major record label was both a blessing and a curse. While they were given promotion and publicity, they also had to balance their recording schedule with that of a better-established EMI ensemble, the Alban Berg Quartet. This meant that they couldn't make the discs they wanted to when they wanted to, which led to tension within the group.

The Emersons, signed to Deutsche Grammophon, have had a more gratifying relationship with their record company. Their latest release is the complete Shostakovich quartets, recorded live at concerts in Aspen, Colorado, over the course of several summers. Their London series coincides with the UK release. "Rock groups have been doing it for years," says Dutton. "You make the album, you go on tour. It's a thing that classical music people have had to learn to do."

While Manning found that his desire to explore other areas of music-making did not fit in with his life in the Britten Quartet, the Emersons have found outlets for solo performance. Finckel in particular has a varied career outside the quartet - he runs a small recording company and is artistic director of the summer chamber music festival in La Jolla, California. In addition to this he gives around 40 recitals a year with his wife, the pianist Wu Han.

But although the musicians like to keep some element of separate musical identity, when they take major decisions everyone is involved. "Nobody is ever outvoted in this quartet," says Setzer, who is responsible for most of the Emersons' programming. "If somebody does not want to do something, go somewhere or play some concert, we just don't do it."

The musical roles are similarly egalitarian. With the Emersons the violinists swap seats from work to work, one way in which they are different from most other professional quartets.

"We started doing it when we were students, and it evolved very naturally. It wasn't something we consciously decided to do," explains Setzer. "I think it's worked for us because we have two players strong enough in technique and personality to play the first violin part, but who can also play the supporting role well." Dutton adds: "At first people assumed 'They're just doing that, they'll figure out eventually who should play first violin.' But we never stopped doing it."

Drucker continues: "During the late-19th and early-20th centuries there were a number of groups named after the first violinist. Sometimes these even consisted of a great soloist who would travel to different cities and play in an ad hoc group with three other people from each city. But we came into a quartet playing at a much more egalitarian period. There's been a natural progression away from a group dominated by the first violin towards a group of equals. That corresponds to the way quartets are written, after all. We didn't start this, by any means."

Doesn't this swapping lead to arguments about who will play which piece? "There were a few pieces where each of us wanted to play first, but the quartet repertoire is so wide and rich that it's easy to compromise." Dutton and Finckel say that they don't find the violins' changing round disruptive. Dutton even claims that it makes no difference to the two lower voices who is in which chair. "That's because he never looks up," chips in Drucker. Another viola joke.

The Emerson Quartet's Shostakovich cycle is at the Wigmore Hall, London W1 (020-7935 2141), and at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), from May 12-21.

fields.headline: The rewrite stuff
fields.standfirst: Why is a West End theatre staging work by a bunch of unknown drama students?  Brian Logan investigates
fields.trailText: Why is a West End theatre staging work by a bunch of unknown drama students? Brian Logan investigates
fields.body:
In a poky teacher's office in Quinton Kynaston School, north-west London, playwright Diane Samuels is keeping calm. This is the last of her four sessions with a quartet of fresh-faced ingenues due to submit scripts for performance at the Theatre Royal Haymarket, in the heart of the West End. But two scripts haven't appeared, one of them because of a greater creative project - its writer's first baby. The other two have been penned, read aloud, and now - as diplomatically as can be - Samuels is suggesting rewrites. "Plays," she intones, speaking perhaps from bitter experience, "are rewritten, not written." Her young charges grumble their resistance.

This is Playwrite, a project organised as part of the Masterclass strand of activities that has run at the Haymarket since 1998. Four playwrights have been sent to schools in London and beyond to supervise the writing of 30-minute plays by A-level students. The results are to be performed by cast members from the theatre's current production Miss Julie, before a panel of writers and critics and an invited audience this weekend.

"It's very limited, what you can achieve with four sessions with people you've never met before," says Samuels, the writer of the much-praised Kindertransport. "All you can do is begin a journey." So she is doing her best to streamline the work of her writers-to-be. All four plays have been conceived along epic lines, and their writers are unwilling to scale them down. "Less is more," Samuels suggests. "Have you heard that phrase?"

The quartet of writers - all female - have little theatrical and even less literary experience. They do drama classes, that's all. It's fascinating to see them attempting to shape their world in literary terms. "When I was writing," says Lizzie, who has penned a piece reflecting her own Christianity, "I knew I had to end with a moral message: what am I trying to say?" Samuels has to chip away at their sense that their plays should provide all the answers. That includes paring back the stage directions. "Don't tell the director what to do," she advises - and then, putting herself in their shoes, adds, "I think you can tell the director what to do, but you have to do it covertly."

The idea is to weld the four scripts into a dramatic whole. It's proving tricky. Lizzie has written a dramatic defence of Christian forgiveness. In Kelly's play, a dentist gouges out his patient's tongue. Meron wants to write about the 19th-century feminist abolitionist Sojourner Truth, and Valentina plans something about Kosovo. Four disparate ideas in search of a common thread. Samuels thinks she's got it: "Your characters are all in the midst of a struggle." Hmm. The kids don't buy it.

"In the end," Samuels says some weeks later, "they decided they wanted to do their individual pieces and not join together. There was a shift over four weeks, from wanting to be in a group to actually standing out and saying, 'No, I want to tell my story'."

Samuels was uneasy, however, about encouraging teenagers into her beleaguered profession. "The theatre business doesn't have much scope to produce work. It's very competitive. You have to develop incredible resources to survive it. There's all this money put into theatres dedicated to new writing, but what about further down the line - five or 10 years after they've found the new voice and the new play? What they do is they look for the next new voice and the next new play. Where does everyone else go? What's nice about this project is that it's not about finding material for a theatre to produce."

If Playwrite were organised by the Royal Court, nobody would bat an eyelid. But it is run by a commercial West End theatre that is family-owned, isn't subsidised and doesn't produce shows of its own. "There's no continuity about Playwrite or sense of something that's going to go on for a long time," says Samuels. "It has an eccentric, slightly philanthropic feel to it."

If anyone can explain that, it's Haymarket chairman Arnold Crook, who set up Masterclass with Peter Hall. He insists, with a seraphic expression on his face, that "this is a pure operation for young people. There's no financial gain for this theatre, nothing but the thought of young people in the theatre." He admits that he devised Masterclass to persuade lottery funders that his theatre had an education policy. But when his lottery application was denied, the project went ahead regardless.

An unlikely evangelist for the "magic" of theatre, the sharp-suited Crook dreams of the day when a play conceived by Masterclass students is given a professional production at the Haymarket. Sunday evening is a stepping stone; whatever the quality of the plays themselves, the writers' faces are full of drama as they see their work come alive for the first time. "Young people shouldn't feel intimidated coming into the theatre," says Crook. "I think Masterclass opens the door for them. I love to stand at the back and look at the kids' faces: their eyes open, their mouths open, they can't believe the beauty of this place. This is our lifeblood, this is the future of all theatres."

There was a shift over four weeks, from wanting to be in a group to actually standing out and saying, 'No, I want to tell my story'." Samuels was uneasy, however, about encouraging teenagers into her beleaguered profession. "The theatre business doesn't have much scope to produce work. It's very competitive. You have to develop incredible resources to survive it. There's all this money put into theatres dedicated to new writing, but what about further down the line - five or 10 years after they've found the new voice and the new play? What they do is they look for the next new voice and the next new play. Where does everyone else go? What's nice about this project is that it's not about finding material for a theatre to produce." If Playwrite were organised by the Royal Court, nobody would bat an eyelid. But it is run by a commercial West End theatre that is family-owned, isn't subsidised and doesn't produce shows of its own. "There's no continuity about Playwrite or sense of something that's going to go on for a long time," says Samuels. "It has an eccentric, slightly philanthropic feel to it." If anyone can explain that, it's Haymarket chairman Arnold Crook, who set up Masterclass with Peter Hall. He insists, with a seraphic expression on his face, that "this is a pure operation for young people. There's no financial gain for this theatre, nothing but the thought of young people in the theatre." He admits that he devised Masterclass to persuade lottery funders that his theatre had an education policy. But when his lottery application was denied, the project went ahead regardless. An unlikely evangelist for the "magic" of theatre, the sharp-suited Crook dreams of the day when a play conceived by Masterclass students is given a professional production at the Haymarket. Sunday evening is a stepping stone; whatever the quality of the plays themselves, the writers' faces are full of drama as they see their work come alive for the first time. "Young people shouldn't feel intimidated coming into the theatre," says Crook. "I think Masterclass opens the door for them. I love to stand at the back and look at the kids' faces: their eyes open, their mouths open, they can't believe the beauty of this place. This is our lifeblood, this is the future of all theatres."

webTitle: New images to make the Holocaust real

fields.headline: New images to make the Holocaust real
fields.standfirst:
Tel Aviv cabaret gives the young an alternative memorial
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Tel Aviv cabaret gives the young an alternative memoria
fields.body:
The performance began with great clouds of smoke, vigorously expelled by an actress who stood alone with her cigarette in a pool of light on the darkened stage.

"Good evening. Is there anyone in the audience who was in Auschwitz, or whose grandmother was in Auschwitz?

On the eve of the day when normal life in Israel is suspended while the country mourns the 6m Jews killed by the Nazis, the "Alternative Holocaust Memorial" reached out to a younger generation overwhelmed by the enormity of the genocide yet alienated from the official ceremonies which dominate the day.

The line-up included a gossip columnist, a stand-up comic, and, perhaps most unusually for a secular occasion, an undertaker from an Orthodox Jewish burial society. The venue was equally unconventional: the crowded, smoky Barbie Club, a converted garage in an industrial district of south Tel Aviv.

While Nazi newsreels played as a backdrop and the bells of railway crossings clanged, the performers and the packed audience of 250 - mainly in their 20s and early 30s - struggled to find meaning in an experience that is central to the Jewish state but remains beyond the comprehension of many of this generation.

"Maybe what we need is something like those weekend supplements: 100 things you never knew about Hitler," said Eliat Alkayam, in her cynical opening act. The comic, Rotem Itach-Ashbel, read from the diary of Anne Frank while chewing two shiny red apples - intended, she said, to show the Dutch teenager's undiminished desire while she was in hiding.

The undertaker told of his three-day experiment in eating only crusts of bread to feel the hunger which the Jews had suffered. He explained that, in his line of work, death no longer moved him.

Another performer displayed pure hatred, saying he discovered the meaning of the Holocaust after a drunken evening in New York, when he beat up someone who called him a "hymie".

By giving a voice to a generation with no direct experience of the Nazi era, and by bringing together secular and religious Jews, Monday night's gathering could not have been more different from the official Holocaust Day.

Yesterday, as every year, there was nothing on television but documentaries about the survivors of the ghettos and the camps and the radio stations played only sombre Hebrew songs.

Cafes and cinemas were closed by law, and at 10am, when the siren sounded for two minutes of silence, everyone froze on the spot, except those Orthodox who believe that the dead should be remembered only with prayer. In Zion Square, Jerusalem, a man muzzled his dog for fear it would break the spell.

But despite the power of such acts, and the Holocaust education in schools, people in the Tel Aviv audience - and the performers - said the official ceremonies failed to move them or to communicate the horrors of what happened.

"I found this more touching," said Shiraz Netzer, whose father was smuggled out of the Warsaw ghetto and hidden by a Polish family. "Usually the children of those who went through the Holocaust are so cynical. But I thought this was nice, because it was not trying to make people cry, and because it was not kitsch."

The producer, Sara Blau, said she started the alternative day of remembrance last year because she felt that the conventional ceremonies had "fossilised".

"Always, we are told that we are a collective group, and that we should all feel a certain way. But this ceremony is individual. Everyone here brings their own content."

Although the event is still very much on the margins of Israeli society, she expects it will eventually help transform the way Israelis regard the Holocaust. "In 10 years' time we will be the mainstream."
