fields.headline: Calculated charity
fields.standfirst:
Money for Aids from an offbeat source
The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The Clinton administration has good domestic reasons to raise its profile over Aids in the wider world. It is election year and there are lobbies to placate. Altruistically, US Aids activists have given Democratic presidential nominee Al Gore a hard time over the non-availability of proven therapies in poor countries; Bill Clinton is doing his best to help him.
fields.body:
The Clinton administration has good domestic reasons to raise its profile over Aids in the wider world. It is election year and there are lobbies to placate. Altruistically, US Aids activists have given Democratic presidential nominee Al Gore a hard time over the non-availability of proven therapies in poor countries; Bill Clinton is doing his best to help him. President and candidate have credentials to burnish with black leaders who have made Aids in Africa a focus (and who have been dismayed by president Thabo Mbeki's recent eccentric attempts to downplay its significance).

The $254m budget allocation proposed by the White House is small beer. Anti-Americans will doubtless think it all too typical that Aids proposals are brought under the national security rubric - as if increasing death rates from the disease in Africa and Asia were not fundamental attacks on the security of scores of other countries as well. And yet this classification - on the back of Central Intelligence Agency reports earlier this year - has some merit.

It is enforced recognition that help now offers security later, that international assistance is in the longer-run interests of American taxpayers. Aids is like the weapons conventionally defined as threats to the well-being of nations. It deprives the United States (and the world) of men and women who might grow and prosper and trade; it deprives humanity (and the United States) of rich increments to its stock. Treatment and nursing absorb money and materials in parts of the world where they might spectacularly be turned to other, positive use.

Of course there is an ideological component to American policy. The US wants to see free market societies blossom. They are not likely to when mortality rates are as high as they now are in sub-Saharan Africa. American political interest implies democracy and liberalism in Africa and Asia, for which surely disease-free bodies are a prerequisite. The case for international action on Aids needs no such buttressing; but it does no harm either.

As Mr Gore's own advisers publicly admit, the amount being set aside to fight Aids outside the US is a pittance. It will not necessarily get spent. Nothing can be guaranteed as congressional Republicans struggle for purchase on a possible Bush presidency. Yet with it a start can be made, for example in trying to meet the United Nations' target of a 25% cut in the rate of infections over five years.

webTitle: Island protesters ready to face US military might

fields.headline: Island protesters ready to face US military might
fields.trailText: The might of the US military machine was turned last night on 70 protesters camped on the beaches of a Caribbean island used by the navy for bombing practice.
fields.body:
The might of the US military machine was turned last night on 70 protesters camped on the beaches of a Caribbean island used by the navy for bombing practice.

The campers, whose number swells to hundreds at weekends and on holidays, have been defying the government for more than a year on Vieques, eight miles east of Puerto Rico.

Civilians live in the central strip of the island, sandwiched between navy bases which occupy two-thirds of the land and include ranges that used to be bombed on up to 198 days a year in war exercises.

The bombing was suspended a year ago after a misdirected missile killed a civilian security guard, whipping up anti-US sentiment and reviving demands for the navy to go.

Protesters then moved on to the sealed-off beaches and dared the Americans to bomb them or arrest them. Until now, the authorities have done neither, but arrests were expected last night as US warships loomed off shore.

Tension increased on Monday when it was reported that the USS Nashville and USS Bataan had picked up 1,000 marines in North Carolina en route to Vieques. It was reported that the marines would secure the range's perimeter once the protesters were removed. Arrests would be made by federal agents, according to Pentagon officials.

"I'm not going to fight with them," said Luisa Guadalupe, 82, one of those blocking the gate to the main camp in front of a sign reading: 378 Days of Peace Claimed Back from the Oppressor. "But to get me out of here, they're going to have to arrest me."

Robert Rabin, a teacher, who helped to organise the original protest a year ago, said: "We want to provoke arrests, but we are not going to be fighting with the police."

Most of those in the 14 camps have said they will offer passive resistance, but some plan to flee into the undergrowth if arrests are made.

The protesters blame the military for the island's cancer rate, which is 27% higher than that on mainland Puerto Rico, and they accuse it of destroying the environment and damaging fishing grounds, which with modest tourism account for what little work there is for the population of 9,300. The unemployment rate is 50%.

The navy, which appropriated much of the island in 1941 and has used it for training ever since, often lends Vieques to its allies, including Britain, for bombing exercises, and claims that it is the only place suitable for the purpose.

But President Clinton has arranged a compromise by which the navy would be able to drop dummy bombs on Vieques until 2003 and then leave, in return for US investment of $40m (£25m) in the local economy.

A referendum is expected to be held next year, in which islanders will also be offered the opportunity to support a return to live bombing, an option that would produce another $50m of US money if taken up. Many islanders regard this option as an attempt at bribery.

The cause has become the catalyst for a burgeoning self-determination movement in Puerto Rico, whose natives are American citizens but cannot vote in presidential elections. Demonstrations both for and against the navy have drawn crowds of up to 90,000 in the capital, San Juan.

fields.headline: Spoils of war
fields.standfirst: Uproar as China buys back looted relics
fields.trailText: Protesters scuffled with police outside a Hong Kong hotel yesterday when Sotheby's sold a looted 18th-century Chinese imperial vase back to the Chinese government for £1.7m.
fields.body:
Protesters scuffled with police outside a Hong Kong hotel yesterday when Sotheby's sold a looted 18th-century Chinese imperial vase back to the Chinese government for £1.7m.

The bid for the hexagonal ceramic vase, commissioned by the Qing dynasty emperor Qianlong in 1743, came from a subsidiary of the state administration of cultural relics, which had condemned the auction and tried to stop it.

The buyer said his company would consult the Beijing municipality about the future of the vase, which was taken fromthe Yuan Ming Yuan in Beijing, also known as the Old Summer Palace, by French and British troops in 1860, during the second opium war.

Sotheby's also raised about £1.3m from another Beijing bidder for a bronze tiger sculpture made in 1744, also seized from the Yuan Ming Yuan.

The sales have outraged many Chinese. "It would be less of an insult to our feelings if they were sold in another country," said Tsang Kin shing, a former MP. "But they're being sold in our motherland. This is a blatant disregard for our feelings."

fields.headline: Penelope Fitzgerald
fields.standfirst: Distinctive writer who brought rare economy to her studies of time, place and life's moral dilemmas
fields.trailText: The novelist and biographer Penelope Fitzgerald, who has died aged 83, was one of the most distinctive and elegant voices in contemporary British fiction. Her novels, spare, immaculate masterpieces (few of them exceed 200 pages), divide into two sections; an earlier group loosely based on her own experiences, and a later group, in which she moves to other countries and periods. fields.body:
The novelist and biographer Penelope Fitzgerald, who has died aged 83, was one of the most distinctive and elegant voices in contemporary British fiction. Her novels, spare, immaculate masterpieces (few of them exceed 200 pages), divide into two sections; an earlier group loosely based on her own experiences, and a later group, in which she moves to other countries and periods. In 1979, she won the Booker Prize for her novel Offshore.

"Reading a Penelope Fitzgerald novel," observed Sebastian Faulks, "is like being taken for a ride in a peculiar kind of car. Everything is of top quality - the engine, the coachwork and the interior all fill you with confidence. Then, after a mile or so, someone throws the steering-wheel out of the window."

Fitzgerald was the second child of Edmund George Valpy "Evoe" Knox and his wife, Christina Hicks, and was educated at Wycombe Abbey and Somerville College, Oxford, to which she won a scholarship. Her father was the eldest son of the Bishop of Manchester, her mother the daughter of Edward Hicks, Bishop of Lincoln.

Neither side of the family was well-off, and the atmosphere of hard living and high thinking was inherited by their daughter, who recalled her father's study as the only warm room in the house. It may also explain the profoundly moral, indeed religious, exploration of the human predicament and the relationship between body and soul apparent in her writing.

Fitzgerald also inherited a habit of literature from her parents. Her father, who had wanted to write from his undergraduate days, was editor of Punch from 1932. Her mother, one of the first Somerville students, also wrote. "Everyone in the house in Well Walk was writing," she remembered.

Fitzgerald delayed her own literary career until the age of 60, when she published a life of Edward Burne-Jones (1975). She wrote two other biographies, a life of the poet Charlotte Mew (1984) and the Knox Brothers (1977), a composite study of her father and his three remarkable brothers, Dillwyn (classicist and cryptographer), Wilfred (Anglican priest) and Ronald (the famous Roman Catholic convert and apologist).

All of them, she said, in explanation of her elliptical style, were given to understatement. This last book is not so much a biography as a portrait of an age and a milieu, both now disappeared; it is told with a dispassionate affection familiar to all readers of Fitzgerald's fiction. Characteristically, she contrived to suppress all mention of herself, any unavoidable reference being made obliquely and without name.

Fitzgerald's first novel, The Golden Child (1977), which was written to divert her husband during his last illness, took the form of the classic detective story. It was inspired by the Tutankhamun exhibition at the British Museum, as Human Voices (1980) was based on her war years in the BBC, and At Freddie's (1982) on her experiences at the Italia Conti stage school, where she taught in the l960s. The Bookshop (1978) recalls her years of living in Southwold, where she herself worked in a bookshop, and Offshore was based on her family's life on a rat-ridden barge at Battersea - which sank twice.

After that, she felt that she "had finished writing about the things in my own life, which I wanted to write about: then you must look and find other experiences, you must launch out." In Innocence (1986), she launched out to 16th and 20th-century Italy, then to Moscow in 1913, in The Beginnings Of Spring (1988), to Cambridge in 1912, in The Gate Of Angels (1990), and to late 18th-century Germany in her story of the romantic poet and philosopher Novalis, in The Blue Flower (1995). This was probably her masterpiece; it won the American National Book Critics fiction prize in 1998, and helped introduce her to a wider American readership.

Any division of this kind, however, tends to obscure the essential homogeneity of Fitzgerald's work. The qualities which make her writing unique are present in all of it, and her style is unmistakable. There is no sentence which could have been written by anyone else, just as no one has ever been able to repeat her peculiar blend of deadpan, slightly surreal, comedy, moral sensitivity and sober dubiety.

What is striking is the accuracy of her observation, the aesthetically satisfying precision with which, stylistically, the arrow goes straight into the centre of the gold. The economy with which she achieved her effects - "I always feel the reader is very insulted by being told too much," she said - and her ability to combine a microscopic with a panoramic perspective, made most other contemporary novels appear flatulent and over-written.

Fitzgerald has been compared in her qualities of social comedy and irony to Jane Austen. The comparison is just in many ways, but ultimately unsatisfactory, for she had a metaphysical quality which is less apparent in Jane Austen - and Jane Austen was not the only novelist of that period by whom she was influenced. She spoke with enthusiasm of the way in which Sir Walter Scott mixed up fictional and real characters, and this is reflected in the appearance of the dying Gramsci, in Innocence, and of Fichte, Goethe and Schlegel in The Blue Flower.

Throughout Fitzgerald's novels, there are certain recurring themes, the most striking of which is the single-minded and blinkered innocent (usually male), whose tunnel vision causes disaster to those around. There is an example in almost every book, the most satisfying perhaps being Fritz von Hardenberg, Novalis in The Blue Flower.

There can be few better examples of her skill than the way in which the focus gradually transfers in the second half of the book from Fritz to his 14-year-old fiancée Sophie, a brash, uninteresting teenager, who is dying of TB. This is a shift in perception, which is not just a fictional device but also a subtle moral judgment. Her work was very much in the tradition of European story-telling, Italo Calvino being a particularly close analogy.

She married Desmond Fitzgerald, an Irish soldier who she met at a wartime party, in 1941; he died in 1976. They had a son and two daughters. In 1996, she was awarded the Heywood Hill Literary Prize for a lifetime's achievement in literature.

The economy with which she achieved her effects - "I always feel the reader is very insulted by being told too much," she said - and her ability to combine a microscopic with a panoramic perspective, made most other contemporary novels appear flatulent and over-written. Fitzgerald has been compared in her qualities of social comedy and irony to Jane Austen. The comparison is just in many ways, but ultimately unsatisfactory, for she had a metaphysical quality which is less apparent in Jane Austen - and Jane Austen was not the only novelist of that period by whom she was influenced. She spoke with enthusiasm of the way in which Sir Walter Scott mixed up fictional and real characters, and this is reflected in the appearance of the dying Gramsci, in Innocence, and of Fichte, Goethe and Schlegel in The Blue Flower. Throughout Fitzgerald's novels, there are certain recurring themes, the most striking of which is the single-minded and blinkered innocent (usually male), whose tunnel vision causes disaster to those around. There is an example in almost every book, the most satisfying perhaps being Fritz von Hardenberg, Novalis in The Blue Flower. There can be few better examples of her skill than the way in which the focus gradually transfers in the second half of the book from Fritz to his 14-year-old fiancée Sophie, a brash, uninteresting teenager, who is dying of TB. This is a shift in perception, which is not just a fictional device but also a subtle moral judgment. Her work was very much in the tradition of European story-telling, Italo Calvino being a particularly close analogy. She married Desmond Fitzgerald, an Irish soldier who she met at a wartime party, in 1941; he died in 1976. They had a son and two daughters. webTitle: East German sports chief on trial for doping

fields.headline: East German sports chief on trial for doping
fields.trailText: The former head of East Germany's Olympics programme went on trial yesterday in what will be an unprecedented public examination of the project to produce super women athletes by feeding them steroids without their knowledge.
fields.body:
The former head of East Germany's Olympics programme went on trial yesterday in what will be an unprecedented public examination of the project to produce super women athletes by feeding them steroids without their knowledge.

Opening the trial of Manfred Ewald, once head of the Gymnastics and Sports Federation, the presiding judge dismissed moves for a one-day, open and shut trial of the sort which became routine for former communist officials accused of doping.

"This is not going to be a trial carried out behind the backs of those affected," Judge Dirk Dickhaus declared.

He rejected defence claims that the 73-year-old defendant would be unable to follow the proceedings.

Mr Ewald is the most senior former official to be brought before the courts on doping charges since the collapse of the German Democratic Republic (GDR).

He is accused, together with a sports doctor, Manfred Höppner, of aiding and abetting the bodily harming of 142 sportswomen, most of them swimmers and athletes.

In earlier cases, former officials have testified that - beginning in the 1970s - the communist state systematically doped its sportsmen and women to boost its achievements.

Some girls were started on injections or pills as young as 11, their coaches instructed to tell them they were taking vitamins, the prosecutor, Klaus-Heinrich Debes, told the court.

He quoted Mr Ewald as saying: "They're still so young and don't have to know everything." The prosecution accused Mr Ewald of dismissing warnings of health risks, ac cusing the experts who made them of "cowardice".

Mr Ewald headed the GDR's top sporting body from 1961 to 1988. From 1974 Mr Höppner was the chairman of its working group on supporting means - the euphemism used to describe doping.

The indictment alleges that the two men were responsible for lasting side-effects from the intake of anabolic steroids. These included hormonal disturbances and damage to internal organs.

Some women were still suffering from gynaecological disorders, it says.

Thirty-two of the sportswomen referred to in the indictment have made themselves party to the case.

They have been waiting for an opportunity to tell their stories, but have been repeatedly thwarted by plea bargaining deals that have resulted in brief hearings at which officials, trainers and doctors involved in doping were fined or given suspended sentences in return for a full confession.

An identical outcome was expected in this case, especially since Mr Ewald's lawyers had produced evidence that he was not fit to stand trial.

But the court's experts concluded otherwise, and Mr Dickhaus ordered that a full range of witnesses should be heard.

fields.headline: Pham Van Dong
fields.standfirst: Formidable Marxist mandarin and a leader of Vietnam's independence struggle, he helped shape his country's future over nearly 70 years
fields.trailText: Pham Van Dong, who has died aged 94 - on the day before the 25th anniversary of his country's final victory in the Vietnam war - was a loyal lieutenant of the Vietnamese leader Ho Chi Minh, and one of the 20th century's longest serving prime ministers. An austere and aristocratic Marxist mandarin, he governed Vietnam for 32 years, from its independence from France through the long war with the United States, and was only finally nudged aside by more reform-minded leaders in the mid-1980s, when Vietnam began shedding the central economic controls he had put in place.
fields.body:
Pham Van Dong, who has died aged 94 - on the day before the 25th anniversary of his country's final victory in the Vietnam war - was a loyal lieutenant of the Vietnamese leader Ho Chi Minh, and one of the 20th century's longest serving prime ministers. An austere and aristocratic Marxist mandarin, he governed Vietnam for 32 years, from its independence from France through the long war with the United States, and was only finally nudged aside by more reform-minded leaders in the mid-1980s, when Vietnam began shedding the central economic controls he had put in place.

Dong was among the most well-known of the group of shadowy leaders in Hanoi, particularly during the war with the US in the late 1960s, when he gave many interviews expressing North Vietnam's determination to defeat its massively more powerful adversary. But despite his elevated government position, and his membership of the Communist party politburo, he seemed to prefer the role of a Confucian administrator aloof from the factional storms blowing through Hanoi.

His real influence came in the early days of the Vietnamese revolution, when he was among the first of a group of young intellectuals, mostly children of the mandarin elite, who joined Ho Chi Minh to fight French colonialism. Along with General Vo Nguyen Giap, he was there at the creation of the small group of guerrillas that grew into a military force capable of defeating France in 1954 and the US in 1975.

Dong was little known before 1954, when he led a Vietnamese delegation to the Geneva conference that ended French rule in Indochina. Indeed, the French foreign minister, Georges Bidault, described him as a "non-existent phantom". The conference was not a success for Dong, and he buckled under pressure from the Soviet and Chinese governments to accept the division of Vietnam pending elections scheduled for 1956 - but never held. The splitting of the country along the 17th parallel kicked off another two decades of conflict.

Elevated to the post of chairman of the council of ministers, or prime minister, in 1955, Dong survived the political turmoil of the early years of communist rule in Vietnam because of his proximity and self-deprecating loyalty to Ho Chi Minh, who referred to him as "my other self" and "my favourite nephew". While others made policy, Dong was there to ensure it was carried out.

As Ho's health failed in the 1960s, Dong took an increasingly public role, travelling frequently to communist- bloc countries and giving interviews to the western press. His pronouncements that North Vietnam would endure US bombardments - and would ultimately prevail - made him an emblem of the hardiness and spirit of the North Vietnamese. This prominence led many at the time to believe that he was the real power in Vietnam, although, in fact, he played little role in the negotiations to end the war.

Those sympathetic to Hanoi were charmed by his determined manner and his ability to pepper interviews with quotes from French writers. "Intelligence and enthusiasm, lucidity and culture are rarely combined to the same degree in the same man," gushed the French photographer and journalist Marc Ribaud in Le Monde in 1969.

Others portrayed his austere demeanour and mirthless, rumbling laugh in a more sinister light. Certainly, it was rare that he strayed from the evasive doublespeak of Marxist-Leninist leaders, but he had polish, fluency in French and a range of cultural references that most Vietnamese leaders lacked. A resentful Henry Kissinger, who met Dong in Hanoi in 1973 to initial the Paris peace agreement - and was infuriated by his demands - described him as "wiry, short, wary and insolent".

Pham Van Dong was born in Quang Ngai province, in central Vietnam. He came from a mandarin family infused with a strong sense of nationalism. His father was a senior court official in Hue and secretary to the deposed Emperor Duy Tan, who was exiled to Réunion by the French in 1919 for being too nationalist. Dong's father was also sidelined from the court, a disappointment that may have forged his son's anti-colonial sentiments.

After the French lycée at Hue, Dong enrolled in the University of Hanoi, where he began a career of political activism. He ran into trouble with the French authorities in 1925 for organising a student strike during the funeral of the nationalist hero Phan Chu Trinh. He was expelled and left for China, where he studied at the Chinese Nationalist party's Whampoa Military Academy, and first met Ho Chi Minh.

On Ho's orders, Dong returned to Vietnam in 1927 to organise the Thanh Nien youth movement. Arrested in 1929, he spent nearly seven years in Poulo Condore, an infamous French prison colony on an island in the South China Sea, which served as something of a university of the revolution. Released under an amnesty ordered by a new French government in 1936, he returned to political organisation, but fled Vietnam again three years later.

In 1941, Dong joined Ho and other leaders in founding the Viet Minh, a united-front organisation aimed at ousting both the French and the Japanese, who by then had occupied Vietnam. In August 1945, taking advantage of the political vacuum at the end of the second world war, they seized power in Hanoi. Dong became finance minister, and was chief aide to Ho Chi Minh at the Fontainbleu talks of 1946 which failed to settle the issue of independence.

As the French returned to Hanoi, the Viet Minh fled to the mountains. Dong was sent to his home province to lead the guerrilla movement there. It was at this time that he was said to have been involved in the violent purges of non-communists in the Viet Minh coalition. In 1951, he became vice-premier and, before the French surrender in 1954, he was made foreign minister.

During the 1960s, Dong repeatedly told journalists that Hanoi had no intention of imposing communism on the south. Yet as soon as the battles ended in April 1975, the government started doing exactly that, interning hundreds of thousands of people in re-education camps and collectivising farms.

At the same time, tensions started to rise with the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia and their supporters in Beijing. Dong led attempts to build closer ties with Vietnam's neighbours in southeast Asia and with Europe. He visited France for the first time since 1946, but failed to win pledges of support. By 1979, Vietnam was once again embroiled in war, this time with the Khmer Rouge and Hanoi's former allies in Beijing.

In the late 1970s, Dong told a visitor that "waging a war is simple, but running a country is very difficult". Indeed, his administrative skills, with which he had channelled the energies of a nation in conflict, were far less successful in peacetime. Already nearly being destroyed by decades of war, Vietnam's economy was unable to endure a rapid shift towards Soviet-style central planning. An international economic embargo, declining agricultural production and a ruinous attempt at currency reform added to the problems.

Later, Dong would only admit that "mistakes were made" after 1975, when the country suffered from what he called "subjectivity and leftism", jargon for the leadership's determined push for socialism that left Vietnam bankrupt and dependent on Moscow.

For much of his time as prime minister, Dong wielded less power than his position would suggest. Increasingly, the reins of policymaking were taken over by the Communist party chief Le Duan and Le Duc Tho, the politburo member who negotiated with the US and, with Kissinger, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. "When I say something, nobody listens," Dong was reported to have said. "I cannot even choose my own ministers."

His character was too remote and arid to capture public affection in the way that Ho Chi Minh had. On the other hand, this self-effacing approach enabled him to escape blame for many of the failures that afflicted Vietnam. Dong was said to speak out rarely in meetings, and was never quick to express an opinion.

In 1986, he stepped down as premier and gave up his seat on the politburo. He held the post of special adviser to the Communist party central committee, and appeared regularly at ceremonial occasions. Dressed in a white Mao suit and dark glasses, his face lean and cadaverous, he was increasingly something of a Banquo's ghost, there to remind the new leadership, in their suits and ties, of their abandonment of all but a thin veneer of Marxism.

Dong's communist credentials remained impeccable to the bitter end. "Capitalism won't go far," he said in 1994. "It carries within it the seeds of its own destruction." He wrote tirades about the dangers of Vietnam's rush towards the market, and was critical of the country's rising inequalities and corruption. But his message was lost on a people enjoying a measure of economic and political freedom that he had never allowed them.

Although a prolific writer, Dong never produced a memoir. His life was sublimated to the cult of Ho Chi Minh, whom he never failed to quote in any interview or article. He wrote a hagiography of Ho in 1960, but most of his other works were collections of speeches and heavy articles published in the Communist party newspaper.

Dong's private life remained resolutely private. Little is known about his marriage, except that his wife suffered from mental illnesses and was frequently hospitalised. He is thought to have had a son and a daughter. His family were never publicly acknowledged, so that, like Ho Chi Minh, he could portray himself as devoted only to the revolution.

In later life, his health was often precarious. He had a pacemaker inserted in the late 1970s, and, from the mid-1980s, his sight failed, leaving him completely blind for the rest of his life. He lived in a modest house in the grounds of the presidential palace in Hanoi, not far from where Ho Chi Minh had also spent his final days. He remained a busy public figure to the end, writing critical articles and appearing at state functions.

webTitle: A Hollywood plot to die for

fields.headline: A Hollywood plot to die for
fields.trailText: Hollywood has traditionally been the place to go if you are dying to get into the movies. Now it is being promoted as the place to stay when you have died, whether you made it in the movies or not.
fields.body:
Hollywood has traditionally been the place to go if you are dying to get into the movies. Now it is being promoted as the place to stay when you have died, whether you made it in the movies or not.

For a few thousand dollars you can now buy yourself a final resting place next to your favourite film star.

A number of reservations to spend eternity beside the matinee idol Rudolph Valentino, who died in 1926, have already been made.

Hollywood Memorial Park was built in 1899 and gradually became known as the burial place for the film industry.

Cecil B DeMille has a substantial family crypt, Tyrone Power's grave overlooks the ornamental lake, and stars from Douglas Fairbanks Sr to Peter Lorre, from Nelson Eddy to Peter Finch, are buried there.

When Valentino was laid to rest wearing a slave bracelet given to him by his last wife, 10,000 mourners crowded into the cemetery on Santa Monica Boulevard in the heart of Hollywood.

But, like so many cemeteries around the world, Hollywood Memorial Park ran into financial problems, and two years ago it faced bankruptcy. It has now been taken over by a young company called the Forever Network, owned by 30-year-old Tyler Cassity, who has set out on an energetic campaign to sell the cemetery to the general public.

Ads have been appearing on the internet (www.forevernetwork.com) and in the LA papers. There is a banner outside the park advertising the budget rates available.

"Most people thought it was only for stars or that it was owned by the studios," a spokesman said yesterday. "They didn't realise that anyone could be buried there. It's completely democratic - and it's a world treasure."

The park, renamed Hollywood Forever, offers a budget deal for $998 (£637) complete with a specially made video of the loved one which will be shown on a big screen during the ceremony, incorporating highlights from home videos. The loved-one's obituary will appear on the company's website.

The number of funerals has risen more than 20-fold since the marketing campaign be gan and the company is anxious to stress that there is room for all; creative use of the 24 hectares (60 acres) of land will provide space for another 100,000 bodies to join the 80,000 already resting in peace.

Of course, being interred next to a famous star costs a little more than the budget price, fees of up to £5,111 being paid for special locations.

"A number of people want to spend an eternity next to Rudolph Valentino," the spokesman said. "So that's going very quickly."

Los Angeles has, of course, long shown the way in the art of dying. Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale, which was built in 1917, was the inspiration for Evelyn Waugh's book The Loved One. The brainchild of Hubert L Eaton, a mining engineer from Missouri, it has burial areas called Slumberland, Vale of Memory and Whispering Pines, and there is a glass replica of Leonardo da Vinci's Last Supper on the premises.

It still does a lively trade, albeit not at budget rates. But Forest Lawn cannot guarantee that you will have a famous neighbour when you settle down for the big sleep.

The Stars of Memorial Park

The death of Rudolph Valentino in 1926 at the age of 31, from a perforated ulcer, provoked national hysteria among his female fans. Some committed suicide and others rioted at his funeral. For many years a mysterious woman in black laid a wreath on his grave.

A major romantic lead in the 1930s and 1940s, Tyrone Power died of a heart attack aged 44 in 1958.

The actress Virginia Rappe died aged 26 in 1921 in Hollywood's first major scandal - a wild party which led to the comedian Fatty Arbuckle being charged with her murder. Arbuckle was acquitted but ruined.

Cecil B DeMille , director, producer and writer, who died in 1959, was responsible for such epics as The Ten Commandments, Cleopatra,and King of Kings.

The gangster Bugsy Seigel was shot dead in 1947 and later became the subject of a film himself.

Star of The Maltese Falcon and Casablanca, Peter Lorre died in 1964, aged 60.

The Oscar winner Peter Finch died in 1977, aged 60.

Veteran director, actor and writer John Huston died in 1987. His films include The African Queen, The Maltese Falcon, The Misfits, Moby Dick, and Prizzi's Honour.

Silent movie star Barbara LaMarr died aged 30 in 1926 of "over-dieting". She was known as "the girl who was too beautiful".

Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale, which was built in 1917, was the inspiration for Evelyn Waugh's book The Loved One. The brainchild of Hubert L Eaton, a mining engineer from Missouri, it has burial areas called Slumberland, Vale of Memory and Whispering Pines, and there is a glass replica of Leonardo da Vinci's Last Supper on the premises. It still does a lively trade, albeit not at budget rates. But Forest Lawn cannot guarantee that you will have a famous neighbour when you settle down for the big sleep. The Stars of Memorial Park The death of Rudolph Valentino in 1926 at the age of 31, from a perforated ulcer, provoked national hysteria among his female fans. Some committed suicide and others rioted at his funeral. For many years a mysterious woman in black laid a wreath on his grave. A major romantic lead in the 1930s and 1940s, Tyrone Power died of a heart attack aged 44 in 1958. The actress Virginia Rappe died aged 26 in 1921 in Hollywood's first major scandal - a wild party which led to the comedian Fatty Arbuckle being charged with her murder. Arbuckle was acquitted but ruined. Cecil B DeMille , director, producer and writer, who died in 1959, was responsible for such epics as The Ten Commandments, Cleopatra,and King of Kings. The gangster Bugsy Seigel was shot dead in 1947 and later became the subject of a film himself. Star of The Maltese Falcon and Casablanca, Peter Lorre died in 1964, aged 60. The Oscar winner Peter Finch died in 1977, aged 60. Veteran director, actor and writer John Huston died in 1987. His films include The African Queen, The Maltese Falcon, The Misfits, Moby Dick, and Prizzi's Honour. Silent movie star Barbara LaMarr died aged 30 in 1926 of "over-dieting". She was known as "the girl who was too beautiful".

webTitle: Baby snatch teenager jailed for 18 months

fields.headline: Baby snatch teenager jailed for 18 months
fields.trailText: An 18-year-old girl who claimed she had a miscarriage abducted a baby boy to avoid disappointing her boyfriend's family, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
An 18-year-old girl who claimed she had a miscarriage abducted a baby boy to avoid disappointing her boyfriend's family, a court heard yesterday.

Katie Archer snatched six-month-old George Tipping from a cafe in Brighton last October and took him to her boyfriend's mother in Alton, Hampshire, pretending the child was hers.

Archer, formerly of Brighton, was sentenced at Lewes crown court to 18 months in a young offenders' institute for the offence of abducting a child. She admitted the charge at a previous hearing.

She was also ordered to serve four months of a previ ous 11 month sentence for blackmail, imposed in March 1999.

Sentencing Archer, Judge Richard Brown said: "The evidence of this case and your record lead me to take the view that you are a very devious and dishonest young woman.

"It is difficult for us sitting in this room to begin to imagine the horror and fear that goes through a mother's mind when her baby is abducted."

Martin Field, prosecuting, told the court that Archer first claimed she was pregnant and then that she had suffered a miscarriage in prison.

But she continued to write to her boyfriend's mother, Sue Appleby, saying how pleased she was to be a part of her family.

On October 12, 1999,she telephoned Mrs Appleby at her home in to say that she had had a baby boy and was about to catch a train to visit her.

Mr Field said: "The defendant says she had a miscarriage but that she was too frightened to tell her boyfriend about it because they had been looking forward to the birth of the child."

On the same day, baby George's mother, Sarah Tipping, left her son with her father, James, and went to work at a Brighton shoe shop.

Mr Tipping said that he had a call from Archer, who was a neighbour, asking him to go to a cafe in Brighton to collect money from a man who owed it to her.

The court was told that he agreed, and left George with Archer at a cafe in Brighton, but when he returned they had gone.

Archer met Mrs Appleby later that day, who called the police. Archer was arrested and George was reunited with his mother 11 hours after being abducted.

Stephen Fuller, defending, asked Judge Brown to accept that Archer believed she was pregnant. He said: "She knows there are very few excuses. She felt great guilt about having lost the baby. Miss Archer had no family up-bringing. This was a way of having an instant family."

fields.trailText: The final line fell from a report about the budgets of British embassies, page 4, in later editions yesterday. We were quoting Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman, commenting on spending on entertainment. He said (in full), "It may have tightened a little but not as much as the stomachs have grown."
fields.body:
The final line fell from a report about the budgets of British embassies, page 4, in later editions yesterday. We were quoting Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman, commenting on spending on entertainment. He said (in full), "It may have tightened a little but not as much as the stomachs have grown."

The Beggar's Opera opened in London on January 29, 1728 (not 1782 as we had it on page 3, May 1). John Gay died in 1732, and John Rich, the theatre manager and actor, died in 1761.

Handel first conducted his Messiah in Dublin, April 13, 1742 (the New Music Hall, Fishamble Street) and not in Bath, as we incorrectly suggested on page 7, yesterday.

Added to the end of an article on a problematic journey home from Kathmandu - page 16, Travel, April 22 - was a list of airlines flying between the Nepalese capital and London. Wrongly included were British Airways, Eva, Qantas and SAS (though BA and Eva will sell tickets that include Kathmandu travel with other airlines). Missing was Royal Air Nepal, flying direct from Gatwick.

Homophone corner, from page 16, G2, yesterday, "Having whetted our palettes for truth, he governed like a liar." Collins Millennium offers the following useful advice after its definition of palette: "Avoid confusion with palate or pallet."

Some linguistic cleansing was apparent in an item on St Mirren winning the Scottish Football League Championship, First Division, page 4, Sport, May 1. The victorious players, it said, did a lap of honour in T-shirts proclaiming: "The bubble didn't burst". The words on the shirts were: "The bubble didnae burst".

webTitle: Cruise down the Swanee  Aurora's maiden voyage halted

fields.headline: Cruise down the Swanee  Aurora's maiden voyage halted
fields.trailText: P&O's £200m cruise ship Aurora was yesterday forced to limp back to port after breaking down off the French coast just one day into her maiden voyage.
fields.body:
P&O's £200m cruise ship Aurora was yesterday forced to limp back to port after breaking down off the French coast just one day into her maiden voyage.

Early reports suggested a problem with a propeller shaft overheating just 350 miles from Southampton.

The Aurora's 1,800 passengers, who were were described by P&O as "bitterly disappointed", were due to arrive home in Southampton this morning with their cruise cancelled.

Passengers were quickly offered a full compensation package, which includes a refund on their ticket as well as another free cruise of an equivalent value.

The 76,000-tonne cruise ship which stands 10 metres higher than the Niagara Falls and 270 metres long, the length of three Statues of Liberty, left Southampton on Monday after being formally named by the Princess Royal.

Ominously, when the superliner was christened, the traditional magnum of champagne dropped into the water without smashing, traditionally seen as a sign of bad luck in nautical circles.

A P&O spokeswoman said Aurora had been off the French coast, heading towards the Bay of Biscay, when the decision was taken to abandon the cruise. Passengers were given the news in an announcement from the captain, Steve Burgoine.

The vessel was due to dock at Lisbon this afternoon. After that, the Aurora had been due to visit Barcelona, Monte Carlo, Livorno, Naples, Ajaccio and Gibraltar, before returning to Southampton on May 15.

P&O said the propeller shaft bearing had over heated, making it impossible for the vessel to continue with her two-week maiden voyage.

Aurora immediately started heading back at half-steam to Southampton.

The huge ship offers 939 cabins accommodating 1,874 passengers and two luxury penthouse suites serviced by a butler.

Four decks of cabins, among the 10 passenger decks, have private balconies and the Aurora has 9,200 square metres of open deck space, enough to accommodate 35 tennis courts.

webTitle: The best business card scene: American Psycho

fields.headline: The best business card scene: American Psycho
fields.trailText: Wall Street, the 80s. Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale) sits at a conference table with his fellow stockbrokers. He removes a silver case from his pocket. One of his colleagues leans across, smirking.
fields.body:
Wall Street, the 80s. Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale) sits at a conference table with his fellow stockbrokers. He removes a silver case from his pocket. One of his colleagues leans across, smirking.

"Is that a gram?"

"New card. Whaddya think?"

Bateman slides his card across the table; it's off-white, with the words PATRICK BATEMAN: VICE PRESIDENT centred and embossed in black.

The assembled party gasp in admiration.

"Very nice."

Bateman leans back in his chair.

"Picked 'em up from the printers yesterday."

"Good colouring."

"That's bone. And the lettering is something called Silian Grail."

Another broker interrupts.

"It's very cool, Bateman, but..."

He whips out his card, laying it next to Bateman's on the table. Off-white with the words ROBERT VAN PATTEN: VICE PRESIDENT centred and embossed in black, it is basically indistinguishable.

"Egg shell, with Roman."

Bateman smiles bitterly.

"Nice."

Now a third broker pulls out his card. It looks exactly like the first two, except it reads TIMOTHY BRICE: VICE PRESIDENT.

"Raised lettering, pale nimbus."

"Impressive", Bateman mutters. "Let's see Paul Allen's card."

The room falls silent as the third broker produces an absent colleague's card.

Bateman speaks in voiceover.

"Look at that subtle colouring. The tasteful thickness."

His face creases in horror.

"Oh my God. It even has a watermark."

See also: Bedazzled

Don't see also: Analyze This

Pointless trivia: Christian Bale will star in John Singleton's impending remake of Shaft.

webTitle: Vorderman snookered by BBC in ratings war

fields.headline: Vorderman snookered by BBC in ratings war
fields.trailText: The battle of the celebrity brains in the unforgiving arena of the Who Wants to be a Millionaire? bearpit made for compelling viewing, but millions shunned the intellectual tussle in favour of nail-biting action of a different sort.
fields.body:
The battle of the celebrity brains in the unforgiving arena of the Who Wants to be a Millionaire? bearpit made for compelling viewing, but millions shunned the intellectual tussle in favour of nail-biting action of a different sort.

According to provisional figures released yesterday, the drama played out at the same time at the Crucible theatre in Sheffield proved compulsive enough to knock the special version of Britain's most popular quiz show into one of its lowest-rated editions on Monday.

While 12.8m watched Carol Vorderman and Kirsty Young sweat it out for charity on ITV, 4m preferred to see Mark Williams claw to victory over fellow Welshman Matthew Stevens at the Embassy world snooker championships on BBC2. After Vorderman and Young had raised more than £300,000 for their nominated good causes, the snooker peaked at 7.5m. The Millionaire rating was disappointing for ITV: in earlier series, the show has achieved audiences of up to 18m. Its lowest was just over 10m.

But while many switched over after Millionaire, 5.2m stayed to watch ITV's new drama-thriller, Metropolis. The BBC's similar "twentysomething" drama, Hearts and Bones, scored 5m when it began on Sunday night.

ITV yesterday claimed 42% of the peak-time audience. BBC1, also affected by the snooker, got 17.1%. "The snooker was an act of God - there's not much you can do when Britain's most boring sport suddenly gets exciting for once," an ITV source said.

A spokesman for Day of Promise, the event of which Millionaire was the centrepiece, said it had been a huge success. Almost 370,000 people called to log a pledge to "make a difference" to their own or someone else's life. "We were ecstatic with the response," he said.

fields.headline: Tracking the birds
fields.trailText:
I was recently waiting on the platform at Farringdon Underground station, when I saw a bird behaving in a very odd way. It seemed to be digging into the rubble. When it flew up I realised that it was a kestrel which had been pursuing a mouse. Is this the first recorded sighting of a raptor on the underground? Could London Underground introduce a few golden eagles to clear the pigeons?
Peter Mellor
City University,
London

fields.headline: Clashes over anti-capitalist demo
fields.trailText: Hugo Young writes of global capitalism that there is "space for forceful attack, based on ideas not gestures" (There is a gap in the market for serious radicalism, May 2). There is in fact no shortage of ideas on alternatives to the current economic system - but precious little gets into the mainstream media.
fields.body:
Hugo Young writes of global capitalism that there is "space for forceful attack, based on ideas not gestures" (There is a gap in the market for serious radicalism, May 2). There is in fact no shortage of ideas on alternatives to the current economic system - but precious little gets into the mainstream media.

Mr Young's analysis alludes to the glaring hole in the media debate about the grassroots movement against economic globalisation. There has not yet been a serious mainstream discussion of the implications for press freedom of the fact that the mass media is mostly made up of profit-seeking corporations controlled by wealthy owners and giant parent companies, and dependent on corporate advertisers.

David Cromwell
Southampton
David.Cromwell@soc.soton. ac.uk

 Although only 27, I'm a veteran of anti-capitalist protests. I was at Twyford Down almost 10 years ago and more recently the protests at the G8 meeting in Birmingham - where street activists first started drawing links with other campaigns and realised the common obstacles to creating a just and sustainable world. I took a lot of heart from the protests in Seattle last year, when our concerns with the unaccountability of our global economy made it onto the agenda of the mass media.

Last weekend I went to the conference preceding the May Day demonstrations in London and was disappointed to find that the search for a political agenda to link the various single-issue movements was being guided by people who hold anarchist and revolutionary Marxist opinions.

Their antagonism towards those who are working to change the global capitalist system from within is creating fragmentation. It was interesting to see that groups such as World Development Movement, Friends of the Earth and Greenpeace were not there. These groups must reclaim the political space being perverted by people using antique theories to justify their personal aggression. People who smash windows and deface statues do nothing for our cause.

We need a coherent set of policies that flesh out a vision of a free and ecologically sound world.

Jem Bendell

Brighton

 The moment I heard there was rioting in central London I leapt out of the house determined to somehow persuade everyone that violence wouldn't solve anything; 45 minutes later I was at Charing Cross (after buying a symbolic single ticket) surrounded by a police cordon and a load of people who, like me, weren't quite sure why they were there. I went home feeling rather silly - in my haste I'd forgotten it wasn't the 1930s. Isabel Hilton (Attacking Goliath, May 1) is right - no one's going to overthrow capitalism. So why dig up a perfectly nice garden and scribble on the Cenotaph?

Paul Engles
London
paul@engles.dircon.co.uk

 At the moment Reclaim the Streets represents the most powerful voice through which anti-capitalist sentiments can be channelled. Yet its failings were visible yesterday - it can all too easily be portrayed as anarchic and destructive. Nevertheless it is crucial that this groundswell of opinion is used to good effect and attracts many more to future protests (greater numbers of peaceful protesters will help to marginalise and contain extremists). The campaign needs to be lent an air of respectability - step foward newspaper editors of the liberal left.

Alex Robertson

London
alexrobe@hotmail.com

 If the current political system is unable to address the concerns raised by the protesters (in so far as there were any), then it is surely time to debate the merits of a better politics, including proportional representation, rather than to support violence and vandalism that defaces the city where I live. Flowers did not bloom in Parliament Square, it is now just a muddy mess.

Michael R Hutchinson
London

 Several thousand peaceful protesters (and a few bemused tourists) were imprisoned in Trafalgar Square for three hours. Your report did not mention the socialist May Day march, due to end in Trafalgar Square, which was trapped in the Strand for the same period. The mix of greens, socialists, anarchists, black, white, old and young were remarkably good humoured but I can't blame people who lost their cool and threw whatever was at hand at their jailers.

The thousands of riot police swamping central London were far more terrifying than a couple of hundred anarchists, and a much greater threat to liberty.

Ken Olende
London
ka.olende@virgin.net

 I've seen the tabloid response to the green divot on Churchill's statue; if Churchill had sported a green mohawk during the war my suspicion is that it would have put the wind right up the SS. The statue of Aneurin Bevan in Cardiff is frequently seen sporting a traffic cone hat and holding a beer bottle, but you'd be a fool to get too worked up about it.

Lawrence Toms
Cardiff

webTitle: A word or two on the language of migration

fields.headline: A word or two on the language of migration
fields.trailText: Mr Hague is tripping over himself in his mad rush to the right (Hague stirs race row, May 1). He insists "we should use words properly with their full meaning and their true meaning". Hear, hear. The Tory leader's linguistic scholarship notwithstanding, I thought apt a quick perusal of the OED for the word "flood". If one took Mr Hague at his word, one would be left, I fear, rather confused; surely his idea of detention centres is not one that holds water.
fields.body:
Mr Hague is tripping over himself in his mad rush to the right (Hague stirs race row, May 1). He insists "we should use words properly with their full meaning and their true meaning". Hear, hear. The Tory leader's linguistic scholarship notwithstanding, I thought apt a quick perusal of the OED for the word "flood". If one took Mr Hague at his word, one would be left, I fear, rather confused; surely his idea of detention centres is not one that holds water.

The point, of course, is that he does not use the word flood "with its true meaning" but is using it figuratively. And the objections raised have still less to do with the word's "true meaning" than with the use of an emotive word whose power to arouse prejudice far outweighs its value in reasoned debate. Young Mr Hague should note that talk of "floods" threatens to throw open gates we have long worked hard to secure - gates which hold back the "rivers of blood".

Zia H Rahman
London

 As it has been well documented that the number of asylum seekers in Britain is falling rather than rising, will Hague stop flooding the media with his bogus claims about them?

John Budis
London
budisjohn@hotmail.com

 In an otherwise well reasoned argument concerning migration, Nigel Harris (Racists are so blind, May 2) erroneously cites Cuban migrants in Miami as an example of an immigrant community that benefits the host economy by working for wages and in jobs the natives won't do. But the first Cubans to leave after the revolution of 1959 were millionaire landowners and members of the Batista junta, who took an estimated $430m in currency and gold with them when they fled. The second wave comprised the professional and upper middle classes.

The cold war policy of isolating and undermining Cuba by economic and terrorist sabotage meant that the federal government, through the CIA, pumped millions of dollars into developing Miami as a base for its anti-Castro activities. Opa Loca Airport and the Miami waterfront for example were developed entirely through CIA money being invested via front companies.

Cubans in Miami have had advantages that no other immigrant group in the history of the US has ever enjoyed (except perhaps those Nazi scientists who built the rocket programme).

Until the world, and more particularly, US public opinion, wakes up to this fact, the Miami Cubans will remain a headache for the presidency that will never be cured.

Stephen Wilkinson
Hampton Wick, Middx

 Thanks, Nigel Harris, for the reminder that the nation state is nothing more than a Trojan horse. What with all the jingoistic rubbish we are bombarded with, I was starting to think it was real.
Anna Cuskin
London

fields.headline: UK African diaspora
fields.trailText:
Your report (DNA tests offer roots revival, May 2) failed to mention that a back-to-Africa movement existed in the UK. Bernie Grant was chair of the African Reparations Movement UK and called for the cancellation of debts, the return of artefacts and the payment of substantial sums in reparations for the enslavement and murder of millions of Africans. Central to the movement is the notion of repair, and the return of many people of African origin to help build a renewed Africa. You should not think that the African diaspora resides only in the US.
Linda Bellos
Treasurer,
African Reparations Movement UK

fields.headline: A referendum of sorts
fields.standfirst:
Beware of a spate of these private polls

More about section 28
fields.trailText: The first ballot papers for the Scottish referendum on section 28 of the Conservatives' Local Government Act, which regulates teaching on homosexuality, are now on their way to voters, and the rest will be delivered over the next 10 days.
fields.body:
The first ballot papers for the Scottish referendum on section 28 of the Conservatives' Local Government Act, which regulates teaching on homosexuality, are now on their way to voters, and the rest will be delivered over the next 10 days.

The use of referendums is spreading - there have been three so far in the life of this government, on devolution to Scotland, Wales and London. But this one is different. It is organised not by government but by private individuals who want to save section 28 from repeal. And voting is entirely by post, not at the ballot box.

The organisers have entrusted the arrangements to a seasoned returning officer, and the questions have been framed by the Guardian's pollsters, ICM. Safeguards have been set in place which have not yet been disclosed for fear of alerting miscreants. But it has yet to be shown that a firm defence is in place against, for instance, zealots acquiring additional voting papers to boost their side's performance.

The results are expected on May 30. If they have the impact the sponsors hope, more are likely to follow: on hanging, for instance. This one is costing £1m, most of which comes from the pocket of the Stagecoach boss, Brian Souter. That underlines the advantage which fat cats will gain in trying, as he is doing, to buy a form of public endorsement for the measures they favour at a cost which few could afford.

The claim that this kind of exercise represents no more than a natural extension of democracy is dubious on several counts, and it may in any case be negated if those who back the scrapping of section 28 stay away in big enough numbers. There is clearly a place for seriously conducted, publicly funded referendums on issues, devolution among them, which alter the role of parliament. Ad hoc privatised jaunts should be treated with much greater scepticism. The Scottish parliament should not swallow this one whole and should certainly not think itself bound to act on it.

fields.headline: Our man in clover
fields.trailText: I share Matthew Taylor's concern about expenditure on our foreign embassies (Big spenders par excellence, May 2). In Germany the suggestion has been made that EU embassies should be established to share costs.
fields.body:
I share Matthew Taylor's concern about expenditure on our foreign embassies (Big spenders par excellence, May 2). In Germany the suggestion has been made that EU embassies should be established to share costs.

This idea could save money for the British government and provide some "best value" for the taxpayer (what's good for local government should also apply to central government) or perhaps the Foreign Office would prefer that such financial information remain unpublished?

Tessa Harding
Ely, Cambridgeshire,

fields.headline: Jailers will be joined-up
fields.trailText: New Labour's spin that merging the chief inspector of prisons with the chief inspector of probation is a positive reform should be greeted with extreme cynicism (Jails watchdog may lose bite, May 2).
fields.body:
New Labour's spin that merging the chief inspector of prisons with the chief inspector of probation is a positive reform should be greeted with extreme cynicism (Jails watchdog may lose bite, May 2).

It seems that the disasters in Wales and in the London mayoral race have done little to dampen ministers' desire to stifle dissent. In the case of Sir David Ramsbotham, the spin is joined-up government. Effectively, as Norman Fairclough has recently demonstrated, joined-up government allows the centre to define problems and the strategies for dealing with them.

Thus the problem has become Sir David's robust approach in highlighting the appalling state of local prisons in particular and in allowing prisoners to talk about what they see as their brutalising experiences at the hands of some prison officers.

The government's spin then becomes Sir David's behaviour rather than facing up to the implications around these issues while the solution is sold as joined-up government rather than the centre's desire to exert greater control over information about what is happening inside.

Prof Joe Sim
School of law and applied social studies
John Moores University, Liverpool

fields.headline: Boost for 'green' farming urged
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Farmers who want to change their techniques so as to protect the countryside and wildlife are penalised under the European Union's subsidy system, according to a report by conservationists WWF-UK.
fields.body:
Farmers who want to change their techniques so as to protect the countryside and wildlife are penalised under the European Union's subsidy system, according to a report by conservationists WWF-UK.

Some farmers who reduce numbers of sheep or cattle on grazing land face penalties because cash from "green grants" does not match money available for livestock under the common agriculture policy.

The report calls for a four-fold increase in annual budgets for eco-friendly farming to ensure farmers see "caring for nature" as a profitable alternative.

This would provide a near £1bn a year strings-attached investment in wildlife and farm businesses. It could also create jobs in protecting the environment and tourism.

The money should be used to increase the percentage of farmers involved in agri-environment schemes from 13% to 70% and raise grant levels, said authors Richard Perkins and Rebecca May.

fields.headline: Hartson charged by FA
fields.trailText: John Hartson has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association. The FA has charged the Wimbledon striker over an alleged scuffle in the tunnel before Sunday's Premiership match with Bradford at Valley Parade.
fields.body:
John Hartson has been charged with misconduct by the Football Association. The FA has charged the Wimbledon striker over an alleged scuffle in the tunnel before Sunday's Premiership match with Bradford at Valley Parade.

Hartson was sent off at Valley Parade by referee Jeff Winter for foul and abusive language. However, on the basis of reports from referee Winter and fourth official John Leek, he has now also been charged by the FA in connection with an alleged incident in the tunnel before the game.

The sending-off means that the Welsh international will already miss the final game of the season away to Southampton, as well as the first two matches of the next campaign. But given his previous record of three past misconduct charges - two fines and a three-match ban for kicking Eyal Berkovic on the West Ham training ground - it is likely that he would be given a further ban if found guilty of misconduct.

fields.headline: The future is Kiwi
fields.standfirst:
New Zealand's leftwing Labour government could teach Tony Blair a thing or two about the 'heartlands'

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: At www.fantasymayor.com you can pick the London boss of your dreams. So why not, in this week of local elections and Labour anniversaries, take the game a stage further - and play fantasy governments?
fields.body:
Click on www.fantasymayor.com and you can pick the London boss of your dreams. So why not, in this week of local elections and Labour anniversaries, take the game a stage further - and play fantasy governments?

Let's start with a faraway Labour party that has ditched its flirtation with Thatcherite economics and come home, relocating itself on the unashamed left. Let's imagine this Labour party is speeding through a programme so progressive it would make radicals everywhere drool. It has raised the taxes of the rich and transferred the cash to pensioners, students and the needy. It has stopped privatisation dead in its tracks, even renationalising one public service because Labour believes there are some things the free market cannot get right. It has given trade unions their rights back and boosted spending on schools and hospitals. It has rewritten employment law, moving the country away from what the prime minister calls the "loony edges of a deregulated labour market". It has started building houses again.

Wait, it gets better. This fantasy government has abolished all honours that come with titles, ensuring an egalitarian nation with no more use for Dames and Sirs. The Labour leader has even taken a tilt at the monarchy itself, describing a republic as "inevitable". She enforces a stoutly non-nuclear defence policy - and has dared confront the right by scrapping an order for 28 swank new American fighter planes, arguing that the country does not need them and cannot afford them. She wants her army to be the world leader in peacekeeping and to shift from militarism to humanitarianism. She has also moved to decriminalise cannabis and encouraged a freedom of information regime so liberal that cabinet papers are available to anyone who wants them within three months. Best of all, this leftwing government is not besieged on all sides by a hostile press or conservative public opinion. Instead, it is surging ahead in the polls leaving the opposition to gasp with envy and awe.

Enough of such fantasy! Surely no such party can exist, able to govern from the left even as it carries a grateful nation with it. Can it? The happy answer is that it can and it does. For this is not a Guardian readers' hallucination; this faraway land is not some impossible Utopia. Rather the country is New Zealand and the party is Labour, under its new prime minister, Helen Clark.

What she is up to makes not only a fascinating tale from the south Pacific. It also provides a warning lesson for Tony Blair and New Labour in what can happen to parties of the left that march too far rightward in the pursuit of power. Those forecasting the shape of New Labour in 2010 don't need to gaze into the crystal ball: they can look down under.

For Helen Clark's party were Blairites a decade before Blair. Their 1997 came in 1984 when, just like New Labour, they were elected in a massive landslide. They promptly dumped every economic principle that had once been Labour holy writ. The party converted to the free market with a zeal that out-Thatchered Thatcher and out-Reaganed Reagan. If it moved, Labour and its finance minister Roger Douglas privatised it. Taxes were slashed, workers' protection binned. New Zealand became the citadel of the new right.

At first it worked. NZ Labour achieved Tony Blair's hallowed goal - winning a second term. The party had seduced rich, middle New Zealand, winning voters old Labour couldn't reach. "But the heartlands started to go off us," Clark told me from her office overlooking Wellington harbour. Labour's core supporters were "pretty appalled at what was happening".

Here is the warning for Blair. New Zealand's heartlands rebelled in what Clark calls - using the plain English that has helped make her so popular - "disgust" at the rightward thrust of their party. Barely into its second term, Labour revolted. Divisions led to a massive election defeat in 1990, with the left breaking off to form a new party and Roger Douglas's right eventually doing the same. Labour was reduced to a rump. With less than 5,000 members, the new leader - Helen Clark - began the 90s with what is said to be the lowest approval rating in world polling history: 2%.

The remedy was to return to Labour's core values. "We'd had experience of going right, we knew there was no market for that," she explains. "But we also knew there was an appetite for an alternative." It took nine years and two more election defeats to get it right. Clark is in no doubt why it took so long: "We weren't left enough."

Could this be the fate of British Labour? Might the full-blooded conversion to the free market - typified by this week's Commons vote on the partial privatisation of the air traffic control system - eventually fall out of favour? Might Labour's left rebel, as they did down under? Could Blair win his precious two terms, only to see his party serve three more in opposition - rejected for its failure to provide an alternative to the Conservatives?

There are differences between the two situations, of course. For one thing, the "Rogernomics" of the Douglas era was much more rightwing than the fiscal prudence of Gordon Brown: after all, the NZ Labour government of the 1980s had to drag a country that was run, in Clark's words, like a "Polish shipyard" into the 20th century.

New Zealand's electoral system, a form of proportional representation, is a key difference. Size matters, too: it's possible that state-run public services make more sense when the population is less than four million. And leftwing politics sits well with a country like New Zealand. As the prime minister says, "In a settler society, you start off with people a lot more even."

NZ is young and egalitarian by instinct: that's why there was barely a whisper of protest at the promise to make no more Dame Kiri Te Kanawas or Sir Edmund Hilarys. If Australia gets its act together and removes the Queen as head of state, then Clark cannot imagine New Zealand lagging far behind. Britain, she appreciates, is different - "essentially a much more hierarchical society" than hers.

Still, we may have something to learn from this country 12,000 miles away, where a prime minister explicitly promised her nation a radical programme and where she is delivering it at a breakneck pace. For Helen Clark is proving that leaders of social democratic, "first world" parties do not always have to talk like conservatives to win and keep power. They can respect the basic rules of sound economic management - and then take on the corporations, stand up for workers' rights, tax the top 5% of earners, curb defence spending, strip the constitution of privilege and deference and open up the government. They can do all that and still ride high in the polls.

Helen Clark met Tony Blair in Downing Street last month. Apparently he asked lots of questions about her flying start in government: let's hope he was taking notes.

Jonathan.Freeland@theguardian.com

They can respect the basic rules of sound economic management - and then take on the corporations, stand up for workers' rights, tax the top 5% of earners, curb defence spending, strip the constitution of privilege and deference and open up the government. They can do all that and still ride high in the polls. Helen Clark met Tony Blair in Downing Street last month. Apparently he asked lots of questions about her flying start in government: let's hope he was taking notes. Jonathan.Freeland@theguardian.com
